     y                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">many have attempted</char>…In these first few verses, Luke alludes to the fact that|
                                        |many have attempted to create a written record of the life of Jesus but did a mediocre job of it. He’s|
                                        |not referring to the Gnostic Gospels or some other heretical works, but to a few Christians who made|
                                        |early attempts to create what we now know as the Gospels but whose workmanship was a failure. Luke says|
                                        |here that he’ll correctly the problem and write his account accurately. Luke, the man of learning that|
                                        |he was, was versed in the correct method of writing history, the theory of which had been formulated|
                                        |by the first century. This passage gives us valuable insight into the formation of the four Gospels.|
                                        |None of the four were haphazardly written, all four gained the approval of the church leadership, and|
                                        |the “many” that Luke refers to in v.1 were rejected because they didn’t live up the standards set by|
                                        |the four that have been handed down through the ages. The four gospels were sponsored, by the church,|
                                        |approved by the church, and propagated by the church.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |To achieve the self-set goals Luke stated in vv3,4, in addition to fulfilling the requirements for writing|
                                        |proper history, Luke had to have conducted direct, meticulous interviews with the eyewitnesses of what|
                                        |he wrote about. From the content in the first few chapters of his Gospel, he certainly would’ve had to|
                                        |interview Mary mother or Jesus, or perhaps (and this is a stretch) one of Jesus’s siblings, at a minimum,|
                                        |the shepherds who were there at his birth, etc. Conducting these interviews and documenting them would’ve|
                                        |taken a few months, would’ve had to have taken place in Israel, and would’ve had to have taken place|
                                        |in the lifetime of all the witnesses. The timeframe which fits these criteria is Paul’s second and third|
                                        |missionary journeys, in particular his third, which was around A.D. 55. This would’ve been the latest|
                                        |date for the composition of Luke’s Gospel, as beyond that the eyewitnesses of Jesus’s birth would’ve|
                                        |died of old age.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Lord Theophilus</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Your Excellency Theophilus</char>. Luke|
                                        |addresses Theophilus like he’s an aristocrat or that he had authority over him or both. This evidence|
                                        |has led scholars to conjecture that Luke was either a freedman, once a slave to Theophilus, or perhaps|
                                        |still a slave. But Theophilus had assigned him to be an assistant to Paul, donating Luke to Paul’s ministry|
                                        |like someone would donate a car to a charity. This might explain why Luke was the only person still with|
                                        |Paul at the time of his death (2 Tim. 4:11)—he had no choice but to stick with him. In any event, slaves|
                                        |in ancient Rome were often educated, and Luke certainly was. In addition, the name Theophilus means God-friend.|
                                        |We’ll assume that his name’s not a coincidence, that he wasn’t born with the name but changed it or acquired|
                                        |it when he became a Christian. In any event, both his name and the interest he has in the events surrounding|
                                        |Jesus’s life indicate that he devoted his life to his faith.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |It might seem remarkable to us, living in modern times, that a slave or former slave such as Luke could|
                                        |write a great work of theology, humanity, and literature, but Epictetus, the Greek stoic philosopher,|
                                        |was born a slave. Two great books were written by his student-followers: <char style="it">Discourses</char>|
                                        |and <char style="it">Enchiridion</char>.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who was of the priestly caste</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of the daughters of Aaron</char>.|
                                        |The priesthood was a hereditary caste consisting of males who descended from Aaron, brother of Moses,|
                                        |of the tribe of Levi. The priests were not required to marry women from within that caste. Luke goes|
                                        |out of his way to mention the fact that Elizabeth was in the Aaronic lineage even before giving her name.|
                                        |This emphasizes the purity of John the Baptist’s parents’ pedigree, the level of sanctity, consecration,|
                                        |and cleanness, the Old Testament prerequisites for holiness. These John inherited as a result. The extreme|
                                        |degree to which the couple were sanctified to God would only magnify the intensity of the view that God|
                                        |was punishing Zechariah and Elisabeth by not providing them with a son (v. 7), one who would propagate|
                                        |the priesthood on their behalf. As there was no sin that Zechariah and Elisabeth were culpable of, whereby|
                                        |they would’ve received God’s disfavor and reproach, it must’ve been a mystery to the people why God would|
                                        |not give them a son.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the holy presence of God </char>(v. 8)…<char style="it">having entered the temple sanctuary|
                                        |itself </char>(v. 9)<char style="it">…</char>This the first chamber inside the temple edifice, accessible|
                                        |only to priest. In OT times, God’s presence dwelled in the Holy of Holies, the hidden chamber behind|
                                        |the temple sanctuary. To a lesser extent, God’s presence was also in the sanctuary. The duties of the|
                                        |priests included entering the temple sanctuary on a regular basis to replenish the incense, which must|
                                        |burn at all times, and to switch out the showbread.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Lord will use him as a herald in a spirit and power the likeness of which Elijah</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">had</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he himself will go before him </char>[<char style="it">be|
                                        |a forerunner</char>]<char style="it"> before Him in a spirit and might of Elijah</char>. Coming back|
                                        |to a city after victory on the battlefield, conquering commanders sent out forerunners to the towns they’d|
                                        |pass through to announce their imminent arrival, to stir up the people to gather in a large, enthusiastic|
                                        |crowd when the commander passed through. Also, see note of 1 Cor. 16:6 for <char style="it">go forth|
                                        |</char>and apply that to <char style="it">forerunner </char>here.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shame in the eyes of others</char>…As the ancients didn’t have a scientific understanding|
                                        |of medicine, they generally assumed that it a couple couldn’t have a child, somehow it was because of|
                                        |the woman. In Elizabeth’s case, they assumed God despised her, perhaps even that she had sinned. Her|
                                        |experience was much like Job’s.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |In this passage of vv. 47-55, Mary breaks into a poetic discourse, which is comprised of these literary|
                                        |elements:|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 47: The two clauses in this verse constitute a figure of speech, one which consists of the repetition|
                                        |of two clauses, both of which in essence express the same thought.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 49: Tacking on <char style="it">And holy is His name </char>(Lit: <char style="it">And holy his name</char>)|
                                        |as a clause instead of as a clause offset by a relative pronoun, i.e. instead of saying <char style="it">the|
                                        |Capable One whose name is holy.</char>|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 49: The omission of the word <char style="it">is </char>before <char style="it">holy </char>gives|
                                        |this more of a poetic ring.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 50: Like in v. 49, the omission of <char style="it">is </char>or <char style="it">is directed</char>|
                                        |is poetic.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 51: <char style="it">He routed…</char>Lit: <char style="it">he scattered. </char>This is a metaphor,|
                                        |a comparison to an army sounding defeating another army, in the same way that <char style="it">scatter|
                                        |</char>is used in Psalm 68:1, causing the enemy to break ranks and run in a disorderly retreat.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 51: <char style="it">The One Exuding power intervened in the affairs of man and did this…</char>Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">The one exuding might did this with his arm</char>. The “arm of the Lord” or a variation|
                                        |of this (like in v. 51) is a Heb. idiom used throughout the Old Testament. It refers to God’s ability|
                                        |to intervene in the affairs of mankind, and the strength and finality by which he does so.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 51: Breaking a single thought into two clauses is a figure of speech. In other words, saying, <char|
                                        |style="it">The one exuding might intervened in the affairs of man and did this</char>: <char style="it">He|
                                        |routed those</char>…instead of saying, <char style="it">The one exuding might intervened in the affairs|
                                        |of man and routed those</char>…|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |v. 51: <char style="it">high-and-mighty where the intention of their heart is concerned</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">high-and-mighty in intention, their hearts</char>. Making <char style="it">their hearts </char>an|
                                        |appositive of <char style="it">high-and-mighty </char>and tweaking the literal meaning is a figure of|
                                        |speech.|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rejuvenation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">resurrection</char>|

     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">very</char> <char style="it">life-being</char>…Lit: <char style="it">very soul</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">awaiting</char> <char style="it">rectification of their dire straits</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">awaiting</char> <char style="it">redemption</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">favor</char>…Lit: <char style="it">grace</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the midst of my Father’s interests</char>…KJV: <char style="it">about my Father’s|

     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">latched on</char>…Same word used in v. 19 and has the same meaning|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">forging ahead</char>…Lit: <char style="it">hack forward. </char>This Gk. word describes|
                                        |someone who’s chopping down brush, trees, or other obstacles—even enemy soldiers—in front of oneself,|
                                        |in order to move forward. This is the means by which Jesus grew in wisdom, stature, and the favor of|
                                        |God and of man; the implication is that life was not handed to him on a silver platter.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the upstairs floor of the house they were at…</char>Or:<char style="it"> the inn</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">unharnessing</char>. The word refers to the unharnessing of horses, hence the derivation|
                                        |of the meaning <char style="it">inn. </char>There is some uncertainty as to what the true meaning of|
                                        |this word is as used by Luke; the word means <char style="it">inn </char>but it also means <char style="it">upper|
                                        |room, dining hall, spare room, guest room. </char>The word is used elsewhere in the NT (Mark 14:14; Luke|
                                        |22:11) to refer to the upper room, where the Last Supper was held, which is assumed to be the same upper|
                                        |room as was occupied on the day of Pentecost. Some claim that this is an upper room of a house. Houses|
                                        |in those days were split-level, and often the downstairs was used to house the animals. The upper room|
                                        |was the main domicile. This could mean that Mary and Joseph were staying at the lower level of a friend|
                                        |or a distant relative’s house, and “there wasn’t any room for them in the inn” simply means that the|
                                        |upstairs was already filled. This is more plausible than <char style="it">inn</char>.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ruler</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tetrarch</char> (a four-part governorship)|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">countryside</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wilderness</char>|

     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every living being will witness God’s rescue program</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all|
                                        |flesh will see the salvation of God</char>. The phrase <char style="it">all flesh </char>is an idiom|
                                        |used throughout the Bible.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">produce the corresponding actions on par with a change for the better</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">produce the fruit worthy of repentance</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">We’re in with God because we’re descendants of Abraham</char>…Lit: <char style="it">We|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shirts</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tunics</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">soles of his shoes…</char>Ref. notes of Matt. 3:11|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">this was the last straw</char>…Lit: <char style="it">added this too on top of everything</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">appearing like a dove</char>…Ref. note of Mark 1:10|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the word of the Lord (i.e. prophetic message) came</char>…This introductory phrase appears|
                                        |throughout the OT, appearing as the lead-in to a prophecy.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all the rough roads will be resurfaced…</char>The quotation from Isaiah up to this point|
                                        |is a series of metaphors, the things described compared to people. The valleys are those who are in despair;|
                                        |the hills are those who are haughty; the windy roads are those who are confused or are in error; the|
                                        |rough roads are those encumbered by sin.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">establish descendants for Abraham from out of these stones</char>…In the mindset of|
                                        |some of the religious Jews of the time, God had chosen the descendants of Abraham to be his people, and|
                                        |His election was final. Jesus is saying that that is not the case; if a people whom God has chosen persist|
                                        |in disobeying him, God will oust them and replace them. <char style="it">These stones</char> in this|
                                        |verse symbolize the random, unknown, and insignificant mass of humanity throughout the world. In this|
                                        |light, Jesus is insinuating that God will replace the disobedient Jews with obedient Gentiles, should|
                                        |the Jews persist in their disobedience.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tax collectors…</char>In the Gospels, tax collectors, since they were involved in so|
                                        |much fraud, are generally assumed to be sinners. The expression <char style="it">tax collectors and sinners|
                                        |</char>is found in various places in the Gospels.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all the wonderful things in them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">their glory</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with their bare hands</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon their hands</char>|

                                        |your God</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">run through</char> <char style="it">his list of temptations</char>…Lit: <char style="it">concluded</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">all temptation</char>. A figure of speech.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hailed and applauded</char>…Lit: <char style="it">glorified</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">forced him along until they got to the crest of the large hill</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they|

     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">What beef do you have with me</char>?…Lit: <char style="it">what to us and to you?</char>|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">system of belief…</char>Also: <char style="it">message; doctrine; thesis; cohesive body|
                                        |of logic or reasoning</char>…Lit: <char style="it">word</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">unwell</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weak, sickly</char>.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wilderness</char>…Also: <char style="it">countryside</char>. The same word is translated|
                                        |<char style="it">countryside </char>in prior verses. The Judean wilderness is harsh, uninhabitable, and|
                                        |rocky.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He stood up and came forward to do a reading</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he stood to|
                                        |read</char>. Unlike churches today, synagogues back then allowed ordinary Israelites to read from the|
                                        |OT and deliver a homily on what they read. Also, ref. note of Acts 19:8.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he’s bestowed upon me a special dispensation of favor and power</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he|
                                        |anointed me</char>. At various times in the OT, God conferred special favor and granted special abilities|
                                        |to select individuals for specific purposes, usually to the benefit of Israel. This favor and these abilities|
                                        |were conferred in a ceremony where a priest or the like would cover (<char style="it">anoint</char>)|
                                        |in oil the one upon whom the favor and abilities were conferred, while making a pronouncement to that|
                                        |effect. An example of this can be found in 1 Sam. 16:12–13.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A season of freedom-celebrations sponsored by the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">an|
                                        |acceptable year of the Lord</char>. A “year of the Lord” refers to the OT Year of Jubilee, which the|
                                        |Law of Moses commands that Israel hold once every fifty years. There were laws specific to a Jubilee|
                                        |year, and these laws involved things like the freeing of slaves and the cancellation of debts. In the|
                                        |same way, this <char style="it">season of celebration </char>is a Jubilee-like occasion, as described|
                                        |in the previous verses, where the captives are set free, the blind regain their sight, the downtrodden|
                                        |are released.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put up or shut up</char>…Lit: <char style="it">doctor, treat yourself</char>…Some liberties|
                                        |taken. An idiom assumed to be a common expression of the time.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He,though, having wriggled his way out of their clutches</char>…Lit: <char style="it">But|
                                        |he himself, having gone through their midst</char>. Some indications in the GT here hint that Jesus didn’t|
                                        |conjure up a miracle that would placate the angry mob, thus allowing him to walk away, but that’s not|
                                        |what happened. He had to exercise a measure of force and recalcitrance on his part to escape their clutches.|
                                        |The evidence in the GT is that, first, Luke uses an explicit personal pronoun for <char style="it">he</char>,|
                                        |which has connotations apart from the face-value meaning of the word <char style="it">he. </char>Luke|
                                        |is telling us something by choosing this pronoun; he’s telling us that Jesus himself was taking some|
                                        |action when leaving the mob. Second, Luke chooses the verb <char style="it">to go through </char>rather|
                                        |than <char style="it">to go out of</char>, the latter form being expected had no force been involved.|
                                        |<char style="it">Going through</char> emphasizes the opposition he faced, while <char style="it">going|
                                        |out of</char> would have deemphasized that opposition.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Not only this, but the phrase used in v. 30 <char style="it">dia mesou </char>[<char style="it">through|
                                        |midst</char>, διὰ μέσου, <char style="w" strong="G01223">διὰ </char>),( μέσου/Strong’s 3319)] is almost|
                                        |identical in wording to the Gk. idiom <char style="it">ek mesou </char>[<char style="it">out of midst,|
                                        |</char>ἐκ μέσου) <char style="w" strong="G01537">ἐκ </char>), <char style="w" strong="G03319">μέσου</char>)],|
                                        |and should be considered to be another idiom of similar or same meaning. <char style="it">Ek mesou</char>|
                                        |(ref. 2 Thess. 2:7, Matt. 13:49; Acts 17:33; Acts 23:10; 1 Cor. 5:2; 2 Cor. 6:17; Col 2:14) “is a Greek|
                                        |idiom for being out of the way, and always implies decisive action, either of the person’s own will or|
                                        |of force on the part of others,” <char style="it">Figures of Speech Used in the Bible</char>, E.W. Bullinger,|
                                        |p. 838.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vile-and-disgusting, assigned-to-harass spirit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">spirit demonic</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">unclean</char>. In the GT, the noun <char style="it">spirit </char>is listed first followed|
                                        |by the adjectives<char style="it"> demonic unclean</char>. The adjective <char style="it">demonic </char>comes|
                                        |from the root verb <char style="it">daimonao </char>(δαιμονάω/no Strong’s number)<char style="it">, </char>which|
                                        |has the primary meaning <char style="it">to be subject to an avenging deity. Daimonao</char> is rooted|
                                        |in Greek mythology, where a person lost favor with one of the gods, and that god sent a lesser god or|
                                        |some other supernatural creature to torment said person. Also related to <char style="it">daimonao </char>is|
                                        |the Gk. verb <char style="it">daimonizomai </char><char style="w" strong="G01139">δαιμονίζομαι</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">, </char>which has a primary definition <char style="it">to have an allotted fate. </char>In|
                                        |the case of <char style="it">daimonizomai, </char>it’s as though a god of mythology choose to use his|
                                        |or her supernatural power against a mortal being, and the person, being mortal, is trapped in the bonds|
                                        |of a superior, supernatural being, and therefore locked into the fate dictated by the god. Related to|
                                        |the use of these two words, Paul’s thorn in the flesh (2 Cor. 12:6–7) is actually that: a <char style="it">daimonion|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G01140">δαιμόνιον</char>): a spirit assigned to him. Therefore, in a biblical|
                                        |context, the word <char style="it">demonic </char>means <char style="it">a being sent to torment or harass|
                                        |someone</char>. The other adjective, the word <char style="it">unclean, </char>is used throughout the|
                                        |OT for things forbidden by the Law of Moses to be touched, handled, things which are impure, unholy,|
                                        |and must be altogether shunned. These three words, <char style="it">spirit demonic unclean, </char>construct|
                                        |a different meaning to what was tormenting this man in the synagogue. First, <char style="it">spirit|
                                        |</char>means that it wasn’t a natural creature but a supernatural one. Second, <char style="it">demonic|
                                        |</char>means that the evil spirit is given a specific assignment to torment a person. Third, <char style="it">unclean|
                                        |</char>means that the spirit is all-around disgusting in its evil, irredeemably so.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Simon’s (Peter’s)</char>…The GT does not say <char style="it">Peter’s. </char>In the|
                                        |NT, Peter has multiple names, the name <char style="it">Peter </char>added to clarify what might otherwise|
                                        |be confusing.|

                                        |but rather sinners to repentance</char>. Mixing up the word order, namely stating, <char style="it">call|
                                        |righteous but rather sinners to repentance, </char>instead of, <char style="it">call righteous to repentance|
                                        |but rather sinners to repentance, </char>is a figure of speech.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your clique</char>…Lit: <char style="it">those with you</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">groom’s cronies</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sons of the groom</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">catching men, taking them alive</char>…Lit: the single Gk. word <char style="it">zōgreō|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G02221">ζωγρέω</char>).<char style="it"> </char>This refers to capturing|
                                        |prisoners of war in combat. In this passage, the fish were hauled in alive and not dead, and Jesus is|
                                        |making an analogy to this. In the same way, people who receive word of God are “captured alive” in a|
                                        |sense; once captured they continue to live. They are like prisoners of war in that their life changes:|
                                        |they are interned, they work in captivity, but are also cared for in captivity. Those who do the capturing|
                                        |must make provide for those captured; this is what Jesus is also hinting at—not only will Peter capture|
                                        |men, but he’ll have to have some sort of plan for them after they’re captured: a plan of discipleship.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">their designated teachers</char>…Lit: (the same). It’s unclear what exactly <char style="it">their|
                                        |</char>means in this verse, but it seems to indicate that the Pharisees were subordinate to the Scribes,|
                                        |or at least held them in high esteem.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Plus, nobody while drinking the old wants the new; you see, he says, ‘The old stuff’s|
                                        |better.’”</char>…A few of the principal manuscripts have omitted v. 39, and one might speculate that|
                                        |this was done because the verse is awkward and enigmatic. Verse 39 describes a person who, while in the|
                                        |act of drinking the older wine, claims that he prefers the older to the newer, without giving due consideration|
                                        |to the new. While drinking the old, his heightened awareness of its subtle, unique flavor causes him|
                                        |to lose any objectivity to the different qualities that the new will possess. His fondness for the wine|
                                        |at the moment produces a reaction which rejects any substitute—even to his detriment, as he may thoroughly|
                                        |enjoy the new wine also, were he to just give it a chance.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |And it reminds me of an old company in the landscape of corporate America which has an excellent product—be|
                                        |it an aircraft, a soft drink, what have you—and management in their hubris (or under pressure from the|
                                        |stockholders) thinks they can tinker with it and either to improve it or to shave a few pennies off its|
                                        |cost. But the old product is better. Or, don’t you miss the way they built such-and-such a few decades|
                                        |ago?—You have to pay top dollar on the used market to get one, because they’re not made anymore.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |These analogies are relevant to this passage. There were movements of God going on at the time, one of|
                                        |austerity (John the Baptist) and one of celebration (Jesus). Both are very different from one another.|
                                        |When one is caught up in the one, he becomes so enthralled with it that he will not see the value in|
                                        |the other. Jesus says that both are necessary and that there’s a time and place for both. Another application|
                                        |is that the old-timers had a more powerful presence of the Holy Spirit in their services than we do today.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">holy bread</char>…This is what we call the <char style="it">show bread. </char>Ref.|
                                        |note of Mark 2:26|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">There was a man there whose right hand was all shriveled up</char>…Lit: <char style="it">A|
                                        |man was there, and his right hand was shriveled up</char>. The literal wording of the GT is a figure|
                                        |of speech. The figure of speech is breaking the two connected thoughts into two loosely connected clauses|
                                        |separated by the conjunction <char style="it">and.</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">designed teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Scribes</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stand front and center</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stand in our midst</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |”<char style="it">missionaries</char>”…Lit: <char style="it">apostles. </char>Translated means <char|
                                        |style="it">sent ones.</char> J.B. Phillip’s translation translates apostle as <char style="it">special|
                                        |messenger.</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vile, disgusting</char>…Lit: <char style="it">unclean</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">directed his attention to</char>…Lit: <char style="it">lifted up his eyes to</char>.|
                                        |Lift up the eyes or is an expression used throughout the Bible. It means to stop focusing narrowly on|
                                        |one thing or one task and look at things more broadly, whether to look at matters in a broader perspective,|
                                        |or (in this case) consider all the people and not just a few.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">chastise you in a shameful, disgracing manner</char>…Also: <char style="it">reproach|
                                        |you</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kick your reputation—and, for that matter, everything you stand for—to the curb as though|
                                        |you’re a bad person</char>…Lit: <char style="it">throw out your name as an evil person</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you’re in for it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">woe</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">evil impersonators of prophets</char>…Lit: <char style="it">false prophets</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">follow in the footsteps of the Highest</char>…Lit: <char style="it">be sons of the Highest</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put</char>…<char style="it">into your pocket</char>…Lit: <char style="it">give</char>…<char|
                                        |style="it">to your bosom</char>. <char style="it">Bosom</char> in this context refers to the fold of|
                                        |clothing near your body where cash and other items are carried. “Giving to your bosom” is a figure of|
                                        |speech called a <char style="it">metonymy</char>; the items will actually be given to you, not given|
                                        |to your bosom.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">buddy’s</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother’s</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">storage</char>…Or: <char style="it">treasure</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one’s</char>…Or: his|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">’Boss, Boss!</char>’…Or, ‘<char style="it">Lord, Lord!</char>’…Also: ‘<char style="it">Master,|
                                        |Master!</char>’. Using the word <char style="it">Boss</char> over <char style="it">Master</char> or <char|
                                        |style="it">Lord</char>, because Jesus is talking about a servant or slave replying to his employer or|
                                        |master.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the one who became a traitor…</char>The twelve apostles are listed here in order of|
                                        |their importance, from greatest to least, with a couple of exceptions. Andrew is listed after Peter because|
                                        |he’s his brother; James is listed before John because he’s his older brother, but John was actually the|
                                        |more important of the two. Judas Iscariot takes last place in the list. Bartholomew is the same as Nathanael|
                                        |. <char style="it">Simon the insurrectionist</char> in the GT reads <char style="it">Simon the Zealot</char>,|
                                        |as the Zealots were insurrectionists.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to those who slap your face—present the other cheek too</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 5:39|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">draw conclusions</char>…<char style="it">write people off</char>…Lit: <char style="it">judge</char>…<char|
                                        |style="it">condemn</char>. To begin to understand what Jesus means by judging and condemning, one should|
                                        |first learn from other Scriptures what it is not. It is not taking no account of what others do (one|
                                        |example: “Know them which labor among you,” 1 Thess. 5:12). In the NT, if someone who claimed to be a|
                                        |Christian conducted himself in an immoral manner, this person was to be treated like an infidel. But|
                                        |ascertaining such behavior is not judging. Judging is drawing conclusions, based on a person’s history,|
                                        |concluding what their fate or destiny must be. Condemning a person is determining that a person who has|
                                        |guilt due to sin will never be able to escape it, that part or all of their life is irredeemable—Even|
                                        |though it may in fact be irredeemable. To judge someone is to weigh them by their motives and not by|
                                        |their actions. To condemn someone is to assign them consequences. Concerning judging, ref. note of Matt.|
                                        |7:1 also.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Since he finished going through all of his material with those listening—a bunch of|
                                        |ordinary folk</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Since he filled all the messages of his unto the listeners|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">set foot in my house for a visit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">come under my roof</char>.|

                                        |of being commanded</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">open coffin</char>…More exactly, <char style="it">bier</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a deep reverence came upon everyone</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all took a fear</char>.|

     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">brought to prominence</char>…Lit: <char style="it">raised</char>|

     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">centurion</char>…The Roman equivalent to an army captain. The issue here was that the|
                                        |centurion was a Gentile and that the Jews were not supposed to have any contact with the Gentiles—certainly|
                                        |not any close contact. This is why the centurion said in v. 6 that it’s not appropriate for Jesus to|
                                        |come pay him a visit of a personal nature.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and</char> <char style="it">have my servant receive healing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">have|
                                        |my servant be healed</char>. The principle manuscripts diverge on this. The other principles instead|
                                        |say, <char style="it">and</char> <char style="it">my servant will be healed</char>. The former, <char|
                                        |style="it">and grant that my servant be healed, </char>is the reading chosen by the UBS NT, the correct|
                                        |choice. The UBS choice is consistent with and confirmed by the centurion’s statement in verse 8 which|
                                        |says,<char style="it"> I say to this one, have him come, and he comes</char>. The verb tense used in|
                                        |both <char style="it">grant that my servant be healed</char> (for <char style="it">grant…be healed</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it"> </char>and <char style="it">I say to this one, have him go forth, and he goes </char>(for|
                                        |<char style="it">have him go</char>) are both 3<char style="sup">rd</char> person imperatives. The meaning|
                                        |in the 3<char style="sup">rd</char> person imperative of <char style="it">have him come </char>is more|
                                        |clear: the centurion is giving an order to a third party, the order being for the third party to relay|
                                        |another order to the person, the one who’s being summoned. What the centurion wants is for Jesus to relay|
                                        |a command through a third party (his friends), instead of Jesus giving a person-to-person order without|
                                        |the third party relay. This is the way that chain-of-command-structured authority hierarchies work; you|
                                        |can give a command to a subordinate who will in turn pass the command down the chain of subordinates.|
                                        |The centurion’s faith caused him to recognize that the kingdom of God must also be a chain-of-command-structured|
                                        |authority hierarchy, or else if wouldn’t function.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his mother’s only son (and she herself was a widow)</char>…With the death of her husband|
                                        |and only son, she had nobody to support her; this magnified the pity which Jesus had for her. |
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the countryside</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the wilderness</char>. John spent all of|
                                        |this time out in the wilderness, avoiding cities, due to his austere lifestyle; Jesus visited both wilderness|
                                        |and city.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">We sang a dirge, and you wouldn’t weep</char> <char style="it">and wail</char> …Ref.|
                                        |note of Matt. 11:17|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a sinner</char>…<char style="it">be mindful of</char>…Also: (<char style="it">for be|
                                        |mindful of</char>) <char style="it">continuously aware of; ever cognizant of</char>. The way that she’s|
                                        |singled out as being “a sinner” (v.37) and the verb tense in <char style="it">be mindful of </char>(v.|
                                        |39) insinuate that she’s an adulterous or is sexually immoral in some other way. This verse literally|
                                        |reads, <char style="it">he would’ve known she was a sinner, </char>leaving the implication that he would’ve|
                                        |done something about it.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you didn’t greet me at the door with a kiss</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you didn’t|
                                        |give me a kiss</char>. As seen in various places in the NT, it was customary back then to greet someone|
                                        |of the same sex with a kiss. The kiss was a cordial greeting, a sign of friendship and comradery. In|
                                        |fact, the Gk. word <char style="it">philos</char> (φίλος /Strong’s 5384), usually translated <char style="it">love</char>,|
                                        |sometimes means <char style="it">kiss </char>or <char style="it">friend.</char>|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">caress my head with lotion</char>…<char style="it">cover my feet with special oil</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">anoint my head with oil…anoint my feet with myrrh</char>. Myrrh is much more expensive|
                                        |than oil. Ref. note of Matt. 6:17 for anointing with oil.|

     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">heading in the same direction</char>…The GT specifies that the man who was assaulted|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And if there happens to be a peaceful soul there, your offer of piece will stick. Otherwise,|
                                        |it’ll bounce back to you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">And if a son of peace happens to be there, your|
                                        |peace will rest upon it</char>. <char style="it">Otherwise, it will return to you</char>. Notice the|
                                        |figurative language here in this passage, and, in fact, starting at the end of the previous chapter.|
                                        |Sprinkled throughout this discourse are Semitic idioms, expressions, etc. (<char style="it">son of peace</char>|
                                        |is a good example). These appear to be literal word-for-word translations from Aramaic to Gk. of Jesus’s|
                                        |actual Aramaic words. In general, Luke uses less Semitic wording than Matthew, but there’s a noticeable|
                                        |difference here in this passage and in the previous chapters of Luke.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">done the burlap-and-ashes thing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sitting in sackcloth and|
                                        |ashes</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 11:21.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Time and time again I saw, like a lightning strike, a demon get ejected from his spiritual|
                                        |dominion</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I was watching </char>(imperfect<char style="it"> </char>tense)<char|
                                        |style="it"> Satan fall from heaven like lightning</char>. Luke 10:18 is one of the most misinterpreted|
                                        |verses in the NT. It is commonly understood to be Satan being cast out of heaven prior to the creation|
                                        |of man (ref. Is. 14:12; Ez. 28:16; Rev. 12:7–9). This is not the case. Instead, Jesus is seeing in the|
                                        |spiritual world (ref. “discerning of spirits”, 1 Cor. 12:10) what the seventy-two who had been sent out|
                                        |were doing in the natural world. Jesus was watching in real time; each time they cast out a demon, he|
                                        |saw a lightning strike.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The elements to the correct interpretation of this passage, first, is that the word translated <char|
                                        |style="it">was watching </char>is in the Gk. imperfect tense. In this case, it insinuates multiple, repeated|
                                        |action, not a single action; plus it insinuates Jesus watching something unfold in real-time (in other|
                                        |words, watching concurrently as the disciples were doing it). Second, the Gk. word for <char style="it">heaven|
                                        |</char>(<char style="it">ouranos</char>/οὐρανός/Strong’s 3772) can mean either the sky (Acts 1:1), heaven|
                                        |itself (Luke 10:14), the spiritual world around us (1 Cor. 12:2; Eph. 6:12), or a place of spiritual|
                                        |dominion. In the case of Luke 10:18, <char style="it">ouranos </char>means the third: a place of spiritual|
                                        |dominion. Third, the word <char style="it">Satan </char>is used as a synecdoche/metonymy for the word|
                                        |<char style="it">demon</char> (also in Matt. 12:26; Luke 13:16). Fourth, the word <char style="it">fall|
                                        |</char>refers to somebody or something losing its authority or dominion, usually by force (Rev. 18:2;|
                                        |Rev. 12:7–9).|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The correct interpretation of Jesus seeing multiple demons get cast down in real-time is relevant to|
                                        |the enclosing context. In other words, Jesus sent the disciples out, and in v. 17 they come back rejoicing,|
                                        |telling what had happened. Jesus regurgitating something which happened thousands of years before would|
                                        |be irrelevant and incongruous to the remark his disciples just made.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">legitimately claim and lay hold of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">inherit</char>. To <char|
                                        |style="it">inherit</char> or <char style="it">the inheritance</char> or simply <char style="it">possess|
                                        |</char>refer to the same biblical concept. The concept of the inheritance is that God has a specific|
                                        |place He has reserved for you, that you have claim to, and He promises to bring you to it (inheriting)|
                                        |and to keep you in it (salvation), and to restore you to it should you lose it (redemption). The concept|
                                        |of the inheritance starts in the OT with God promising Abraham a land, not only to him but to his descendants,|
                                        |and this land is eventually subdivided into continuously smaller pieces, down to individual, single-family|
                                        |lots. Such subdividing of the land is enumerated in Joshua chapters 13–22. Though the concept of the|
                                        |inheritance begins with God communicating to His man, His tribe, His people that He has promised them|
                                        |a portion of land, it then extends into the journey to get to that land and to the obedience required|
                                        |to take possession of that land. Some examples: Ps. 37:9,29; Prov. 10:30; Is. 14:21; Is. 57:13; 60:21).|
                                        |The concept is applicable beyond land to anything God promises a believer to have, which in the case|
                                        |of v. 25 refers to eternal life.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">eternal life</char>…This phrase is used throughout the NT, particularly in the Gospel|
                                        |of John. From the face-value meaning of the words, <char style="it">eternal life </char>would appear|
                                        |to mean life after death, but there are a couple of problems with that interpretation. First, the OT,|
                                        |and by extension Judaism, emphasizes the here-and-now and de-emphasizes life after death, to the point|
                                        |where some Jews (the Sadducees) didn’t even believe in life after death. Second, Jesus said in v. 28,|
                                        |“Do this and you shall live.” He’s talking about the here-and-now, not the life to come. This leaves|
                                        |the unanswered question: what exactly does the NT mean by the phrase <char style="it">eternal life</char>?|
                                        |The answer comes from reading all the passages that talk about eternal life, reading them with an understanding|
                                        |that it’s talking about the here-and-now, not life after death, and meditating on the evidence. The answer|
                                        |will then present itself.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">To choose the one good thing is what’s needed. You see, Mary considered her options|
                                        |and made the best choice; the very thing she chose will not be taken away from her</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">Of one thing is there need. For Mary chose the good part, whatsoever will not be taken away|
                                        |from her.</char> The rendering is not entirely certain. Max &amp; Mary claim that <char style="it">of|
                                        |one thing is there need </char>is short for the Semitic idiom <char style="it">of few things is there|
                                        |need or of one. </char>It’s universally agreed that the word <char style="it">good </char>is to be translated|
                                        |<char style="it">best</char>. An inference is made with the word <char style="it">part</char>, that it|
                                        |is one of many. Put together, it’s assumed that this paints a picture of Mary choosing between good and|
                                        |bad options.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">my children are all tucked in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">my children are with me in|
                                        |the bed</char>. The GT hints that the parents and children are sharing the same bed, and if the friend|
                                        |could not get out of bed without stirring the children also.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">how much more will the Father give from heaven above a spirit which is indeed the Holy|
                                        |Spirit to those asking Him</char>…Two points to make concerning the rendering here. First, The principle|
                                        |manuscripts differ in the addition or omission of a single letter which changes the rendering somewhat.|
                                        |The rendering of the accepted GT reads, <char style="it">the from-heaven-Father will give</char>; the|
                                        |alternate GT reads, <char style="it">the Father will give from heaven</char>. Second, the omission of|
                                        |the definite article in <char style="it">Holy Spirit. </char>Although the words for <char style="it">Holy|
                                        |Spirit </char>occur in forms throughout the NT in both using and not using the definite article, in this|
                                        |context the omission of the definite article indicates the nature of the gift which the Father is giving,|
                                        |that the nature of the gift is good and never bad, and that if He’s giving the gift of a spirit, you|
                                        |can rest assured that it is none other than the Holy Spirit.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">casting out a deaf demon (i.e., a demon of deafness)</char>…Other manuscripts read,|
                                        |<char style="it">was casting out a demon, and it itself was deaf</char>. The majority of the principle|
                                        |manuscripts read the former and not the latter. The demon was a type of harassing spirit that causes|
                                        |deafness.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with whose assistance do your protégés cast out demons?</char>…The only answer the skeptics|
                                        |could give to this question is that their protégés don’t rely on anyone’s help to cast out demons, because|
                                        |they do not nor ever will cast out demons. They’re questioning where Jesus is getting the ability to|
                                        |cast out demons; Jesus is asking why they don’t have any ability to cast out demons. Jesus goes on to|
                                        |say that whatever the answer to this question happens to be will decide whether he (Jesus) is getting|
                                        |help from God or from Beelzebub.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a man who’s armed to the hilt</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the fully-armed strong man</char>.|
                                        |The GT says <char style="it">the strong man </char>instead of <char style="it">a strong man</char> in|
                                        |the same way that John 10:10 reads, <char style="it">the thief </char>(both are a figure of speech).|
                                        |Also, the GT emphasizes the fact that the man is wearing armor, as v. 22 literally reads, <char style="it">he|
                                        |takes away the armor upon which he had relied, </char>instead of,<char style="it"> he takes away the|
                                        |weapons and armor upon which he had relied</char>. It is the armor which turns the man a strong man,|
                                        |more so than the weapon he wields. His armor (and presumably a weapon to go along with it) makes him|
                                        |nearly invincible against someone who’s simply armed but is wearing no armor.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">seeking a place to take a break or to settle in, at least for a little while, and doesn’t|
                                        |find any</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 12:44|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Right around now</char>…The GT suggests that the Pharisees used to clean their cups|
                                        |and plates before each meal, likely making a ceremony out of it, and Jesus was noticing them doing it|
                                        |and for that reason drew up a metaphor of it as they were about to do it.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">avarice</char>…Lit: the Gk. word <char style="it">harpagay </char><char style="w" strong="G00724">ἁρπαγή</char>).|
                                        |This word refers to a physical item: a hook used to draw a bucket out of a well or a garden rake of some|
                                        |sort, something used to gather brush. In both cases, the purpose of the physical object is that of gathering|
                                        |and pulling something in. In the context of this passage here in Luke, and perhaps for most usages, <char|
                                        |style="it">harpagay </char>is the pulling in of non-material things, immorally so. It applies not only|
                                        |to wealth but to fame and to other things. Therefore, <char style="it">harpagay</char> can alternately|
                                        |be translated <char style="it">covetousness</char>, <char style="it">greed</char>, or <char style="it">rapacity</char>.|
                                        |In addition to the word <char style="it">harpagay, </char>the Gk. word in the NT more frequently rendered|
                                        |<char style="it">covetousness</char> or <char style="it">greed</char> is <char style="it">pleonexia </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G04124">πλεονεξία</char>), which is from the root word <char style="it">pleon </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G04119">πλείων</char>), which means “too much.” <char style="it">Pleonexia</char> is|
                                        |defined as, “a disposition to take more than one’s share”; in addition to meaning covetousness and greed,|
                                        |<char style="it">pleonexia</char> can also mean, “something one feels forced to do.” <char style="it">Pleonexia</char>|
                                        |is the compulsion to gather an inordinate amount of material goods; <char style="it">harpagay</char>|
                                        |is the gathering of such things, or the gathering of fame and the like. The word used in 1 Tim. 3:3 for|
                                        |“not covetous” is <char style="it">aphilarguros </char><char style="w" strong="G00866">ἀφιλάργυρος</char>),|
                                        |which broken down from its concatenated roots is, <char style="it">not-a-comradely-love-of-silver</char>.|
                                        |Since <char style="it">silver</char> means <char style="it">money</char>, it is better rendered<char|
                                        |style="it">, not-a-comradely-love-of-money</char>.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Just purge yourself of those things on the inside, and—presto—you can handle anything|
                                        |that’s off-limits from a ritualistic perspective</char>…Lit: <char style="it">But rather give those inner|
                                        |things, alms, and behold all things are clean to you</char>. The phrase <char style="it">give those inner|
                                        |things, alms</char> appears to be an expression or perhaps even an idiom, and its meaning is inferred|
                                        |from the context. It’s assumed that this phrase is a metaphor that compares the purging of what’s on|
                                        |the inside to someone giving alms.|

     x                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">decide amongst yourselves what’s the right thing to do</char>…Lit: <char style="it">judge|

                                        |the same word rendered <char style="it">against </char>in vv. 52, 53.|
     x                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t five sparrows sell for $6</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Don’t five sparrows sell|
                                        |for 2 coins </char>[<char style="it">valued at 1/10 drachma apiece</char>]. 1/10 of a drachma is a small-currency|
                                        |coin and is equal to 1/16 of a denarius. See note of Matt. 18:28 for denarius conversion.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s angels</char>…Certain angels surround the holy presence of God, who in addition|
                                        |to closing off visibility to Him, act as attendants, courtiers, servants, and the like. They form a king’s|
                                        |court of a sort, and just like in mediaeval or ancient times ambassadors or others, when they had an|
                                        |audience with the king, had an audience with his entire court and not just with the king alone. Often,|
                                        |matters submitted to the king were submitted to the entire court, with the king presiding over it, and|
                                        |the court would vet and argue the matter for the benefit of the king, with the King presiding over the|
                                        |interrogation and giving his final word at the end. Jesus saying that he’ll confess or deny a person|
                                        |in front of God’s angels means that he is doing so in God’s court, the formal venue to present matters|
                                        |which God presides over.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Holy Spirit, having blasphemed, will not be forgiven</char>…Ref. note of Mark 3:29 concerning|
                                        |the unforgiveable sin, blasphemy of the Holy Spirit.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Grim Reaper is coming for you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they demand your soul|
                                        |from you</char>. The literal rendering uses (howbeit by implication) the word <char style="it">they</char>,|
                                        |and in addition the word <char style="it">demand </char>is in the active voice, not passive. This usage|
                                        |could have one of two meanings. First, it could be an obscure reference to angels whose job it is to|
                                        |appear at the time of death and escort a person from this life to the next life, whether to heaven or|
                                        |to hell. Or second, it could be a tongue-in-cheek reference to some sort of ancient superstition of mythological|
                                        |creatures who appear at the appointed time of death to escort a person somehow.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">that swarm of difficulties that engulfs you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the little|
                                        |flock-ette</char> (<char style="it">to mikron poimnion, </char>τὸ μικρὸν ποίμνιον), <char style="w" strong="G03588">τὸ </char>),(|
                                        |μικρὸν /Strong’s 3398), <char style="w" strong="G04168">ποίμνιον</char>). Usage here is strange and is|
                                        |assumed to be an expression or an idiom. Therefore, the meaning is not presumed to be the word-for-word|
                                        |literal interpretation; the exact meaning of this expression is inferred from the context. Some notes|
                                        |on the grammatical construct of this expression in the GT:|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |1. The appearance of the definite article (<char style="it">to</char>) precludes this phrase from being|
                                        |in the vocative case; it must therefore be accusative|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |2. The word <char style="it">poimnon</char> <char style="w" strong="G04168">ποίμνιον</char>)<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>is the diminutive form of <char style="it">poimnā </char><char style="w" strong="G04167">ποίμνη</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">. </char>Diminutives are likely candidates for usage in expressions.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |3. The use of the adjective <char style="it">micron </char>is somewhat redundant considering that <char|
                                        |style="it">poimnon </char>is already a diminutive, and by implication describes something small.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |4. Preceded by the definite article, the adjective is attributive and not predicative, which makes it|
                                        |more likely to be an expression.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |3. The use of the definite article means that Luke is referring to something specific.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Sell…make…make</char>…The verb tense used here (the aorist) for these imperative verbs|
                                        |insinuate a few things. First, this tense is more emphatic than the default tense (the present). Second,|
                                        |it implies a one-time action. The one-time action of selling and giving doesn’t mean that there won’t|
                                        |be subsequent times in which this must be done, but it means that one doesn’t have to sell one’s belongings|
                                        |every time one accumulates belongings. Jesus is being emphatic to get them to break a mindset of hoarding|
                                        |possessions, hoarding them for fear of not having enough in a time of need.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I have to undergo</char> <char style="it">an all-consuming, totally transformative event</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">I have a baptism to be baptized </char>[<char style="it">in</char>]. This verse (Luke|
                                        |12:50), along with 1 Cor. 10:2 and with the accounts of John the Baptist, shed light on what the word|
                                        |<char style="it">baptism </char>means in the Bible, and consequently what it is for a Christian to be|
                                        |baptized. In Luke 12:50, the baptism Jesus is referring to is his death and resurrection. In 1 Cor. 10:2,|
                                        |the nation of Israel was baptized into Moses by the cloud and the sea. And John the Baptist’s baptism|
                                        |was one of repentance. These passages on baptism reveal the following: Baptism is a totally transformative|
                                        |event. A person’s post-baptism life is changed entirely with respect to his pre-baptism life. The person|
                                        |being baptized enters into a binding contract, a covenant, of some sort. In order to undergo the transformation|
                                        |associated with baptism, the person being baptized must surrender his life to the transformation. After|
                                        |the baptism, the covenant which the person entered into is subject to terms, terms not only for the one|
                                        |baptized but also for God. God commits Himself to terms which consists of promises, and though a person|
                                        |is bound by the terms of the covenant, on the other hand he benefits from the terms God commits to, acquiring|
                                        |the promises. This baptism-covenant pattern summarizes Christianity: a total commitment by the one being|
                                        |baptized to the terms of the covenant (God’s commandments); access through faith to the promises of God|
                                        |(found in the Bible) which protects one from the depravations of life.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And now why do you also not decide amongst yourselves what’s the right thing to do about|
                                        |a dispute…</char>In this parable, Jesus tells his followers that each person should objectively consider|
                                        |both sides of a dispute he’s embroiled in, and determine if his opponent’s case is stronger than his|
                                        |own. Jesus is teaching them to impartially weigh the merits of both sides of the case. He repeats this|
                                        |point in a different parable in Luke 14:31. But in addition to objectively considering both sides to|
                                        |an argument, what Jesus says in vv. 57–59 is that once you weigh both sides of a dispute, you’ll find|
                                        |that your case is in fact the weaker of the two, and that being the situation, it would behoove you to|
                                        |settle the dispute between just the two of you and not let it go before a judge and have him settle it|
                                        |instead. This parable has several applications, the first application is that one is better “settling|
                                        |out of court” and receiving the remission of sins offered by Christ and not attempting to prove one’s|
                                        |own righteousness based on works in a courtroom before God, where the verdict will be against you. Another|
                                        |application is walking in the Spirit rather than walking in your plain self. If you weight the evidence,|
                                        |you’ll find that plain-self, as it turns out, is dominated by the carnal nature, and as such cannot fulfill|
                                        |the lofty requirements of the Christian life. Christians should recognize that living their life apart|
                                        |from the indwelling Spirit is a losing proposition and should seek to redress the problem as soon as|
                                        |possible.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">where he takes you before a judge, the judge rules against you, and you get thrown into|
                                        |debtors’ prison</char>…Lit: <char style="it">where he hauls you before the judge, and the judge hands|
                                        |you over to the bailiff, and the bailiff throws you into prison</char>. Some liberties taken. Up until|
                                        |modern times, if one couldn’t pay the fine or penalty meted out by a court settlement, then that person|
                                        |was thrown in prison (debtors’ prison) until he could pay. The problem, of course, is that once in prison,|
                                        |the debtor is no longer free to earn money to pay the fine or penalty requisite to get out of prison.|
                                        |Unless someone else pays it or they cut you a break on the settlement terms, you’re stuck. And this is|
                                        |the point Jesus makes in v. 59: once thrown in prison, you’ll get not breaks on the settlements and you’ll|
                                        |ever get out.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ten and eight years</char>…This is the literal rendering of the GT. In v. 18, Luke writes|

                                        |style="it">ten and eight </char>instead of the shorter <char style="it">eighteen. </char>The longer form|

                                        |The phrase <char style="it">whence are you </char>is an expression, the keyword being <char style="it">whence|
                                        |</char>(<char style="it">pothen</char>, πόθεν/Strong’s 4159). This expression also appears in John 7:27–28|
                                        |(three times); John 8:14 (somewhat); John 9:29–30; John 19:9. The expression roughly corresponds to the|
                                        |English, <char style="it">where are you coming from? </char>Alternately, it may mean, <char style="it">what|
                                        |are you all about?</char>; w<char style="it">hat’s your driving motivation?; what makes you tick?; what’s|
                                        |your raison d’être?; I don’t know if you’re on the level; you’re a wacko. </char>On another note, this|
                                        |phrase is repeated in v. 27. The principle manuscripts differ in the reading. The accepted reading is|
                                        |lit. <char style="it">I don’t know you, whence you are</char>; but other principal manuscripts read <char|
                                        |style="it">I don’t know whence you are. </char>The latter is a shortened version of a well-known expression,|
                                        |readily understood and registered as such by the hearer because of the conspicuousness of the word <char|
                                        |style="it">whence.</char>|

     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A word to the wise is sufficient</char>…Lit: <char style="it">He having an ear to hear,|
