     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">So they gathered and filled twelve baskets of scraps from what was leftover by those|
                                        |who had eaten, leftovers from out of the five loaves of the barley-bread</char>…Lit: <char style="it">So|
                                        |they gathered and filled twelve baskets of scraps out of the five loaves of the barley </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">bread</char>]<char style="it"> that they leftover by those who had eaten</char>. The way John|
                                        |penned this sentence in its literal form is not lock-tight from a logical perspective, even given the|
                                        |leeway which Gk. allows in reordering sequences of words. In other words, what John should’ve written|
                                        |is this: <char style="it">So they gathered and filled twelve baskets of scraps that were leftover by|
                                        |those who had eaten out of the five loaves of the barley </char>[<char style="it">bread</char>]. The|
                                        |movement of the clause <char style="it">that were leftover by those who had eaten </char>and the changing|
                                        |of it from active to passive voice (from <char style="it">that they leftover </char>to <char style="it">that|
                                        |were leftover</char>) would’ve had made what he said more logically coherent. Of course, we understand|
                                        |what he meant.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in no time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">immediately</char>. John again (see previous|
                                        |note from v. 13) loosely constructs the logic of a sentence; in its literal rendering, it appears to|
                                        |the reader that once Jesus boarded the boat, the boat miraculously transported itself in a split-second|
                                        |(as insinuated by the word <char style="it">immediately</char>)<char style="it"> </char>to the destination|
                                        |shore. I doubt if that was the case—rather, it was near the destination in the first place.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miraculous sign</char>…The Jews were following the guidelines outlined in the OT for|
                                        |vetting a prophet (Exod. 7:9; Deut.13:1–5). As John has stated in length in earlier parts of his gospel,|
                                        |Jesus did miraculous signs. In fact, the crowd had just chased him down because he’d walked on water.|
                                        |The problem was that that wasn’t good enough—they wanted him to produce a miracle on-demand. This is|
                                        |symptomatic of unbelief, the stubborn refusal to believe.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I will usher him into an afterlife of bliss on the Day of Reckoning</char>…Lit:<char|
                                        |style="it"> I will raise him up </char>[<char style="it">resurrect him</char>]<char style="it"> in the|
                                        |Last Day</char>. This is connected to what Jesus said in John 5:29. In 6:39 here, <char style="it">raise|
                                        |him up</char> in Gk. is equivalent to <char style="it">resurrect him</char>, and in the NT resurrection|
                                        |refers to <char style="it">life-after-death</char>. A phrase like the Last Day is similar to other phrases|
                                        |found in the Bible, such as the <char style="it">last days</char> [plural] (Isa. 2:2; Mic. 4:1; Acts|
                                        |2:17; 2 Tim. 3:1; 2 Pet. 3:3); <char style="it">the last hour</char>; <char style="it">those days</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">that day</char>; etc. All these phrases in general refer to the time of a fulfillment|
                                        |of a prophecy or a promise of some sort. According to its usage in the NT, we are living in the Last|
                                        |Days. This means we’re living in the fulfillment of the promises in the OT and in the Gospels of the|
                                        |fulfillment of Jesus’s mission to die and to be resurrected and the consequent access to God through|
                                        |faith in him, even for the Gentile; the indwelling of the Holy Spirit in all believers; God working through|
                                        |the church; etc. But the Last Day [singular] refers to the fulfillment of a different promise, that is,|
                                        |what God will do with those who died, in this case with believers who died trusting in Him. For unbelievers,|
                                        |the Last Day is the Day of Judgment.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t we know about the father and the mother?</char>…The word <char style="it">about|
                                        |</char>doesn’t appear in the GT, but the insinuation—which is present when carried over into English|
                                        |via a literal rendering—is a result of the GT saying <char style="it">the father and the mother </char>rather|
                                        |than <char style="it">his father and mother</char>, or something. Furthermore, the Judeans just finished|
                                        |Joseph as Jesus’s father, then a few words later refer to him as <char style="it">the father </char>instead|
                                        |of saying <char style="it">Joseph </char>again. The insinuation is that they have a low opinion about|
                                        |Mary and Joseph. This could be for a few reasons, because Mary and Joseph don’t live in Judea and aren’t|
                                        |part of the political hierarchy. Or because they’re poor, they’re common laborers. Or perhaps Mary’s|
                                        |virgin birth was assumed to be an adulterous relationship. But whatever low opinion they had of Mary|
                                        |and Joseph, it could not have been because of their genealogy.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Would it make any difference if you were to see me ascend into heaven from the spot|
                                        |I was just standing at?…</char>Lit: <char style="it">So then, if you were to see the son of man go up|
                                        |from the place he was just at?</char>…This is a best-guess at what Jesus meant; I’m not exactly sure.|

                                        |3:17.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">no one’s been able to figure out</char>…Lit: <char style="it">no one knows</char>. John|
                                        |writes the phrase <char style="it">where he’s from </char>three times in short succession: twice in v.|
                                        |27 and once in v. 28. The word for <char style="it">know </char>(<char style="it">ginōskō</char>, γινώσκω/Strong’s|
                                        |1097) in this occurrence (<char style="it">has been able to figure out</char>)<char style="it"> </char>is|
                                        |a different word for <char style="it">know </char>than what he uses for the other two occurrences (<char|
                                        |style="it">oida</char>, οἶδα/Strong’s 1492). Generally speaking, John prefers <char style="it">oida </char>over|
                                        |<char style="it">ginōskō, </char>so he’s signaling the employment a meaning which differs from <char|
                                        |style="it">oida</char>, and hence <char style="it">ginōskō </char>as used here more accurately means|
                                        |<char style="it">to</char> <char style="it">figure out </char>rather than <char style="it">to know.</char>|

                                        |<char style="it">you’ll die trying</char>. This is an expression, and the first time Jesus uses it (v.|
                                        |21), he uses it as an expression. When he uses it the other times (v. 24), he means it literally.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">down below…up above</char>…The definition of these as the carnal domain and the spiritual|

     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Do I need to repeat whatever I’ve been saying from day one?</char>…Various translators|
                                        |disagree on what exactly he meant by this fragment. In my opinion, John left out some words that he assumed|
                                        |the reader would understand and fill in. This is common in conversational speech, English included. In|
                                        |addition, it may be that the text in the UBS Gk. NT, which inserts a space and renders three letters|
                                        |as two words <char style="it">o ti </char>(ὅ τι), <char style="w" strong="G03739">ὅ</char>), <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G05100">τι</char>)(could instead be rendered with no space in the single word <char style="it">hoti|
                                        |(</char>whatsoever; whatever), which is the nominative singular neuter form of <char style="it">hostis|
                                        |</char>(whosoever; ὅστις), <char style="w" strong="G03748">ὅστις</char>).|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Come clean on this and tell us the truth</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Give glory to|
                                        |God</char>. An idiom used a few times in the Bible, Josh. 7:19; Acts 12:23 to name a couple of instances.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">needs to get his head straightened out</char>…<char style="it">if he’s a wacko or not</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">whence he is</char>. An expression; ref. note of Luke 13:25.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pay any regard</char>…Lit: <char style="it">hear</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">devout</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God-fearing</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shunned him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cast him outside</char>. Obviously, from its|
                                        |usage in v. 35, this is an expression. Ref. note of John 15:6.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to settle a matter</char>…Lit: <char style="it">for a judgment</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sticks to you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">remains</char>. Ref. John 6:56.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">We must continue to work doing the works of He who sent me</char>…Or perhaps: <char|
                                        |style="it">The works of He who sent me must continue to be done by us </char>[or <char style="it">among|
                                        |us</char>]. An unusual or incorrect grammatical case for the word <char style="it">we </char>causes this|
                                        |verse to be ambiguous. Some ancient manuscripts were modified in an attempt to resolve the ambiguity|
                                        |(Textus Receptus replaces <char style="it">we </char>with <char style="it">I</char>, for example).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">until we run out of daylight</char>…Lit: <char style="it">until a day is</char>. The|
                                        |phrase <char style="it">until a day is</char> can also be translated, <char style="it">until the day|
                                        |ends.</char> John’s referring to the end of a Jewish day which occurs at sundown. A field worker would|
                                        |normally work—say—ten hours, but quit work early enough so there was enough time to walk home in the|
                                        |daylight, receive your daily wage (ref. Matt. 20:8), or whatnot. When night arrives, it gets too dark|
                                        |to get any work done, etc. He would only work in the field until sunset if he had to, like during harvest,|
                                        |when there was too much work and barely enough time to do it. This is what Jesus meant by working until|
                                        |there’s no more daylight—there’s way too much to do and not enough time to do it in (i.e. working overtime;|
                                        |crunch time). Jesus uses a similar analogy about daylight in John 11:9,10 also.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Go on over to the Siloam (translated ‘Sent’) pool and wash yourself off in it</char>…The|
                                        |likely reason why Jesus had him dip in the pool after rubbing the saliva-mud on him is because bodily|
                                        |discharges of any and every sort (spittle included) are specified as unclean in the Law of Moses (ref.|
                                        |Lev. 15, the entire chapter). Lev. 15:5 states that one should wash himself after being in contact with|
                                        |a bodily discharge of any sort; hence Jesus’s instruction for the man to bathe himself. Why Jesus rubbed|
                                        |the saliva-mud on the man’s eyes in the first place is anyone’s guess…|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">This person has doorway access</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the door opens to </char>[i.e.,|
                                        |<char style="it">for</char>] <char style="it">him</char>. A personification.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The thief’s sole purpose in coming is</char>…Lit: <char style="it">The thief doesn’t|
                                        |come except that he would</char>. A figure of speech.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">puts his life on the life</char>…<char style="it">I lay my life down</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">puts his life</char>…<char style="it">I put my life</char>. This same idiom used in v. 11,|
                                        |15, 17, 18 have similar, howbeit different, meanings. It is both the decision to risk one’s one life|
                                        |(v. 11, 15) and the loss of one’s life as a consequence of such a decision (v. 17, 18).|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pick it back up again</char>…Lit: <char style="it">take it again</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">directive</char>…Lit: <char style="it">commandment</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">How much longer are you going to leave us in the dark? We’re dying to know</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">How much longer are you going to take our life away</char>. An hyperbole.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Messiah</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Christ</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">at the behest of my Father and of by His authority</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the|
                                        |name of my Father</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">make a statement</char>…Lit: <char style="it">testify</char> or <char style="it">witness</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Old Testament</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Law</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assuming that</char>…Lit: <char style="it">if</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Scripture</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">commissioned</char>…Lit: <char style="it">set apart</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">acquire the understanding and continue in the understanding</char>…Lit: <char style="it">know</char>|
                                        |[aorist subjunctive] <char style="it">and know</char> [present subjunctive]. A figure of speech.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">escaped from their clutches</char>…Lit: <char style="it">exited their hands</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miracle</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sign</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">climbing over the wall</char>…Lit: <char style="it">goes up</char>. In ancient Israel,|
                                        |sheepfolds were enclosed with tall, formidable, stone walls, higher than the average person. These walls|
                                        |were to not only contain the sheep but to prevent predators and thieves from getting in.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a thief, and not only a thief but a violent, villainous thug of a thief</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">a thief and a robber</char>. This is a hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11. The two Gk.|
                                        |words here for <char style="it">thief </char>and <char style="it">robber </char>are differentiated in|
                                        |a similar fashion to their English renderings. Generally speaking, a thief attempts to avoid confrontation|
                                        |when stealing; a robber, on the other hand, assaults the person or persons whom he steals from. A robber|
                                        |therefore employs physical harm and violence on a regular basis, and is a much rougher, belligerent,|
                                        |and violent criminal than the ordinary thief. In this hendiadys, Jesus explains that this thief is not|
                                        |your ordinary thief, but one who commits unwarranted and wanton acts of violence in addition to his thievery.|
                                        |When Jesus speaks of the thief in v. 10, the thief he refers to is the same one he describes in vv. 1,8.|
                                        |So the thief of v. 10 is a violent destructive thief, not just simply a larcenist.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">came by</char>…Lit: <char style="it">came prior to </char>[or <char style="it">in front|
                                        |of</char>] me. First, <char style="it">in front of me </char>could be rendered <char style="it">prior|
                                        |to me, </char>resulting in, <char style="it">came prior to me. </char>Second, the best manuscripts are|
                                        |split fairly evenly on whether the phrase <char style="it">in front of </char>me/<char style="it">prior|
                                        |to me </char>is spurious or not. The Gk. phrase <char style="it">pro emou</char> (πρὸ ἐμοῦ) <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G04253">πρὸ </char>), <char style="w" strong="G01700">ἐμοῦ</char>) could be rendered <char style="it">in|
                                        |front of me </char>or <char style="it">prior to me</char> (while a face-value reading would prefer <char|
                                        |style="it">prior to me, </char>the more sensible rendering would be <char style="it">in front of me</char>).|
                                        |No matter what’s chosen, the reader is left scratching his head trying to figure out the point that Jesus|
                                        |through John was trying to get across. My guess (and it is very much a guess) is that the phrase is spurious;|
                                        |I have added the word <char style="it">by </char>as a weak guess at an interpolation, which leaves unspecified|
                                        |the time which these thieves came by.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he will enter and exit through the door and find pasture to graze in</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">he will enter and exit and find pasture</char>. Jesus compares himself to a sheep pen door|
                                        |for a couple of verses. The sheep must pass through the door to get into the pen and must pass through|
                                        |the door to get out of the pen. While they are in the pen, they are <char style="it">kept safe from harm|
                                        |</char>(also v. 9). While they are out of the pen, they can <char style="it">find pasture, </char>i.e.|
                                        |eat, drink, etc. The sheep must divide their time between the pen and the pasture; they cannot stay in|
                                        |the one or the other for too long a period. Therefore, they are constantly being shuttled into and out|
                                        |of the pen, and must pass through the door—and this door is narrow—each time. If they’re in the pen for|
                                        |too long, they’ll need to get out; if they’re in the pasture for too long, they’ll need to get in. They|
                                        |must pass through the door in order to have their needs met, in summary.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Awesome Shepherd</char>…The Gk. word behind <char style="it">Awesome </char>is <char|
                                        |style="it">kalōs </char>(καλῶς /Strong’s 2773) and not <char style="it">agathos </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00018">ἀγαθός</char>). <char style="it">Kalos</char> describes something which is beautiful|
                                        |on the outside; in this context, it speaks of something which is beautiful because it does what it’s|
                                        |supposed to do so well. Applied to being a shepherd, it describes an utra-competent, excellent, diligent,|
                                        |hard-working shepherd, one who excels at what a shepherd is supposed to do. A <char style="it">kalos|
                                        |</char>shepherd is one that others, who by viewing his actions, confirm that he’s excellent at being|
                                        |a shepherd—to the point of being beautiful—at his job. <char style="it">Kalos </char>describes excellence|
                                        |by viewing what’s on the inside of a person, his actions, and does not describe (not necessarily) what’s|
                                        |on the inside, the attitudes of the heart, etc. On the other hand, <char style="it">Agathos</char> describes|
                                        |someone who’s good on the inside. Choosing to describe Jesus as the <char style="it">Kalos</char> Shepherd|
                                        |rather than the <char style="it">Agathos</char> Shepherd doesn’t mean he’s not good on the inside, it|
                                        |simply means that the emphasis is on Jesus’s competency as a shepherd.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Furthermore, the term <char style="it">Awesome Shepherd</char> is rendered in English as capitalized|
                                        |because of the use of the Gk. attributive adjective here.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t frequent this</char> <char style="it">sheep pen compound</char>…Lit: <char style="it">out|
                                        |of this</char> <char style="it">courtyard</char>. The definition of the Gk. word for <char style="it">courtyard|
                                        |</char>is a courtyard enclosed by a house around its perimeter. In this verse, instead of a house, the|
                                        |perimeter of the courtyard is the stone wall of the sheep pen; the courtyard is the pen itself. Jesus|
                                        |is saying that there are other sheep out there which he owns. The sheep in the pen comprise the nation|
                                        |of Israel; those other sheep are the Gentile nations.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">edited out</char>…Lit: <char style="it">broken </char>[primary word <char style="it">loosed</char>];|
                                        |Gk. <char style="it">luo </char><char style="w" strong="G03089">λύω</char>)<char style="it">. </char>The|
                                        |word <char style="it">kataluo </char><char style="w" strong="G02647">καταλύω</char>)<char style="it">,|
                                        |</char>derived from <char style="it">luo</char>, is used in Luke 21:6 to describe the destruction of|
                                        |the temple by the disassembling of its stones. The temple was comprised of tightly-fitting stones; its|
                                        |destruction consisted of tearing these stones apart and casting them aside, completely out of place;|
                                        |the use of the word <char style="it">kataluo </char>describes this, with the prefix <char style="it">kata|
                                        |</char>meaning <char style="it">to the ultimate extent. </char>Therefore, a meaning of <char style="it">luo|
                                        |</char>is to tear something out of its tightly-fitting location within a larger structure and casting|
                                        |it aside. This is what John means by his use of <char style="it">luo </char>in this verse: removing a|
                                        |single verse from the Bible as though you were tearing a carefully-placed stone out of larger structure.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">poured oil over the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">anointed the Lord in oil</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">twin</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Didymus</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">1 ¾ miles/2.7km</char>…Lit: <char style="it">15 stadia</char>. Ref. note of Luke 24:13|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Day of Reckoning</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Last Day</char>. Ref. John 6:39.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">groaned deeply</char>…Same Gk. word used in Mark 1:43; ref. note there.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">come out</char>…In the Gk. text, the polite form of <char style="it">come </char>is|
                                        |used.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because the objects in this world are illuminated by the daylight, and he sees them</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">he sees the light of this world</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">light</char>|
                                        |is not quite the same as the English word <char style="it">light</char>. In addition to its core meaning,|
                                        |light also means the images of objects as seen by the eye when they are illuminated by a light source.|
                                        |This is way it’s used here in vv. 9,10. This is usage also applies, although to a lesser degree, to Matt.|
                                        |6:22,23.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because nothing’s illuminated</char>…Jesus is referring to the daylight analogy that|
                                        |he spoke about in 9:4,5, and assumes the disciples remember the point he made then. His point is that|
                                        |you have to strike while the iron is hot. There are just a finite number of instance where God performed|
                                        |spectacular miracles like raising Lazarus from the dead, and Jesus had to act swiftly and decisively|
                                        |to ensure that they took place.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Let’s go too so that we get to die with him too</char>…Thomas is being sarcastic, thinking|
                                        |that if they go to Bethany, which is near Jerusalem, those who are trying to stone Jesus to death will|
                                        |catch them and have them all killed. Thomas sees no sense in risking a visit to a dead man, and it doesn’t|
                                        |occur to him that Jesus is going to raise him from the dead.|

     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fair citizens of that glorious land over the rainbow</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Zion-daughter</char>.|
                                        |Some liberties taken. The word <char style="it">daughter </char>is a synecdoche of all those who belong|
                                        |to Zion, with the implication that the daughters are those who love it and never want to depart from|
                                        |it. Zion is the ethereal, uncorrupted land that God promises Israel, and not just land but the state|
                                        |of living. It is the fulfillment of His promises; it is the elimination of the shortcomings of what is|
                                        |achievable in this life; it is the existence to come for those who love and follow God.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the world’s gone chasing after him to be his follower</char>…Or perhaps: <char style="it">the|
                                        |world’s left to be his disciples, to be in subjection to him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the world’s|
                                        |departed behind him</char>. The expression <char style="it">behind him/go behind him </char>is used in|
                                        |Matt. 4:19 to mean <char style="it">be my disciple, </char>and is used in Matt. 16:23 to mean <char style="it">be|
                                        |in subjection to.</char>|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Greek-speaking Jews</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Greeks</char>. Assumed that these are|
                                        |the same people as the <char style="it">diaspora of the Greeks</char> referred to in John 7:35. Some,|
                                        |however, argue that these people are <char style="it">God-fearers </char>(ref. Acts 13:16):<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>Gentiles who adhered to Jewish practices buy hadn’t converted to Judaism per-se. Whether Greek-speaking|
                                        |Jews or God-fearers, they are likely one or the other and not Gentiles (the word used here could also|
                                        |be rendered <char style="it">Gentiles</char>), since Jews wouldn’t have any interactions with Gentiles,|
                                        |especially during a festival.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">enjoys</char>…Gk: <char style="it">phileō </char><char style="w" strong="G05368">φιλέω</char>).|
                                        |<char style="it">Philos</char> is typically rendered <char style="it">love</char>, but is not to be confused|
                                        |with <char style="it">agapā </char><char style="w" strong="G00026">ἀγάπη</char>), which is also rendered|
                                        |<char style="it">love</char>. The philos-kind of love is the love of another person, or in this verse|
                                        |of another thing, for the friendship, comradery, and enjoyment that one receives from such association;|
                                        |agapā<char style="it"> </char>is the love of another because one treasures that other person.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">honor him, including providing his financial support</char>…Lit: <char style="it">honor|
                                        |him</char>. The Gk. word for honor means both to honor as the face-value of the word means and to provide|
                                        |financial support. Ref. Matt. 15:3–6, 1 Tim. 5:17–18.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hoisted up</char>…The Gk. word also means <char style="it">exalted </char>and also means|
                                        |<char style="it">killed</char>. The verse has multiple meanings, based on the Gk. word having multiple|
                                        |meanings. On the one hand, Jesus will be hoisted off the ground by being put on a cross. Another meaning|
                                        |is that he’ll be killed, just as the same Gk. word is used to mean <char style="it">killed</char> in|
                                        |Acts 7:28. On the other hand, Jesus will be exalted, lifted up as a spectacle for everyone to see, but|
                                        |afterwards exalted above every name (ref. Phil. 2:9).|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He who dines with me in a fellowship setting</char> …Lit: <char style="it">he who munches|
                                        |on my bread</char>. The eating of bread here symbolizes the bond of fellowship and unity between those|
                                        |who partake of it together. This makes the Judas’s betrayal all the more wicked.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">One of his disciples, whom Jesus loved and loved, was seated next to him, and since|
                                        |he was a close companion was in physical contact with him, leaning against him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">He|
                                        |was reclining, one of his disciples, in Jesus’s bosom, whom Jesus was loving</char>. Liberties taken|
                                        |here; also in vv. 12, 25. The disciples were reclined, not sitting (ref. note of Luke 16:22). It’s likely|
                                        |that John was propped up on his arm (hand on side of head, elbow on the couch); in v. 25 the Gk. text|
                                        |literally says that he <char style="it">fell back </char>[<char style="it">leaned back</char>] <char|
                                        |style="it">at Jesus’s bosom</char>. One can deduce that he took away his arm-prop, laid down completely,|
                                        |and leaned back. This change in position caused his head to be in contact with Jesus’s bosom, specifically|
                                        |his stomach and chest. He leaned back so that his head would be in close proximity to Jesus’s head, so|
                                        |that he could speak a few words with him that no one else could hear.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Satan entered into</char>…Though speculation, it may be that Jesus placed the morsel|
                                        |of bread directly into Judas’s mouth, similar to how a bride and a groom put wedding cake into each other’s|
                                        |mouth—a similar type of symbolism. It may be that John is implying that, just as the bread was physically|
                                        |placed into Judas’s mouth and entered his body, on a parallel level Satan entered Judas’s heart.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m giving you a brand-new directive, that you would love one another</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">I’m giving you a brand new commandment, so that you would love one another</char>. The wording|
                                        |is a figure of speech: instead of stating the commandment, the end-result of the commandment is stated|
                                        |instead; the commandment is insinuated.|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">If you’re set on loving me</char>…Lit: <char style="it">if you were to love me</char>.|
                                        |The subjunctive verb form is of someone who’s faced with a choice of doing something or not doing it.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I will not have</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I will not</char> [Gk. <char style="it">ou|
                                        |</char>(οὐ/Strong’s 3756 )]. The Gk. word <char style="it">ou </char>is unexpected, whereas the word|
                                        |<char style="it">ma </char>is expected here, skewing the meaning.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t let your heart be troubled</char>…The same exact wording as used in v. 1.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he can accuse me of nothing, tempt me with nothing, or intimidate me in any way</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">he has nothing in me</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And if I manage to prepare a place for you—and I will</char>…Lit: <char style="it">If|
                                        |I were to prepare a place for you</char>. The tentativeness of the subjunctive verb tense used in the|
                                        |GT is a figure of speech. But what is actually meant is arduousness. In order for Jesus to prepare a|
                                        |place, he must first endure the cross, and only then afterwards, being resurrected and ascending to the|
                                        |Father, can he prepare a place. He having to go to the cross is not tentative but arduous; hence the|
                                        |figure of speech. |
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Let me repeat—If you were to ask me to do something while acting in my delegated authority,|
                                        |I will do it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">If you were to ask me something in my name, I will do</char>.|
                                        |Obvious to the reader of the GT, v. 14 is a repetition of v. 13a. The difference between the wording|
                                        |in these two verses is that v. 13 is a more compact repetition, omitting a few words with the confidence|
                                        |that the reader will understand that they were omitted for brevity. Therefore, the repetition of the|
                                        |statement is a figure of speech, one where Jesus wants to be clear about what he’s saying and to emphasize|
                                        |it.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’ll ask the Father to give you a helper of a different kind</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I’ll|
                                        |ask the Father</char> [<char style="it">to give you another helper</char>] <char style="it">and He will|
                                        |give you another helper</char>. The Gk. text omits the phrase <char style="it">to give you another helper</char>,|
                                        |with the wording shortened to <char style="it">I’ll ask the Father and He will give you another helper.|
                                        |</char>This short form is a figure of speech.|

                                        |keeping the commandments viewed in its entirety.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put his life on the line</char>…Or: <char style="it">lay his life down</char>. Ref.|
                                        |note of John 10:11.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">set you up</char>…Or: <char style="it">positioned</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">while acting in my delegated authority</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in my name</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a part of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">out of</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reputation and the authority I’ve delegated to you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">my name</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">be in sin</char>…Lit: <char style="it">have sin</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sacred book</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Law</char> [<char style="it">of Moses</char>]|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Helper</char>…Also: <char style="it">Advocate</char>, <char style="it">Comforter</char>,|
                                        |<char style="it">Intercessor</char>. Same word used in John 14:16. The Gk. word refers to someone who,|
                                        |nowadays, fills the role of an attorney.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">proceeds forth</char>…Lit<char style="it">: goes out</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He removes all branches that are attached to me that don’t produce</char>…The meaning|
                                        |of this remark should be understood in light of what Jesus said in Matt. 3:10, 7:19, and also later in|
                                        |John 15:6; in other words, branches that don’t produce fruit are unbelievers: those who are presented|
                                        |with Jesus’s message but refuse to believe. It is not the believer who makes mistake after mistake.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">discarded</char>…Lit: <char style="it">thrown outside</char>. This expression (the keyword|
                                        |in the expression being <char style="it">outside</char>) appears in Matt. 5:13, 13:48, 21:39; Mark 4:11,|
                                        |12:8; Luke 14:35, 20:15; John 6:37, 9:34 (and perhaps more) and has the consistent meaning of <char style="it">categorically|
                                        |rejected </char>in all these occurrences.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">If I had not done the miraculous works among them that no one else ever did, they wouldn’t|
                                        |be in sin</char>…This is consistent with what’s found in Mark 3:29, namely blaspheming the Holy Spirit.|
                                        |The rejection of an irrefutable display of God’s miraculous power is a deep sin.|

                                        |get you ready</char>…Lit: <char style="it">were girding yourself</char>…<char style="it">will gird</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">follow me, even in death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">follow me</char>. Also means,|
                                        |be my disciple. Same phrase used in Matt. 4:19.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">at the dinner</char>…Ref. John 13:23|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char> [<char style="it">brethren</char>]|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">going on record and giving an official account</char>…Lit: <char style="it">witnessing</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">boys</char>…Not unusual in a lot of cultures to address grown men who are at work as|
                                        |<char style="it">boys. </char>This is done in the Deep South; in France, waiters are called garcon (boy).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anything that’s edible</char>—<char style="it">namely fish</char>…The Gk. word here|
                                        |for <char style="it">edible </char>occurs once in the NT and the lexicon is sparse on detail. The word|
                                        |is derived from <char style="it">food</char>, and I’m guessing the prefix changes its meaning to <char|
                                        |style="it">ready-to-eat. </char>The Gk. experts say that the word means <char style="it">fish</char>,|
                                        |but they probably deduce this from the context.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">100 yards/90 meters</char>…Lit: <char style="it">200 cubits</char>. 1 cubit = 18 inches.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Simon son of John</char>…Jesus speaking to him formally, somewhat like a mother talking|
                                        |to a misbehaving son using the full form of his first name, plus the middle and last names (for example:|
                                        |<char style="it">William Patrick Smith</char> instead of just <char style="it">Bill</char>).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you will stretch your hands out and another will get you ready</char> [Lit: <char style="it">gird|
                                        |you</char>] <char style="it">and will carry you where you don’t want to go</char>…Church tradition says|
                                        |that Peter was crucified in his old age, and that this statement refers to his crucifixion. <char style="it">Stretching|
                                        |your hands out </char>refers to Peter stretching his hands out to have them nailed to a cross, and <char|
                                        |style="it">carry you where you don’t want to go </char>refers to taking the cross and posting it in the|
                                        |ground.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">if I were to want him to remain</char>…The point John’s making is that Jesus is speaking|
                                        |hypothetically; he didn’t really intend for John to stay on the earth until his second coming.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reinstate Israel as its own sovereign nation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">restore the|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">exact dates or windows of time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">times and seasons</char>.|
                                        |Likely an expression; therefore, it’s meaning is more expansive than the literal rendering. The expansive|
                                        |meaning would include: sequences of events, prerequisites—things such as these.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">will attest to my truthfulness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">will be my witnesses</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Gentlemen, fellow Galileans</char>…<char style="it">Gentlemen, fellow comrades</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">Men, Galileans</char>…<char style="it">Men, comrades</char>. This rhetorical form is|
                                        |the opening to a public speech, as though one will attempt to persuade the audience.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">half-mile/1 km</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a Sabbath </char>[<char style="it">permissible</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">journey</char>]|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by women</char>…Or: <char style="it">by their wives</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">verses in the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Scripture</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he wound up being the unfortunate one who performed this duty</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |lot-casting the lot of this service</char>. A metaphor is used whereby Judas competed in the casting|
                                        |of lots (a game of chance) and was the loser. We might say, “he would up being the one who drew the last|
                                        |stick and got stuck with performing this duty.”|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was acquainted with us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">entered and departed at us</char>.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for his own purpose</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to his Own Place</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they flipped a coin, and Matthias won the toss</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they gave|
                                        |them lots, and the lot fell on Matthias</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">got himself in a head-first direction and</char> <char style="it">killed himself in|
                                        |such a way that his torso ruptured…</char>Lit: <char style="it">became head-first and burst </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">the</char>]<char style="it"> middle</char>. The verb form for <char style="it">head-first</char>|
                                        |<char style="w" strong="G04248">πρηνής</char>) from verb <char style="it">pranizō</char>/no Strong’s|
                                        |number) means to throw oneself head-first or to fall headlong, so other translations say that he dove|
                                        |head-first and that the impact of the fall caused his body to split open and his intestines to come out.|
                                        |But the word <char style="it">head-first </char>also refers to the prone position, so the phrase <char|
                                        |style="it">became head-first </char>could mean <char style="it">became prone </char>instead. There’s|
                                        |not enough content and enough clarity to conclude with certainty that he dove head-first off a high cliff|
                                        |or off some other precipice—not to mention the practicalities of what that entails. Suffice to say that|
                                        |there remains ambiguity and uncertainty of what exactly Luke was talking about in this verse. |

     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it caused their hearts to melt</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they were pierced the heart</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Have a change of heart and of ways</char>…Lit: <char style="it">repent</char>|

     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">escape</char>…Lit: <char style="it">be saved</char>. The rendering of the Gk. word <char|
                                        |style="it">save </char>or <char style="it">saved </char>is context-specific. This rendering is the same|

     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">contemporary Zeitgeist</char>…Lit: <char style="it">generation</char>|

     w                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">properties and possessions kept on being sold</char>…Lit: <char style="it">properties|
                                        |and possessions kept on selling</char>. The GT uses the active voice instead of the passive, perhaps|
                                        |an expression similar to what we use in English.|
     w                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">When all the days had been checked off until fifty were reached</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in|
                                        |the day of the fifty filling-together</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">filling-together </char>refers|
                                        |to manning a ship with a full complement of sailors. In other words, <char style="it">filling-together|
                                        |</char>is a metaphor which compares the counting of the days until fifty is reached to a ship captain|
                                        |who desires to set sail but needs a nominal number of sailors, and sailors with a list of essential skills.|
                                        |The captain cannot depart until he fills out his quota, so he searches the harbor looking to recruit|
                                        |sailors needed to staff his ship. He sets sail immediately once the quota has been filled.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sweet wine</char>…This is a young, sweet wine, the wine known as <char style="it">must</char>.|
                                        |It’s likely a wine that’s drunk undiluted, a wine which has a higher alcohol content, is less expensive,|
                                        |or both: the beverage-of-choice when the goal of is to get drunk as easily and as cheaply as possible.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it is just as much given to the one as to the other</char>…This phrase is not an interpolation|
                                        |but is justified by the insertion of the word <char style="it">and </char>before the word <char style="it">children</char>,|
                                        |an <char style="it">and </char>which is in addition the <char style="it">and </char>between <char style="it">children|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">everyone who’s far away. </char>In v. 39 here, Luke says that the promise|
                                        |is for those closest to you and that you have the closest human bonds to—your children—and for those|
                                        |who are furthest from you geographically and for whom you have no human bond whatsoever. The point he’s|
                                        |making (and he clears this up immediately after) is that if the promise is for both extremes relationally|
                                        |and physically, then certainly it is for everyone else.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stating</char>…Lit: <char style="it">witnessing</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">witness|
                                        |</char>is used throughout Acts, John’s Gospel and his epistles, and elsewhere in the NT. This usage in|
                                        |v. 40 here is about as good a definition of what is meant by witnessing as can be found anywhere in the|
                                        |NT. First, begin with an understanding of the usage of <char style="it">witness </char>in the OT, which|
                                        |is a person testifying in a court of law. After that, study the context of v. 40 here, and the definition|
                                        |of <char style="it">witnessing </char>becomes apparent. Apply this understanding to other places in the|
                                        |NT where <char style="it">witness </char>is used (Acts 1:8 for example).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">distributed to every person according to whoever happened to have a need</char>…Some|
                                        |have said that this (and Acts 4:35) rings of Karl Marx’s quotation, “From each according to his ability,|
                                        |to each according to his need.” Keep in mind the following, however. First, Luke states this as a fact|
                                        |and does not say that it was a command, confirmed by what Peter said in Acts 5:4. Second, the apostles|
                                        |were convinced that Jesus would return to earth any day now—certainly no more than a few weeks hence—so|
                                        |what’s the use of owning property? Third, Acts 8:1 said that there was a great persecution against the|
                                        |church in Jerusalem. In such a persecution, those persecuted would surely have had their property confiscated,|
                                        |so they might’ve anticipated this and sold what they owned preemptively. Fourth, not everyone sold what|
                                        |they owned; otherwise they wouldn’t have been able to meet from house to house (v. 46), as there wouldn’t|
                                        |have been any houses to meet at. Fifth, this was an extraordinary period of revival, and extraordinary|
                                        |things happen in extraordinary revivals, things that don’t otherwise happen.|

     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the epitome of one who fills the role of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">son of</char>.|

     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">clergyman</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Levite</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who authorized you to do this in their agency</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in what name|
                                        |you did this</char>. The phrase <char style="it">in his name </char>or something akin to it is used throughout|
                                        |the NT, and this occurrence here in vv. 7 and 9 provide one of the best examples of what the phrase means.|
                                        |To do something in the name of someone else means one or several of the following: To do something at|
                                        |one’s bidding or command; to do something as one authorized by another, using delegated authority which|
                                        |the other grants; to acquire the right to do something that one naturally has no right to do, only because|
                                        |of the reputation or authority of the one whose name is invoked. Related to <char style="it">in his name</char>,|
                                        |ref. notes of Matt. 21:9; Mark 9:41; Mark 16:17; Rom. 2:24.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">distributed to each person in proportion to what a given person happened to need</char>…Ref.|
                                        |note of Acts 2:35|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assistant, advocate, counselor, and encourager</char>…The well-known Gk. word <char|
                                        |style="it">paraklātos </char><char style="w" strong="G03875">παράκλητος</char>) is used here, and the|
                                        |word has several meanings. The specific meaning of <char style="it">paraklātos </char>which best applies|
                                        |to Barnabas, however, can be discovered by studying what Barnabas did through the Book of Acts (Acts|
                                        |11:23–26, for example) and drawing conclusions based on that. Barnabas assisted Paul in his missionary|
                                        |journeys, but also advocated for Mark, thereby causing a dispute between him and Paul. In the end, though,|
                                        |Barnabas’s judge of Mark’s character was vindicated by Mark’s maturity.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now a certain man named Ananias sold a piece of property in conjunction with his wife Sapphira |

     v 4                                |to human beings but to God.”|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">While you still had it, wasn’t it yours to keep</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a remaining|
                                        |to you kept remaining</char> [Gk: <char style="it">menon soi emenen </char>(μένον σοὶ ἔμενεν), <char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G03306">μένον</char>), <char style="w" strong="G04771">σοὶ</char>), <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G03306">ἔμενεν</char>)]. In the GT, the terse wording of the phrase, the repetition of the verb|
                                        |<char style="it">menō, </char>and the fact that this is a quotation of someone speaking and is not narrative|
                                        |leads to the conclusion that this is an expression, and therefore has a meaning beyond the face-value|
                                        |word-for-word transliteration. The bottom line is that an equivalent English expression for this Gk.|
                                        |expression would be, “what’s yours is yours.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to try to pull a fast one on</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to test</char>; <char style="it">to|
                                        |tempt</char>. The context of the usage of the Gk. word <char style="it">peiradzō </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G03958">πειράζω</char>) used here in v. 9 sheds light on the meaning of this multi-faceted word,|
                                        |aiding in one’s understanding of how it’s used in other passages, Matt. 4:7, 1 Cor. 10:9 for example.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Take a look at the feet</char>…Of course, Peter meant <char style="it">take a look at|
                                        |the young men </char>instead. The word <char style="it">feet </char>is a synecdoche for the young men|
                                        |themselves. Throughout the Bible, the word <char style="it">feet </char>is symbolic of what a person|
                                        |does at a high-level, or the things a person does which are more involved than simple actions. The word|
                                        |<char style="it">hand </char>is for simple actions, but <char style="it">feet </char>is symbolic of something|
                                        |which requires a sequence of actions to complete. In this verse here, Peter’s synecdoche indicates what|
                                        |the young men are about to do. Of particular interest is how deeply rooted such figures of speech were|
                                        |in the Israelis of that time, that they were used in impromptu, conversational speech such as this. We|
                                        |can assume that Jesus talked the same way; passages such as Matt. 18:8, though they sound out of place|
                                        |to the modern ear, were commonplace remarks for the time and place. |
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">at the door</char>…One possible reason that those who carried off Ananias where standing|
                                        |at the doorway instead of being in the building could be because, having handled a dead body, they were|
                                        |unclean according to Jewish purity law and therefore were banned from rejoining the others.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">peer down and check in on any one of them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the shadow would|
                                        |cast a shadow on</char> [or <char style="it">overshadow</char>] <char style="it">any one of them</char>.|
                                        |Not absolutely certain, but this appears to be an idiom/expression. This phrase paints a picture of someone|
                                        |sitting or lying on the ground when the sun’s shining, and someone else walks up to this person stands|
                                        |near them in such a way as to block the sun. Sometimes movies, especially Westerns, have scenes like|
                                        |this where a stronger person approaches a weaker person and blocks the sun when close. The weaker person|
                                        |squints up until when the stronger person is close, and he no longer needs to squint because of the shadow|
                                        |provided by the stronger person. The stronger person has come by to have an encounter of some sort with|
                                        |the weaker person—in this case, for Peter the stronger, the one standing, to heal the weaker one, who’s|
                                        |sitting or lying due to his weakness.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">an angel</char>…Lit: <char style="it">an angel of the Lord</char>. At times the NT uses|
                                        |the phrase <char style="it">angel of the Lord</char> instead of simply <char style="it">angel</char>|
                                        |(Luke 2:9 for example) to clarify any ambiguity as to the meaning of <char style="it">angel</char>, specifying|
                                        |the angelic being as opposed to a human being. Since the word <char style="it">angel </char>is rendered|
                                        |a couple different ways into English, once in English there’s no need to retain the words <char style="it">of|
                                        |the Lord </char>as the ambiguity has been stripped. Also, ref. usage in Rev. 1:20.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">having hung him on a wooden cross-beam</char>…A figure of speech—a synecdoche—where|
                                        |instead of using the obvious words <char style="it">crucify, cross, </char>etc.<char style="it">, </char>which|
                                        |the listener normally hears used, the act of crucifixion is described in more detailed, graphical terms.|
                                        |To illustrate by analogy, if we were to describe someone being executed by electrocution in the following|
                                        |way: “We shaved his head, strapped him in a chair, put electrodes on his head and legs, and jolted him|
                                        |with electricity,” instead of simply saying, “We electrocuted him,” which every listener would understand.|
                                        |The point of such figures of speech is to illustrate how barbaric the act was, as the well-known words,|
                                        |being overly used, desensitizes one to the reality of what was perpetrated. |

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by being restaurant waiters</char> …Lit: to <char style="it">serve tables</char>. Some|
                                        |liberties taken. <char style="it">Serving tables </char>is more a figure of speech akin to hyperbole|
                                        |than a completely accurate description of what the apostles were doing.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it’s been observed</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being witnessed</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kept on being proclaimed, being received, and producing results</char>…Lit: <char style="it">kept|
                                        |on growing</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs and wonders</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Moses</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the councilmen, and the designated teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Elders|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">widows</char>…Widows were the poorest in society, since they had no one to care for|
                                        |them and no way to earn a substantial living. Ref. note of Mark 12:40.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirit</char>…In this context, the word <char style="it">spirit</char> means <char style="it">deeply-rooted|
                                        |fervor, dedication, etc</char>. It is listed as a personal quality just as <char style="it">wisdom </char>is|
                                        |listed as such<char style="it">. </char>It does not mean <char style="it">Holy Spirit, </char>in spite|
                                        |of other translations rendering this <char style="it">the Spirit</char>, short for <char style="it">the|
                                        |Holy Spirit</char>. In the Bible the word <char style="it">spirit </char>has multiple meanings; sometimes|
                                        |it means <char style="it">Holy Spirit</char>, sometimes it means a person’s spirit, sometimes it refers|
                                        |to a deeply-rooted disposition of one sort or another (example of that is 2 Tim. 1:7). The NT writers|
                                        |understood the potential for ambiguity, and if, when writing, they were referring to the Holy Spirit,|
                                        |they added qualifiers to the word <char style="it">spirit </char>where ambiguity might exist. (Or they|
                                        |added qualifiers for emphasis.) The qualifiers consist of adding an article, adding the word <char style="it">Holy</char>,|
                                        |or<char style="it"> </char>forming a full predicative construct. So in v. 5, such a qualifier is added,|
                                        |as Stephen is <char style="it">full of the Holy Spirit</char>, not <char style="it">full of spirit</char>.|
                                        |But the usage in v. 3 has no qualifiers, is paired with another personal quality <char style="it">wisdom</char>,|
                                        |so therefore does not refer to the Holy Spirit.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put in charge of this matter</char>…This key phrase indicates why the seven—the first|
                                        |church deacons—had to be filled with spirit and wisdom in order to do their job. They were put in charge|
                                        |of the food distribution in order to ensure that it was being done fairly, that widows were not being|
                                        |overlooked because of their ethnicity. This required spirit and wisdom. But it is not a necessary prerequisite|
                                        |for the ordinary church worker to be filled with spirit and wisdom in order to do the simple, mundane|
                                        |labor that all churches require (such as being an usher, a greeter, etc.). Faithfulness and a willingness|
                                        |to work with others is about all such a worker needs. Furthermore, the takeaway from this passage is|
                                        |that a deacon is an overseer, one who can oversee an area of responsibility which is fraught with moral|
                                        |challenges; the run-of-the-mill church worker is not a deacon. If the qualification for every church|
                                        |worker was that he had to be filled with spirit and wisdom (in addition to being faithful and getting|
                                        |along with others), then there would be very few church workers, and much work would remain undone. Also,|
                                        |see description of <char style="it">deacon </char>in note of 1 Cor. 15:24.|
