     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he wasn’t given a tract of land in this country, one that he and his descendants would|
                                        |own in perpetuity—not even a tiny plot that would’ve been barely big enough to get by on</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">it wasn’t given to him an inheritance in it, nor a step of the foot</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">came out of nowhere and oppressed</char>…Lit: <char style="it">came upon</char>. A figure|
                                        |of speech, a personification, portrays the famine arriving like a nomadic bandit and overpowering another.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">paying in cash</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of a price of silver</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to the highest degree</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to God</char>. A Hebrew idiom.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in momma’s house</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the house of the mother</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he felt an urging</char>…Lit: <char style="it">it went up upon his heart</char>. A Hebrew|
                                        |idiom.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his abilities and actions</char>…Lit: <char style="it">his hand</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was coming to their rescue</char>…Lit: <char style="it">giving a salvation</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">acquaintance</char>…Lit: <char style="it">neighbor</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’ve seen</char>…Lit: <char style="it">While looking I saw</char>. A figure of speech.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spectacular miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs and wonders</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vast array of planets and stars in the sky</char>…Lit: <char style="it">atmospheric|
                                        |hosts</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prophet-section of the Old Testament</char>…Lit<char style="it">: in the book of the|
                                        |prophets</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">house of worship</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tent</char> [<char style="it">tabernacle</char>].|
                                        |A temporary cheap imitation of the real tabernacle.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">while</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by the onslaught</char>…Lit: <char style="it">from the face</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">resist</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fall against. </char>The word <char style="it">fall|
                                        |</char>can be taken to mean <char style="it">assault.</char>|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">were piqued and went into a rage of fury</char>…Lit<char style="it">: kept on being|
                                        |touched in the raw in their hearts</char>|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and proceeded to grit their teeth, biting down hard, gnashing them against him</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">proceeded to gnash their teeth upon him</char>. This is a NT expression (Matt. 8:12;|
                                        |13:42,50; 24:51; 25:30; Luke 13:28) typically describing agony.|
     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">jackets</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cloaks</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     v                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">may you not hold them accountable for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">may you not let stand|
                                        |to them</char>|
     v                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his descendants—his progeny</char>…Lit: <char style="it">his seed</char>. This is actually|
                                        |singular, not plural, but the meaning is plural. However, in Gal. 3:16, Paul, using the same word, emphasizes|
                                        |that this is not plural but singular, singular referring to Christ.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">be our banner on the march and in battle, ensuring success at every turn</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">go before us</char>. Images of gods were put on carts which preceded those going into|
                                        |battle or those on the march, just as a strong warrior preceded the host.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I will exile you to a place which is somewhere out beyond Babylon</char>…As it says|
                                        |in Ps. 37:29, “The righteous shall inherit the land, and dwell therein forever.” Going back to Genesis,|
                                        |God promised the land which is Israel to the Israelites. If they obeyed, God would have them live in|
                                        |the land. If they disobeyed, they would eventually be driven out. <char style="it">Out beyond Babylon|
                                        |</char>shows how far away they’ll be removed from the promised land.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">unyielding and unchanged in hearts and ears</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stiff-necked|
                                        |and uncircumcised in hearts and the ears</char>. The words/phrases <char style="it">stiff-necked</char>|
                                        |and <char style="it">uncircumcised</char> <char style="it">of heart</char> are OT expressions (Exod.|
                                        |32:9, Deut. 10:16). Stiff-necked means a person won’t bend his head either downwards in contrition or|
                                        |upwards in hope and faith. Circumcision is the OT pact, the acceptance of and entry into God’s covenant.|
                                        |Also, the removal of the foreskin in the circumcision ceremony symbolizes the peeling away and discarding|
                                        |of a hardened outer layer surrounding the heart (Deut. 10:16).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">took their jackets off and set them next to an aspiring young man named Saul</char>…The|
                                        |removal of the jackets (cloaks actually) was done so that the witnesses would be able to move about more|
                                        |freely when casting the stones. It’s also a gesture of intent, analogous to high school boys who are|
                                        |about to get into a fight and taking off their jackets and showing how tough they are while doing so.|
                                        |Once the high school boy takes off his jacket, he turns a person next to him and hands him his jacket|
                                        |for safekeeping. Now the boy who’s about to get into a fight would’ve been flanked by his close friends,|
                                        |so the person he hands his jacket to is a close friend. All of this paints a picture of who Saul was;|
                                        |he was standing next to the witnesses, so he was part of the inner clique, someone who was trusted, someone|
                                        |who, though younger, was permitted to tag along closely with the high-priest-caste. When the witnesses|
                                        |put their jackets next to Saul, the assumption was that Saul was responsible for their safekeeping. As|
                                        |the witnesses quickly scanned their throng looking for someone to entrust their jackets to, Paul was|
                                        |the logical choice because of his trustworthiness, his close proximity to the witnesses (indicating his|
                                        |zeal), and his youth (indicating that he was the younger among elders). It’s more appropriate to give|
                                        |a young man menial duties than someone who’s older and more senior.|

     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Holy Spirit</char>…the definite article (<char style="it">the) </char>isn’t in the|
                                        |GT, but in Acts 5:3 the definite article is present in <char style="it">the Holy Spirit. </char>Although|
                                        |there are several reasons for inclusion or exclusion of the definite article, it appears that the inclusion|
                                        |of the article in Acts 5:3 emphasizes the Holy Spirit as a person, whereas the exclusion here in v. 15|
                                        |emphasizes the effects that the Holy Spirit has after coming upon a person.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fallen</char>…There is a distinction between the Holy Spirit being in a person and the|
                                        |Holy Spirit falling upon a person. The Holy Spirit went into the eleven when Jesus breathed on them in|
                                        |John 20:22. Later, the Holy Spirit fell on the eleven (plus one) on Pentecost.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they only existed in a state where they had been baptized</char>…<char style="it">Existed|
                                        |in a state</char> is the Gk. word <char style="it">huparchō </char><char style="w" strong="G05225">ὑπάρχω</char>),|
                                        |and the words <char style="it">had been baptized </char>reflect the Gk. perfect participle <char style="it">to|
                                        |be baptized</char>. This adds clarity to the fact that they had become believers and were baptized in|
                                        |water but that the Holy Spirit had not come upon them. It is the rule and not the exception that the|
                                        |Holy Spirit comes upon a person a span of time after he becomes a believer.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s offering</char>…Or: <char style="it">God’s gift</char>. The Gk. word for <char|
                                        |style="it">gift </char>here (<char style="it">dōrean</char>), <char style="w" strong="G01432">δωρεάν</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it"> </char>is not the same word for <char style="it">gift </char>used in 1 Cor. 12:4 (<char style="it">charisma</char>),|
                                        |<char style="w" strong="G05486">χάρισμα</char>); the word <char style="it">charisma </char>is expected.|
                                        |A <char style="it">dōrean </char>is a gift brought and offered to another, like the offerings of the|
                                        |OT Mosaic Law. A dōrean is also a gift that the recipient has earned or deserves, whereas a charisma|
                                        |is a gift a person hasn’t earned. Charisma comes from <char style="it">charis </char>(grace), <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G05485">χάρις</char>); ref. note of Rom. 12:6). Therefore, the gift (<char style="it">dōrean</char>)|
                                        |of the Holy Spirit is something that God brings to mankind and presents as a gift, as an offering.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">heard him reading</char>…In ancient times, those who could read always read aloud and|
                                        |never silently to themselves, even when alone.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |vs. 37 would read: <char style="it">Philip said, “If you believe with all of your heart, you may.” He|
                                        |said in response, “I believe the Son of God to be Jesus Christ.”</char> This verse is not to be found|
                                        |in almost all of the best manuscripts, and is therefore a spurious addition. Verse 37 is instructive|
                                        |of text added years after Luke wrote Acts. Rather than attempting to propagate a lie, it attempts to|
                                        |embellish the text.|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what I stand for</char>…<char style="it">acting as my representative</char>…Lit: <char|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of</char> [<char style="it">from</char>]|

     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">conducting their lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">walking</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">donations to the poor</char>…Lit: <char style="it">alms</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Simon Tanner</char>…Or: <char style="it">Simon the tanner</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |”<char style="it">the Way</char>”…The sect or movement that believed in Jesus was called <char style="it">the|
                                        |Way. </char>One had to be Jewish to join the Way. It wasn’t until Acts 11:26 that those who believe in|
                                        |Jesus are called Christians, where one believes in Jesus without first being Jewish, coming to God while|
                                        |circumventing Judaism altogether.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Israeli descendants scattered all around</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sons of Israel</char>.|
                                        |The assumption is that this refers to the Hellenistic Jews scattered throughout the Roman Empire.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fellow comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>. Saul had become a brother|
                                        |in the Lord before Ananias prayed for him to receive the baptism in the Holy Spirit; being baptized in|
                                        |the Holy Spirit almost always occurs at a time after believing in Jesus. Therefore, Saul was a believer|
                                        |already, when he was baptized in the Holy Spirit. Since the Holy Spirit comes to live in every believer|
                                        |at the time they receive Christ, the baptism in the Holy Spirit must be something different.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was in the habit of making</char>…From the sounds of it, Tabitha used to make clothing|
                                        |and donate it to the needy. Those whom she showed the most generosity to in life (i.e. the widows) wept|
                                        |the hardest when she died.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">battalion</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cohort</char>|

     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on top of which</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in which</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reptiles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">creatures which crawl on the ground</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">isn’t kosher</char>…Lit: <char style="it">is profane and unclean.</char> A hendiadys.|
                                        |<char style="it">Profane </char>is something which one should never indulge in; <char style="it">unclean|
                                        |</char>is something which you shouldn’t indulge in until it flips back to <char style="it">clean </char>(assuming|
                                        |it can or ever does). Also, ref. Rom. 14:14.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prostrated himself before him in worship</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fell at the feet|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">praying just like we pray during the Three-in-the-Afternoon-Prayer-Time</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">praying a ninth</char>[-<char style="it">hour prayer</char>]. <char style="it">Ninth|
                                        |</char>refers to <char style="it">three in the afternoon</char>. Ref. Acts 3:1.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">really, really floored</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon a truth overtaken</char>. <char|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who reverence Him and go about doing right are acceptable to Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">who|
                                        |fear Him and work righteousness are acceptable to Him</char>. Also, <char style="it">acceptable to Him|
                                        |</char>means <char style="it">accepted by Him, </char>meaning that He accepts them if they were to ask.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God</char> <char style="it">singled out and specially chose Jesus of Nazareth and put|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">an oh-so-powerful-dose</char> of <char style="it">the miracle-working power of the Holy|
                                        |Spirit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Holy Spirit and power</char>. A hendiadys similar to the one|

     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wooden cross-beam</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wood</char> [<char style="it">beam</char>].|
                                        |This is a synecdoche for crucifixion. Ref. 5:30.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">through his authority and what he stands for</char>…Lit<char style="it">: through his|

     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the men who were dedicated to a strict form of Judaism</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |faithful from out of circumcision. </char>This phrase is an expression which wraps a metonymy. Circumcision|

                                        |Moses. Similar wording as Acts 11:2.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">offering—the gift</char>…Ref. note of 8:20.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">water for someone to be baptized in can’t be denied to</char>…A figure of speech; water|

     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by the authority of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the name of</char>|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">From (the Roman Province of)</char> <char style="it">Italia</char>…Lit: [<char style="it">from</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">Italia</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">Italia </char>in the ablative case; hence|
                                        |the insertion of <char style="it">from.</char> Just like Waffen-SS divisions had names given to them,|
                                        |and some American divisions have nicknames, in the same way this battalion was given a name. It’s reasonable|
                                        |to assume that all the soldiers in this battalion were conscripted from the Roman province of Italia.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a devout Gentile who was a sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">pious and fearing God</char> [<char style="it">a God-fearer</char>]. God-fearers were Gentiles|
                                        |who followed Jewish practices but weren’t converts to Judaism.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have percolated upwards to where they’ve garnered God’s attention, and He’s quite pleased|
                                        |by what He sees</char>…Lit: <char style="it">have ascended for a memorial before God</char>. This literal|
                                        |wording is taken from Lev. 2:2; Therefore, OT offerings such as the gift offerings of Lev. 2 are a metaphor|
                                        |for Cornelius’s prayers and alms. The metaphor made a few times in the NT (2 Cor. 2:15; Eph. 5:2; Heb.|
                                        |13:15; etc.) compares Christian duty to the aroma that went up in the smoke in the burning of OT offerings.|
                                        |The way it is presented, God left commandments in the OT for His people to burn offerings, then way up|
                                        |in the sky sniffs the air for the smell of the sacrifices being burned as He commanded, and is pleased|
                                        |when He smells them.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Also, the fact that this angel spoke to Cornelius using an OT metaphor means that Cornelius must’ve known|
                                        |the OT pretty well, or he wouldn’t have understood what the angel was saying.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">back deck</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the rooftop</char>. Some liberties taken. Houses|
                                        |in that time and in that part of the world used their rooftops the same way we use back decks, and they|
                                        |had ladders or stairways which led up to them. A rooftop provided privacy from the confines of the house|
                                        |(ref. Prov. 25:24), and one presumes that Peter sought such privacy for prayer. Peter got a whiff of|
                                        |the smoke from the midday meal, he was hungry already, and it distracted him. God used this distraction|
                                        |as a vehicle to teach him something new.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the thing which God has purged of its non-kosher-ness is permissible for you to eat</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">that which God has cleaned is not profane</char> [<char style="it">for</char>] <char|
                                        |style="it">you</char>. The kosher laws are listed in the Law Moses in chapters such as Lev. 11. Various|
                                        |creatures are specified to be clean or not clean, and if clean, permissible to eat. However, there are|
                                        |other passages in the Law of Moses where a person, for example, will be unclean for a while, but then|
                                        |can purge the uncleanness from himself and thereby become clean again. Verse 14 here alludes to this|
                                        |concept.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The vision came to Peter when he was hungry and the vision was concerning food—at least superficially.|
                                        |In a broader sense, it was redefining what is and isn’t permissible for Peter to do, according to Jewish|
                                        |beliefs, and the lifting of the ban on non-kosher foods is applicable to the lifting of the ban on Gentiles|
                                        |themselves. And—incidentally—this is one of a few NT passages which teaches that Christians are not subject|
                                        |to certain taboos enumerated in the Law of Moses.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all of us are on the edge of our seats waiting</char>…Lit: <char style="it">we all exist|
                                        |before God</char>. This appears to be an idiom; it’s not entirely certain if this rendering is correct.|
                                        |In fact, some manuscripts have been redacted to change the wording here so this verse reads, <char style="it">we’re|
                                        |present here before you.</char>|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">healing all who were being oppressed by the devil</char>…The Gk. word used for <char|
                                        |style="it">healing </char>here <char style="it">iaomai</char> (ἰάομαι/Strong’s 2390<char style="it">)</char>|
                                        |refers specifically to physical healing; Luke selected this word over the all-encompassing Gk. word for|
                                        |healing <char style="it">therapeuō </char>(θεραπεύω /Strong’s 2323), which generally means <char style="it">treated|
                                        |</char>and can and often does encompass more than physical healing; in the NT, <char style="it">therapeuō|
                                        |</char>is generally preferred over <char style="it">iaomai </char>when describing the treating of a person|
                                        |who’s demon-possessed (i.e., casting the demon out). The point being made is that this is another instance|
                                        |in the NT where physical sickness is said to be an oppression of the devil. If this is so, how can sickness|
                                        |be a means which God uses to teach people something?|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">whole-heartedly embraced and acted upon</char>…Lit: <char style="it">received</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they who adhere to Judaism strictly</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they from out of circumcision</char>.|
                                        |The phrase <char style="it">they</char> <char style="it">from out of circumcision </char>is an abbreviated|
                                        |form of <char style="it">the faithful from out of circumcision, </char>which appears in Acts 10:45.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those outside of Judaism</char>…Lit: <char style="it">uncircumcised</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by which you will be rescued you from your spiritual malaise</char>…Lit: <char style="it">by|
                                        |which you will be saved</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who was I to stand in God’s way</char>…Lit: <char style="it">was I somebody who could|
                                        |block God</char>?|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Complete-Changeover which leads to</char>…Lit: <char style="it">repentance to</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Lord was supernaturally and spectacularly working behind the scenes in conjunction|
                                        |with them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Lord’s hand was with them</char>. An expression found throughout|
                                        |the Bible.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |first part of v. 24 moved to v. 23.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">using Barnabas and Saul as couriers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through the hand of|
                                        |Barnabas and Saul</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">men sent as messengers</char>…The participle used here is the root word for apostle.|
                                        |The usage here provides insight into what an apostle is.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you and your entire household</char>…Some have taken this (along with Acts 16:15,31,33;|
                                        |Acts 18:8) to be a promise that God will cause your immediate family to become believers if you simply|
                                        |have faith in that promise. This is a principle, not a promise. The principle is that those who submit|
                                        |to and follow you in natural affairs will do the same with spiritual affairs; if a person submits his|
                                        |will to another, it will carry over into spiritual things also. Cornelius was the head of his household,|
                                        |which included his family, his relatives that were living with him, and his servants, and his household|
                                        |were following his spiritual lead (Acts 10:27) before Peter arrived. The literal wording of Acts 16:33b|
                                        |confirms this; the entire half-verse says, “He himself was baptized and all they of his immediately”;|
                                        |the confirming phrase is “all they of his.”|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">advised, encouraged, and in every way helped</char>…This is the verb from which the|
                                        |well-known Gk. word <char style="it">paraklātos </char><char style="w" strong="G03875">παράκλητος</char>)|
                                        |is derived<char style="it">.</char> Ref. note of Acts 4:36. This passage demonstrates what the “the Son|
                                        |of Encouragement” (Acts 4:36, NASB) is all about. In the role of Son of Encouragement , Barnabas had|
                                        |a knack for knowing who was needed, where and when they were needed, and this urged him to bring Paul|
                                        |to Antioch (v. 26). In the rift between Barnabas and Paul in Acts 16:36–41, Barnabas’s instincts derived|
                                        |from his gift of Encouragement caused him to stand against Paul on John-Mark’s behalf. His instincts|
                                        |were later vindicated as some of Paul’s last words, spoken in 2 Tim. 4:11, attested to Mark’s faithfulness.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Christians</char>…It’s insinuated that the renaming of the disciples as <char style="it">Christians|
                                        |</char>was a result of Barnabas’s and Paul’s teaching, just after Cornelius’s conversion, who was the|
                                        |first Gentile to become a believer. We can deduce that Paul at this time was teaching that a non-Jew|
                                        |could become a believer, and this new teaching was the crux of this new movement called “Christianity.”|
                                        |Therefore, technically-speaking, a Christian is one who circumvented Judaism and became a believer directly,|
                                        |as opposed to a person who’s a part of “the Way,” which is a Jew who becomes a believer in Jesus (ref.|
                                        |Acts 9:2). Consequently, in terms of technicalities, it is not possible for a Jew to become a Christian;|
                                        |a Jew who believes in Jesus the same way that a Christian does becomes a part of the Way, and not a Christian.|
                                        |A Jew can be a genuine believer in Jesus and not renounce his Judaism.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the entire civilized world</char>…Or: <char style="it">the entire inhabited world</char>.|
                                        |Assumption is that Luke was principally speaking of the Roman Empire.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the presiding board, the leaders of the church in Jerusalem</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |elders</char>. In the early days of Christianity, passages such as these indicate that the churches were|
                                        |led similar to the way synagogues were: they were led by a board of elders. To claim that, according|
                                        |to the Bible, the only true and proper model for governing a church is that the church be headed by one|
                                        |and only one person fails to reconcile verses like this.|

     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bodily decomposition</char>…Or: <char style="it">decay</char>. A synecdoche for death,|
                                        |one taken from the OT in the quotation in v. 35. When Paul uses this word in v. 34, he’s thinking ahead|
                                        |about the OT verse which he quotes in v. 35.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">holy things</char>…<char style="it">Holy-One</char>…Plural and singular forms of the|
                                        |same word. Since the word itself is uncommon, Paul appears to be associating the two OT quotations, and|
                                        |that’s why he begins v. 35 with the word <char style="it">therefore. </char>In other words, one of the|
                                        |things referred to by “David’s holy things” in v. 34 is the “Holy-One” (Jesus) in v. 35.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">destine</char>…Lit: <char style="it">grant</char> [or perhaps, <char style="it">allow</char>]|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">expired</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fell asleep</char>. A NT expression.|
     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get the better of you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">come upon you</char>. A well-known|
                                        |biblical expression.|
     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because I’m doing something special in your lifetime</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I|
                                        |am working a work in your days</char>. <char style="it">Working a work</char> is a figure of speech,|
                                        |emphasizing that the work is something special, unusual, and to be anticipated.|
     v                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wiped their hands of it…</char>Lit: <char style="it">shook the dust off their feet.|
                                        |</char>This is an expression; it’s questionable—doubtful—whether Paul and Barnabas actually did this.|
                                        |Ref. Matt. 10:14; Mark 6:11.|
     w                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a Holy-Spirit-fueled-joy</char>…Lit: <char style="it">joy and the Holy Spirit</char>.|
                                        |A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     w                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Joshua-2.0</char>…[<char style="it">2.0</char> is <char style="it">two-point-oh, </char>a|
                                        |remake of the original]…Lit: <char style="it">Bar-Joshua</char> [which some render <char style="it">Bar-Jesus</char>].|
                                        |<char style="it">Bar </char>is the Hebrew prefix for <char style="it">son of. </char>It’s unlikely that|
                                        |he knew anything about Jesus, so <char style="it">Bar-Joshua </char>is the logical choice over <char|
                                        |style="it">Bar-Jesus. </char>By the sounds of his name, he fancied himself as another Joshua, one who|
                                        |assumes the leadership of the people and takes them into the Promised Land.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">This fellow Sergius Paulus</char>…Lit: <char style="it">This fellow</char>. The context|
                                        |suggests that <char style="it">this fellow </char>refers to Sergius Paulus, not Bar-Joshua, as the grammatical|
                                        |inflections more strongly suggests it refers to Bar-Joshua. The conclusion is that Luke should’ve done|
                                        |a better job at resolving this ambiguity and should’ve avoided any insinuation that <char style="it">this|
                                        |fellow </char>refers to Bar-Joshua. Along these same lines, in v. 8 the interpolation “Joshua-2.0’s name,|
                                        |that is”<char style="it"> </char>was added to clarify that Luke means that Bar-Joshau and Elymas are|
                                        |not two different people.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">also “Paul”</char>…From here out, Saul is mostly referred to as <char style="it">Paul</char>.|
                                        |Notice how the spelling of <char style="it">Saul </char>and <char style="it">Paul </char>differ only|
                                        |by a single consonant; <char style="it">Paul </char>is the Gentile-equivalent of the Jewish name Saul.|
                                        |To give an analogy, let’s say there’s a man from Central America with the Spanish name <char style="it">Jaime</char>|
                                        |who’s working in an English-speaking company in the U.S. Among his coworkers, he goes by <char style="it">Jimmy</char>,|
                                        |an English-equivalent of <char style="it">Jaime.</char> But in the Spanish conversation among his family|
                                        |and friends, he’s still <char style="it">Jaime</char>.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">if any among you has an encouraging word</char>…Paul and Barnabas were strangers attending|
                                        |the synagogue for the first time and were asked if they wanted to stand up and speak to the audience,|
                                        |which Paul proceeded to do for a few minutes. This was standard practice back then; nowadays, churches|
                                        |won’t even invite those who itinerate in their denomination (if there’s any still around) to speak at|
                                        |their church for the weekend that the pastor’s on vacation. Pastors these days completely monopolize|
                                        |the pulpit only, occasionally throwing out a bone to their obsequious staff underlings, and only so they|
                                        |don’t get discouraged and quit…and—after all—who’s going to speak when the pastor’s on vacation anyways?|
                                        |Churches claim to faithfully adhere to the practices of the Bible. They do not. In this day and age of|
                                        |the abundant availability of information, over the years they have further restricted what is spoken|
                                        |in their church instead.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you reject it and render yourself unworthy of that special fullness of life</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">you reject it deliver a judgment </char>[<char style="it">on</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |yourselves </char>[<char style="it">as</char>]<char style="it"> those unworthy of eternal life. </char>From|
                                        |v. 48, <char style="it">the very ones who were appointed to eternal life believed. </char>In the debate|
                                        |between free will and predestination, the two sides of the coin are presented in these two verses. Rejecting|
                                        |Christ, an act of their free will, made them unworthy of eternal life. Those who rejected Christ were|
                                        |not appointed to eternal life (v. 48). Free will and predestination are in harmony with one another,|
                                        |not in opposition.|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Greek-speaking Jews</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Greeks</char>. The assumption (which|
                                        |is not certain) is that these are Jews, not Gentiles, as is the case in John 7:35; John 12:20.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">succeed in their life of faith (enter God’s kingdom)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">into-go|
                                        |into[enter] God’s kingdom</char>. This verse is key in the assertion that the NT phrase <char style="it">enter|
                                        |God’s kingdom </char>is an idiom. (Being an idiom, perhaps this explains the double-use of the word <char|
                                        |style="it">into </char>in the phrase.) In the context here of Acts 14:22, Paul is giving advice to those|
                                        |who are already disciples, telling them what they must do to “enter God’s kingdom.” If one takes <char|
                                        |style="it">enter God’s kingdom </char>literally, then this makes no sense, since they are already in|
                                        |God’s kingdom. It only makes sense if <char style="it">enter God’s kingdom </char>is taken as an idiom.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">presiding boards</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>. Paul did not appoint pastors|
                                        |to rule these churches but committees of elders. Though bishops would eventually replace the elders,|
                                        |both forms of church government are legitimate, not one or the other. Ref. note of 11:30.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">presiding board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">no one discriminated against them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">no one discriminated|
                                        |between us and them</char>, or, <char style="it">no one made a distinction between us and them</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs and wonders</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">condo</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tent</char> [<char style="it">tabernacle</char>].|
                                        |Liberties taken. Ref. note of Luke 16:9.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">My mark of ownership</char>…Lit: <char style="it">My name</char>. Similar to, “And I|
                                        |will write my God’s name upon him,” from Rev. 3:12.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and</char> <char style="it">who’s been making this</char> <char style="it">known from|
                                        |eternity</char> <char style="it">past</char>…The principle manuscripts differ for this verse.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">decided what was best to do</char>…Lit: <char style="it">thought</char> [<char style="it">it|
                                        |right</char>]|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Greetings</char>…Lit: <char style="it">To be rejoicing</char>. Standard introductory|
                                        |remark for letters back then.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mind</char>…Lit: <char style="it">soul</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">dedicated their lives to</char>…Lit: <char style="it">given their lives over to on behalf|
                                        |of</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all that our Lord Jesus Christ stands for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the name of our|
                                        |Lord Jesus Christ</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">make you shoulder any more burden</char>…Lit: <char style="it">place much on your neck</char>.|
                                        |The metaphor of placing a yoke, and thereby a load to pull, on an oxen. This metaphor is used here and|
                                        |there throughout the NT, and in fact is used in v. 10.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">short prophetic messages</char>…Lit: <char style="it">words</char>. The usage of <char|
                                        |style="it">words</char> in v. 32 should be applied to understanding what <char style="it">word </char>means|
                                        |in the phrases <char style="it">word of wisdom, word of knowledge, </char>and <char style="it">prophecy|
                                        |</char>found in 1 Cor. 12:8.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">putting the churches on a firm footing</char>…Same Gk. word used in Acts. 14:22 (ref.|
                                        |note there), which is rendered <char style="it">rely on the Lord.</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tell them how things ought to be done, instructing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">teach</char>|
                                        |[Gk: <char style="it">didaskō </char><char style="w" strong="G01321">διδάσκω</char>)]. <char style="it">Didaskō,|
                                        |</char>while normally translated <char style="it">teach, </char>has the additional meaning of instructing|
                                        |a person on how he should conduct his life, as it does in v. 1 here, and also in 1 Tim. 2:12, where Paul|
                                        |says that a woman shouldn’t teach a man (i.e., tell a man how to conduct his life).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">James</char>…Verse 13 quietly introduces James the brother of Jesus, the context insinuating|
                                        |that he’s the head of the church in Jerusalem and also that the Jerusalem church consists solely of practicing|
                                        |Jews who believe in Jesus.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for the first time, God paid a visit—a caring, helping type of visit—in order to form|
                                        |a unique group of people from out of the Gentiles, a people consecrated to everything He represents</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">God visited to receive a people to His name out of Gentiles</char>. The wording that|
                                        |James speaks with here in v. 14 are phrases, expressions, idioms, etc. plucked out of the OT. Since this|
                                        |is a snippet of conversational speech and is impromptu, we deduce that James spoke this way all the time,|
                                        |his speech heavily seasoned with OT phraseology. Since he grew up with Jesus, Jesus spoke the same way|
                                        |also. Or perhaps he picked up the habit from Jesus himself.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bizarre sexual immorality</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fornication</char>. This is a|
                                        |reference to the prohibitions in Lev. 18:6–23, sexual practices that even the world, jaded as it sometimes|
                                        |is, generally disdains. Both the usage of the word <char style="it">fornication </char>here and the usage|
                                        |in 1 Cor. 5:1 refer to extreme practices. In the NT, the Gk. word for <char style="it">prostitute </char>is|
                                        |the female form of <char style="it">fornicator, </char>and keep in mind that a lot, if not most, prostitutes|
                                        |were temple prostitutes and fornication was combined with the pagan cult rituals. A preponderance of|
                                        |evidence indicates that the NT word for fornication implies something more severe than simply shacking|
                                        |up with your fiancée a few months before getting married, which is commonplace in the West nowadays.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">drinking the blood remaining in the body of an animal after it’s been killed by having|
                                        |its neck broken</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the strangled and the blood</char>. A figure of speech,|
                                        |apparently: an expression built out of a hendiadys. This apparently refers to the practice of slaughtering|
                                        |an animal in such a way that no blood is spilled, so none of the blood is spilled and wasted, preserving|
                                        |more blood to be drunk.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">certified letter so there would be no doubt of its authenticity</char>…Lit: <char style="it">having|
                                        |been written from a hand of theirs</char>. This appears to be an idiom. The idiom helps explain Gal.|
                                        |6:11.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">released</char>…One might have expected the word <char style="it">departed </char>to|
                                        |be used instead of <char style="it">released</char>, a word which is used twice, once in v. 30 and again|
                                        |in v. 33. The context together with the choice of this word seems to insinuate that Paul and Barnabas’s|
                                        |bed and board was provided by some other party, whoever was hosting them at the moment. When they were|
                                        |“released,” the hosts were relieved of the responsibility of providing for them. In v. 33, <char style="it">they|
                                        |were released back to the ones who sent them, </char>means that the ones who sent them were to start|
                                        |providing meals for them. Here and there in his epistles, Paul addresses the support which he receives|
                                        |(or doesn’t receive) from his hosts; 1 Cor. 9:11 is one example. The support of ministers of the Gospel|
                                        |has been a thorny issue from the inception of Christianity, and not only that but in the OT as well in|
                                        |regard to Priests and Levites. Suffice to say that congregations, like the example in vv. 30,33 here,|
                                        |should assume the responsibility of providing for the pastor or pastors who lead their congregation and|
                                        |furthermore for the itinerating speakers who speak at their church. Like this passage here in Acts, congregations|
                                        |should take ownership of that responsibility rather than the pastor having to force the issue.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in good standing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with peace</char>. The word <char style="it">peace|
                                        |</char>in this context has an idiomatic meaning. Ref. usage of <char style="it">peace </char>in Matt.|
                                        |10:12,13. The word <char style="it">peace </char>here means not only that they left in good standing|
                                        |but the folks they were visiting weren’t anxious to get rid of them because they were annoying, nettlesome,|
                                        |or a burden, but rather felt sorry when they left.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 34 missing from the better manuscripts|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">presiding board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">from speaking</char>…Lit: to <char style="it">speak</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">over</char>…Lit: <char style="it">down</char>. They were coming down in elevation, coming|
                                        |out of the mountains.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">trying</char>…The word used here implies that each attempt to go into Bithynia was a|
                                        |trial|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">luxurious cloth</char>…Lit: <char style="it">purple cloth</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fearing God</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of Acts 10:2.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wouldn’t take “no” for an answer</char>…Lit: <char style="it">urged</char>; <char style="it">compelled</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bosses</char>…Or: <char style="it">overlords</char>; or perhaps <char style="it">owners</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what you need to do to set things right with God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the way|
                                        |of salvation</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by the authority vested in me by Jesus Christ</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in name of|
                                        |Jesus Christ</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">we</char>…First occurrence of <char style="it">we</char> instead of <char style="it">they</char>,|
                                        |as Luke joins up with Paul at Troas.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the women who had formed a group there</char>…Many believe that this group of women|
                                        |were the seed out of which the church at Philippi was formed, and as a result the Philippian church—the|
                                        |one Paul’s epistle was addressed to—consisted entirely of women. Upon examining Paul’s epistles, the|
                                        |Philippian church stands out as one of the more mature and spiritual congregations written about in the|
                                        |NT.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Exasperated</char>…The Gk. word <char style="it">diaponeuomai </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G01279">διαπονέομαι</char>) used twice in the NT, here and in 4:2, literally means <char style="it">being|
                                        |toiled throughout</char>. Though <char style="it">exasperated </char>is in line with 4:2, and also that|
                                        |the NIV renders it <char style="it">became so annoyed </char>and the NASB <char style="it">greatly annoyed,|
                                        |</char>this context seems to insinuate something different, closer to the KJV’s rendering of <char style="it">diaponeuomai|
                                        |</char>as <char style="it">grieved. </char>It’s as though Paul didn’t know that this woman was possessed|
                                        |by a demon spirit until the Holy Spirit revealed it to him instantly, at a discrete point in time. He|
                                        |became grieved that moment and immediately cast the spirit out of her. Paul wouldn’t have procrastinated|
                                        |for several days in dealing with a spirit.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">flew off the handle</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tore their cloaks</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken. Ref. note of Matt. 26:65. Strange thing is that this is a Jewish practice and one would assume|
                                        |that the magistrates here are Gentiles. Perhaps the magistrates were Jews after all, and this would explain|
                                        |their animosity towards Paul and Silas. Also, in vv. 21,22 the bosses who dragged Paul and Silas before|
                                        |the magistrates harp on the fact that Paul and Silas are Jews encouraging Romans to adopt Jewish practices.|
                                        |This would mean that the bosses are painting Jews (Paul and Silas) as troublemakers in front of other|
                                        |Jews (the magistrates) for their own personal gain (playing the race card, as we say nowadays).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all who were under his authority</char> …Lit: <char style="it">all them of his</char>.|
                                        |Obviously, this refers to those in his household, but the literal, face-value meaning of these words|
                                        |insinuates anyone who’s “his,” or anyone who is under his authority, which would include any other jailers|
                                        |who worked under him too. Ref. note of 11:14.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">brought them upstairs</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he led them up</char>. As this is|
                                        |rendered literally, the jailer must’ve lived in an apartment on a floor above the prison. This agrees|
                                        |with other details in the narrative. In v. 27, the jail keeper was awakened from his sleep by the earthquake,|
                                        |as he was sleeping on the upper floor of the same building which was shaken. Also, the problem of sending|
                                        |a message across town in the middle of the night to awaken his family and have them come to the prison|
                                        |(and many cities had curfews back then too) is solved. Verse 33 says that all of them were baptized <char|
                                        |style="it">immediately. </char>So when the jail keeper took Paul and Silas and served them a meal, he|
                                        |took them upstairs to his apartment, never leaving the jail. Taking Paul and Silas out of the building|
                                        |in the middle of the night likely would’ve cost the jailer his job and probably his life too.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers</char>…Or: <char style="it">certain Epicurean|
                                        |and Stoic philosophers</char>. In the GT for, Luke is explicit in saying that the philosophers here were|
                                        |only Epicurean and Stoic, and no other kinds. As the two schools of philosophy, stoicism and epicureanism,|
                                        |have debated each other since their inception, Luke is insinuating that they’re wanting to see how Paul|
                                        |and his teaching fit into the framework of the stoicism vs. epicureanism debate.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">What point is this dilettante-intellectual here trying to make</char>?…Lit: <char style="it">What|
                                        |would this logic-dabbler keep saying</char>? What Luke wrote here, and what was originally spoken, here|
                                        |and in the surrounding verses shows a marked upturn in the sophistication of the Gk. used—unlike what|
                                        |is found in the Gospels or other places. It demonstrates the intelligence, education, and sophistication|
                                        |of those speaking (as recorded by Luke), speaking in their native language. This is more on the level|
                                        |of something from the classical era.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s offspring</char>…Lit: <char style="it">offspring of </char>[<char style="it">Him</char>].|
                                        |This is a quotation from the Gk. poet Aratus, Paul knows those listening are familiar with the entire|
                                        |poem and therefore its context. We, however, receive a fragment of the poem, and the fragment taken in|
                                        |isolation is ambiguous. But what Paul says next in v. 29 clarifies the ambiguity and states explicitly|
                                        |what he meant by <char style="it">of Him </char>in Aratus’s quotation in v. 28. In v. 29, Paul says <char|
                                        |style="it">has its existence from God</char>, the words <char style="it">from God </char>refer to <char|
                                        |style="it">of </char>[<char style="it">Him</char>]. |

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">You’re to blame for your own destruction</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Your blood</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">be</char>] <char style="it">upon your head</char>. A biblical idiom.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m wiping my hands of it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I clean</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was taken into the home of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">entered into the house of</char>.|
                                        |<char style="it">Entered into </char>in the context of entering someone’s house is a NT expression that|
                                        |means that the homeowner extended an invitation to stay for several days.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t fall into fear</char>…<char style="it">fall silent</char>…Lit<char style="it">:|
                                        |don’t be afraid</char>…<char style="it">don’t be silent</char>. The Gk. grammar suggests that Paul was|
                                        |not already afraid nor was he silent; the encouragement was to stay away from fear and avoid silence,|
                                        |rather than to pull oneself out of one or the other or both.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a dedicated group of people</char>…<char style="it">A</char> [<char style="it">folk</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">people</char>. The word for <char style="it">people </char>here is the same used throughout|
                                        |the NT to describe the people of Israel. It means ordinary people who share a common bond, to the point|
                                        |of comprising a nation. The interpolation <char style="it">dedicated </char>is insinuated by the context.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">filled the role of teacher</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sat</char>. The word <char style="it">sat|
                                        |</char>is similar in meaning to when we when we refer to a professorship as a chair.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">courtroom where Gallio sat as judge</char>…<char style="it">right there in the courtroom</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">judgment seat</char>…<char style="it">before the judgment seat</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Everyone</char>…This is a figure of speech, a type of synecdoche, which does not literally|
                                        |mean everyone. Ref. note of Matt. 3:5.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">schooled</char>…Lit: <char style="it">taught by word-of-mouth</char>. Probably referring|
                                        |to something learned in a lecture-style classroom environment, rather than self-studying books.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">joined in tight unison</char>…The lectionary says this word was used for the confluence|
                                        |of streams or for soldiers locking their shields together during battle|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Priscilla and Aquila</char>…Noteworthy is that Priscilla is named before Aquila, though|
                                        |in v. 2 Aquila is named first. This is a hint that Priscilla was of greater assistance to Paul than Aquila.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Arrived in Ephesus</char>…Rev. 2 gives hints that the Ephesian church was stamped with|
                                        |Apollos’s characteristics, namely his scholasticism. For more info, ref. book <char style="it">A Path|
                                        |through Revelation.</char>|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">John’s baptism was an initiation into a covenant of a change of heart and of ways</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">John baptized a baptism of repentance</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">speaking Holy-Spirit-inspired words</char>…Lit: <char style="it">prophesying</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s interaction with mankind</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the kingdom of God</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">resistant</char>…Lit: <char style="it">hardened</char> [<char style="it">of heart</char>]|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">run-down</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weak</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Jewish exorcists</char>…<char style="it">I exorcise</char>…Same base-word used for <char|
                                        |style="it">exorcists</char> and <char style="it">exorcise</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to invoke the delegate authority of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to name the name of</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">half-naked</char>…Lit: <char style="it">naked</char>. Assuming that “naked” means “half-naked”|
                                        |and not “completely naked,” same as in Matt. 25:36.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what the Lord Jesus is all about</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the name of the Lord Jesus</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Paul determined by the Spirit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Paul put himself by the Spirit</char>.|
                                        |The word <char style="it">put </char>when<char style="it"> </char>used concerning one’s heart is an expression.|
                                        |This expression appears in 5:2 also.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">engage the mob</char>…Lit: <char style="it">enter into the mob</char>. Same expression|
                                        |used in v. 8; see note there.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Gentlemen, fellow Ephesians</char>…Ref. note of Acts 1:9|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Not only did we not receive it, but we’ve not heard of there being a baptism in the|
                                        |Holy Spirit</char>…This sentence doesn’t lend itself to word-for-word translation; the GT reads like|
                                        |conversational Gk., needing interpolations, rather than written Gk. In other words, what we see in the|
                                        |first half of this verse is a the sort of language everyday people spoke in back then—not formal Gk.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they were baptized by the authority of the Lord Jesus</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they|
                                        |were baptized in</char> [<char style="it">by</char>] <char style="it">the name of the Lord Jesus</char>.|
                                        |This is when they received Christ as Lord. An open question is whether they were baptized in water a|
                                        |second time after this, as all Christians are baptized when they believe, or whether John’s baptism sufficed.|
                                        |But in any case, after being “baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus” (after believing in Jesus), they|
                                        |were baptized in the Holy Spirit, thus demonstrating once again that, generally speaking, the baptism|
                                        |in the Holy Spirit happens after one accepts Christ as Savior—not at the same time.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Holy Spirit came upon them</char>…The Holy Spirit coming upon a person is an expression.|
                                        |It does not refer to the indwelling of the Holy Spirit that a person receives as part of believing in|
                                        |the Lord; rather, it means that a person receives the baptism in the Holy Spirit, which is almost always|
                                        |an event distinct from receiving the Lord and one which occurs afterwards.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he introduced himself to the synagogue and became affiliated with the people there</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">he entered into the synagogue</char>. This idiom is used in elsewhere in the NT, specifically|
                                        |in Mark 3:1; Luke 4:16; Luke 6:6, 13:14; 14:1; 17:1,2,10; 18:19; 19:30; 28:8; James 2:2. It has a few|
                                        |different meanings (or multiple meanings at the same time). What should be kept in mind is that a synagogue|
                                        |is first and foremost an assembly of people, in the same way that a church is an assembly of people,|
                                        |and secondly a building or some other premise. Therefore, this expression means: He introduced himself|
                                        |to those in the synagogue and attended one of their meetings; He became a member of the synagogue; He|
                                        |became affiliated with the synagogue; He visited the synagogue. It may be that this expression denotes|
                                        |a formal custom of introduction where a new member is greeted by those in the synagogue. As part of this,|
                                        |the new member’s credentials are submitted, and if he’s learned enough in the Scriptures, he’ll be given|
                                        |the opportunity to stand before the synagogue and teach—or at least to talk in smaller, more informal|
                                        |groups. This idiom is also used in phrases like “enter into the kingdom of heaven,” “enter into eternal|
                                        |life,” etc., as in Matt. 7:21; 19:17,23; 25:21, 26:41; Luke 11:52; 22:40,46.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and the diseases left them, and the Evil Spirits went out</char> <char style="it">of|
                                        |them</char>…Yet another example of disease and evil spirits lumped into the same category. If God causes|
                                        |disease, does He cause evil spirits to afflict people as well?|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">$6.25 million</char>…Lit: <char style="it">50,000 silver</char> [<char style="it">coins</char>].|
                                        |Assume that the coin is a drachma. Ref. conversion notes in Matt. 18:28 and elsewhere.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">two of his helping-assistants</char>…Lit: <char style="it">two of those serving him</char>.|
                                        |The word for <char style="it">those</char> <char style="it">serving </char>here is translated <char style="it">deacon|
                                        |</char>elsewhere<char style="it">. </char>These were Paul’s servants, doing his bidding. Timothy started|
                                        |out at a young age helping Paul, and as he proved trustworthy, Paul assigned him more and more challenging|
                                        |tasks, as Timothy continued to prove his faithfulness and dedication, to the point where a couple of|
                                        |letters Paul sent him are enshrined in the NT. All of this is included in the post of NT deacon.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Ephesians’ Artemis is awesome!</char>…Since the same exact wording appears in v.34|
                                        |and since these words are blurted repeatedly, this was likely a popular, well-known, often-repeated chant.|
                                        |Whenever the crowd got whipped into a frenzy, they would repeat this chant. This is like something that|
                                        |goes on nowadays at a sporting event, protest, or political rally.|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pronounced dead on the spot</char>…Lit: <char style="it">taken away dead</char>. When|
                                        |they got to his body, they immediately pronounced him dead and instead of trying to treat him proceeded|
                                        |to take away his dead body.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vigorously attended to him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fell to him</char>. The word|
                                        |<char style="it">fell </char>is similar to usage in the common NT expression <char style="it">fall upon</char>,|
                                        |which means to assault. <char style="it">Fell to him </char>here has the same meaning as when paramedics|
                                        |attend to a person in an emergency. They are acting quickly, decisively, and aggressively, appropriate|
                                        |for the life-threatening situation.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he’s alive</char>…Lit: <char style="it">his soul is in him</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prayed over the meal</char>…Lit: <char style="it">broke the bread</char>|

                                        |good amount</char>. An expression.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">change of heart and of ways</char>…Lit: <char style="it">repentance</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">compelled</char>…Lit: <char style="it">bound</char>|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">flock of Christians</char>…Lit: <char style="it">flock of sheep</char>. The metaphor|
                                        |of shepherd as leaders and sheep as followers is extensive throughout the Bible, particularly in the|
                                        |NT.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">monstrous</char>…Lit: <char style="it">heavy</char>; metaphorically means <char style="it">ruthless,|

     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">will join up with you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">will go into you</char>. Similar|

     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s end-goal plan for your lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the inheritance</char>|
