     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wrapped their arms forcefully around Paul’s neck</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they fell|
                                        |upon Paul’s neck</char>. Same expression used in Luke 15:20. <char style="it">Falling upon </char>in|
                                        |other contexts means <char style="it">assaulting; </char>in this context it is used metaphorically to|
                                        |insinuate a physical—to the point of being forceful even—kind of embrace.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kept on explaining to them in depth the logic behind what he taught, pointing out to|
                                        |them the logical fallacies of the opposing points of view, and in general covering a given subject with|
                                        |them from top to bottom</char>…Or: <char style="it">reasoned to them</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">reasoned|
                                        |</char>here is the same word used in 17:2,17; 18:4,19; 19:8,9; 20:9, and in those verses means the same|
                                        |thing. Paul’s epistle to the Galatians show him “reasoning” in this way, and this is what Luke says he|
                                        |was doing here in 20:7. Nowadays, this would fall under the category of “teaching,” but the Gk. words|
                                        |for reasoning and teaching don’t correspond exactly to the English words reasoning and teaching. The|
                                        |Gk. word for teaching implies dictating moral instruction (ref. 15:1), whereas the word for reasoning|
                                        |is explaining the logic behind something, the topic at times being difficult to understand.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">church governing board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the elders of the church</char>.|
                                        |The church at Ephesus, a Gentile church, was run by elders. Later in Acts, we see churches run by bishops.|
                                        |Both forms of church government were in use in the NT; therefore, both forms are sanctioned.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">overseers</char>…<char style="it">leading</char>…Lit: <char style="it">bishops</char>…<char|
                                        |style="it">shepherding</char> [or <char style="it">pastoring</char>]. This is the first occurrence of|
                                        |the word <char style="it">bishop </char>[<char style="it">overseer</char>] in the NT. In modern times,|
                                        |we often use the word <char style="it">pastor </char>when we technically-speaking mean <char style="it">bishop.</char>|
                                        |Note that these bishops are the elders referred to in v. 17. Also, the word rendered <char style="it">leader|
                                        |</char>here is actually <char style="it">shepherd </char>or <char style="it">pastor. </char>Throughout|
                                        |the Bible, the word <char style="it">shepherd</char> means <char style="it">leader. </char>In the NT,|
                                        |the word means <char style="it">pastor, </char>and it is where we get the word in its modern usage.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">causing some of the disciples to commit apostasy by becoming their followers</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">drawing away the disciples after them</char>. The word <char style="it">drawing away|
                                        |</char>is the same base-word that is rendered <char style="it">apostasy</char> in 2 Thess. 2:3. The words|
                                        |<char style="it">after them </char>are used throughout the NT to mean one person following another, or|
                                        |submitting to the will of another (same usage in Matt. 4:19; ref. note there).|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to their kinfolk and fellow citizens</char>…Lit<char style="it">: to their own</char>.|
                                        |Assuming <char style="it">their own </char>refers to people; it could refer to affairs, things, etc.—or|
                                        |all of these.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">were invited to stay at</char>…Lit: <char style="it">entered into</char>. An idiom.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">unmarried</char>…Lit: <char style="it">virgin</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">came over from Jerusalem</char>…Lit: <char style="it">came down</char>. The phrase <char|
                                        |style="it">came down </char>implies that he came from Jerusalem, as the GT of the NT is consistent in|
                                        |saying that a person “goes up” to Jerusalem or “comes down” from Jerusalem.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all that the Lord Jesus stands for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the name of the Lord|
                                        |Jesus</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">church governing board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">live a lifestyle of keeping</char> …Lit: <char style="it">walk</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what’s the story here?</char>…Lit: <char style="it">what is?</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">this is what you should do</char>…Lit: <char style="it">do this that we tell you</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who have taken the Old Testament pledge called the Nazirite vow and they’re partway|
                                        |through it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">having a vow</char>. Same wording as 18:18.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is baloney</char>…Lit: <char style="it">is nothing</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was dispatched to</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a report went up</char>. Here and in|
                                        |the next few verses, the words <char style="it">up </char>and <char style="it">down </char>are used in|
                                        |reference to the colonel and the soldiers, as though they were stationed in a tower or something of the|
                                        |sort.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Roman garrison</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cohort</char>. Around 500 soldiers.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">junior officers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">centurions</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prophesied on a regular basis</char>…Lit: <char style="it">prophesying</char>. The Gk.|
                                        |text does explicitly say that they were prophetesses but that they prophesied. Since prophecy by its|
                                        |most basic definition is speaking Holy Spirit-inspired utterance, and not necessarily foretelling the|
                                        |future (word of wisdom) or having supernatural revelation of something going on that you would not otherwise|
                                        |know (word of knowledge), it is likely that they didn’t speak words of wisdom or words of knowledge,|
                                        |and were therefore not technically prophetesses.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">nor to live a lifestyle of keeping the ancient, man-made traditions that go hand-in-hand|
                                        |with following the Law of Moses</char>…Lit: <char style="it">nor walk in the traditions</char>. The traditions|
                                        |were man-interpreted rules derived from the Law of Moses, with the intention of complying with the letter|
                                        |of the Law.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Continues without break into the next chapter|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Is it legal for you all to whip a Roman citizen who hasn’t been convicted in a court|
                                        |of law?</char>…An indication that the Roman Empire of Paul’s time hadn’t yet descended into decadence|
                                        |and immorality, in spite of the feuding and turnover of emperors. It’s doubtful that, had this situation|
                                        |occurred in the Roman Empire of the fourth century or later, the soldiers would have had any qualms about|
                                        |whipping Paul. This statement by Paul, similar circumstances as 16:37, refutes certain preconceived ideas|
                                        |connected with “turning the other cheek” (Matt. 5:39). Namely, when Jesus said to turn the other cheek,|
                                        |he didn’t mean that a person should not press for what’s rightfully his when being walked over.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the council</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Sanhedrin</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to God</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hit you back</char>…Lit: <char style="it">be striking you</char>. The Gk. verb tense|
                                        |used in the word <char style="it">hit </char>insinuates an open-ended retaliation rather than a tit-for-tat|
                                        |retaliation.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bogus judge</char>…Lit: <char style="it">whitewashed wall</char>. Liberties taken. A|
                                        |commonly-used idiom used in Israel at that time. Ref. Matt. 23:27, Luke 11:44.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">very product</char>…Lit: <char style="it">son</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for the hope that life after death offers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">about hope and|
                                        |resurrection of dead people</char>. <char style="it">Hope and resurrection </char>is a hendiadys (ref.|
                                        |note of Matt. 3:11). <char style="it">Resurrection of the dead</char> is an idiom meaning <char style="it">life|
                                        |after death</char>.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">designated teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Scribes</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">That night</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the night</char>. As the Jewish day starts|
                                        |at sundown, for them it would be the next day.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">swearing that we would be cursed if we break it</char>…In Gk. reads <char style="it">anathemati|
                                        |anethematisamev </char>(Ἀναθέματι ἀνεθεματίσαμεν), <char style="w" strong="G00332">Ἀναθέματι</char>),|
                                        |<char style="w" strong="G00331">ἀνεθεματίσαμεν</char>), which shares the same root as the word <char|
                                        |style="it">anathema; </char>and the words are repeated as a figure of speech.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirits</char>…Or perhaps: <char style="it">the Holy Spirit</char>. The GT is somewhat|
                                        |ambiguous. The word <char style="it">spirit </char>here is singular in the GT, just as the word <char|
                                        |style="it">angels </char>is actually singular (<char style="it">angel</char>). Since angels is singular|
                                        |but the intent is plural, logic suggests that the intent for <char style="it">spirit </char>is plural|
                                        |as well. This also is consistent with the usage in v. 9.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to enjoy a morsel of food</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to taste</char>. This is an expression,|
                                        |as the text simply says <char style="it">taste </char>with no predicate supplied. The word <char style="it">taste|
                                        |</char>is used as a metonymy; the entire thing is a figure of speech. This helps explains what Jesus|
                                        |said in Matt. 26:29; Mark 14:25; Luke 20:10 about drinking of the fruit of the vine: he meant enjoying|
                                        |the fruit of the vine.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">two hundred soldiers in order that they hike all the way to Caesarea, plus seventy cavalrymen|
                                        |and two hundred javelin-throwers</char>…Scholars are uncertain what <char style="it">javelin-throwers</char>|
                                        |(Lit: <char style="it">those-who-grasp-with-the-right-hand</char>) refers to. Perhaps they were Roman|
                                        |velites, younger, less experienced men who served as the light infantrymen who threw javelins. By the|
                                        |size of the contingency, the colonel feared a confrontation which would escalate into a large skirmish,|
                                        |which might even trigger a revolt. Both the cavalry and the velites are fast-moving troops. Apparently,|
                                        |the strategy was to have some troops outrun any opposition, getting him on horseback to Caesarea quickly|
                                        |if the need arose.|

     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">It’s hard to swim against the tide</char>…Lit: <char style="it">It’s hard to kick at</char>|
                                        |[or <char style="it">against</char>] <char style="it">a cattle prod</char>. Liberties taken. This is|
                                        |spuriously (but not erroneously) inserted in 9:5 in the Textus Receptus. The metaphor is of a steer or|
                                        |some other cattle being jabbed with a cattle prod: the more forceful the prod, the more it hurts the|
                                        |steer. When the steer kicks the prod, he hurts himself even more but doesn’t accomplish anything.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">close to God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon God</char>. The appearance of the word|
                                        |<char style="it">upon </char>(<char style="it">epi, </char>ἐπί/Strong’s 1909)<char style="it"> </char>seems|
                                        |a bit idiomatic. The usage of <char style="it">upon</char> is the same as 25:9,26 where Festus asks Paul|
                                        |if he’d like to have the trial held “before me” (lit: <char style="it">upon me</char>), and<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>where the word <char style="it">before </char>(<char style="it">epi</char>)<char style="it"> </char>is|
                                        |used twice in v. 26: “I brought him <char style="it">before</char> us and especially <char style="it">before</char>|
                                        |you<char style="it">.</char>” Other usages, however, like Luke 1:17, “to turn the hearts of the fathers|
                                        |to [epi] the children,” suggest exact proximity, as the base definition of <char style="it">epi </char>suggests.|
                                        |Therefore, <char style="it">close to</char> is the chosen rendering.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the people whom God separated to Himself</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God’s saints</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">separated-ones</char>]. Though this is somewhat ambiguous, the assumption is that by|
                                        |the context, the people separated to God refers to the Israelites.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in a little way</char>…Or: <char style="it">in little time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">a</char>] <char style="it">little</char>, or, <char style="it">with little</char>.|
                                        |Many scholars take this as a figure of speech or reject it in lieu of a different interpretation, one|
                                        |which isn’t obvious. Some render it <char style="it">almost, </char>while others render it <char style="it">hardly</char>.|
                                        |I see no reason not to render the remark literally, however.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Italy</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Italia</char>. The Roman province of Italia, as there|
                                        |was no “Italy” at that time.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Battalion</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cohort</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Turkish</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Asian</char>. The Roman province of Asia.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">abandoned</char>…Same word as used in v. 40 to describe the cutting loose of the anchors|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Oh you guys</char>…Lit: <char style="it">oh men</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t be afraid</char>…The Gk. verb tense insinuates that Paul was not afraid at the|
                                        |time the angel spoke to him, but is being encouraged not to fall into it.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get ahold of this</char>…Lit: <char style="it">behold</char>; <char style="it">lo and|
                                        |behold</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">looking at</char> <char style="it">what will happen</char>…Lit: <char style="it">look|
                                        |at</char>; <char style="it">behold</char>. The common Gk. word <char style="it">theōreō </char>(θεωρέω|
                                        |/Strong’s 2334) is used here but in an uncommon way.<char style="it"> </char>Since the voyage had not|
                                        |yet taken place and since Paul had seen something, one may deduce that Paul had some sort of premonition|
                                        |in which he saw what was going to take place.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">angel of God</char>…Generally speaking, the GT of the NT refers to an angel as an “angel|
                                        |of the Lord,” “angel of God,” etc., instead of simply “angel.” This is done to clarify the ambiguity|
                                        |between an angel and a messenger, as the word means either. But in English, we simply say “angel” instead|
                                        |of the word-for-word rendering “angel of the Lord.” But in v. 23, Paul takes opportunity of the word|
                                        |<char style="it">God </char>to add appositives to which describe his relationship with Him.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not a single one of the hairs on your head will be lost</char>…Seeing that there were|
                                        |over two hundred who had to endure the storm and swim to shore, the likelihood that none of them lost|
                                        |a single strand of hair is slim. Therefore, Paul’s remark here is an expression, a figure of speech,|
                                        |and not to be taken literally. From the sounds of it, this is the same expression as is found in Matt.|
                                        |10:30; Luke 12:7; what Jesus said there can also be understood as an expression and is not to be taken|
                                        |literally.|

     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fellow-comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they cordially invited us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">we were encouraged from them</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">strengthened his nerve and stiffened his composure</char>…Lit: <char style="it">took|
                                        |courage</char>. The word <char style="it">courage</char> here is derived from the same verb Jesus used|
                                        |when he encountered the disciples while walking on water (Mark 6:50) and has the same meaning.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">solemnly stating the truthfulness of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">witnessing</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Old Testament</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Law of Moses and the prophets</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">agreeable to his propositions and conceding his points</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being|
                                        |persuaded</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">were politely told it was time to leave</char>…Lit: <char style="it">were freed</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">redirect their lives in the right way</char>…Lit: <char style="it">turn towards</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rescue program</char>…Lit: <char style="it">salvation</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">welcomed as guests</char>…Lit: <char style="it">received</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">coming to interact with him in a friendly visit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">coming|
                                        |into to him</char>. This is an idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">They gave us many donatives as an allowance</char>…Lit: <char style="it">They honored|
                                        |us with many honors</char>. In this context, the Gk. words <char style="it">to honor </char>and <char|
                                        |style="it">honors </char>draws on a secondary definition which the lexicon says is “a reward, present”|
                                        |(the multi-faceted meaning propagated to the English <char style="it">honor</char> vs. <char style="it">honorarium</char>).|
                                        |This is in the form of a monetary obligation, pay, or entitlement. That the usage here of <char style="it">honor|
                                        |</char>refers to contributing financially is supported by these three facts: First, the words <char style="it">many|
                                        |honors </char>insinuate something which is quantitative (cash or items) rather than qualitative (honor|
                                        |or respect). Second, the latter half of v. 10 (“put necessities on the ship”) also concerns itself with|
                                        |giving material goods. Third, the word <char style="it">honor </char>is also used this way in 1 Tim.|
                                        |5:17.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sailed the circuit</char>…Some disagreement in the wording of various Gk. manuscripts|
                                        |here, and some conjecture from bible scholars as to what exactly Luke means. I’m guessing that this refers|
                                        |to ships that shuttled from town to town on short hops which were on a fixed and repeated schedule, competing|
                                        |with one another one prices, etc., sort of like how airlines offer flights and compete with one another.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 29 omitted from the better manuscripts|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, servant of Christ Jesus, called as a missionary, designated to God’s good news—the Gospel, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |what He promised before over and over through His prophets in the Old Testament |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |about His son, who—physically speaking—came into being through the lineage of David, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who was declared in a powerful way to be God’s son according to the Holy Spirit due to the resurrection|
     v 4                                |from the dead, namely Jesus Christ our Lord, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |through whom we’ve received grace and have received a missionary assignment that has the end-goal of|
     v 5                                |obedience—a consequence of faith—among all the Gentiles and the far-off nations on behalf of all he stands|
     v 5                                |for, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |by which you too are called by Jesus Christ:|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To God’s beloved who are holy and called of God who are in Rome: Grace be to you—and peace—from the Father-God|
     v 7                                |and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |First and foremost, concerning you I thank my God through Jesus Christ, that the word is being spread|
     v 8                                |about your faith throughout the entire world. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, God is my witness, whom I offer a service of worship to in my spirit in the evangelization of|
     v 9                                |his son, as I’m constantly making mention of you |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |every time I offer up prayers, asking if somehow, sometime, I will have succeeded by the will of God|
     v10                                |in visiting you. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that I long to see you so that I might bestow on you a spiritual gift, a gift|
     v11                                |whose goal is to establish you. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This bestowing of a spiritual gift is done to take comfort together with you through the faith shared|
     v12                                |between you and me.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I don’t want you to be left in the dark, comrades, that I purposed many times to come to you, but I was|
     v13                                |prevented from doing so up until now, so that I would have the opportunity in the meantime to observe|
     v13                                |the germination and growth of tangible signs of maturity among you as well just I observed it in the|
     v13                                |other Gentiles— |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m in debt not just to the civilized but to the uncivilized also, to not just the wise but to the foolish|
     v14                                |also. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is what motivates me to evangelize to you too who are in Rome.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is, I’m not ashamed of the Gospel, for it’s God’s power in all those who believe|
     v16                                |for them to end up with salvation (i.e., the state of being kept from from spiritual, moral, mental,|
     v16                                |and physical calamity)—and not just the Jews but the non-Jewish Westerners as well. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For in the Gospel God’s righteousness (i.e., God’s requirements of how a person must lead his life in|
     v17                                |order to please Him and be approved by Him) is revealed out of faith and back into faith, just as it’s|
     v17                                |been written in the Old Testament, “The one who’s righteous (i.e., the one whose life is to be approved|
     v17                                |by God) shall live out of faith.”|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, God’s wrath is unfurled from up in the sky, up in heaven, upon ungodliness and unrighteousness|
     v18                                |inherent in people who withhold the truth in and by their unrighteousness, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and it is unfurled because the knowledge of God has appeared and been made known to them. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, from the inception of human society, His invisible aspects (that is, His everlasting power|
     v20                                |and divine nature) have been clearly seen and understood by means of the things which were created, resulting|
     v20                                |in all humans being without excuse. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore, while knowing and understanding God, they didn’t glorify or thank Him as God, but became empty-headed|
     v21                                |in their reasonings instead, and their non-understanding heart darkened. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Asserting to be wise, they became idiots |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and exchanged the glory of the Immortal God for the facsimile of a Mortal Human and of animals.|
 +   V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So for the aforementioned reasons, as they were wallowing in the desires of their hearts, God handed|
     v24                                |them over to dirty and disgusting unholy things in dishonoring and disgracing their bodies among themselves,|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the very people who, as they were wallowing in the aforementioned lie, swapped the truth of God and worshipped|
     v25                                |and held religious services for the creature, circumventing the Creator, the One who is forever blessed|
     v25                                |(and let us pause a moment for that to sink in).|
 +   V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On account of this, God handed them over to an unnatural, disgraceful, excruciating passion of lust.|
     v26                                |In this regard, both the women swapped the Natural Function for that which circumvents what comes naturally;|
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the men too—and in the same manner—leaving the Natural Function of the woman, burning in their longing|
     v27                                |for one another, men perpetrating the disgraceful deed with men and receiving the corresponding reward|
     v27                                |which they have coming to them and which they were bound to receive due to their error, an error which|
     v27                                |they adhered to among themselves.|
 +   V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And just as they did not approve of retaining the accumulated knowledge and understanding of God, God|
     v28                                |handed them over to an unapproved mind, to do what is not fitting to do, |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having been filled to the brim with every kind of unrighteousness: with wickedness, greed, malice, they|
     v29                                |are full of envy, murder, strife, Machiavellian-styled rivalry, malevolence; they’re gossips and slanderers,|
     V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |trash-talkers, God-haters; they’re insolent people, they’re arrogant, they’re braggarts, they dream up|
     v30                                |evil, they rebel against their parents, |
     V31              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they’re dull-witted, treacherous, without the natural affection one has for parents, children, nation,|
     v31                                |etc.; they’re unmerciful— |
     V32              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The very people who know and understand God’s righteous precepts exactly, that those who practice such|
     v32                                |things deserve to die—not only do they do these things, but they’re in lockstep-agreement and think highly|
     v32                                |of those who practice them.|

     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">women</char>…<char style="it">men</char>…In the GT, Paul uses the archaic versions of|
                                        |these words, the versions found in the LXX quotation of Gen. 5:2, “He made them man and woman, husband|
                                        |and wife.” These are the same words used in the embedded Gen. 5:2 quotations in Matt. 19:4 an Mark 6:6.|
                                        |By selecting the same words as found in Gen. 5:2, instead of choosing the more commonly used Gk. words|
                                        |for <char style="it">men</char> and <char style="it">women</char>, Paul is signaling that the statements|
                                        |he makes in vv. 26,27 are based on Gen. 5:2.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |…Which leads to this: who do you think you are, you who pronounces judgment over others (i.e., draws|
     v 1                                |conclusions about others for the purpose of writing them off)?—There’s no excuse for this. The fact is,|
     v 1                                |in the area in which you judge another, you condemn yourself, for the one who’s doing the judging practices|
     v 1                                |the same thing. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we know for a fact that God renders a guilty verdict in line with the truth against those who practice|
     v 2                                |such things. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You rascal, you who commits such sins and practices such things—do you figure that you’ll evade God’s|
     v 3                                |judgment? |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or while despising the riches of His goodness, forbearance and patience, you’re unaware that the goodness|
     v 4                                |of God leads one to repentance (i.e., to change one’s heart and one’s ways)? |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But in accordance with your hard—downright unrepentant—heart, you’re accumulating your own individualized-wrath|
     v 5                                |to be regurgitated on that date when wrath is unveiled and readily distributed, the day of God’s righteous|
     v 5                                |judgment, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who “will repay every person according to what that person’s done.” |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On the one hand to those who, in accordance with a consistent pattern of good works, seek after glory,|
     v 7                                |honor, and immortality, the repayment will be eternal life. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But on the other hand, to those who, out of an attempt to promote themselves by buying influence with|
     v 8                                |God and out of not being persuaded and being disobedience to the Truth but are convinced that doing unrighteousness|
     v 8                                |is alright, the repayment will be wrath and an outburst of rage— |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Distress and anguish for every last person who leads a life of evil, Jews at a higher level and non-Jewish|
     v 9                                |Westerners at a level below them. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But glory, honor, and peace to all who lead a life of good, Jews at a higher level and Westerners at|
     v10                                |a level below them. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that God shows no favoritism.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, anyone at all who sinned without the benefit of possessing a law (i.e., a list of God’s rules)|
     v12                                |will perish; and anyone at all who sins while immersed in a law will be judged by that law. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To be clear, it’s not the ones who have heard a law and can spout off what it says who are right with|
     v13                                |God, but the ones who put a law into practice will be pronounced righteous by God.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, when the Gentiles who don’t have a law (i.e., a list of God’s rules) instinctively do|
     v14                                |the things of the Law (i.e., the definitive, comprehensive list of God’s rules, which is the Law of Moses),|
     v14                                |they, though not possessing the Law, are a law (i.e., a set of God-given rules) for themselves. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |These particular people point out what the law written in their hearts (i.e., their particular list of|
     v15                                |God’s rules written in their hearts) has accomplished—and while pointing this out their consciences join|
     v15                                |in and testify even to the extent of arbitrating between the various differing rationales condemning|
     v15                                |or defending— |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |on whatever day it happens to be when God judges the hidden things of mankind through Christ Jesus according|
     v16                                |to my positive message—my Gospel.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if you call yourself a Jew and are fixated on law (i.e., mankind possessing and putting into practice|
     v17                                |the definitive list of God’s rules), boast over (i.e., take pride in; swagger over; loudly extol the|
     v17                                |virtues of; defend vociferously) the things of God, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |know the will of God, and accept or reject the differing oral traditions of interpretation which are|
     v18                                |derived from the Law of Moses— |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and all these to the extent that you’ve convinced yourself that you’ve reached the point where you’re|
     v19                                |a guide to the blind, a light in darkness, |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |a trainer to the foolish, a teacher to the young, possessing in the Law of Moses the embodiment of the|
     v20                                |knowledge and the truth of God— |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so now, does the one who’s teaching someone else teach himself anything? Does the one who preaches to|
     v21                                |others not to steal steal himself? |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Does the one who says “don’t commit adultery” commit adultery? Is the one who abhors idols a temple robber?|
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Does the one who boasts in law (i.e., takes pride in—to the point of bragging about—his ability to follow|
     v23                                |the list of God’s rules) dishonor God by the transgression of the Law of Moses? |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, “God’s reputation is slandered among the Gentiles because of you,” like it says in the Bible.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that—yes—circumcision (i.e., committing one’s life to following the Law of|
     v25                                |Moses) is beneficial if one were to put the edicts of the Law of Moses into practice, but if one were|
     v25                                |to transgress the Law, his circumcision will have become uncircumcision (i.e., as though he never committed|
     v25                                |himself to follow the Law of Moses). |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So if the archetypical circumcised man were to keep the edicts of the Law of Moses, wouldn’t his uncircumcision|
     v26                                |count as circumcision? |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the physically-uncircumcised man who satisfies the requirements of the Law of Moses will judge you,|
     v27                                |the quintessential transgressor of law (i.e., one who doesn’t fulfill the requirements of the list of|
     v27                                |edicts given by God), a transgressor in the midst of having a verbatim copy of God’s edicts and by having|
     v27                                |signed up to comply with those edicts.|
 +   V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, a person is not Jewish because he appears Jewish on the outside, nor is circumcision a physical|
     v28                                |characteristic, |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but rather one is Jewish by virtue of what’s on the inside, and circumcision is of the heart done by|
     v29                                |the Spirit not by the letter (i.e., by the rigid interpretation and application of God’s edicts); that|
     v29                                |person’s praise is not from people but from God.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who do you think you are, you who</char>…Lit: <char style="it">oh man all who</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pronounces judgment over others (i.e., draws conclusions about others for the purpose|
                                        |of writing them off)</char>…Also: <char style="it">decides</char>…Lit: <char style="it">judges</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of Matt. 7:1.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you rascal</char>…Lit: <char style="it">oh man</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for every last person</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon all soul </char>[<char style="it">person</char>]<char|
                                        |style="it"> of man</char>. The word <char style="it">soul </char>means <char style="it">person </char>in|
                                        |this context.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anyone at all</char>…In the GT this is actually plural, not singular|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for</char>…Or: <char style="it">in</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s reputation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the name of God</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">like it says in the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">according what’s been written</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the midst of having a verbatim copy of God’s edicts and by having signed up to comply|
                                        |with those edicts</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through letter and circumcision</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the one who’s doing the judging practices the same thing</char>…Paul’s referring to|
                                        |a curious psychological condition I’ll call “The Jimmy Swaggert Phenomenon.” The TV evangelist in his|
                                        |heyday in the ‘80’s was calling out other ministers for their sexual sins while at the same time visiting|
                                        |prostitutes. What Paul is saying here is that, generally speaking, people tend to judge others in the|
                                        |same areas they are guilty of themselves.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Jews at a higher level and non-Jewish Westerners</char> <char style="it">at a level|
                                        |below them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Jew first and Greek</char>. Since Jews were God’s chosen people|
                                        |and since they were given the word of God, Paul’s saying that judgment will be harsher on them. But on|
                                        |the flip side, v. 10 says that Jews will receive a higher level of glory, honor, and peace for the same|
                                        |reason.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">oral traditions of interpretation which are derived from the Law of Moses</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">taught-by-word-of-mouth out of the Law</char>. This might be a reference to the Oral|
                                        |Torah, which evolved into the Mishnah.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s so much better about being Jewish? Put another way, what’s the advantage of being circumcised|
     v 1                                |(i.e., being in a covenant to obey the Law of Moses)? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Much and in many ways. First—certainly first—is that they were entrusted with the safekeeping and preservation|
     v 2                                |of God’s words. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, what if some of them refused to have faith and believe? Does their refusal to believe cancel|
     v 3                                |God’s faithfulness?— |
   N V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t even think about it; think this instead: God is true, but every person is a liar, just like it’s|
     v 4                                |written,|
 +PN V 4            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V 4                  VERSES_PROSE: |…So You’d be absolutely right in Your words|
 +P  V 4                  VERSES_PROSE: |And come out on top in Your judgments|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So having been justified (i.e., examined by God the judge and declared to be righteous) as a result of|

     v 4                                |approval hope, |

     v 5                                |the Holy Spirit who was given to us.|

     v 7                                |will muster the courage to die on behalf of a good person. |

     v 8                                |still sinners. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now that we’ve been justified by his blood, we’ll all the more be spared from the wrath which is due|
     v 9                                |us through him. |

     v10                                |been reconciled, we’ll all the more be spared, preserved, and kept intact by his life. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not only that but we’ll also boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in God through our Lord Jesus Christ,|
     v11                                |through whom we at this time have received the previously stated reconciliation.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Throughout this all, just as sin entered the world through one man and death (i.e., stagnation of waste,|
     v12                                |joylessness, futility, and destruction) through the sin which entered, and in this way death propagated|
     v12                                |to all men, seeing that everybody has sinned— |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the fact is, up until law (i.e., an enumeration of God’s commandments) was given, sin was in the world|
     v13                                |(i.e., the established order of human beings), but sin is not transacted and counted against a person|
     v13                                |when law doesn’t exist. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That aside, death reigned from Adam until Moses and it also reigned over those who didn’t sin by committing|
     v14                                |the same transgression that Adam committed, who is a prototype of and symbolic of all human beings who|
     v14                                |come after him.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But put that aside. The gift of grace doesn’t operate the same way as the initial transgression: for|
     v15                                |if the many died (i.e., were transformed into a state of spiritual death, resulting in their lives becoming|
     v15                                |a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction—culminating in physical death itself) by|
     v15                                |the single transgression, all the more did the grace of God and the unrequited-gift overflow to the many|
     v15                                |by grace, by the one man Jesus Christ. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the unrequited-gift doesn’t operate the same way as the affair with the lone person who sinned: on|
     v16                                |the one hand the judicial review which came out of an incident involving a single person resulted in|
     v16                                |condemnation, but on the other hand the grace which came out of many transgressions resulted in an act|
     v16                                |of righteousness.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Put another way, if by the transgression of the singular person death reigned through the singular person,|
     v17                                |all the more will they who receive the abundance of the grace of God and the gift of righteousness reign|
     v17                                |in life through the singular person Jesus Christ. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, just as condemnation came to every person as the result of one transgression, in the same way|
     v18                                |one act of righteousness resulted in making available to every person the ability of to have the slate|
     v18                                |of his entire life wiped clean. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For just as through the disobedience of the singular person the many were declared by imposition to be|
     v19                                |sinners, in the same way too through the obedience of the singular person the many are declared by imposition|
     v19                                |to be righteous. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But law (i.e., the expectation of living up to the standards imposed by a list of right and wrong) slipped|
     v20                                |in, sneaking in unplanned as though crashing a party, in order that the transgression seeded by Adam|
     v20                                |and propagated to the entire human race would multiply; but if the sin which was seeded multiplied, grace|
     v20                                |multiplied even more so, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that just as the sin which was seeded reigned by the death that it spawned, in the same way grace|
     v21                                |would reign through righteousness resulting in eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life, one|
     v21                                |which begins in this lifetime) through our Lord Jesus Christ.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in a hope</char>…Lit: <char style="it">boast upon|
                                        |hope</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">won’t disappoint</char>…Lit: <char style="it">won’t be ashamed</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s own love is endorsed to us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God commends His love|
                                        |to us</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">commend </char>was in ancient times used when someone|
                                        |introduced a person whom he recommends to someone else, with the intention of the two becoming friends|
                                        |or joining together in a common cause.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">seeing that</char>…Lit: <char style="it">at which</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">overflow</char>…Also: <char style="it">abound</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to have the slate of his entire life wiped clean</char>…Lit: <char style="it">justification|
                                        |of life</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">transacted and counted against a person</char>…Lit: <char style="it">charged to one’s|
                                        |account; imputed</char>. Paul says here and elsewhere that sin cannot take place without God having published|
                                        |a list of His commandments. God doesn’t count deeds done in ignorance as sin. This is why when toddlers|
                                        |die, they don’t face condemnation: toddlers aren’t old enough to comprehend the commandments. It also|
                                        |explains Gen. 4:15, where God didn’t kill Cain for killing Abel but said he’d kill anyone who killed|
                                        |Cain.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">death reigned from Adam until Moses</char>…Paul is referring to the timeframe before|
                                        |the ultimate law, the Law of Moses, was delivered to the people. Even without the Law, which is the ultimate,|
                                        |definitive list compiled by God of what sin is, sin managed to wreak its devastation (i.e., death) during|
                                        |that time. Paul said a verse earlier that sin is not transacted (imputed) where law doesn’t exist; but|
                                        |he’s clarifying that remark by saying that sin indeed reigned in spite of the Law of Moses not existing.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s there to say about this? Shall we dwell in the sin inherent in all humans so that more and|

     v 2                                |in the sin inherited by all humans—how will we live in it still? |

     v 4                                |resulting in death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father,|
     v 4                                |we too in like fashion would go about in a brand-newness of life. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if we’ve become united together in a way which replicates his death, then certainly we will|
     v 5                                |also be a product of the resurrection, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing this: that our old-self was jointly-crucified, so that the body of sin (i.e., the sinful propensity|
     v 6                                |incumbent to our human nature) would be done away with, done away with in respect to us slaving in the|
     v 6                                |sin inherited by all humans: |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for he who’s died has been justified from (i.e., cleared of; absolved of) the sin.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if we jointly-died with Christ, we believe that we’ll also jointly-live with him, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing for a fact that, now that he’s been raised from the dead, Christ won’t die anymore: death no|
     v 9                                |longer has control over him. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, what died died once and for all in the sin inherited by all humans; what lives lives in|
     v10                                |God. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the same way we also consider ourselves to be, on the one hand, dead in the sin, but on the other|
     v11                                |hand living in Christ Jesus.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So don’t keep on letting sin reign in your mortal bodies (i.e., the part of you which hosts carnal desires|
     v12                                |during your life here on Earth) to where you obey its sinful desire, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor put your body parts (i.e., your physical body parts, each part being a metonymy for various activities|
     v13                                |one engages in. In this case, each part is a metonymy for this or that sin, the whole comprising your|
     v13                                |personal carnal signature) in a place where they’re available to be used as tools, mechanisms, or weapons|
     v13                                |of unrighteousness in the sin inherent in all humans, but instead put yourselves in a place where you’re|
     v13                                |made available in God as alive from the dead and your body parts as tools, mechanisms, and weapons of|
     v13                                |righteousness in God. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, sin will not control you; you see, you’re not under the jurisdiction of law (i.e., your|
     v14                                |life is decided by a list of do’s-and-dont’s) but under the jurisdiction of grace instead.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now…shall we sin since we’re not under the jurisdiction of law but under the jurisdiction of grace|
     v15                                |instead?—Don’t even think about it. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You ought to know that whatever thing you make yourself available to be used by—used to the point of|
     v16                                |being obedient to—you’re enslaved to, a slave of either sin culminating in death or obedience culminating|
     v16                                |in righteousness. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God is so good: you were slaves of sin, but you whole-heartedly obeyed what was presented to you in a|
     v17                                |clear, orderly, and systematic way: the particular kind of instruction which has you walking in the righteousness|
     v17                                |of faith rather than just following a set of rules; |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having been freed from the sin inherent in all humans, you were enslaved by righteousness.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The subject I’m talking about is the human condition and human experience on account of the weakness|
     v19                                |of your flesh (i.e., of your lack of self-ability apart from God; of that part of you which has carnal|
     v19                                |desires; of that part of you which fails to live up to God’s standards). You see, just as you made your|
     v19                                |body parts available to be used as slaves in the filth and degradation of carnality and in an artifact|
     v19                                |of sin, namely the refusal to be restrained by any laws, rules, or codes of conduct, which leads to even|
     v19                                |more of the same, in like fashion make your body parts available at this time to be used as slaves by|
     v19                                |the righteousness which is a consequence of faith which leads to holiness. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, when you were yet slaves of sin, you were free with respect to living in righteousness.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what final result did you obtain back then, based on the things which you’re now ashamed of? The fact|
     v21                                |of the matter is that those things end in death. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But as things stand now, on the one hand having been freed from the sin inherent in all humans but on|
     v22                                |the other hand having become slaves in God, you’re getting holiness as your final result on the one hand,|
     v22                                |but you end up with eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life) on the other. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For the wages of the sin inherent in all humans is death, but the gift of God is that special fullness|
     v23                                |of life (eternal life) in Christ Jesus our Lord.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what’s there to say about this</char>…Lit: <char style="it">what shall we say</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t even think about it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">may it not be</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the sin</char>…Or: <char style="it">to the sin</char>. Literal rendering is <char|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in a way which replicates his death</char>…Lit<char style="it">: in the likeness of|
                                        |his death</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">old-self</char>…Lit: <char style="it">old man</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">won’t die anymore</char>…Lit<char style="it">: dies no longer</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what</char>…Lit<char style="it">: that which</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">So now</char>…Lit: <char style="it">So what?</char> Or: <char style="it">What then?</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t even think about it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">may it not be</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">You ought to know</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Don’t you know</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God is so good</char>…Lit: <char style="it">grace</char> [<char style="it">kindness</char>,|
