     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">physically-speaking but present spiritually-speaking</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in|
                                        |body but present in spirit</char>, or, <char style="it">in body but present in the Spirit</char>. The|
                                        |ambiguity of whether it’s <char style="it">in spirit </char>or <char style="it">in the Spirit </char>is|
                                        |rendered <char style="it">in spirit </char>because of the parallelism of <char style="it">in body, </char>and|
                                        |also the phrase <char style="it">the spirit of mine </char>in v.4. The argument on the flip side of the|
                                        |coin, to mean <char style="it">in the Spirit:</char> <char style="it">in the spirit </char>with the explicit|
                                        |inclusion of the definite article the majority of the time refers to the Holy Spirit.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">will avoid utter calamity when the Lord “settles all Family business” so-to-speak</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">will be saved in the Day of the Lord</char>. The <char style="it">Day of the Lord </char>is|
                                        |the same as when Michael Corleone tells Carlo “Today I settled all Family business” in <char style="it">The|
                                        |Godfather</char>—but of course, the Lord judges in righteousness, but the Don did not. The Day of the|
                                        |Lord is the swift, sudden, violent, decisive judgment upon those who obviously deserve it, who, from|
                                        |a human perspective, should’ve received it earlier. Paul refers to the Day of the Lord in 1 Thess. 5:2,|
                                        |the concept originating foremost from Joel (Joel 1:15; 2:1,11,31; 3:14) but occurs in other OT books|
                                        |as well (Amos 5:20; Zeph. 1:7; Zech. 14:1).|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">partake of the Passover meal</char>…Lit: <char style="it">celebrate</char>. The Gk.|
                                        |word <char style="it">celebrate</char> is a verb form of the Gk. word rendered <char style="it">festival</char>,|
                                        |which in addition to meaning <char style="it">festival </char>refers to religious observances which aren’t|
                                        |accompanied by festivity, including simple meals like the Passover meal. But this verse demonstrates|
                                        |the metaphor Paul draws comparing Christians to the unleavened bread used in the Passover unleavened|
                                        |bread (matzah). Starting with Moses commanding the Israelites to purge every spec of yeast from the entire|
                                        |nation and eat matzah instead of real bread for the Passover, yeast and bread infected by it symbolize|
                                        |sin, impurity, and the tendency for attitudes—sinful ones in particular—to spread.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">greedy and rapacious</char>…A hendiadys perhaps. The Gk. word for <char style="it">greedy|
                                        |</char>means <char style="it">to want more and more</char>; the Gk. word for <char style="it">rapacious|
                                        |</char>means <char style="it">grabbing</char> <char style="it">or</char> <char style="it">seizing things</char>.|
                                        |Also, Paul associates greed, fornication, and idolatry in this verse and in Eph. 5:3,5; there are more|
                                        |references in the NT as well. These sins are interrelated.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I wrote to you just now</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I wrote to you now</char>. Paul|
                                        |says <char style="it">I wrote </char>instead of <char style="it">I write, </char>using the past tense|
                                        |instead of the present to refer to what he’s about to write at the end of the sentence. This would make|
                                        |sense if one were to assume that Paul first wrote a draft of this epistle, perhaps on wax tablets, made|
                                        |corrections, then copied the edited version onto the scroll which was sent to Corinth.|

 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So when you do happen to form a panel for arbitrating day-to-day affairs, you put those in the church|
     v 4                                |who are despised and lowly-esteemed on the panel. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Shame on you—Isn’t there even one of you who has wisdom when it comes to this sort of thing, someone|

     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Instead, a comrade takes another comrade to court, and the court consists of unbelievers. |

     v 7                                |you just be wronged? Why don’t you just be cheated? |

     v 8                                |comrades. |
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t you know that those who wrong others won’t inherit the kingdom of God (i.e., won’t have a relationship|

     v 9                                |adulterers nor catamites nor homosexuals |

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Shame on you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I speak to your shame</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">straighten out a situation his comrade is in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">can judge|

     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a comrade takes another comrade to court, and the court consists of unbelievers</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">a brother judges </char>[also<char style="it">, seeks a decision</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |with a brother, and this at unbelievers</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by the authority of</char>…Lit<char style="it">: in the name of</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t even think about it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">let it not come-into-being</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of Rom. 3:4.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">becomes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">is</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">becomes a single spirit with him</char>…A mirror of the wording in v. 16, <char style="it">becomes|
                                        |a single body with her</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t own yourselves</char>…Lit<char style="it">: are not your own</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">glorify</char>…Paul choice of verb tense to make this a harsh command|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">catamites</char>…Also<char style="it">: those who are effeminate</char>…Lit: <char style="it">soft|
                                        |to the touch. </char>The commentators aren’t exactly sure what this refers to; some say it refers to|
                                        |a man who lives a soft life—which is reasonable. But considering that the context is egregious sexual|
                                        |sin, and that the other sins listed in this verse are severe, this word here might refer to men who dress|
                                        |like and behave as though they’re women. |
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">To me, everything is permissible but not everything is beneficial</char>…Though Paul|
                                        |said that everything is permissible, it’s impossible to accept this statement at face-value, as he lists|
                                        |a few things in this chapter which are not permissible for anyone to do, stealing and being covetous|
                                        |for example. How is this logical dilemma to be solved? Paul is stating his perspective—his philosophy—on|
                                        |whether he will engage in an activity or not. Rather than looking at some deed as permissible or forbidden,|
                                        |he changes the perspective to look at whether said deed is beneficial or non-beneficial. The understanding|
                                        |is that whether it’s permissible or not will logically align with whether it’s beneficial or not. The|
                                        |examples of greed and covetousness Paul categorizes as non-beneficial, so it’s irrelevant whether they’re|
                                        |permissible or not, since Paul’s not going to do them anyways because they’re non-beneficial. By this|
                                        |reasoning, whether something is permissible or not is moot. Adopting this perspective goes a long way|
                                        |to resolving the issue of legalism which inevitably arises in the pursuit of religion.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all sins that a person happens to commit are done outside the body, but the fornicator|
                                        |commits a sin which is done to (or even into) his own body</char>…The reason why fornication differs|
                                        |from all other sins, being a sin done to your body, is given in the previous verses: a fornicator unites|
                                        |his body with the person he commits the act with, and the two become a single body. When a couple is|
                                        |united sexually, their bodies merge into one body. Merging your body with someone who’s trash causes|
                                        |your body to be corrupted by the trash from the other body.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a temple which is a dwelling-place for the Holy Spirit to dwell in, thereby living among|
                                        |us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a temple among us of </char>[<char style="it">the</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |Holy Spirit</char>. According to Gk. grammar, the placement of <char style="it">among us </char>between|
                                        |the two phrases <char style="it">a temple </char>and <char style="it">of the Holy Spirit </char>indicates|
                                        |the tight coupling of the phrase <char style="it">among us </char>to the other two phrases. So Paul’s|
                                        |saying that our bodies form a temple and within this temple the Holy Spirit dwells. The analogy is the|
                                        |temple of Jerusalem in which God’s presence dwelled in the Holy of Holies.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To elaborate on what I wrote to you in the previous letter, it’s good for a man not to go about touching|

     v 2                                |own man to be her husband. |

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">virginity</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the of-oneself virgin</char>. Paul uses the word|
                                        |<char style="it">virgin </char>a few times in this passage, but his use of the reflexive pronoun <char|
                                        |style="it">oneself </char>inserted between the definite article and the word <char style="it">virgin|
                                        |</char>selects <char style="it">virginity, </char>a secondary meaning of the Gk. word for <char style="it">virgin.|
                                        |</char>Note Paul’s careful insertion of the reflexive pronoun both here and in v. 38.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to go about touching a woman for the purpose of instigating</char>…First, the Gk. verb|
                                        |for<char style="it"> touch </char>[<char style="it">haptō</char>, <char style="w" strong="G00681">ἅπτω</char>)]|
                                        |appears in the present tense, insinuating continuous action rather than a one-time act—hence the added|
                                        |phrase <char style="it">go about touching</char>. Second, this verb is unusual in that it has one meaning|
                                        |when used in the active voice (<char style="it">to light on fire) </char>and another meaning when used|
                                        |in the middle voice (<char style="it">to touch</char>). Since the active voice is the primary tense,|
                                        |the meaning in the middle voice influenced by a hint of the meaning from the active voice. Most of the|
                                        |NT occurrences of this verb are in the middle voice, and they not only mean <char style="it">to touch|
                                        |</char>but also acquire some of the active voice’s definition to more specifically mean <char style="it">to|
                                        |touch for the purpose of instigating something. </char>This verb is used when Jesus touches someone to|
                                        |heal them; he touched the person but did so for a purpose. What is “lit on fire” so-to-speak is determined|
                                        |by the context, and the context of v. 1 here insinuates touching sexually. To further reinforce the point|
                                        |that <char style="it">haptō </char>means more than a simple touch, take a close look at Col. 2:21. Note|
                                        |how <char style="it">haptō </char>appears in that passage with <char style="it">thigganō </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G02345">θιγγάνω</char>)<char style="it">. </char>They both mean <char style="it">to|
                                        |touch </char>but thigganō<char style="it"> </char>means touching without instigating anything; to touch|
                                        |lightly; to brush up against something. Had they meant the same thing, Paul wouldn’t have used two different|
                                        |verbs.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">leave</char>…<char style="it">divorce</char>…Different Gk. words are used for <char|
                                        |style="it">leave </char>and <char style="it">divorce </char>here; we infer from this verse here and from|
                                        |other NT references (such as Matt. 5:31) that, in ancient times, only the husband had the right to instigate|
                                        |a legal divorce. A wife, however, would at times simply leave her husband without fulfilling the legalities|
                                        |of a divorce. This might explain the two different words used here.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God has called us to live in peace (i.e., live free of the conflict, duress, or affliction|
                                        |that many unbelieving spouse brings)</char> <char style="it">whatever our situation might be</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">God has called us in</char> [or: <char style="it">with</char>; <char style="it">by</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">peace</char>. Apparently, “God has called us to live in peace” means that it’s not God’s|
                                        |will for a Christian to be married to a person who’s violent, who’s abusive, who’s reckless, who’s irresponsible|
                                        |to the point of it causing harm to the family, etc. Notice that it says “God has called us to live in|
                                        |peace,” and not “God has called us to be happy” (Christians shouldn’t necessarily be “happy” but they|
                                        |should have joy). In other words, this isn’t a license for a person to divorce simply because he’s unhappy.|
                                        |But it is a license for a Christian who was married before he became a Christian to divorce an unbelieving|
                                        |spouse if that spouse is causing trouble.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have each person lead his life in the way that the Lord deems appropriate for the particular|
                                        |situation he was in when he became a believer</char>…Lit: <char style="it">as the Lord partitioned</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">an inheritance</char>] <char style="it">each as God has called</char>…Or: <char style="it">as|
                                        |the Lord partitioned</char> [<char style="it">an inheritance</char>] <char style="it">as God has called|
                                        |each</char>. Some guesswork as to what exactly Paul was saying. He seems to be making a comparison to|
                                        |dividing an inheritance, the inheritance being a biblical theme that refers to the specific plans God|
                                        |has for an individual or a particular group, plans which are bespoke for that person or group.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t obliterate the effects of circumcision</char>…What Paul meant by this can be seen|
                                        |in his own life. Paul used the fact that he was circumcised to his advantage from time to time, as he|
                                        |writes later in 9:22, “I am made all things to all men, that I might by all means save some.” Examples|
                                        |are found in Acts 18:18, 21:23–29.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">overly-ripe</char>…Or: <char style="it">beyond her prime</char>…Lit: <char style="it">beyond|
                                        |peak</char>. The passage of vv. 36–38 has puzzled translators, and every rendering is not without criticism.|
                                        |To a large extent it hinges on what <char style="it">beyond peak </char>means in this context. Some believe|
                                        |it means that the virgin woman is <char style="it">beyond her prime </char>in age, but the meaning of|
                                        |<char style="it">beyond peak </char>which best fits the context is a woman who’s pregnant and beginning|
                                        |to show or perhaps or is a woman who’s late in her monthly cycle.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now about the issue of eating meat sacrificed to idols, every one of us has our own understanding of|
     v 1                                |how this ought to be handled. The understanding a person has on a given issue makes him rather full of|
     v 1                                |himself, but the love shown in the handling of said issue edifies. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If any given person thinks he’s reached the point where he’s acquired some level of understanding, he|
     v 2                                |has not yet understood the matter as it must be understood. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If someone loves God, this individual has been known and understood by Him.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, about the consumption of food offered to idols: we know for a fact that the idols in the world|
     v 4                                |don’t amount to a hill of beans, and no person or thing is God except for One being only. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now, granted, there are those who claim there are gods, whether they be in the sky, in the atmosphere,|
     v 5                                |among the stars, in a spiritual world beyond that, or on the earth, so that there’re many gods and many|
     v 5                                |lords, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but from our point of view there’s one God the Father, out of Whom are all things, and we are returned|
     v 6                                |to Him and to the Lord Jesus Christ, through whom are all things, and we are through him.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That aside, we are not on the same level in every aspect of understanding. Up until now some people have|
     v 7                                |been in the habit of eating food sacrificed to idols, and since their consciences are weak (i.e., their|
     v 7                                |consciences prod them with pangs of guilt over matters they have a deficient understanding of, in this|
     v 7                                |case in regard to food sacrificed to idols), they violate their consciences. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Eating or not eating this food doesn’t get us anywhere with God: we’re neither worse off if we were to|
     v 8                                |not eat it nor are we better off if we were to eat it.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |See to it that the right you have to eat such food doesn’t somehow in and of itself become a stumbling|
     v 9                                |block (i.e., an influence for causing sin) for those who have a weak conscience. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if someone with a weak conscience were to watch you, a person who has the correct understanding|
     v10                                |on this issue, sitting at the dinner table with food sacrificed to idols lying on the plate in front|
     v10                                |of you, wouldn’t his conscience, because it’s in a state of weakness, being built up in regard to the|
     v10                                |eating of foods sacrificed to idols (i.e., because of an incorrect understanding in regard to this issue|
     v10                                |of food sacrificed to idols, his conscience has been conditioned to respond with guilt when it ought|
     v10                                |not)? |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, he who’s weak—the comrade whom Christ died for—is being destroyed by your correct understanding.|
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the way that you sin against the comrades and beat on their weak consciences, you sin against Christ.|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That’s why if food causes my comrade to stumble, there’s no way whatsoever that I’ll ever eat sacrificial|
     v13                                |meat again, so that I won’t be a stumbling block to my brother.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t amount to a hill of beans</char>…Lit: <char style="it">are nothing</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one being only</char>…Lit: <char style="it">one</char>. Alludes to the statement “God|
                                        |is One”; ref. James 2:19.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">violate</char>…Lit: <char style="it">defiling</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">doesn’t get us anywhere with</char>…Lit: <char style="it">doesn’t present us to</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stumbling block</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 18:6.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sitting at the dinner table</char>…Lit: <char style="it">reclining</char>. Ref. note|
                                        |of Matt. 9:10.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">their conscience are weak</char>. In his epistles, Paul talks about four types of consciences:|
                                        |a good conscience, an evil conscience, a weak conscience, and a seared conscience. A person’s conscience|
                                        |is something that affirms when he’s doing right but condemns when he does wrong. From this context, we|
                                        |can deduce that a weak conscience is one which has been programmed with an incorrect understanding of|
                                        |the truth and therefore misfires, sending the wrong signals for the wrong reasons, causing a person to|
                                        |experience guilt over something he shouldn’t and not experience it over something he should. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Am I not a freeman? Am I not an apostle (i.e., have I not been sent by God to pioneer the spread of Christianity)?|

     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If I’m not an apostle sent to root others in Christianity, at least I’m an apostle sent to root you;|

     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My rebuttal to those examining me for the purpose of judging and condemning me is the same.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Do we not have the right to be hosted in such a way that we eat and drink for free? |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Do we not have the right to have a fellow-comrade-wife accompany us as she follows our lead on our journeys|
     v 5                                |and have her hosted as well, as all the other apostles of the Lord and Peter do?— |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or is it just Barnabas and I who don’t have the right to not have to work to support ourselves? |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When did any soldier ever serve in the army and have to pay for his own rations? Who plants a vineyard|
     v 7                                |and doesn’t feed off what it produces? Or who cares for a ewe and doesn’t feed off the sheep’s milk?|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m not talking from a human perspective, or talking about concepts that the Law does not also talk about.|

     v 9                                |threshing wheat.” You don’t think God cares about the welfare of the oxen when it’s threshing, do you?|
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or is it that the Law’s addressing this topic for our benefit? Furthermore, it’s written in the Law for|
     v10                                |our benefit that the sower ought to sow and the thresher to thresh with the hope of getting a percentage|
     v10                                |of the harvest. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we sowed into you the Holy Spirit-related things which are the backbone of your spiritual lives, is|
     v11                                |it a big deal if we reap the physical things we need to live by from you? |
   N V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If others have the right of taking a percentage from you, don’t we all the more so?|
 +P  V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No, we’re not asserting this right; instead we put up with all kinds of things so that nothing would|
     v12                                |hinder the Gospel, the good-news message of Christ. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t you know that they who work the sacred duties in the temple feed on the sacrifices offered at the|
     v13                                |temple; that they who attend to the altar divide the spoils of the altar among themselves? |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the same way the Lord planned for and commanded those who proclaim the Gospel to make their living|
     v14                                |from the Gospel. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I have not used any of these mandates. I didn’t write about these things to make them happen to me; in|
     v15                                |fact, I’d rather die than have someone invalidate the proud assertions which I openly pride myself in.|
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Should I proclaim the Gospel, it’s not my place to make proud assertions, you see: by necessity they’re|
     v16                                |imposed on me. I’ll be in deep trouble, you see, should I not proclaim the Gospel. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If I put this into practice voluntarily, you see, I’ll earn my pay. If I do this voluntarily, I’ve reached|
     v17                                |the point where I can be entrusted with a managerial position. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s my pay rate? I’m not getting paid a penny so that I can present the Gospel free of charge with|
     v18                                |a view towards me not exercising my right to receive financial support as one who proclaims the Gospel.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Being a freeman, freed from all things, in all things I made myself a slave, so that I’d win over the|
     v19                                |many. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I became a Jew to the Jews so that I would win over Jews: to those who live under the Law of Moses, I|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by virtue of the cloud and the sea</char>…Also: <char style="it">in the cloud and in|
                                        |the sea</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what exactly am I trying to tell you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">what am I saying</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">idolatry is something</char> <char style="it">which needs to be taken seriously</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">idolatry is something</char>. Same expression used in Gal. 6:3; the meaning of it can|
                                        |be inferred from that passage.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">drinking from the Lord’s cup (i.e., following the Lord’s plan for your lives)</char>…The|
                                        |metonymy of the cup is best understood from its usage in Matt. 20:22; Mark 10:38 and in others.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">partaking of the Lord’s table (i.e., receiving the Lord’s provision for your nourishment)</char>…The|
                                        |metonymy of the table is best understood from its usage in 2 Sam. 9:7–13; 1 Kings 4:27; Neh. 5:17; Psalm|
                                        |23:5; 69:22; 78:19 and in others.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">do you intend to provoke the Lord to wrath</char>…Lit: <char style="it">are you provoking|
                                        |the Lord to wrath</char> [also, <char style="it">to jealousy</char>].|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Everything is permissible, but not everything is beneficial</char>…Paul repeats what|
                                        |he said in earlier in 6:12; Ref. note there.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his own interests exclusively</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the things of himself</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">qualms</char>…Lit<char style="it">: judging through the conscience</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The abundant, splendid variety of things that the earth contains was put there by the|
                                        |Lord’s doing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the earth and its fullness</char> [<char style="it">are</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">of the Lord</char>. <char style="it">The earth and its fullness</char> is a hendiadys;|
                                        |ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a Westerner</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a Greek</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was initiated into and joined up with Moses in totality</char>…Lit: <char style="it">were|
                                        |baptized into Moses</char>. The usage of <char style="it">baptize </char>here anchors its definition|
                                        |in the NT. In my opinion, the most complete definition of <char style="it">baptidzō </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00907">βαπτίζω</char>), the Gk. word for <char style="it">to baptize</char>, is the definition|
                                        |that James H. Strong gives: <char style="it">whelm. </char>Ref. Luke 12:50. The Israelites passing through|
                                        |the Red Sea is symbolic of baptism.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The folk-people sat down to eat and drink and when they were done got up to play</char>…At|
                                        |first, this quotation seems irrelevant with respect to idolatry, that other verses from Exod. would’ve|
                                        |been better suited to highlight the golden calve story, but the opposite is true: it is an accurate description.|
                                        |Idolatry is attributing care, provision, and protection (in Bible terms, the saving and the salvation)|
                                        |to a false god, to worship that god as being the provider, celebrating the fact that he cares and provides|
                                        |for you. The eating, drinking, and playing points to this celebration.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the ends of the ages</char>…This expression is similar to “Last Days” (ref. note of|
                                        |John 6:39), and both lend support to the idea of there being different ages of mankind. Furthermore,|
                                        |God’s dealings with man change from age to age, and there’s a progression as mankind passes through the|
                                        |ages. Quoting Wikipedia, “At the core of dispensationalism is the concept that God has acted in different|
                                        |ways in dealing with his chosen people throughout human history.” The <char style="it">ends of the ages|
                                        |</char>is the age in which God makes available the ability to come to Him through Christ directly. The|
                                        |<char style="it">ends </char>(plural) is not only the singular command to accept Christ but also includes|
                                        |outpourings of the Holy Spirit.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">an intimate association with the body of Christ</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a fellowship</char>|
                                        |[also <char style="it">a commonality</char>] <char style="it">of the body of Christ</char>. This verse|
                                        |adds clarification to what Jesus meant when he held up the bread and said “This is my body” (Luke 22:19).|
                                        |Partaking in the communion bread is fellowship with the body of Christ, but Jesus didn’t literally mean|
                                        |that the bread becomes his body.|

                                        |style="it">house </char>also means <char style="it">building</char> in a generic sense, a building which|
                                        |is not a residence. In this context, Paul seems to be referring to establishments and not homes per se.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">run down with a long-running illness or have maladies</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 4:23|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">dying</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sleeping</char>. Ref. 1 Cor. 7:39.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the man which God created is the head of woman</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the man|
                                        |is the head of woman. </char>The Gk. words for <char style="it">man</char> and <char style="it">woman</char>|
                                        |used here are used in some of Paul’s other writings (1 Cor. 7:1–3; Eph. 5:22–23; 1 Tim. 2) and elsewhere|
                                        |in the NT to refer to <char style="it">husband </char>and <char style="it">wife, </char>introducing the|
                                        |potential for ambiguity. Paul was cognizant of this as he was committing his words to paper (parchment,|
                                        |actually) and explicitly selected <char style="it">wife </char>or <char style="it">husband </char>by|
                                        |saying <char style="it">own woman </char>and <char style="it">own man </char>in 1 Cor. 7:2 and <char|
                                        |style="it">own man </char>in Eph. 5:22. Since <char style="it">own woman </char>or <char style="it">own|
                                        |man </char>doesn’t appear in the 1 Cor. 11 passage referenced here, Paul means <char style="it">man </char>and|
                                        |<char style="it">woman. </char>The context favors this conclusion as well.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Any man who has something down over his head while praying or prophesying disgraces|
                                        |his head</char>…One can only speculate as to what exactly Paul is talking about in this passage. Having|
                                        |said that, cultural traditions stretch back for millennia, traditions where women wear head covering.|
                                        |It appears that Paul is talking about a tradition which was peculiar to the Corinthians, where it was|
                                        |shameful for a man to have something over his head in a public forum of some sort, while it was shameful|
                                        |for a woman to not have something over her head in the same forum. There’s a parallel between one’s head|
                                        |which is a body part and one’s head which is the next level up in the submission chain (Paul speaks of|
                                        |the “head” in Eph. 5:23 the same way). So the woman not having a covering over her head would be seen|
                                        |as a sign of disrespect to her head, to man.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Because of this the woman ought to have control over her head because of the angels</char>…Speculation|
                                        |again due to the ambiguity in this verse. The Gk. words for <char style="it">have control over </char>can|
                                        |also be rendered <char style="it">be</char> <char style="it">having authority. </char>The phrase <char|
                                        |style="it">through the angels </char>can be rendered in a couple of variations such as <char style="it">by|
                                        |means of the angels, on account of, </char>or <char style="it">through the angels. </char>The question|
                                        |is whether <char style="it">her head</char> (lit., <char style="it">the head</char>)<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>in this verse refers to the woman’s physical head or to her higher-up (man). Assuming that the|
                                        |latter is the case and that <char style="it">head </char>here doesn’t refer to her physical head, then|
                                        |this would mean that the woman exercises power, authority, and control over the man, but it is done by|
                                        |means of the angels. This agrees with Paul’s previous observation that woman came out of man, but man|
                                        |is birthed by woman; both woman comes from man, and man comes from woman; neither is superior; both are|
                                        |dependent on the other. This is simply a restatement of v. 12. In keeping with this, the woman has authority|
                                        |(has control over) the man, a control which is accomplished on a spiritual level by the employment of|
                                        |angels.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">This is my body which is lifted up, broken, and distributed for your sakes</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">This is my body which is on your behalf</char>. What Jesus was did with the bread at|
                                        |the Last Supper is what was done to his body: it was lifted up, broken, and distributed to everyone around|
                                        |the table.|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Spirituals</char>…The plural form of the Gk. word <char style="it">pneumatikos </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G04152">πνευματικός</char>) with the definite article, which isn’t ordinarily needed|
                                        |in this case (this creates emphasis).<char style="it"> </char>The Gk. noun <char style="it">pneuma </char>(spirit,|
                                        |πνεῦμα/Strong’s 4151) terminated with the adjective ending <char style="it">tikos, </char>a suffix<char|
                                        |style="it"> </char>which “marks ability or fitness” of the verb it appends according to Bullinger. The|
                                        |adjective, having been formed, is used substantively as a noun in this verse, forming a new noun. This|
                                        |new Gk. noun means “belonging to or of pneuma; of the pneuma.” As pneuma has multiple meanings—a spiritual|
                                        |being (the Holy Spirit, a human spirit, a demonic spirit); related to things of the spirit; prevailing|
                                        |attitude—pneumatikos acquires these flavors of meaning: related to or of the Holy Spirit; related to|
                                        |or of a human spirit; or simply the word <char style="it">spiritual</char> as it’s understood in English.|
                                        |Though Paul didn’t invent this word, he coined the usage of it in the NT. The meaning of pneumatikos|
                                        |in Paul’s writings is best understood from the way Paul uses it and from firsthand Christian experience—not|
                                        |from what’s written in the lexicons. When pneumatikos appears in the NT, the context will guide you as|
                                        |to which of these various definitions to use. In v. 1 here, the context suggests things related to or|
                                        |pertaining to the Holy Spirit, where <char style="it">Holy Spirit </char>is a synecdoche which refers|
                                        |to his workings, similar to the way Holy Spirit is used a synecdoche to refer to the baptism in the Holy|
                                        |Spirit (an example being Acts 8:15). So pneumatikos as used here refers to things that the Holy Spirit|
                                        |does and not the Holy Spirit himself per se. This is not the case in other NT usages of pneumatikos,|
                                        |as pneumatikos’s meaning is context-dependent.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">through the Spirit is given to one person</char>…The nine items listed in this passage,|
                                        |the Gifts of the Spirit, are all supernatural workings of the Holy Spirit, in spite of some of these|
                                        |item’s titles, titles which suggest that they are personal qualities. Among such titles is the first,|
                                        |the <char style="it">word of wisdom; </char>the Gk. word for <char style="it">word </char>in this context|
                                        |means a piece of information. The word <char style="it">wisdom, </char>apart from meaning wisdom, also|
                                        |means sophistication, cleverness, highly-skilled in a specific area, and even cunning. For the second|
                                        |item, the <char style="it">word of knowledge</char>, the Gk. word for <char style="it">knowledge </char>means|
                                        |knowledge or understanding which isn’t obtained through the physical senses. <char style="it">Faith </char>,|
                                        |the third item, must be talking about faith of a supernatural type, not to be confused with personal|
                                        |faith, which all believers must have and are encouraged to grow in.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Pentecostal tradition (and the Pentecostals have studied this passage the most) defines the spiritual|
                                        |gifts as follows:|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Word of wisdom—supernatural understanding of some future event|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Word of knowledge—supernatural knowledge of a current or past event|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Special faith—supernatural faith to receive a miracle|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Gifts of healings— spectacular healings, usually instantaneous|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Working of miracles—just like it sounds|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Prophecy—Holy Spirit-inspired utterance|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Discerning of spirits—the ability to see into the spiritual world; seeing angels or demons|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Tongues—Holy Spirit-inspired utterance in an unknown language|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Interpretation of tongues—Holy Spirit-inspired interpretation of an utterance in tongues|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">gifts of healings</char>…This is <char style="it">gifts of healings </char>(plural)|
                                        |not <char style="it">gift of healing </char>(singular). There is no single, generic gift of healing,|
                                        |rather there are a multitude of specialty healing gifts just like there’s a multitude of doctors who|
                                        |are specialists. Those who have a healing gift will usually excel at healing certain types or categories|
                                        |of disorders more than others. Similarly, when this same verse mentions <char style="it">helps</char>,|
                                        |it does so in the plural instead of singular because there’s a wide variety of helps ministries, and|
                                        |therefore people tend to specialize in one specific type of helps ministry.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have little value</char>…Also: <char style="it">handle the necessary but distasteful|
                                        |body functions</char>…Lit: <char style="it">dishonorable</char>. Paul may be referring to hair: it has|
                                        |little functional value and serves little function, but gets dressed, clothed, and is something which|
                                        |is of value to us.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Not everyone speaks in tongues, do they? Not everyone interprets messages in tongues,|
                                        |do they</char>…Lit: <char style="it">not all speak in tongues; not all interpret</char>. Keep in mind|
                                        |that what’s spoken about in vv. 27–31 are ministries, a subset of the “spirituals” specified in v. 1.|
                                        |Ministry gifts are full-time callings, such as an apostle or teacher, a vocation that the Holy Spirit|
                                        |calls a person to and enables him to do on a regular basis. A ministry is done for the benefit of the|
                                        |body and not for a personal edification. As such, the tongues listed in v. 30 is a vocation, a ministry,|
                                        |something done for the edification of the body. Not everyone has this ministry. But there is another|
                                        |kind of tongues described in 14:4 which is for personal edification. The restriction of “not everyone|
                                        |speaks in tongues” doesn’t apply to the speaking in tongues done for personal edification.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Yet I’ll show you a way which is superior to this</char>…Lit: <char style="it">And yet|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a brass instrument</char>…Lit: a copper|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">or</char>…Lit: <char style="it">and</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">its self-interest</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the things of itself</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">breaks down</char>…Lit: <char style="it">falls</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">know for certain</char>…The Gk. verb <char style="it">oida </char><char style="w" strong="G01492">οἶδα</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">, </char>in contrast to the Gk. root verb <char style="it">ginōskō </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G01097">γινώσκω</char>)used for <char style="it">knowledge and understanding </char>in this verse.|
                                        |<char style="it">Oida </char>is knowing by seeing (by physical sense); <char style="it">ginōskō </char>is|
                                        |understanding something which is abstract. This difference is exemplified in 2 Cor. 5:16, where both|
                                        |<char style="it">ginōskō </char>and oida are used in the same verse. Furthermore, in this verse Paul|
                                        |said “if I were to have a prophecy” and not “if I were to prophesy.” In other words, Paul said “if I|
                                        |were to possess a prophecy” and not “if I were to prophesy [i.e. speak a prophetic utterance].” He goes|
                                        |on to insinuate that the prophecy would contain the answers to the mysteries of life—hence the choice|
                                        |of the word <char style="it">oida </char>instead of <char style="it">ginōskō </char>when he said “know|
                                        |all the mysteries, etc.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Should there be prophecies, they’ll be done away with; should there be tongues, they’ll|
                                        |cease; should there be knowledge and understanding, it’ll be done away with</char>…Some have used this|
                                        |verse as a basis to argue that prophecies and tongues have ceased because the time for it to cease has|
                                        |come already. But notice that Paul mentions three things: prophecy, tongues, and knowledge. All three|
                                        |of these will cease at the same time, and not just two of three. It’s obvious that the third item knowledge|
                                        |hasn’t ceased yet, therefore the other two haven’t either.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">knowledge and understanding, it’ll be done away with…</char>There is a time coming,|
                                        |as specified in the v. 10, when the “perfect” will come, and the “partial” will be done away with. Has|
                                        |this time come yet? No, it couldn’t have. Verse 8 lists three things that will cease when this time arrives:|
                                        |prophecy, tongues, and knowledge. Not one, not two, but all three will cease. Some have taught in the|
                                        |past that this time arrived when the last book of the Bible was written, therefore tongues and prophecy|
                                        |have ceased. But what about knowledge? Paul tells us in a few other places in his epistles that he desires|
                                        |for Christians to increase in knowledge-certainly it has not ceased, and therefore the fulfillment cannot|
                                        |have been the completion of the NT canon.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |But there is coming a time—probably after death—when all three will cease, including knowledge. One might|
                                        |see why tongues and prophecy will cease, but what about knowledge? Does this mean that when we get to|
                                        |heaven, we’ll forget everything we knew on the earth? I should think not. The answer lies a bit deeper,|
                                        |specifically in an understanding of the Gk. word used for <char style="it">know</char>. NT Gk. has two|
                                        |principle verbs for “to know,” and from the verbs all the other forms, in this case the nouns, are derived.|
                                        |The first word is <char style="it">oida</char>, and it&apos;s actually an awkward form of another verb|
                                        |which means “to see.” The other word is <char style="it">gnōskō</char>. Oida and <char style="it">ginōskō</char>,|
                                        |although both translated &quot;to know&quot;, have distinct meanings. Oida means to know because a fact|
                                        |or thing is obvious, it’s something one knows because one has seen it, hence the connection to the verb|
                                        |“to see.” Ginōskō, on the other hand, refers to knowledge that one has obtained without the use of the|
                                        |senses. Ginōskō involves a level of abstraction, or reasoning, to arrive at the thing known, since it’s|
                                        |not directly discernable. For example, I “oida” that the shirt I’m wearing is red, but I “<char style="it">ginōskō|
                                        |</char>“ that the spare-penny dish at the checkout line at the convenience store is usually empty, because|
                                        |people are more apt to reach for a penny when they’re two or three cents short of the next dollar than|
                                        |they are to remember to put their spare pennies in the dish. Ginōskō is also a root used to derive other|
                                        |words, but in every case the meaning still involves some thought process. Hence, ginōskō or its derivatives|
                                        |are, among others, translated “understand,” “discern,” or “recognize.” In the NT, ginōskō is sometimes|
                                        |used in reference to spiritual knowledge, because spiritual things cannot be seen, and faith, by nature,|
                                        |believes in what one cannot see, and therefore is always abstract.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |But there’s coming a day when the faith necessary to believe in God won’t be necessary, because we won’t|
                                        |be living on this earth anymore. All ginōskō knowledge will be replaced with oida knowledge, which will|
                                        |not cease—only ginōskō knowledge will. Questions and mysteries will be done away with too, at that time.|
                                        |But while we’re still here on earth, there are certain things we must know without having seen, or having|
                                        |conclusive proofs demonstrated to us. There’s things that also happen to us, or to others we know, that|
                                        |are a mystery. Why did this tragedy occur? Many ask, was it God’s will? Where was God in all of this?|
                                        |A lot of things we don’t—nor ever will—know the answer to, not here on this earth. This doesn’t mean|
                                        |that there’s not a good explanation for it; what it does mean is that the explanation is beyond our reach.|
                                        |Often when people don’t have the answer, they must fill that unknowing in them and produce their own|
                                        |explanation, and often this results in speculations about God’s will. This has become the source of a|
                                        |lot of poor doctrine. Just accept the fact that there are certain things that we’ll never understand|
                                        |in this lifetime until the perfect comes, but that there’s probably a good explanation for these things.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by</char> <char style="it">his</char> <char style="it">spirit</char>…Or: <char style="it">with|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sing a song</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to pluck</char> [<char style="it">the strings|
                                        |of a musical instrument like a harp; to play a stringed instrument; to sing to the music of a harp</char>].|
                                        |Weak as it may be, this is one of the few pieces of evidence in the Bible of post-resurrection believers|
                                        |using musical instruments in worship.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a person who isn’t versed in the things of the Spirit and doesn’t speak in tongues</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">the one filling up the place of the outsider</char>. The phrase <char style="it">the|
                                        |one filling up the place </char>is an expression, and what deeper meaning or further nuance that this|
                                        |expression communicates, I don’t know . The Gk. word for <char style="it">outsider </char>is contingent|
                                        |on the context. Given a skill, profession, or some area of knowledge, the “outsider” is a novice, is|
                                        |unskilled, or is ignorant when it comes to the matter at hand.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">This is the case so much so that the tongues referred to by this Old Testament passage|
                                        |are intended to be a sign (i.e., a miracle God performed, done in such a way to demonstrate beyond any|
                                        |doubt that He did it)</char> <char style="it">not to those who believe but rather to those who refuse|
                                        |to believe</char>…Lit: <char style="it">so much so that the tongues are intended to be a sign not to|
                                        |those who believer but rather to those </char>[<char style="it">in</char>]<char style="it"> unbelief</char>.|
                                        |A puzzling verse. J.B. Phillips, author of <char style="it">The New Testament in Modern English </char>(1958|
                                        |version), wrote, “This is the sole instance of the translator’s departing from the accepted text. He|
                                        |felt bound to conclude, from the sense of the next three verses, that we have here either a slip of the|
                                        |pen on the part of Paul, or, more probably, a copyist’s error.” In other words, Phillips is justifying|
                                        |the fact that he swapped a couple words to make sense of this verse. I disagree with Phillips; however,|
                                        |this verse must be supplied with interpolations to make sense of it. Verse 22 begins with the Gk. word|
                                        |<char style="it">hōste</char> [<char style="it">so much so</char> <char style="w" strong="G05620">ὥστε</char>)].|
                                        |Hōste connects two thoughts, and an interpolation has been added to beginning of the verse to make this|
                                        |more apparent (Matt. 12:12 is an example). Verse 22 is tightly coupled with v. 21, being linked to the|
                                        |quotation from Is. 28:11–12. What this means is that tongues is a sign that the prophecy from Isaiah|
                                        |has been fulfilled, so that those who don’t believe should recognize it as the fulfillment of this prophecy.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Should someone speak in tongues, let there be two or at the most three messages given|
                                        |at a time one after the other and let one person interpret each message</char>…As Paul left a few key|
                                        |words to one’s imagination, it’s not quite clear which of a couple different things he meant. It seems|
                                        |that these verses here are referring to one person speaking, as the words <char style="it">someone </char>in|
                                        |<char style="it">should someone speak; him </char>in <char style="it">let him remain silent; </char>and|
                                        |<char style="it">him </char>in <char style="it">let him speak to himself </char>are all singular.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">let him speak in tongues to himself and to God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">let him|
                                        |speak to himself and to God</char>. The interpolation <char style="it">in tongues </char>is justifiable|
                                        |based on the context and is affirmed by v. 2, which says that a person who speaks in tongues speaks to|
                                        |God. Many have taken the first half of v. 28, “Now if there’s no interpreter, have him remain silent|
                                        |in church,” to mean that there should be no speaking in tongues in church whatsoever unaccompanied by|
                                        |an interpretation. For this reason, Paul added the second half of v. 28 to allow speaking in tongues|
                                        |done without interpretation, as long as it’s done quietly (i.e. <char style="it">to himself</char>).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Many claim that the Bible commands that all speaking in tongues must be followed by an interpretation,|
                                        |but there’s not a single example of a message in tongues followed by an interpretation when one closely|
                                        |examines every instance of speaking in tongues in Acts. In fact, in each of those instances, not only|
                                        |was there no interpretation given, but everyone was speaking in tongues at the same time. None of those|
                                        |who were speaking in tongues in Acts are “outsiders” (see above note), so it’s alright for them all to|
                                        |speak in tongues at the same time since they’ll all be self-edified.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Furthermore, as v. 28 says “…have him remain silent in church…” but also says “…let him speak to himself|
                                        |and to God,” we should infer that what Paul meant by “remain silent in the church” is actually a command|
                                        |to not speak in a loud voice so as to address the congregation rather than a command to not speak at|
                                        |all—otherwise, how can such a person simultaneously remain silent and speak to himself? This observation|
                                        |gains importance later on in this chapter when Paul talks about women keeping silent in church. The same|
                                        |applies in that case for women: he’s not saying that women can’t talk at all in church, rather he’s saying|
                                        |women shouldn’t talk out loud in a way that they address the entire congregation. This observation makes|
                                        |sense, as the problem in the Corinthian church was multiple parties trying to speak to the entire congregation|
                                        |at the same time, talking over top of each other—one speaking to himself or speaking in a subdued voice|
                                        |was not the problem.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the spirits of prophets are subordinate to and take directions from prophets</char>…Regardless|
                                        |of whether prophets have been given the unction from the Holy Spirit to prophecy, the may choose not|
                                        |to, and this is not a slight against the Holy Spirit. This passage insinuates that a prophet will receive|
                                        |such unction but will have to wait his turn to deliver it. Put another way, the Holy Spirit will at times|
                                        |give unctions to multiple people at the same time, but it’s up to them to deliver these messages serially.|
                                        |An unction from the Holy Spirit can be held for a period of time—it doesn’t have to be blurted out the|
                                        |moment it’s received.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to speak</char> <char style="it">aloud</char> <char style="it">addressing the entire|
                                        |congregation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to speak</char>. Ref. note of v. 27 for justification for adding|
                                        |<char style="it">aloud addressing the entire congregation. </char>Paul is not forbidding women to engage|
                                        |in normal conversation while at church; that notion is preposterous.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Continuing on in vv. 35–36, Paul says it’s disgraceful for a woman to speak in church. Paul’s statement|
                                        |“If they want to learn something in particular, let them ask their husbands at home” implies that the|
                                        |women were disrupting the entire church by interrupting the speaker with a question. Not only were they|
                                        |interrupting the speaker, Paul’s remark, “did the word of God issue forth from you (etc),” indicates|
                                        |that their questions did not come from a sincere, humble desire to learn but from a position of arrogance,|
                                        |from a know-it-all attitude. These reasons are why Paul said it was disgraceful for the women (these|
                                        |women) to speak in church.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |But we know that women were permitted to speak in church at that time, since Acts 21:9 mentions four|
                                        |young women who prophesied. In order to prophesy, these women would have to do so in a church setting,|
                                        |and doing so meant that they were addressing the congregation while prophesying. This fourteenth chapter|
                                        |plus the ancient treatise called the <char style="it">Didache </char>indicate that the first century|
                                        |church had prophets stand up and address the congregation in prophesies on a regular basis—something|
                                        |which is radically different than even what Pentecostals do nowadays. I imagine that the four daughters|
                                        |of Acts 21:9 took their turn at the pulpit.|
