     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every ruler, every authority, and every power</char>…An explanation of the Gk. words|
                                        |for positions of authority and the like. The first three correspond to what’s quoted here:|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Ruler [archōn, <char style="w" strong="G00758">ἄρχων</char>)]—When referring to people, the very top|
                                        |of a hierarchy; the one who has the ultimate power over the entire hierarchy. It refers to a person or|
                                        |the people who are at the top of the pyramid, whatever that pyramid may be. It’s translated <char style="it">principalities|
                                        |</char>in Eph. 6:12 (KJV), and in that case does not refer to people but refers to demons, demons who|
                                        |are at the top of some demonic hierarchy. When referring to time, it’s the very start or beginning of|
                                        |an epoch of time, sometimes spoken of abstractly when the start of time isn’t known (John 1:1). The KJV|
                                        |translates this as <char style="it">prince </char>instead of the NASB’s <char style="it">ruler </char>in|
                                        |places such as John 16:11, etc. See below for more on <char style="it">prince</char>.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Authority [eksousia, <char style="w" strong="G01849">ἐξουσία</char>)]—The literal meaning is <char style="it">existing|
                                        |out of. </char>Power which is given to a person to act on behalf of a hierarchy, government, etc. which|
                                        |has the ultimate power. Also, one who’s given the legitimate right to exercise power. Also, the power|
                                        |itself, with the understanding that it was granted in such a way and not simply usurped; the position,|
                                        |the seat itself.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Power [dunamis, <char style="w" strong="G01411">δύναμις</char>)]—The natural, inherent capability to|
                                        |exercise control over others. The ability may or may not be legitimate or have been granted by the government|
                                        |or hierarchy. The word <char style="it">power </char>simply states the capability to exercise power,|
                                        |but does not specify where this ability comes from, whether the power is transferrable, or what the nature|
                                        |of it is; whereas the word <char style="it">authority</char>, while in certain contexts simply refers|
                                        |to power, is, in its essence, power which is derived from the main body; power delegated; legitimate|
                                        |power; non-usurped power. Therefore, dunamis may refer to usurped power or illegitimate power.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Leader [haegemon, <char style="w" strong="G02232">ἡγεμών</char>)]—This has two similar meanings. First|
                                        |is the Latin <char style="it">dux</char>: it’s the one who’s the leader; who takes charge and leads the|
                                        |way for others to follow; the commander, the one who not only makes the decisions everyone follows but|
                                        |is responsible for those decisions, whom everyone relies on to ensure that the decisions are intelligently|
                                        |made. The second is the Latin <char style="it">princeps</char>: the one who does a thing first. The princeps|
                                        |is the person who’s the most eminent, most distinguished, the first person; the leading citizen of the|
                                        |country; the person who’s the best at something and therefore has taken the lead; the person everyone|
                                        |relies on the most to lead the way when facing difficulties. In modern terms, the captain of a sports|
                                        |team is a princeps: the best player, and as the best takes the initiative the most, and as a result of|
                                        |taking the initiative, he’s the one who leads and drives the others to victory.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Dominion [kuriotās, <char style="w" strong="G02963">κυριότης</char>)]—The literal meaning is <char style="it">the|
                                        |nature of lordship</char>. It is “the majestic power that a lord wields, ruling power, lordship, dominion”|
                                        |(Danker &amp; Bauer). The nature of lordship is the assumption that the expected order of things is for|
                                        |there to be a lord and that this lord will rule over others, and that there are guidelines by which this|
                                        |is done, either codified in law or in an unspoken understanding. As this word is derived from <char style="it">lord</char>,|
                                        |it follows that it refers to the powers a lord has and the way that he obtained them. Unlike the word|
                                        |<char style="it">authority, </char>a lord is not a ruler who derives his power from the government, but|
                                        |rather is like the owner of a large private estate, say, somewhere out in a remote rural area. In a feudal|
                                        |system this would include a dukedom or earldom, but a lordship can be much smaller also. Those who live|
                                        |in remote, rural areas are in many respects autonomous from the rest of society, including the government.|
                                        |While the lord rules like an authority (eksousia), his sphere of power doesn’t fall under the authority|
                                        |to another, so within his sphere he’s not answerable to anyone else. As expected, this also refers to|
                                        |a lordship seat which is transferrable, like from father to son, etc.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Throne[(thronos, <char style="w" strong="G02362">θρόνος</char>)]—A ruler whose powers extend to sitting|
                                        |on a judgment seat: arbitrating disputes, acting as a judge in a civil or criminal proceeding; receiving|
                                        |emissaries; forming policy, including do so with the advice of a counsel. The throne is not an ad-hoc|
                                        |judgment seat, but is a persistent seat, passed from person to person. As is apparent, there’s overlap|
                                        |in these terms for rulers.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Pastor/shepherd [poimān, <char style="w" strong="G04166">ποιμήν</char>)]—(Ref. note of 1 Pet. 5:2). This|
                                        |Old Testament word means <char style="it">leader</char>, but the implication is that this person is leading|
                                        |ordinary people (sheep) and not soldiers under his chain of command. The sheep-analogy means that such|
                                        |a leader will have to deal with problems that are eradicated in an army due to the discipline instilled|
                                        |into that army. The problems Moses had to deal with when leading Israel in the wilderness are analogous|
                                        |to a shepherd over sheep. Since poimān has its roots in the Old Testament, the word is only used in conjunction|
                                        |with ecclesiastical leadership.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |To come forward as a leader [proistāmi,<char style="w" strong="G04291">προΐστημι</char>)]—This appears|
                                        |in the NT as a verb but is also used substantively as a noun. It literally means <char style="it">to|
                                        |stand forward</char>, and appears in Rom. 12:8; 1 Thess. 5:12; 1 Tim. 5:17. Danker &amp; Bauer defines|
                                        |it first, “to exercise a position of leadership, rule direct, be at the head of,” and second, “to have|
                                        |an interest in, show concern for, care for, give aid.” There are only three occurrences in the NT and|
                                        |all are in relation to church leadership. |
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Steward [oikonomos, <char style="w" strong="G03623">οἰκονόμος</char>)]—Someone whom a lord (the ruler|
                                        |of a sizeable estate) puts in charge of the affairs of the estate. Luke 12:42; 16:1; Titus 1:7 are examples.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Overseer, bishop [episkopos, <char style="w" strong="G01985">ἐπίσκοπος</char>)]—The Gk. word means “one|
                                        |who visits,” more specifically, “one who checks up on things to ensure that things are in order”; hence|
                                        |the NASB rendering <char style="it">episkopos</char> as <char style="it">overseer</char>. What we nowadays|
                                        |call a “head pastor.” Someone who’s the single individual who’s the head over a congregation. This position|
                                        |didn’t exist in the early days of the church, as the early church was ruled by elder councils, probably|
                                        |imitating the way that synagogues were ruled by elders. Apparently, as Christianity diverged more and|
                                        |more from Judaism, the forms of church government diverged as well, with churches replacing elder councils|
                                        |with bishops. |
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Deacon [diakonos, <char style="w" strong="G01249">διάκονος</char>)]—A deacon is a leader (a poiman) in|
                                        |the church who has oversight over a specific area in the church, but does not have total oversight like|
                                        |a bishop does. Deacons existed in both elder-ruled and bishop-ruled churches. Nowadays, we call a deacon|
                                        |an associate pastor or a ministry director. A deacon is similar to a steward (see how these two words|
                                        |are used together in Col 1:25) but applied to a church context, as the word’s used in the NT. Deacon|
                                        |appears in Rom. 12:7; 1 Cor. 16:15; Eph. 6:21; 1 Tim 3:10.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Slave or servant [doulos, <char style="w" strong="G01401">δοῦλος</char>)]—This word is translated either|
                                        |servant or slave. As slavery was pervasive in the ancient world, most of the times a <char style="it">doulos</char>|
                                        |is a slave, but since the slavery-mindset is absent from us in modern times, we must make distinctions|
                                        |in this word. This word means a servant, a menial servant, one who takes orders and is not entrusted|
                                        |with any significant responsibilities. This word means a slave, someone who’s owned by another person;|
                                        |someone who’s locked into this position; forced servitude. Doulos as appears in the NT can refer to one|
                                        |or multiple of these definitions, and the most appropriate rendering is dictated by context. In the NT,|
                                        |a doulos can be a menial servant without specifically or explicitly referring to someone who’s locked|
                                        |into slavery, i.e. owned by another person. In this respect, a person who’s “locked into” a nine-to-five|
                                        |job is a doulos of a sort, even though he’s not a bona fide slave.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they who are getting themselves baptized as a symbol of their resurrection from the|
                                        |dead</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being baptized </char>[<char style="it">or getting themselves baptized]|
                                        |on behalf of the dead</char>. Translators and commentators are puzzled at the meaning of this. Some guess-work|
                                        |is required. A good explanation from one of the commentators is that an interpolation was intended, one|
                                        |which changes <char style="it">the dead </char>to <char style="it">the resurrection of the dead. </char>Also,|
                                        |the prepositional phrase usually translated <char style="it">on behalf of </char>has been bent from its|
                                        |traditional meaning to mean something that symbolizes something else. Also, the verb <char style="it">to|
                                        |baptize </char>seems to acquire some middle voice usage, but that’s speculative. Those who disagree with|
                                        |these explanations—and there are several good reasons to do so—are welcome to explain how their interpretation|
                                        |makes better sense.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s people</char>…Lit: <char style="it">saints</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Sunday</char>…Lit: <char style="it">first of the Sabbath</char>. As they didn’t have|
                                        |names for the days of the weeks, they referred to each day by how many days past the Sabbath it is.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">doesn’t get to where he’s intimidated by you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">will be fearless|

     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stay focused</char>…Lit: <char style="it">watch</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">crème de la crème of the converts</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a first-fruit</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of Rom. 8:23.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">filled in the pieces that you’re missing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">filled up your|
                                        |lack</char>|

                                        |<char style="it">Greet each with a holy kiss</char>. Liberties taken.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">like the Lord a lot</char>…Lit: <char style="it">love</char> [<char style="it">phileo</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">the Lord</char>. Note the Gk. word <char style="it">phileō </char><char style="w" strong="G05368">φιλέω</char>)|
                                        |is used and not <char style="it">agapaō </char><char style="w" strong="G00025">ἀγαπάω</char>)<char style="it">.|
                                        |</char>Ref. note of Matt. 10:37.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">an issue of respect</char> …Lit: <char style="it">worthy</char>. Same word used similarly|
                                        |in Rom. 16:2. Guessing that Paul was referring to the respect the Jewish believers in Jerusalem would|
                                        |give to Gentile couriers—although this is very much a guess on my part.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">send me on my way</char> <char style="it">refreshed and prepared for the journey</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">send me forth</char>. Based on the usage in the NT of the Gk. word for <char style="it">forth-send|
                                        |</char>(Acts. 15:3, 20:38, 21:5; Rom. 15:24; 1 Cor. 16:11; 2 Cor. 1:16; Titus 3:13; 3 John 1:6), the|
                                        |word appears to have an meaning beyond what its roots suggest of simply sending someone forth. Additionally,|
                                        |it appears to mean, “sending someone on a journey prepared for that journey; sending someone away one|
                                        |good terms after they’ve spent a long with you; sending someone away with sorrow at seeing them go, with|
                                        |gladness of the work they’ll do; sending someone out to accomplish a mission; sending someone with your|
                                        |support and blessings; recommending a person sent to the next party which will receive him.”|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by God’s will, and his fellow comrade Timothy—|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the church of God that is in Corinth, joined by the saints (i.e., God’s people) who are all over Achaia:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Give praise to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Originator of all sorts of compassion|
     v 3                                |and of advice, encouragement, and consolation, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which consoles, etc. us in all of our distresses, resulting in our ability to console those in all kinds|
     v 4                                |of distresses with the same consolation with which we’re being consoled by God. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just as Christ’s sufferings proliferate to us, in the same way through Christ the consolation we receive|
     v 5                                |proliferates as well. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Whether we’re being pressured, it’s for the sake of your consolation and salvation (i.e., your being|
     v 6                                |rescued from spiritual, moral, mental, and physical calamity); whether we’re being consoled, it’s for|
     v 6                                |the sake of your consolation, a consolation which is accomplished by enduring the same sufferings which|
     v 6                                |we too suffer. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the hope which we have for you—our hope is firm, fixed in the observation that as you are joint participants|
     v 7                                |of the sufferings which we suffer, in the same way you are joint participants of the consolation as well.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard, we don’t want you to be left in the dark, comrades, about the extreme difficulties we|
     v 8                                |experienced in the Roman province of Asia, that we were overloaded and overwhelmed to the point that|
     v 8                                |we lost the will to live. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Anyways, deep inside ourselves we concluded that we were doomed to die, so we reached the point where|
     v 9                                |we couldn’t be convinced that our own abilities would save us, but were convinced that the God who raises|
     v 9                                |the dead would do so instead: |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He Who rescued us from a narrow brush with death—and rescues us continuously—we set our hope in Him that|
     v10                                |He’ll rescue us yet again, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |while you too were joining in lending a helping hand by the prayers that you prayed for us, so that the|
     v11                                |outcome of the stances, disposition, and full attention of many people is that the mercy and kindness|
     v11                                |shown to us would be thanked by many on our behalf.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, our proud talk and bold claims are on par with the solemn declaration of our conscience, since|
     v12                                |the lifestyle we led in the world (i.e., among those who aren’t believers) was by God’s simplicity and|
     v12                                |sincerity, not by the wisdom of flesh (i.e., by the cunning shrewdness of our own ability apart from|
     v12                                |God tainted by the carnal nature) but by God’s grace instead—and that lifestyle was all the more so with|
     v12                                |you. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact we’re writing to you nothing other than what you’re reading to the congregation or what you’re|
     v13                                |coming to understand, but I hope that you continue to gain an exact understanding until it’s all said|
     v13                                |and done, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just as you also gained an understanding of us, at least partially, that we are the reason for your proud|
     v14                                |talk and bold claims just as you too will be ours in the Day of the Lord Jesus (i.e., when he’s revealed|
     v14                                |in the fullness of his might).|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We formed a long-term desire for this, for what we’ve reached the point where we’re convinced is the|
     v15                                |thing that we want to do more than anything else, namely to go visit you, so that you would get a second|
     v15                                |grace (i.e., a second impartation of our face-to-face ministry), |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to continue on our journey through your city to Macedonia, to resume the journey going from Macedonia|
     v16                                |back to your city again, and to be sent forth by you (i.e., depart fully rested, provisioned, and in|
     v16                                |good spirits—all on account of the your generosity and hospitality) to the Jews in Judea.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, was this plan treated with a nonchalant thought-process? Or what I’m planning, I’m planning|
     v17                                |according to flesh (i.e., from my own self apart from God, according to my own needs, and somewhat tainted|
     v17                                |to feed my carnal appetite), so that it would be “the yes-yes and the no-no” with me (i.e., I’d vacillate|
     v17                                |or renege on what I planned or promised to do)? |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But—by God—trust me that the statements we made to you aren’t “the yes-yes and the no-no.” |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, God’s son Jesus Christ, who through us has been preached among you—through me, Siloam,|
     v19                                |and Timothy—hasn’t wound up being “the yes-yes and the no-no,” but rather has wound up being “yes” in|
     v19                                |him. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For as many promises as there are from God, in him they are all “yes” (i.e., no vacillating or reneging|
     v20                                |on them), and in light of this through him is also the Amen (i.e., the acknowledgement of the finality|
     v20                                |of a matter; the familiar profession to God of “Let it be so”) to God with glory through us. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God’s establishing us together with you in Christ and anointed us. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He also stamped us with His seal of approval and gave us the down payment of the Spirit in our hearts.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I swear to God—cross my heart and hope to die—that it was to spare you that I no longer went to Corinth—|
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not that we act in a domineering manner towards you of the Faith—no—we work together as helpers of your|
     v24                                |grace: for you have stood by faith.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Originator</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Father</char>. This has a dual meaning: both|
                                        |God the Father and Someone who creates.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all sorts of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all</char>. A figure of speech. Use of the|
                                        |word <char style="it">all </char>figuratively also occurs 1 Tim. 6:10.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">distresses</char>…Also: <char style="it">tribulations</char>; <char style="it">extremely|
                                        |difficult circumstances</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">we concluded that we were doomed to die</char>…Lit: <char style="it">we had the sentence</char>|
                                        |[or <char style="it">diagnosis</char>] <char style="it">of death. </char>Appears to be an expression|
                                        |or idiom.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">from a narrow brush with death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">out of a great death</char>.|
                                        |Appears to be an expression.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the outcome of the stances, disposition, and full attention of many people</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">out of many faces</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">proud talk and bold claims</char>…Lit: <char style="it">boasting</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">until it’s all said and done</char>…Lit: <char style="it">until</char> [<char style="it">the</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">end</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by God—trust me</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God</char> [<char style="it">be</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">faithful</char>. This appears to be an idiom.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I swear to God—cross my heart and hope to die</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I call upon|
                                        |witness-God upon my soul</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">work together as helpers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fellow workers</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stamped us with His seal of approval</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sealed us. </char>Seals|
                                        |were used in ancient times the same way they are today, howbeit for the occasional different application.|
                                        |A messenger who was assigned the task of delivering a papyrus scroll with a message written on it to|
                                        |a remote destination was handed a scroll which was sealed. The sealing more than likely was a hot wax|
                                        |dripped across the overlapping edges of the scroll, so that when the wax cooled and hardened, the scroll|
                                        |couldn’t be opened and read without irreparably breaking the wax seal—similar to how an envelope, once|
                                        |opened, cannot be closed again and how, if it was opened, it would be apparent. In addition, the wax,|
                                        |while still hot, was stamped with a stamp or a signet ring which had a detailed image etched into it|
                                        |which became imprinted into the wax, so that the cooled wax retained this image. The receiver would inspect|
                                        |the image to make sure it was genuine, as only a limited set of stamps or signet rings would be made.|
                                        |The receiver would be ensured that the document was genuine, not a forgery from an imposter, as a potential|
                                        |imposter, though capable of writing a forgery, could not (at least easily) make a duplicate of the stamp|
                                        |or signet ring.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |So now, as Paul uses the word <char style="it">seal</char> a few times in his epistles, what he’s referring|
                                        |to is this:|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |1. God has placed his stamp of approval on something|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |2. The thing God stamped is genuine, valuable, and special|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |3. Any third party, someone other than God the stamper and the person being sealed, upon examination|
                                        |will be able to recognize that such a stamp is indeed from God|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">down payment</char>…Also: <char style="it">collateral</char>…Lit: <char style="it">surety;|
                                        |pledge. </char>As seen in the OT (one example is Prov. 6:1–5), loans were secured with collateral, so|
                                        |a person who needed to borrow a small amount of cash for a day or two could leave his cloak with the|
                                        |person who lends him the money as collateral. Now on a few occasions Paul in his epistles states that|
                                        |the Holy Spirit is given to us like collateral for a loan. What he means is:|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |1. God hands us something immediately with the promise He’ll “repay” us with something greater in the|
                                        |future. In other words, the Holy Spirit is God’s guarantee to us that He’ll give us something greater|
                                        |in the future|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |2. The Holy Spirit is something we get to hold onto and make use of in the meantime|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |3. The Holy Spirit will never—can never—be taken away from us, as he is “surety”|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Getting to the point, I made up my mind that I wouldn’t visit you again while laden with the pains of|
     v 1                                |sorrow. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, if I’m making you feel sorry, who in particular will cheer me up apart from the one I made feel|
     v 2                                |sorry? |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The very thing I wrote, I wrote so that I wouldn’t come for a visit and wind up being made sorry by the|
     v 3                                |ones I ought to rejoice over, as my nearness to you all has convinced me that my joy is derived from|
     v 3                                |you all. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, what I wrote to you through many tears came out of a great deal of distress and heart-felt anguish,|
     v 4                                |not so that it would cause you sorrow, but so that you’d understand the abundant love which I have for|
     v 4                                |you.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a certain person has caused sorrow, he hasn’t caused me sorrow (actually no, he has partially), so|
     v 5                                |I won’t dump any more of this on you all. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The very punishment inflicted by the many is enough for such a person, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that on the flip-side, you should be all the more kind and merciful to him and comfort and encourage|
     v 7                                |him, so that such a person not somehow be deluged with even more sorrow. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this I advise you to broadcast love to him. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, another reason I wrote is so that I could discern if you live up to my standards, that is if|
     v 9                                |you obey everything you’re told. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if you forgive somebody of something, so do I; you see, if in addition to you I forgave somebody|
     v10                                |of something, what I’ve forgiven (assuming there’s something I’m forgiving), I did so through you under|
     v10                                |the scrutiny of Christ, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that we won’t be swindled by Satan: we are not ignorant of his intentions, you see.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now that I’ve arrived at Troas for the purpose of spreading the Gospel of Christ (i.e., the good news|
     v12                                |about Christ), a door has been opened to me in the Lord (i.e., in regard to the things of the Lord, a|
     v12                                |tremendous opportunity has presented itself to me), |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I was uncomfortable in my spirit not finding my fellow-comrade Titus, so instead I excused myself, said|
     v13                                |goodbye to them, and left for Macedonia.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But thank-you God, Who always makes us roadies on Christ’s victory tour, and Who’s propagating the fragrance|
     v14                                |of his knowledge through us in all regions, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since in God we are a pleasant aroma (like the incense they burned in the Old Testament, or the pleasing|
     v15                                |smell of a burnt offering) of Christ among those being saved (i.e., those being rescued from calamity)|
     v15                                |and among those perishing; |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |we who on the one hand are a whiff of going from death to even more death, and on the other hand are|
     v16                                |a whiff of going from life to even more life—and that’s not good enough for some people? |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we’re not like so many other preachers who hustle the word of God—no—we preach the Gospel like|
     v17                                |it’s coming from someone who’s sincere through-and-through—no—we speak the word of God in Christ like|
     v17                                |it’s coming directly from God while we stand before God.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wind up being made sorry</char>…Lit: <char style="it">have sorrow</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">dump</char>…<char style="it">on you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">burden you</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">broadcast</char>…Lit: <char style="it">preach</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">under the scrutiny of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the face of</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I was uncomfortable</char>…Also: <char style="it">I remained ill at ease</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">my fellow-comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">my brother</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fragrance of his knowledge</char>…A well-crafted metaphor, one which is continued in|
                                        |the next couple of verses|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pleasant</char>…Or<char style="it">: sweet-smelling</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hustle</char>…The meaning of this Gk. word is “trade in, peddle, huckster.” It refers|
                                        |to “the tricks of small tradesmen,” so “…the word almost comes to mean <char style="it">adulterate” </char>(Danker|
                                        |&amp; Bauer).|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">like it’s coming from someone who’s sincere through-and-through</char>…Lit: <char style="it">as|
                                        |out of sincerity</char>. An idiom.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">we speak the word of God in Christ like it’s coming directly from God while we stand|
                                        |before God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">as from out of God before God in Christ we speak</char>. Same|
                                        |idiom as before.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">makes us roadies on Christ’s victory tour</char>…Or: <char style="it">leads us around|
                                        |in a triumphal procession in Christ</char>. Some liberties taken. The single Gk. word used here refers|
                                        |to the following: In Roman times, generals returned from a battlefield victory in a procession and led|
                                        |the procession through the capitol. The triumphal general and his lieutenants formed the vanguard of|
                                        |the procession; those in the defeated enemy’s army, including women and children, were bound and formed|
                                        |the rear of the procession, being led to the city to be sold as slaves. The analogy is that we are a|
                                        |part of the procession, though I prefer to believe that we’re part of the vanguard and not the rear,|
                                        |but that’s open to debate.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a whiff of going from death to even more death</char>…<char style="it">from life to|
                                        |even more life</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a smell out of death unto death</char>…<char style="it">out|
                                        |of life unto life</char>. Same Gk. wording as is used in in Paul’s statement <char style="it">from faith|
                                        |to faith </char>(Rom. 1:17), as this is the same expression. Similar to the English usage of <char style="it">whiff,|
                                        |</char>the usage here means <char style="it">a living example; a glimpse</char>. Paul’s life and his|
                                        |companions’ lives exemplify a life of death and, even more, of life and even more life. Paul goes into|
                                        |detail about the death he’s referring to in the eleventh and twelfth chapters; but in the midst of this|
                                        |Paul experiences more and more of the life of God.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Are my comrades and I starting over again in doing self-promotion to bolster your opinion of us? Put|
     v 1                                |another way, we’re not in need of letters of recommendation to be sent to you or to be received from|
     v 1                                |you, like some people do, are we? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You are our letter of recommendation, written in our hearts, understood and read by all people. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s plain for all to see that you are a letter of Christ transcribed and delivered by us; not written|
     v 3                                |with ink, but with the Spirit of the Living God; not written in stone but written in a flesh-heart.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re convinced that we have such a thing through Christ with God— |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that we’re up-to-par in and of ourselves to where we figure that something in particular which is|
     v 5                                |good was self-generated, but rather that our adequacy comes out of God, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who also made us up-to-par ministers of a new covenant, not of the letter (i.e., the literal, exacting|
     v 6                                |listing of rules, compliance with those rules, and consequences for breaking them) but of the Spirit:|
     v 6                                |for the letter kills, but the Spirit causes things to spring into life.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if the administering of death, which was packaged in letters etched in stone, occurred in glory to|
     v 7                                |the point that it wasn’t possible for the run-of-the-mill Israelite to gaze at Moses’s face because of|
     v 7                                |the glory of his face—a glory that was deteriorating no less— |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |how much more will the administering of the Spirit be accompanied by glory? |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, if there was glory in the administering of condemnation, how much more does the administering|
     v 9                                |of righteousness exceed it in glory? |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And furthermore, that which has been made glorious hasn’t been made glorious relative to the glory which|
     v10                                |surpasses it. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, if the glory which has been nullified has been nullified by glory, the glory which remains does|
     v11                                |so all the more in glory.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So having such hope, in our outspokenness and boldness we conceal nothing, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |unlike Moses who placed a veil over his face so that the run-of-the-mill Israelites couldn’t gaze at|
     v13                                |the vestige of the glory that was deteriorating— |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not a chance—their minds were dead-set against it. In fact to this very day the same veil remains uncovered|
     v14                                |at the reading of the Old Testament, since it’s done away with in Christ. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No—to this day whenever the Old Testament happens to be read aloud a veil lies over their heart, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but, if they were to turn to the Lord, the moment they do so, the veil gets taken off.|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">demolished</char>…Lit: <char style="it">completely broken into pieces</char>. The word|
                                        |describes breaking a stone edifice apart, as it’s the same root word Jesus used to describe the dispersal|
                                        |of the stones of the Temple.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">way up in the sky</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the heavens</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">our home—our cozy cottage</char>…The Gk. word here is a diminutive form of <char style="it">house</char>,|
                                        |and as such acquires a connotation of coziness|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">encumbered</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weighed down</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">down payment</char>…Ref. note of 1:22|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">making yourself at home in the body will leave you far from home</char>…Lit (inserting|

                                        |style="it">in the body ekdāmoumen </char><char style="w" strong="G01553">ἐκδημέω</char>). These two Gk.|
                                        |words forms a rhyme, assonance, or pun, making this a figure of speech.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">go about our lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">walk around</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">manifest</char>…The same Gk. verb is rendered <char style="it">appear</char> in v. 10,|
                                        |and assuming that the reuse in v. 11 here links the two thoughts together, then what Paul means by “manifest”|
                                        |in v. 11 is similar to its usage in v. 10, i.e. of appearing before a judge to have your deeds reviewed|
                                        |and judged.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Not that we’re trying to promote ourselves again</char>…Same wording as 3:1|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in everyone’s place</char>…Also: <char style="it">on everyone’s behalf</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">come and gone</char>…Lit: <char style="it">passed by</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not holding all the times they crossed over the line in doing wrong as strikes against|
                                        |them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">not reckoning their trespasses to them</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was made</char>…Lit: <char style="it">made</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">If we really have put on</char> <char style="it">our eternal building …</char>Or: <char|
                                        |style="it">If we really have shed our clothing</char>….The UBS Greek NT, 3<char style="sup">rd</char>|
                                        |Edition reads<char style="it"> shed our clothing</char> (also, <char style="it">undressed </char>or <char|
                                        |style="it">stripped naked</char>);<char style="it"> </char>the photocopies of both Codex Vaticanus and|
                                        |Codex Sinaiticus read <char style="it">put on </char>instead (and a translation of the Latin Vulgate|
                                        |agrees), therefore most of the translators render this <char style="it">put on </char>and not <char style="it">undressed.|
                                        |</char>One can only speculate if the UBS made a mistake here or if they changed the reading based on|
                                        |“internal” considerations and didn’t footnote with a citation of the various manuscripts. The UBS reading|
                                        |makes sense: assuming such a reading, the “undressing” referred to would be the same as “if our Earth-suit|
                                        |were to be demolished” (v. 1). When the physical body is destroyed, we’ll be clothed with a heavenly|
                                        |body, rather than being “found naked.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the new has come into being</char>…The KJV says “all things are become new.” The words|
                                        |“all things” are not found in the better manuscripts.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">righteous of a nature of God’s righteousness</char>…Lit: [<char style="it">a</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">righteousness of God</char>. Noteworthy is that, in the GT, there’s no definite article|
                                        |preceding <char style="it">righteousness. </char>This verse does not say we would become the righteousness|
                                        |of God (insertion of definite article before <char style="it">righteous</char>), but that we would become|
                                        |righteous in a way that our righteousness is of the same nature as God’s righteousness. This is a far|
                                        |cry from becoming equivalent to God in His righteousness—which is an absurd proposition.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So having these promises I quoted just now, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all defilement of|

     v 3                                |lives, until death do us part. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s a lot for me to be blunt with you, a lot for me to talk about you with pride. I’ve reached the point|
     v 4                                |where I’m full of encouragement and comfort; I’m way overjoyed every time we’re faced with a really bad|
     v 4                                |situation.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, not once after arriving in Macedonia did our weary bodies get a chance to rest, uh-uh…all kinds|
     v 5                                |of pressure…on the outside we faced conflict, on the inside fear. |

     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not just by him showing up, but by the encouragement, comfort, and advise he showered on us, relaying|
     v 7                                |to us your longing, your grieving, your fervency you have regarding me, resulting in it giving me all|
     v 7                                |the more joy.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Even if I hurt you by what I put in the previous letter, I have no regrets; even if I had regrets (for|
     v 8                                |I see that that letter did cause you pain for some time), |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m glad now, not because you were simply hurt, but rather that the pain that you suffered resulted in|
     v 9                                |a change of heart and of actions. In fact, you were hurt God’s way, so you suffered no loss in any area|
     v 9                                |of your life. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, being hurt (hurt intentionally in a way that you suffer pain) God’s way effects a change of|
     v10                                |heart and actions working towards the end goal of dodging a bullet and having no regrets about what had|
     v10                                |to be done to accomplish that; the pain that the world (i.e., those outside of Christ) experiences works|
     v10                                |in a way that, when it’s run its course, results in death (i.e., a stagnation of waste, joylessness,|
     v10                                |futility, destruction, and ultimately physical death).|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While I’m on this topic, this very thing—being hurt God’s way—look how much it accomplished in you and|
     v11                                |what a priority you made it. From where you were instead is a rebuttal—instead you have indignation,|
     v11                                |fear, longing, fervency, and self-vindication. In everything you demonstrated to everyone that you’re|
     v11                                |cleared of these matters. |

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bread for the food that you eat</char>…Lit: <char style="it">bread for food</char>.|
                                        |the majority of one’s calories were derived from eating bread in ancient times. In the context of the|
                                        |writing of this epistle, therefore, bread was what people survived on (ref. Matt. 6:11). So saying that|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I, Paul, through the gentle restraint and kindness of Christ, who, when I was here on Earth face-to-face|
     v 1                                |with you was humble indeed, but audacious when away from you, beg you personally— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but with the infusion of audacity which comes from not being present—I ask with confidence, which I figure|
     v 2                                |makes me brash enough to confront some people who suppose that we live day in, day out according to the|
     v 2                                |flesh (i.e. of our own ability apart from God; as though God doesn’t work through us). |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, though living day in, day out in flesh (i.e., in a physical body, one subject to human weaknesses),|
     v 3                                |we don’t wage war according to the flesh: |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |our battle-gear isn’t fleshly (i.e., of a physical nature; of our own ability apart from God)—uh-uh,|
     v 4                                |it’s quite capable in God of leveling heavily-fortified defenses—leveling schemes, machinations, detailed|
     v 4                                |plans, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and every erected fortification or entrenched high-ground which opposes the knowledge and understanding|
     v 5                                |of God, and capturing every thought and making it a prisoner of the obedience of Christ, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and of being prepared to avenge every disobedience, when your obedience happens to reach the tipping|

 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the person who promotes himself—that’s not the individual who obtains the approval of God, rather|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 11  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If you would bear with me a bit while I act stupid—scratch that: you are bearing with me. |

     v 3                                |ulterior motives, hidden agendas, or religious quid-pro-quo) and the purity which has Christ as its goal.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For indeed, if a passerby stops over and preaches that another person is the real Jesus, a person whom|

     v 6                                |amateur when it comes to knowledge and understanding—no—I’ve made that apparent to you in every possible|

 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Is it that I committed a sin in humbling and debasing myself so that you would be made to stand on two|

     v 7                                |to you free of charge? |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Scratch that—I robbed other churches by drawing a wage from them and applying it to your ministry. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not only that, when I was staying with you and was in need, I wasn’t a burden to anyone: the comrades|
     v 9                                |who came from Macedonia provided what I needed. My living expenses weren’t a burden in any way to you,|
     v 9                                |nor will they be. |

                                        |<char style="it">to be boasting</char>|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mourn much…</char>Ref. Matt. 5:4; 1 Cor. 5:2|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the third heaven</char>…The ancients had a different view of the universe than we do,|
                                        |and they assumed that the spiritual world, which includes heaven itself, is simply a layer on top of|
                                        |another layer. So the Gk. word<char style="it"> </char>for <char style="it">heaven </char>conflates a|
                                        |couple of concepts we do not. The first of the “heavens” is the sky above. The second heaven-layer, being|
                                        |above that of course, is where the sun, the moon, and the stars exist. We call it outer-space, but they|
                                        |assumed that these astronomical objects were closer to the earth than they actually are. They assumed|
                                        |that the sun travelled across the sky each day in the second “heaven.” So the third heaven is the layer|
                                        |above the second, but since the second includes all physical objects (and from our perspective extends|
                                        |to the far reaches of the universe), the third layer steps into the spirit-world. Now, is this spirit-world|
                                        |heaven as we know it? Paul calls it <char style="it">paradise </char>in v.4, so it may be. Ref. notes|
                                        |of John 3:3; 1 Pet. 1:5.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">be lifted up and over</char>…This is rendered word-for-word. It’s used as a metaphor.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |”<char style="it">thorn in the flesh</char>”…This is an idiom from the OT, appearing in Num. 23:55; Josh.|
                                        |23:13; Judg. 2:3; Ezek. 28:24. Since it is an idiom, it should not be taken literally; and indeed, it|
                                        |is not used literally in any of the aforementioned references. This idiom was originally used to describe|
                                        |the vexation which came from the enemy nations which surrounded Israel. In fact, Paul goes on to state|
                                        |exactly what this idiom refers to in an appositive phrase a few words after: it is an “agent of Satan.”|
                                        |Furthermore, this verse doesn’t say that God gave Paul a thorn in the flesh, rather the passive voice|
                                        |of “was given” is used, thereby not specifying the subject, the one doing the giving.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">weakness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">asthenia</char> (the Gk. word for <char style="it">weakness</char>).<char|
                                        |style="it"> Asthenia </char><char style="w" strong="G00769">ἀσθένεια</char>)at times means sickness (Luke|
                                        |10:9 for example), but at other times means weakness as the English word suggests. When asthenia is used|
                                        |to mean sickness, it refers to a prolonged, undiagnosed ailment which lasts for a long time and causes|
                                        |a person to become weak. The context determines whether this refers to a physical ailment or not. In|
                                        |addition, asthenia is used a few times starting from the 10<char style="sup">th</char> chapter until|
                                        |this verse, and nowhere in those occurrences does it conclusively refer to a sickness of some sort. To|
                                        |cap it off, v. 10 says “for when I’m weak,” where “weak” summarizes the words before it, which are “insults,|
                                        |dire need, persecutions, and circumstances of distress”—none of which are a sickness of any sort. This|
                                        |implies that the insults, dire need, persecutions, and circumstances of distress are Paul’s weakness.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the defining characteristics of an apostle</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the signs of|
                                        |an apostle</char>. Although this translation often renders <char style="it">apostle </char>as <char style="it">missionary</char>,|
                                        |the complete definition of an apostle also includes what Paul says here, namely that a true apostle performs|
                                        |signs and wonders. Likewise, to be considered an evangelist according to the strictest biblical definition,|
                                        |one must perform miracles, healings, or something of a supernatural nature. This is because Philip (Acts|
                                        |21:8) is the only evangelist that the NT identifies by name, so his example must serve as the archetype|
                                        |for all evangelists. In other words, since Philip performed miracles, and Philip is the only evangelist|
                                        |in the Bible, all evangelists must perform miracles in order to conform to the strictest definition laid|
                                        |down by Acts 21.|
