  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From the Apostle (i.e., missionary; pioneer of new churches; worker of miracles) Paul, who’s not an apostle|
     v 1                                |created from human agency nor an apostle who exists through human agency but through Jesus Christ and|
     v 1                                |God, the Father Who raised him from the dead, |
   N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and from those who are together with me—not just physically but are joint participants in my endeavors—namely|
     v 2                                |all of the comrades:|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the churches of Galatia:|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave his own self for our sins, and gave himself so he could yank us out of this evil day-and-age|
     v 4                                |we live in, according to the will of our God and Father: |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to Him be the glory forever and ever (and let us pause a moment for that to sink in):|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m astounded that you’re setting aside and replacing the Gospel (i.e., the good-news message we preach)|
     v 6                                |which came from the One Who called us (i.e., summoned us to believe) by the grace of Christ in exchange|
     v 6                                |for another so-called gospel— |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not that there’s another gospel to be had—but I’m astounded at how this could possibly happen except|
     v 7                                |for the fact that there are certain individuals among you who are trouble-makers, wanting to distort|
     v 7                                |the Gospel, the message of what Christ did. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Never mind that for a moment: if even we or an angel who came down from heaven were to evangelize to|
     v 8                                |you something different than what we evangelized to you, let him be accursed. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I said it before and I’ll say it again: if someone evangelizes you with something different than what|
     v 9                                |you received and took to heart already, let him be accursed.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, am I trying to win people or God over to my side now? Or am I just trying to please people?|
     v10                                |If I was still going about pleasing people, I wouldn’t be a slave of Christ.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just to let you know, comrades, the Gospel which was evangelized by me: it’s not a man-made contrivance,|
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor were we taught it by anyone, but rather we were taught it through a Jesus Christ-revelation.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, you heard about the way I used to live back then when I lived as a strict Jew, that I was caught|
     v13                                |up in persecuting God’s church to an inordinate degree and in wreaking havoc on it, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and I was getting deeper and deeper into the stricter practices of Judaism, well beyond many of my peers,|
     v14                                |as I had become even more fanatical about all the man-made rules and regulations that were passed down|
     v14                                |to me from my ancestors. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But when God, Who set me apart from the time I was in my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,|
     v15                                |was pleased |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to reveal His son in me so I’d evangelize him to the Gentiles, I didn’t drop everything I was doing and|
     v16                                |see what the experts had to say about it, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor did I go down to Jerusalem to secure the approval of the founding apostles, who are my superiors|
     v17                                |by default, but went over to Arabia instead and returned to Damascus.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then after three years I went down to Jerusalem to visit Peter and stayed with him for fifteen days.|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I didn’t see the other apostles except for the Lord’s brother James. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |(What I’m writing here for you—look—I swear to God I’m not lying.) |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then I went to the districts of Syria and Cilicia. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I had no direct interaction or encounter with the special assemblies of Judea who are in Christ,|
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the only information they had about me was that they kept hearing that the guy who was persecuting|
     v23                                |them before is now evangelizing the Faith which he was wreaking havoc on, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and they glorified the God who is with me.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">worker of miracles</char>…Ref. 2 Cor. 12:12|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and let us pause a moment for that to sink in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">amen. </char>Ref.|
                                        |note of Rev. 19:4.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">man-made contrivance</char>…Lit: <char style="it">according to man</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">deeper and deeper</char>…Lit: <char style="it">more advanced</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">see what the experts had to say about it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">consult with flesh|
                                        |and blood</char>. <char style="it">Flesh and blood</char> is a NT idiom (ref. Matt. 16:17; 1 Cor. 15:50),|
                                        |and it refers to the best that human reasoning, ability, etc. can bring to bear on the issue at hand.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">down</char>…Lit: <char style="it">up</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">had no direct interaction or encounter with</char>…Lit: <char style="it">was unknown|
                                        |to the face</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">special assemblies</char>…Lit: <char style="it">churches</char>. Using the literal meaning|
                                        |of <char style="it">church, </char>which is those who are called out, as Paul seems to think there are|
                                        |other “special congregations” of those who aren’t believers in Christ.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the founding apostles…</char>Lit: <char style="it">those who were apostles before me</char>.|
                                        |In ancient Jewish culture, the default leadership structure was one of seniority, hence the elders of|
                                        |the Sanhedrin. In keeping with this, the original apostles would outrank Paul in seniority, and by this|
                                        |human reasoning, Paul should’ve submitted to them. But that wasn’t God’s plan.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then after spending fourteen years away, I went back down to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking Titus along|
     v 1                                |as well. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I went down there to discuss my conformance to a revelation, and laid out in front of them the glad-tidings|
     v 2                                |message—the Gospel—which I preach among the Gentiles. But I submitted this in private to those who’re|
     v 2                                |considered to be the leading figures of the movement, lest somehow all of this be a huge waste of time|
     v 2                                |on my part—and has been all along. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No, uh-uh—not even my companion Titus was required to be circumcised (the act of circumcision being the|
     v 3                                |initiation rite whereby one adopts Judaism as his own religion and begins following its myriad rules|
     v 3                                |and traditions), seeing that he’s Greek (i.e., a Westerner, far from being Jewish).|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But because of the bogus comrades who infiltrated our movement, those in particular who slipped in under|
     v 4                                |the radar to gain intelligence about the freedom which we possess in Christ Jesus, those whose aim is|
     v 4                                |to enslave us— |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We didn’t knuckle under to them for even a moment, so that the truth of the Gospel remain in effect with|
     v 5                                |us. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the decision from those who are considered to be of some importance—just how important they were|
     v 6                                |makes no difference to me: God doesn’t give a hoot about a person’s status, outward appearance, or public|
     v 6                                |persona—in fact, the important people don’t score any points with me simply because they’re “important”…|
 + N V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—Enough of that.|
 +P  V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On the contrary seeing that I had been entrusted with the Gospel of uncircumcision (i.e., the glad-tidings|
     v 7                                |message that one can come to God through Christ as a Gentile without converting to Judaism and without|
     v 7                                |following the Jewish rules and traditions) just as Peter was entrusted with the Gospel of circumcision|
     v 7                                |(i.e., the glad-tidings message to the Jews that the Messiah promised by the Old Testament has come in|
     v 7                                |the person of Jesus Christ), |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and in this regard he who’s been active in Peter for him to be an apostle of the circumcised is also|
     v 8                                |active for me to be the same to the Gentiles. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Recognizing and understanding the grace (i.e., the special gift and calling given to me, and not earned|
     v 9                                |by me) that was given to me, James, Peter, and John (those considered to be the key players and head|
     v 9                                |honchos) were in total agreement with us giving their unequivocal endorsement and full support to me|
     v 9                                |and Barnabas, so that we would continue as apostles to the Gentile and they to the circumcised (i.e.,|
     v 9                                |the Jews). |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They only asked that we remember the poor, the very same thing I too had been eager to get done.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now when Peter came to Antioch, I confronted him point-blank because he was in the wrong. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, prior to when select individuals from the churches under James’s authority arrived, he partook|
     v12                                |of meals with the Gentiles, but when they arrived, he withdrew from the Gentiles and kept himself at|
     v12                                |a distance from them, fearing those from the circumcision (i.e., those who believe that one must obey|
     v12                                |the Law of Moses and adopt Jewish rules and restrictions in order to be accepted by God; those who say|
     v12                                |that believing in Christ but not following the Law is not acceptable to God). |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The other Jews joined him in his hypocrisy, so that even Barnabas was caught up in the hypocrisy…|
 + N V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—Not a chance.|
 +P  V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I saw that he was disingenuous about the truth of the Gospel, I told Peter in front of everybody,|
     v14                                |“If you being a Jew live as a Gentile and not as a Jew, how can you get away with requiring that the|
     v14                                |Gentiles be Jewish?”|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”We ourselves are Jews by nature and not sinners from far-away, Gentile nations, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having reached the point where we know for certain that a person isn’t justified (i.e., God examining|
     v16                                |a person’s righteousness like a judge would and declaring them to be righteous) as a result of works|
     v16                                |of law (i.e., obeying the commandments of the Law of Moses, or following the do’s and don’ts of any godly|
     v16                                |list of rules for that matter) if it happens to not be through Christ Jesus-faith. We believed in Christ|
     v16                                |Jesus so that we would be justified as a result of Christ-faith and not as a result of works of law,|
     v16                                |since all flesh (i.e., any human endeavor and all human effort apart from God) won’t be justified as|
     v16                                |a result of works of law. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if in the process of seeking justification in Christ, it’s been determined that even we are sinners,|
     v17                                |you can’t seriously believe that Christ has been delegated the responsibility of caring for and promoting|
     v17                                |sin?—No way.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”Furthermore, if I rebuild the things that I demolished, I demonstrate conclusively that I’m a transgressor.|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, because of law I died to law (i.e., because of the failure in trying to live up to the requirements|
     v19                                |of the Law of Moses—which can be said of any set of rules and not just the Law of Moses—and thereby earning|
     v19                                |righteousness, I ceased all attempts and completely severed myself from earning righteousness through|
     v19                                |the Law), so that I would live to God. I’ve been crucified in unison, in joint participation, with Christ;|
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. What I now live in flesh (i.e., in my physical body, with my|
     v20                                |human ability, and in contention with my carnal nature), I live by faith for the son of God who loved|
     v20                                |me and gave himself for me. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m not nullifying the grace of God: if one is justified through law, Christ really did die for nothing.“|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all of this be a huge waste of time on my part</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I am running|
                                        |in vain</char>. An expression.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bogus comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">false brothers</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">knuckle under</char>…Lit: <char style="it">yield in subjection; yield meekly</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for even a moment</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with an hour</char>. Ref. note of Matt.|
                                        |26:40.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God doesn’t give a hoot about a person’s status, outward appearance, or public persona</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">God doesn’t receive</char> [<char style="it">take to heart</char>] <char style="it">the|
                                        |face of a man</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">key players and head honchos</char>…Lit: <char style="it">pillars</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">were in total agreement with us giving their unequivocal endorsement and full support</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">gave their right hand of fellowship</char>. An idiom.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">caught up</char>…Lit<char style="it">: lead away with them</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">how can you get away with</char>…Lit: <char style="it">how do you</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">no way</char>…Lit: <char style="it">let it not happen</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Peter</char>…Note that in the GT Paul refers to him as <char style="it">Cephas </char>in|
                                        |1:18, but here and in v. 8 also he’s referred to as <char style="it">Petros </char>(Peter); in vv. 9,11|
                                        |he’s <char style="it">Cephas </char>again. Paul’s use of the name <char style="it">Petros </char>over|
                                        |<char style="it">Cephas </char>is his acknowledgement of the authority given to him by Jesus himself,|
                                        |as he’s using the name Jesus gave to him. Paul’s use of <char style="it">Cephas </char>is the recognition|
                                        |that Peter is a human like everyone else.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">withdrew from the Gentiles and kept himself at a distance from them</char>…Jews were|
                                        |forbidden to mingle with Gentiles. He was a hypocrite because he had been sharing meals with the Gentiles|
                                        |prior to that.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sinners from far-away, Gentile nations</char>…The assumption among Jews was that anyone|
                                        |who wasn’t Jewish was a de facto sinner, was unclean (despicable), and had no relationship with God—nor|
                                        |could they. Of course, the latter assertion, that a Gentile couldn’t have a relationship with God, is|
                                        |refuted by the OT itself in the persons of Rahab and Ruth. What Jesus said in Matt. 15:26 summarizes|
                                        |this preconception—but at the same time Jesus makes an exception for the Gentile Canaanite woman on account|
                                        |of her faith.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">has been delegated the responsibility of caring for and promoting sin</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">a deacon of sin</char>. Note the Gk. word for <char style="it">deacon </char>is used here|
                                        |and not the Gk. word for <char style="it">servant</char> or <char style="it">slave. </char>A survey of|
                                        |the NT shows that a deacon is one who’s been entrusted with an area of responsibility. A servant or slave,|
                                        |on the other hand, follows orders.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh, brainless, short-sighted Galatians, who cast an evil spell over you, you whom eye-witness accounts|
     v 1                                |of Jesus Christ were previously written for, accounts describing his being crucified? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The only thing I want to ascertain from you is this: Did you receive the Spirit from the works of law|
     v 2                                |(i.e., following the do’s and don’ts of the Law of Moses, or any other list of rules for that matter)|
     v 2                                |or from hearing a particular message from the vantage point of faith?|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You’re brainless this way. Having begun in spirit (i.e., living a spiritual life; a life where your regenerate,|
     v 3                                |human spirit, one filled with fruit, dominates your carnal nature), are you now continuously improving|
     v 3                                |yourselves in flesh (i.e., by your own ability apart from God; not living a spiritual life; trying to|
     v 3                                |please God by adhering to the Law of Moses, Jewish tradition, or other rules)? |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And are you so far off course that you suffered living this way for nothing?—If you really was for nothing.|
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So does he who supplies you with the Spirit and makes power (including supernatural power and the miraculous)|
     v 5                                |happen in you do so from works of law or from a particular message you heard from the vantage point of|
     v 5                                |faith? |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s just like the Old Testament verse says, “Abraham had faith in God, and it was credited to him as|
     v 6                                |righteousness.”|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You really need to understand that they who live from the vantage point of faith—those are the ones who|
     v 7                                |are sons of Abraham (i.e., imitate and duplicate Abraham; carry on Abraham’s legacy). |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the Scriptures anticipated the justification (i.e. clearing of one’s record so he’s considered to|
     v 8                                |be righteous) of the Gentiles who live from the vantage point of faith—Before it was made widely known,|
     v 8                                |God announced the good news to Abraham, telling him that, “In you a blessing will be imparted to all|
     v 8                                |the Gentiles,” |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that they who live from the vantage point of faith are jointly blessed with Abraham by means of faith.|
   N V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, every last person without exception who seeks justification from works of law is subject to|
     v10                                |a curse because of what is written in the Law Moses: |
 +PN V10            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V10                  VERSES_PROSE: |Cursed is everyone who doesn’t carry through|
 +PN V10                  VERSES_PROSE: |With accomplishing the doing of everything|
 +PN V10                  VERSES_PROSE: |Which has been written in the official, authoritative|
 +P  V10                  VERSES_PROSE: |Version of the Law of Moses|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That no one is justified with God (i.e., has had God officially clear their record of wrong-doing and|
     v11                                |declared them to be righteous) by law (i.e., by an attempt to strictly follow the Law of Moses or by|
     v11                                |any list or rules, code of ethics, etc. for that matter) is obvious, since the Law of Moses says, “The|
     v11                                |righteous individual will live from the vantage point of faith.” |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the Law of Moses isn’t from the vantage point of faith, but instead, “He who does the very things|
     v12                                |commanded here shall live in them (i.e., shall live with the consequences one way or another).” |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Christ redeemed us from (i.e., got us out from under) the curse of the Law of Moses, having become a|
     v13                                |curse for us (because it’s written, “Everyone who’s hung on a tree is accursed”) |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the blessing of Abraham would appear to the Gentiles in Christ Jesus, so that we’d receive the|
     v14                                |promise of the Spirit through the faith we’re talking about.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Comrades, let me state this in terms of human contractual law. If a person has gone ahead and had a will|
     v15                                |drawn up and has had it signed, witnessed, and notarized, if he were to die, no one can void it, disregard|
     v15                                |it, or amend it by tacking an addendum onto it. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the promises were given to Abraham and to his father-to-son direct descendant. The Old Testament|
     v16                                |doesn’t say “and to his direct descendants” (in the plural) but “to his direct descendant” (in the singular)|
     v16                                |instead.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What I’m getting at is this: A will was drafted, signed, witnessed, and notarized by God, one that can’t|
     v17                                |be invalidated by a law-code which came into being 430 years after the will was notarized resulting in|
     v17                                |cancelling the promise. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Along these same lines, if the beneficiaries‘ inheritance were to be based on a law-code, then it would|
     v18                                |no longer be based on a promise. But God, in an act of mercy and kindness, has granted the inheritance|
     v18                                |to Abraham by staking it on a promise.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So where does the Law of Moses fit in to all of this? It was added as an agency of grace and mercy which|
     v19                                |overlooks the transgressions which would inevitably occur, until the time when the father-to-son direct|
     v19                                |descendant happens to arrive, the one whom the promise was given to. The Law was ordained, established,|
     v19                                |and set in order through angels and physically carried out by the hand of a priest acting in the role|
     v19                                |of intermediary between man and God. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the intermediary is not one, but God is One (i.e., the intermediary isn’t an incomparable, all-wise,|
     v20                                |all-encompassing, single-minded being, one who is the end-all of everything, but God is just that).|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So is the Law of Moses compatible with the promises?—Don’t even think such a thought. You see, if a law-code|
     v21                                |which has the power to make a person alive was given, the righteousness we live in would actually be|
     v21                                |from a law-code. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not a chance—the Scripture locked every last thing down tight under sin so that the promise would be|
     v22                                |given from the vantage point of faith to those who believe in Jesus Christ.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Before the Faith came, we were kept under guard, locked down with the end-goal in mind of the revealing|
     v23                                |of faith which was on its way, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |done in a way that the Law of Moses has become our tutor with the end-goal of Christ in mind, so that|
     v24                                |we would be justified from the vantage point of faith. |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now that the Faith has come, we are no longer sitting under a tutor.|
 +   V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is that all of you are sons of God through the Faith which is in Christ Jesus. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, without exception every last one of you who’s been baptized into Christ (i.e., has fully accepted|
     v27                                |and been initiated into Christ and the Christian faith) has put on Christ like they’ve put on a piece|
     v27                                |of clothing. |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |There is neither Jew nor Westerner, there is neither slave nor person freed from slavery, there is neither|
     v28                                |male nor female, for all of you are in Christ Jesus (i.e., are melded with Christ). |
 +   V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if you are derived from Christ, you certainly are father-to-son direct descendants of Abraham, heirs|
     v29                                |according to the guarantee that a promise provides.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cast an evil spell over you</char>…A metaphor|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirit</char>…This doesn’t refer to the Holy Spirit per se, as the definite article|
                                        |is missing from <char style="it">spirit</char> here but precedes <char style="it">spirit </char>in vv.|
                                        |2,5. (Nor is there a preceding preposition which might hide the article).|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">continuously improving yourselves</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being perfected</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every last person without exception…without exception every last one of you</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">as many as</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">obvious</char>…Lit: <char style="it">evident</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">signed, witnessed, and notarized</char>…Some liberties taken|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">father-to-son direct descendant</char>…Lit: <char style="it">seed</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">What I’m getting at is this</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Now this I say</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God is One</char>…Ref. note of James 2:19|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t even think such a thought</char>…Lit: <char style="it">let it not be</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every last thing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the alls</char> [<char style="it">all|
                                        |things</char>]. Common expression, used as a figure of speech, encompassing not just people but things|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Westerner</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Greek</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">derived from</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">receive the Spirit</char>…Same wording used in John 20:22; Acts 8:15, 19; 19:2. Since|
                                        |what Jesus did in John 20:22 is a one-off where his disciples were born again at that moment, what Paul’s|
                                        |referring to here in Galatians is the baptism in the Holy Spirit, what’s in Acts 8:15, etc. This verse|
                                        |gives insight into how one receives the baptism of the Holy Spirit: it’s by “a particular message you|
                                        |heard from the vantage point of faith.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">official, authoritative version of the Law of Moses</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |scroll of the Law</char>. An expression used throughout the Bible (Josh. 1:8, 8:34; Heb. 10:7; 2 Kings|
                                        |22:8,11; Deut. 31:26, etc.). This refers to the master scroll, the agreed-upon definitive copy, the original|
                                        |scroll of an ancient book, in this case the Law of Moses. It’s probable that, at least some of the time,|
                                        |it refers to the entire set of the Torah, not just one of its five scrolls. There was originally only|
                                        |one copy of the Torah, and as time went by, more copies were made, but there was only one copy (the “control|
                                        |copy”) which was considered the authoritative one, as the others were potentially flawed to a small degree.|
                                        |In addition to this meaning, <char style="it">book of the Law</char> (scroll of the Law) also serves|
                                        |as a figure of speech which emphasizes the accuracy of a verse or passage which has been quoted and its|
                                        |authority as having come directly from the hand of God.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">governess</char>…Lit: <char style="it">guardian</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assume</char>…Lit: <char style="it">take from another</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Papa</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Abba</char>. Ref. note of Rom. 8:15.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you</char> (singular). Paul always uses the plural|
                                        |form (an example is in v.6) of you in his letters when referring to the Galatians, Corinthians, etc.|
                                        |And also, Paul sometimes uses <char style="it">you </char>(singular) as <char style="it">one</char>,|
                                        |as it is in this case.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">worried</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fear</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prevent you</char> …Lit: <char style="it">lock you out of</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">haven’t you heard what the Law teaches</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you didn’t hear|
                                        |the Law</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he</char>…Lit: <char style="it">it or that</char>. It’s commonplace for nouns describing|
                                        |children or infants to be neuter rather than masculine.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the carbon-copies of herself which she’s spawned</char>…Lit: <char style="it">her children</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the one who’s spawned us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">who’s our mother</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">subject to the prevalent idea of God accepting you based on how well you follow the|
                                        |list of do’s and don’ts</char>…This phrase <char style="it">elementary principles </char>is used here|
                                        |and also in Col 2:8,20. The meaning of <char style="it">elementary principles</char> should be determined|
                                        |by the context of its appearances in the NT.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the authority and privileges entailed upon a son when he reaches adulthood</char>…The|
                                        |Gk. word for this is usually translated <char style="it">adoption </char>but literally means <char style="it">son-placement.|
                                        |</char>In this context, it’s referring to Jesus coming into the rights and privileges which were reserved|
                                        |for him. This passage starting from v. 1 draws an analogy between a child who is born the son of the|
                                        |lord of a great estate but is raised no differently than a household slave. Once he reaches an age of|
                                        |maturity, he joins his father and becomes a joint-owner of the estate. Jesus underwent this process by|
                                        |being born into this world and having to live under the dictates of the Law—but only for a fixed time|
                                        |interval. The interval expired when he was raised from the dead. At that time he assumed his full privileges|
                                        |as Son of God. This is also what Heb. 1:5 refers to.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Put yourselves in my shoes, since I’m putting myself in your shoes, comrades</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">become as me, since I become as you, brothers</char>. I’m guessing that this is what|
                                        |Paul meant. Same applies for the next few verses.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your testing</char>…Or: <char style="it">your temptation</char>. Though some manuscripts|
                                        |read <char style="it">my testing</char> instead, the consensus favors the former over the latter. The|
                                        |redacting of the manuscripts in this area goes to show how difficult vv. 12–16 are to make sense of.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because, if possible, you plucked out your eyes and gave them to me</char>…Some claim|
                                        |that the “weakness of the flesh” Paul spoke about in v. 13 was a seeing disorder, and that the Galatians|
                                        |wanted to pluck out their eyes and give them to Paul out of sympathy. As difficult as the passage of|
                                        |vv. 12–16 is to interpret, a healthy skepticism is in order. But the context of this passage doesn’t|
                                        |confirm this dubious claim. Verse 15 begins, “why aren’t you happy anymore?”, while verse 16 begins,|
                                        |“So this means I’ve become your enemy…?” No concurrence is found ; the context suggests that this is|
                                        |an idiom.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Jerusalem above</char>…Paul refers to a concept, also called the New Jerusalem, which|
                                        |has its origins in the OT, in Ezekiel, Jeremiah, and Isaiah, and appears in the NT in Rev. 21:12. In|
                                        |the Bible, cities are metonymies for a concentration of those who intensely believe and put into practice|
                                        |a particular doctrine, religion, etc. The present-day Jerusalem of v. 25 is a metonymy for those who|
                                        |expect to obtain righteousness by adhering to the Law, whereas the Jerusalem above represents righteousness|
                                        |through faith in Christ.|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">recreational drug use, drug abuse, drug dealing, dabbling in the occult, or extreme|

                                        |style="w" strong="G05331">φαρμακεία</char>), from where the words <char style="it">pharmacy </char>and|
                                        |<char style="it">pharmaceutical </char>are derived. This comes from ancient practices of making potions|
                                        |from exotic plants and using such potions in occult-like practices, often to control others. The ancients|
                                        |didn’t understand drugs per-se, the only understood that certain plants had magical powers. They were|
                                        |effectively using these plants for the drugs found in them. Also ref. Rev. 22:15.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Comrades, if a person happens to inadvertently be caught in some transgression, you the spiritual ones|

     v10                                |continue to do good things for the households of those who are of the Faith.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pay attention to the capital letters I’m using here as I write this in my own handwriting:|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |THE VERY PEOPLE WHO WANT TO MAKE THEMSELVES APPEAR ON THE OUTSIDE AS THOUGH THEY’RE GOOD—THEY’RE THE|
     v12                                |ONES WHO REQUIRE YOU TO BE CIRCUMCISED (i.e., to formally adopt the Law of Moses in the rite of circumcision,|
     v12                                |thereby committing to following it) FOR THE SOLE REASON THAT THEY WON’T BE PERSECUTED FOR THE CROSS OF|
     v12                                |CHRIST. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |IN FACT, THOSE WHO PROMOTE CIRCUMCISION DON’T EVEN KEEP LAW (i.e., keep the Law of Moses or any code|
     v13                                |of conduct for that matter) THEMSELVES. ON THE CONTRARY, THEY WANT YOU TO BE CIRCUMCISED SO THEY CAN|
     v13                                |BRAG IN YOUR FLESH (i.e., can brag about the amount of personal effort you’re putting into following|
     v13                                |the Law).|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But far be it for me to brag or beam with pride except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through|
     v14                                |whom the world is crucified to me and I to the world (i.e., the ungodly established order of mankind|
     v14                                |has completely disavowed and shunned me, wanting nothing to do with me, and I have done the same to it).|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Neither circumcision nor uncircumcision is of any significance, but a new creation is the only thing|
     v15                                |which is significant. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And whosever conforms to this standard: peace be upon him and mercy, and may it also be upon God’s people|
     v16                                |Israel.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Henceforth, let no one try to hassle me, for I bear the marks of Jesus in my body as though I’m trudging|
     v17                                |about carrying a weight.|
 + N V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, comrades.|
 +P  V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Amen (so be it).|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a prevailing attitude</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a spirit</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">full of baloney</char>…Lit<char style="it">: self-deluded</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he’ll be entitled to speak proudly</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he will have the boast</char>|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  EPH Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  EPH Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, apostle (i.e., missionary) of Christ Jesus through the will of God—|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the saints (i.e., God’s people) who are in Ephesus and to those who are faithful in Christ Jesus:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace to you from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Blessed is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, He Who blessed us with every spiritual blessing|
     v 3                                |imaginable in the spiritual domain in Christ, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just as in love He chose us in him before the foundation of the world to be holy and unblemished when|
     v 4                                |subjected to His scrutiny, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having determined beforehand that He would adopt us, making us His sons through Jesus Christ, according|
     v 5                                |to the benevolent thought-process of His will, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |resulting in praising the glory of His grace, which in an act of mercy and kindness He gave us by means|
     v 6                                |of the Beloved-One, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in whom we have the Redemption (i.e., the master-plan to put our lives back to the way they were supposed|
     v 7                                |to be) through his blood, the forgiveness of the trespasses which caused us to need redemption in the|
     v 7                                |first place, according to the riches of His grace, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which He copiously showered on us with every kind of wisdom and thought-process imaginable, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having made known and understood to us the mystery of His will, according to His benevolent thoughts|
     v 9                                |which He purposed and put forth openly in him |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for the management of when the eras of history come to a head, resulting in the redefinition of every|
     v10                                |last thing in the Messiah, the Christ, every last thing that resides in the spiritual domain and on the|
     v10                                |Earth—all things in him, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in whom we also received an inheritance (i.e., things which have been parceled out and reserved specifically|
     v11                                |for us, and for us only, to receive or walk, spiritual or otherwise. The plan for us to have such things|
     v11                                |is immutable. ) which has been predestined (i.e., decided upon ahead of time) according to the plan and|
     v11                                |purpose of the One who works every last thing according to the deliberation of His will, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |resulting in us being disposed to praise His glory, we who have set our hope in Christ beforehand, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and in whom we also, having heard the ultimate message of truth, the Gospel of our salvation (i.e., the|
     v13                                |good news that there is a program in place to rescue us and protect us from calamity), in which, now|
     v13                                |that we have believed this message, we were sealed (i.e., identified as belonging to someone or intended|
     v13                                |for some purpose and labeled and marked as genuine as such) by the guaranteed-by-promise Holy Spirit,|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who is the down payment of our inheritance up until we take delivery of what was purchased, resulting|
     v14                                |in praising His glory.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On account of this, having heard about your expression of the Faith, a faith which is in the Lord Jesus,|
     v15                                |and the love which you show to all the saints, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I also haven’t stopped offering thanksgiving for you, bringing you up in my prayers, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of Glory, will give you a spirit (i.e., a prevailing|
     v17                                |attitude; an all-encompassing mindset that reaches down deep into the heart, into your own human spirit)|
     v17                                |of wisdom and revelation in a recognition and an arrived-at, more precise knowledge and understanding|
     v17                                |of Him, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which is the eyes of your heart having reached the point where they’re enlightened resulting in us knowing|
     v18                                |for a fact what is the hope of our calling (i.e., what the full potential and ramifications are of us|
     v18                                |being chosen and accepted by God), what is the wealth of the glory of His inheritance that’s been distributed|
     v18                                |among the saints, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and what is the over-the-top greatness of His power made available to us, we who believe in accordance|
     v19                                |with the actuation of the might of His strength (i.e., the sheer amount of force He’s able to bring to|
     v19                                |bear when He unleashes his power), |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which he actuated in the Messiah, the Christ, having raised him from the dead and having seated him at|
     v20                                |his right hand (i.e., having taken his position of God’s chief executive officer) in the spiritual domain,|
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |superseding by far all rule and authority and power and dominion and every name which has been named|
     v21                                |(i.e., every authority which has ever been established; every person or being who’s ever been given or|
     v21                                |has otherwise assumed a position of authority) not just in this age—no—in the Age to Come as well. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And He subjected all things under his feet (i.e. God made all things absolutely subservient to Christ,|
     v22                                |to be forcefully dominated by him), and gave him—the one who’s the head over all things—to the church,|
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which is his body, the maximum amount which every little bit of everything is filled to.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the spiritual domain</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the heavens</char>. Ref. note of 2|
                                        |Cor. 12:2.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">when subjected to His scrutiny</char>…Lit: <char style="it">before Him</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">when the eras of history come to a head</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the fullness of|
                                        |the seasons</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">redefinition</char>…Also: <char style="it">summarization</char>; <char style="it">recapitulation</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every last thing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the all</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the ultimate message</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the word</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the guaranteed-by-promise Holy Spirit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the of promise Holy|
                                        |Spirit</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your expression of the Faith</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the according-to-you faith</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bringing you up in my prayers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">making a remembrance at my|
                                        |prayers</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what</char>…Or: <char style="it">who</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">superseding by far</char>…Lit: <char style="it">far above</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to the saints who are</char> <char style="it">in Ephesus and to those who are faithful</char>…Or:|
                                        |<char style="it">to the saints who exist and are faithful </char>. Some of the oldest and most important|
                                        |manuscripts omit the words <char style="it">in Ephesus</char>, which changes the translation to what’s|
                                        |noted here. It’s uncertain whether these words were added later or not.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who</char>…Or: <char style="it">the thing that is</char>. The latter appears in some|
                                        |of the principal manuscripts.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rule and authority and power and dominion</char>…These are both earthly rulers and spiritual|
                                        |beings. Ref. note of 1 Cor. 15:24.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the maximum amount which every little bit of everything is filled to</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">the full extent of the all things in all things being filled</char>. <char style="it">All|
                                        |things in all things </char>(the preferable rendering being <char style="it">all in all</char>) is an|
                                        |idiom which also appears in 1 Cor. 12:6; 15:28; Col. 3:11. The meaning of this idiom is understood by|
                                        |context.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  EPH Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And while you were dead (i.e., dead spiritually: in a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and|
     v 1                                |destruction) in your trespasses and sins, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in which you went about day in, day out back then according to the age (era) of this world (i.e., according|
     v 2                                |to the philosophies, attitudes, and beliefs that are in vogue in this particular era of human history),|
     v 2                                |according to the ruler of the authority of the air (i.e., according to the being who determines the underlying|
     v 2                                |unseen power that influences and guides human society), the spirit who now works in those who take it|
     v 2                                |upon themselves to be disobedient, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you also conducted your lives this way among them back then, living by the desires of your flesh (i.e.,|
     v 3                                |your carnal nature), acting out the wants of the flesh and of the thoughts which randomly enter your|
     v 3                                |mind, and you were by nature characterized by indulgence in violent emotions just like everyone else.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But God, rich in mercy because of the great amount of love which He has, loved us, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and we, dead in the trespasses I mentioned earlier, were made alive in Christ—by grace you have been|
     v 5                                |saved— |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and were raised in conjunction with him and seated jointly with him (i.e., given joint authority with|
     v 6                                |him) in the spiritual domain in Christ Jesus, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the over-the-top riches of His grace in goodness in Christ Jesus would be showcased by being|
     v 7                                |lavished upon us in the coming ages. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, by grace you have been saved through faith, and this grace—the gift of God—does not originate|
     v 8                                |from yourselves, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |it does not originate from works, so that no one would have bragging-rights. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we are His handiwork, created in Christ Jesus in a position to handle the good works which God|
     v10                                |has waiting in the wings for us to occupy our day-to-day lives with.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, recall that in flesh (i.e., according to your physical bodies which indicate the method|
     v11                                |and means by which you approach God) you were “the Gentile Nations” back then, those called uncircumcised|
     v11                                |(i.e., not God’s people) by those called circumcised in flesh by hand (i.e., God’s people according to|
     v11                                |a ritual performed by humans), |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because in that phase of your life you were apart from Christ, excluded from the political and social|
     v12                                |community of Israel and strangers to the covenants of promise, hopeless and godless in the world. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But now you are melded with Christ Jesus; you being far away back then became close by the blood of Christ.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, He personally is our peace, who made both peoples into one and by means of his flesh tore|
     v14                                |down the dividing wall—the animus—|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having abolished the wall, namely the Law of Moses which consists of the commandments of God enumerated|
     v15                                |in decrees, so that by means of him He would merge the two entities into one new entity, making peace|
     v15                                |by doing so, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and by means of one body would reconcile both to God through the cross, having killed the animus by means|
     v16                                |of him. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And he went and proclaimed the glad-tidings message of peace to us who are afar and peace to those who|
     v17                                |are near, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the message that through him both entities have the access I’ve been talking about in one Spirit to the|
     v18                                |Father.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So I’ll state this emphatically: you’re no longer strangers and foreign-residents, but fellow-citizens|
     v19                                |of the saints and households of God (i.e., God’s people, historically speaking) instead, |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |built on top of the foundation of the apostles and the prophets, Christ Jesus being the foundation’s|
     v20                                |main anchor point, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in whom you too are being custom-built into a dwelling place of God in the Spirit.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the ruler of the authority of the air</char>…Up until modern times, it was a commonly|
                                        |held belief that the large masses of air which blow from place to place bring with them not only plagues|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and this grace—the gift of God—does not originate from yourselves</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">and this not from out of you all the gift of God</char>. The gender of the word <char style="it">this|
                                        |</char>is neuter, agreeing with the gender of <char style="it">gift. </char>The genders of <char style="it">grace|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">faith </char>are both feminine, which means that in the strictest sense <char|
                                        |style="it">this </char>does not refer to <char style="it">faith </char>because of the gender disagreement.|
                                        |Many assume that it does and use this verse as proof that faith is a gift and that God must give us this|
                                        |gift to “boot us up” so to speak as Christians. Faith is not a gift, nowhere in the Bible does it say|
                                        |that faith is a gift, and neither does this verse.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I ask you with all sincerity—I the prisoner in the Lord—to go about your day-to-day lives in a worthy|

     v16                                |its share to cause the growth of the body towards the goal of the building up of itself in love.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What I’m telling you—and I swear by it in the Lord—is this: No longer go about your day-to-day lives|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he bedazzled the captives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he took captive the captives</char>.|
                                        |A repetition of the same root, first the verb then the noun with not article is a figure of speech, likely|
                                        |an idiom also. This figure of speech originates in the Hebrew text of Ps. 68:18 and was simply copied|
                                        |to the LXX, from where it was copied to this epistle.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fully take ownership of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fulfill</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pastor</char>…Lit: <char style="it">shepherd</char>. Ref. note of 1 Pet. 5:2.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the cheap hustles that pool sharks dream up to con people</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |cunning</char> [from <char style="it">dice-playing</char>; <char style="it">sleight</char>] <char style="it">of|
                                        |men in villainy, knavery, trickery</char> [lit: <char style="it">readiness to do anything</char>] <char|
                                        |style="it">to the scheming</char> [from the root <char style="it">method, system; device; scheming; deal|
                                        |craftily with</char>] <char style="it">of deception. Pool sharks </char>is actually <char style="it">dice-throwers</char>|
                                        |(liberties taken).|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">while being straight-up about the truth</char>…Lit<char style="it">: truth-speaking</char>.|
                                        |Of note is that this is a single Gk. word and not a multi-word phrase. Since it is a single word, it|
                                        |has a more specific definition.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">its share</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in a measure</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all sorts of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all</char>. Same idiom used in 1 Tim. 6:10.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">filthy, disgusting things</char>…Lit: <char style="it">uncleanness</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">old-self</char>…Lit: <char style="it">old man</char> [<char style="it">person</char>]|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prevailing attitude and disposition</char>…Lit: <char style="it">spirit</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">derived</char> <char style="it">from</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of</char>|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">One God who occupies the role of Father</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God and Father</char>.|
                                        |An hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11. In this case, the hendiadys emphasizes the fact that God is the|
                                        |Supreme Father, and as the Father is the One Who is over everything, plans, originates, directs, and|
                                        |gives purpose to everything. This very thing is elaborated in the words which follow.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the unearned gift which God gives out of His kindness</char>…Also: <char style="it">the|
                                        |grace</char>. The definite article precedes the word <char style="it">grace </char>when it refers to|
                                        |grace in a Christian context, and not one of the other meanings the Gk. word might convey. This is sort-of|
                                        |idiomatic.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The context suggests that this is talking about the special abilities God gives to select individuals|
                                        |to be used in the ministry. Note that the word <char style="it">grace </char>in this verse is the root|
                                        |for the word <char style="it">gift </char>(<char style="it">charisma) </char>used in 1 Cor. 12,14. Now,|
                                        |the word <char style="it">gift </char>used in v. 7 here in <char style="it">gift of Christ</char> uses|
                                        |the generic word for <char style="it">gift </char>(<char style="it">dōron, </char>δῶρον/Strong’s 1435)|
                                        |<char style="it">, </char>which, unlike <char style="it">charisma,</char> has no sense of grace attached|
                                        |to it (ref. note of Rom. 12:6). But this was probably because <char style="it">dōron </char>was used|
                                        |in Ps. 68:18 in the LXX, which is quoted in v. 8, so Paul uses it in reference to this quotation, not|
                                        |because there’s no grace associated with this <char style="it">dōron.</char>|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ascended to a high place</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ascended to high</char>. A few|
                                        |verses later (v. 10) Paul clarifies what <char style="it">high </char>means: <char style="it">far above|
                                        |all the heavens. </char>This is not so much a physical location as a position of authority.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">instructor</char>…Also: <char style="it">teacher</char>. Ref. note of Acts 15:1. Also|
                                        |note that there is only one definite article before <char style="it">pastor and instructor</char>, whereas|
                                        |apostle, prophet, and evangelist each have their own definite articles. The missing definite article|
                                        |before <char style="it">teacher </char>binds it to <char style="it">pastor.</char>|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">should the time ever come</char>…This seems to be insinuated by the verb tense of <char|
                                        |style="it">attain, </char>but others (in this case, the <char style="it">Expositor’s Greek Testament</char>)|
                                        |claim that the tense of <char style="it">attain </char>“…points to the event [of attaining the unity|
                                        |of the faith] as expected, and not as a mere hypothetical possibility.” According to this reasoning,|
                                        |<char style="it">should the time ever come </char>would be rendered <char style="it">when the time actually|
                                        |does come</char> instead.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">being a full-grown man (i.e., getting our act together) to the point where we reach|
                                        |Christ’s height and body-weight</char> …Lit: <char style="it">to a complete man, to a measure of stature|
                                        |of the fullness of Christ</char>. <char style="it">Complete man </char>is the same idiom/metaphor used|
                                        |in James 3:2. The metaphorical sense of this is signaled by the use of the more specific Gk. word for|
                                        |<char style="it">man, </char>which is<char style="it"> anār </char><char style="w" strong="G00435">ἀνήρ</char>),|
                                        |over the more general <char style="it">anthrōpos </char><char style="w" strong="G00444">ἄνθρωπος</char>).|
                                        |Also, choosing <char style="it">anār </char>over <char style="it">anthrōpos </char>refers to the physical|
                                        |size of a grown-man’s body. The comparison to a full-grown body continues in the phrase <char style="it">to|
                                        |a measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ. </char>Furthermore<char style="it">,</char> <char|
                                        |style="it">complete man </char>also refers to a man’s physical body size. A “complete man” is one who|
                                        |has a full-grown body. The metaphor is that, when our body is fully grown, we will have attained the|
                                        |same height and weight as Christ. The reference to children in v. 14 continues this stature-metaphor.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to put on</char> <char style="it">once and for all…</char>There is a noteworthy change|
                                        |in verb tense between the verb <char style="it">to put aside </char>in v. 23 (Gk. present tense) and|
                                        |the verb <char style="it">to put on </char>in v. 24 (Gk. aorist tense); the words <char style="it">repeatedly|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">once and for all </char>are insinuated by these tenses. Also, as these two|
                                        |verbs are imperatives, a present-tense imperative is softer than an aorist-imperative. So the command|
                                        |<char style="it">to put on </char>is like an order that an army captain would give to one of his soldiers|
                                        |or that a lord would give to one of his slaves. So the command to put on the new-self is more urgent,|
                                        |abrupt, and forceful than the command to put off the old-self.|

     v 3                                |things is what’s appropriate for the saints (i.e., those who believe in Christ). |
