     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">head</char>…See 1 Cor. 11 for usage of the word <char style="it">head </char>in this|
                                        |context|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it</char>…Also: <char style="it">her</char>. This has a dual-meaning, since the Gk.|
                                        |word for <char style="it">flesh</char> is feminine, it can—and does—refer to both “it” (the flesh) and|
                                        |“she” (the wife).|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">deep</char>…Lit: <char style="it">great</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anything which itself brings things out in the open and makes them plain to see is light</char>…Or:|
                                        |<char style="it">all which is being manifested is light</char>. Interpreting the Gk. verb tense of <char|
                                        |style="it">is being manifested </char>as a middle voice instead of passive, in order to make sense of|
                                        |this and fit it into the context. Usage of the middle voice like this is extremely rare in the NT (this|
                                        |is skating on thin ice).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">popular songs accompanied by instruments, songs of praise</char>…Lit: <char style="it">psalms|
                                        |and hymns</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">psalm </char>means, “to vibrate by touching” (Thayer);|
                                        |“song of praise accompanied on the harp” (Max &amp; Mary); the Gk. word for <char style="it">hymn </char>means,|
                                        |“a song in praise of gods, heroes, and conquerors” (Thayer). Thayer goes on to say (with a quotation|
                                        |from Synesius? embedded), “[the Gk. word for] <char style="it">song </char>is the generic term; [the|
                                        |Gk. words for] <char style="it">psalm </char>and <char style="it">hymn </char>are the specific, the former|
                                        |designating a song which took its general character from the OT Psalms (although not restricted to them,|
                                        |see 1 Cor. 14:15,26), the latter a song of praise. ‘While the leading idea of <char style="it">psalm|
                                        |</char>is a musical accompaniment, and that of <char style="it">hymn </char>praise to God, <char style="it">song|
                                        |</char>is the general word for a song, whether accompanied or unaccompanied, whether of praise or on|
                                        |any other subject. Thus it was quite possible for the same song to be at once <char style="it">psalm,|
                                        |hymn, </char>and <char style="it">song.’ </char>The words occur together in Col. 3:16 and Eph. 5:19.”|
                                        |Also, ref. note of 1 Cor. 14:15.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spiritual songs</char>…The word for <char style="it">spiritual </char>here is the same|
                                        |word used in 1 Cor. 12:1 “concerning spirituals” (see note there) and is also found in 1 Cor. 14:15,37.|
                                        |In both v. 19 here and 1 Cor. 14:15:37, this phrase means a prophetic utterance or the equivalent of|
                                        |a prophetic utterance in the form of tongues and interpretation. A <char style="it">spiritual song</char>|
                                        |is a prophetic utterance which is put to song.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">submit</char>…Ref. note of 1 Pet. 2:18, which explains the Gk. words for <char style="it">submit|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">obey. </char>A case in point is the usage of <char style="it">submit </char>here,|
                                        |but the usage of <char style="it">obey </char>in 6:1. Wives are told to submit, but children are told|
                                        |to obey.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  EPH Chapter 6  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Children, obey your parents as part of your walk with the Lord; this is the right thing to do, you see.|
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”Honor your father and mother,” which is the foremost commandment found in the Law of Moses with a promise|
     v 2                                |appended to it: |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”…So that it would go well with you and you would be blessed during your stay on the planet.” |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And, parents, don’t exasperate your children but raise them in the discipline, coaching, mentoring, and|
     v 4                                |instruction of the Lord instead.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Slaves and menial servants, obey those who are your masters or bosses in the natural with the utmost|
     v 5                                |reverence and respect in the simplicity of your heart (i.e., without making something bigger out of it)|
     v 5                                |as if being reverent to Christ, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not just making the boss think you’re doing a good job when he’s looking and acting up when he’s not|
     v 6                                |but obeying as though you’re Christ’s slave instead, doing the will of God from the soul, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |serving with a good attitude as if your service is to the Lord and not to humans, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing for a fact that each person, if he were to do something in particular which is good, he’ll get|
     v 8                                |this same thing back from the Lord, whether slave or free. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And masters and bosses, treat them the same way, giving up the constant threat of punishment as your|
     v 9                                |primary means of motivating your slaves, knowing for a fact that in the spiritual domain the Lord is|
     v 9                                |master and boss of both them and you, and there is no favoritism based on position in society or such|
     v 9                                |with him.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, be strong in the Lord and reach into the vastness of his power. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Put on all the components of God’s complete suit of armor so you’ll have the ability to stand against|
     v11                                |the schemes of the devil, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because the fight we’re in isn’t against flesh and blood, but against the rulers (i.e., the evil spirits|
     v12                                |who have dominion at the top of a hierarchy, presumably over other evil spirits), against the authorities|
     v12                                |(i.e., the evil spirits with power over a specific area), against the world-dominators of this darkness|
     v12                                |(i.e., the evil spirits who dominate the ungodly human system and society that is the darkness we’re|
     v12                                |surrounded by), against the spirit-forces of wickedness in the spiritual domain.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On account of this, take up God’s complete suit of armor, so that you’ll be able to withstand the spiritual|
     v13                                |forces of the devil in the day of evil and—after you’ve accomplished everything on that day—to stand.|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So stand, after having fastened the belt of truth around your waist, and having put on the breastplate|
     v14                                |of righteousness, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and having put on your feet the preparation of the good-news message of the Gospel of peace, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in all situations having taken up the shield of faith, by which you’ll be able to extinguish and knock|
     v16                                |out all the Evil One’s flaming projectiles, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and having received the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit (which is the word of God), |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |with every sort of prayer and supplication (i.e., an urgent request put into prayer) praying in every|
     v18                                |season of life in the Spirit, and while at it with maximum perseverance and prayer be on the lookout|
     v18                                |looking around to see how all the saints (i.e., believers) are doing, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and for me, so that a message may be given to me when I open my mouth to boldly make known the mystery|
     v19                                |of the Gospel |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |(for which I’m an ambassador kept on a short leash) so that with the same I will speak out freely, boldly,|
     v20                                |and confidently as it is incumbent on me to speak.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now, so that you too would know what’s going on with me and how I’m doing, Tychicus, a dear brother and|
     v21                                |a faithful assistant in the Lord, will fill you in on everything, |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |whom I sent to you with that very goal in mind, so you’d know what I’m up to and that he’d give your|
     v22                                |hearts encouragement and comfort.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Extend a greeting of peace to the brothers and love with faith from God the Father and the Lord Jesus|
     v23                                |Christ. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace be with them who love our Lord Jesus Christ with sincerity.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">as part of your walk with the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the Lord</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">foremost</char>…Also: <char style="it">first</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the utmost reverence and respect</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fear and trembling</char>.|
                                        |An idiom; also found in 1 Cor. 2:3; 2 Cor. 7:15; Phil 2:12.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not just making the boss think you’re doing a good job when he’s looking and acting|
                                        |up when he’s not</char>…Lit: <char style="it">not according to eye-serving as man-pleasers</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">good attitude</char>…Also: <char style="it">goodwill</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">treat them the same way</char>…Lit: <char style="it">do the same things to them</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spiritual domain</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the heavens</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put on</char>…The Gk. verb tense used for this imperative is a strong command, like|
                                        |one an officer gives to a soldier, something he should snap to attention and get done immediately.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all the components of God’s complete suit of armor</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |full armor of God</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">panoplia</char> <char style="w" strong="G03833">πανοπλία</char>),|
                                        |where we get the English word <char style="it">panoply</char>, is used here for <char style="it">full|
                                        |armor.</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">after having fastened the belt of truth around your waist</char>…Lit: <char style="it">having|
                                        |your loins girded in truth</char>. A reference to Is. 11:5; 59:17.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in all situations</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in all</char>. Older commentaries (and|
                                        |one would assume they’re based on Textus Receptus) read <char style="it">upon all </char>(rendered <char|
                                        |style="it">above all</char>) instead; Codex Vaticanus/UBS NT read <char style="it">in all</char>.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every sort of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kept on a short leash</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in a chain</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">how I’m doing</char>…Or: <char style="it">what I practice</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assistant</char>…Lit: <char style="it">deacon</char>. Ref. note of Rom. 12:7.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From Paul and Timothy, slaves of Christ Jesus,|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To all the saints (i.e., believers) in Christ Jesus who live in Philippi together with the bishops (i.e.,|
     v 1                                |head pastors; overseers) and deacons (i.e., assistant pastors; assistants entrusted with significant|
     v 1                                |responsibilities; heads of ministry departments):|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I give thanks to my God every time I think about you while reminiscing, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |always making every one of my requests put into prayer for you all with joy, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and I give thanks for your working closely with me in the spreading of the Gospel (i.e., the good-news|
     v 5                                |message of Christ) from the first day until the present. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ve reached the point where I’m convinced of this very thing, that He who began a good work in you will|
     v 6                                |complete it, working towards that ends until the day of Christ Jesus, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just as it’s right for me to be thinking about all of you this way, on account of me having you both|
     v 7                                |in my heart and in my chains and in the verbal defense and confirmation of the certainty of the Gospel—you|
     v 7                                |all being my fellow-workers of this grace.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard, God is my witness to the fact that I long for all you with the deep, inner affections|
     v 8                                |of Christ Jesus. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And I pray this, that your love would proliferate even more and more in recognition, in more precise|
     v 9                                |knowledge, and in every sort of insight gained from perception, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |resulting in your continual testing and approving of those things which excel, so that you would be sincere|
     v10                                |and won’t get tripped up and would maintain this to the day of Christ, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having reached the point where you’ve been filled from the byproduct of righteousness which is through|
     v11                                |Jesus Christ to the glory and praise of God.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I want you to know, comrades, that the situation I find myself in has further advanced the Gospel, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in that an awareness and understanding of my bonds in Christ has been made known among the entire palace|
     v13                                |guard detachment and among everyone else, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and many of the comrades in the Lord, urged on by my bonds, are much more daring about going around speaking|
     v14                                |the word of God without fear.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While it’s true that some preach Christ because they’re motivated by jealousy and strife, on the other|
     v15                                |hand some are motivated by good intentions. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While they who spread the Gospel out of love know for a fact that I’ve been appointed to give a verbal|
     v16                                |defense of the Gospel, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |on the other hand they who proclaim Christ out of ambition and not with sincerity expect to stir up vexation|
     v17                                |for me while I’m in jail. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what?—except for this: that Christ is proclaimed in all respects, whether with ulterior motives or|
     v18                                |with no hidden agenda, and in this I rejoice—and indeed I will rejoice, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for I know for a fact that this will result in deliverance for me through your prayer and the support|
     v19                                |of the Spirit of Christ Jesus, |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in line with my eager expectation and hope that I won’t be embarrassed or humiliated in any way, but|
     v20                                |rather with every sort of frankness, forthrightness, and openness imaginable Christ will be magnified|
     v20                                |now—as always—in my body, whether through life or through death.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the way I see it, to live is Christ and to die is gain (i.e., is advantageous; is a desirable|
     v21                                |option). |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If I live on in the flesh, this will yield tangible results from my work. And what will I choose?—I can’t|
     v22                                |tell; |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m caught between the two, having the desire to be set free again and to be together with Christ, for|
     v23                                |this is much, much better. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But to remain in the flesh is more necessary for your sakes. |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And convinced of this I know that I will remain here on Earth and stay by your side—with all of you—for|
     v25                                |your progress and for the joy which comes from faith, |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that your grounds for speaking proudly would proliferate in Christ Jesus by my doing, on account of|
     v26                                |me visiting you again.|
 +   V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Only let your life in society be worthy of the Gospel of Christ, so that, whether I come and see you|
     v27                                |or am away, I hear what you’re up to, that you stand together in one spirit, one soul, joined together|
     v27                                |by the Faith of the Gospel |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and are not frightened and intimidated by anything done by your adversaries, which in particular is indicative|
     v28                                |of their ruin, but of your salvation (i.e., your being kept from ruin); and this intimidation-ruin-salvation|
     v28                                |pattern is from God, |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since the thing given—undeservedly so—to you on Christ’s behalf is to not only to believe in him but|
     v29                                |to suffer on his behalf, |
     V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having the same anguish and conflict as he did, the very thing you saw happening to and in me and now|
     v30                                |hear reports are happening to and in me.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">byproduct</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fruit</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stir up vexation for me while I’m in jail</char>…Lit: <char style="it">raise distress|
                                        |in my bonds</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with no hidden agenda</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in</char> [<char style="it">the</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">truth</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the way I see it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to me</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">this will yield tangible results from my work</char>…Lit<char style="it">: this in</char>|
                                        |[or <char style="it">by</char>] <char style="it">me fruit of work</char>. Paul didn’t word this clearly.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">much, much better</char>…Lit: <char style="it">much more better</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirit</char>…Or: [<char style="it">Holy</char>] <char style="it">Spirit</char>. The|
                                        |GT is ambiguous. One should not exclude the possibility that it means both.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">given—undeservedly so</char>…The Gk. word used for <char style="it">given </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">charidzomai,</char><char style="w" strong="G05483">χαρίζομαι</char>)] here is not what one|
                                        |would expect. <char style="it">Charidzomai </char>also means <char style="it">to give</char>, but has|
                                        |emphasizes the magnanimousness of the person doing the giving, and/or insinuating that the person receiving|
                                        |the gift didn’t earn it.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, if there’s any comfort or exhortation in Christ, if any consolation offered by love, if any commonality|
     v 1                                |and fellowship of spirit, if any deep, inner affection— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you’ll make me overjoyed if you would adopt that way of thinking, having the same love, being harmonious|
     v 2                                |and on the same page, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |with no one motivated by ambition or by conceit but by humility instead, considering each other to be|
     v 3                                |better than yourselves, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not paying careful attention to your own affairs exclusively but instead paying careful attention to|
     v 4                                |each other’s affairs as well.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Maintain in you the way of thinking that was also in Christ Jesus, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who, while existing in the form of God, didn’t think being equal to God was a thing that had to be to|
     v 6                                |be held onto with everything you’ve got, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but instead depleted himself and assumed the form of a slave, having turned into something similar to|
     v 7                                |humans, and, unveiled to the public having the appearance of that of a human being, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |he humbled himself and became obedient until it reached a point where the obedience required his death,|
     v 8                                |not just any-old death but the death of crucifixion on a cross. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And in light of this, God exalted him (i.e., promoted him to a high position) and out of His generosity|
     v 9                                |gave him the name which is above all names (i.e., gave him the ultimate top rank, outranking every other|
     v 9                                |rank), |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that in the name of Jesus (i.e. when Jesus’s authority is invoked) every knee would bow of the things|
     v10                                |in the heavens (i.e., in heaven; in the spiritual domain) and of the things on the Earth and of the things|
     v10                                |under the earth (i.e., the world of the dead, including hell) |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and every tongue would confess out loud that Jesus Christ is Lord to the glory of God the Father.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, my dear comrades, just as you have always obeyed, not just when I was there in person but even|
     v12                                |more in my absence, work at the salvation where your own selves are concerned with the utmost reverence|
     v12                                |and respect; |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, God is the One Who’s working in you both the wanting and the working-on of what pleases Him.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Do all things while distancing yourselves from grumbling and scheming or plotting, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that you would become blameless and innocent, children of God in the midst of a crooked and perverted|
     v15                                |Zeitgeist, in which you shine as lights in the world, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |holding fast to a message of life, resulting in me having proud words to tell others up to the day of|
     v16                                |Christ, since you haven’t run life’s race or toiled for nothing.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Anyways, if I’m being poured out like a libation upon the altar and during the liturgy of your faith,|
     v17                                |I will rejoice and will rejoice together with you all— |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the same for you: you will rejoice and will rejoice together with me.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you posthaste, so that once I know what you’re up to,|
     v19                                |it’ll put me at ease. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I have no one, you see, who sees things the way I do, a certain someone who’ll truly care for you. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, everyone I’ve tried to find to work with me is pursuing their own self-interests, not the interests|
     v21                                |of Jesus Christ. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you’re familiar with how he qualified to receive my trust, that he served me in the Gospel like a|
     v22                                |son serves a father. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So I certainly hope to send this fellow as I could immediately turn my attention to my affairs were he|
     v23                                |to be sent. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m convinced in the Lord of the same, that I too will come posthaste.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I deemed it necessary that I send you Epaphroditus, my comrade, coworker, and fellow soldier-in-arms—your|
     v25                                |missionary and my personal attendant— |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since he was longing to see all of you and was quite distressed because you heard that he was rundown|
     v26                                |with some sort of sickness. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, he was weakened by sickness to the point of death, but instead of him dying God had mercy on|
     v27                                |him, and not just on him but on me too so that I wouldn’t be wrenched with pain upon pain. |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So with even more urgency I sent him on his way so that after seeing him again you would rejoice and|
     v28                                |I would be relieved of my pain. |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So receive him in the Lord with all the joy you can muster, and honor individuals like him, |
     V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since he came close to death on account of Christ’s work, risking his very life so that he would fill|
     v30                                |in the gap caused by your drop-off in serving me.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">of spirit</char>…Or: <char style="it">of</char> [<char style="it">the</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |Holy Spirit</char>. Ref. note of 1:27.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you’ll make me overjoyed if you would adopt that way of thinking</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fulfill|
                                        |my joy so that you would think the same</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on the same page</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of one thinking</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">held onto with everything you’ve got</char>…Lit: <char style="it">snatched by force|
                                        |and held onto</char>. Here’s a mental picture: a football player (American football) who has a fumbled|
                                        |football and is holding onto it, with a pile of other players on top of him trying to pull it out of|
                                        |his hands, before the referee comes over.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">unveiled to the public</char>…Lit: <char style="it">found</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">utmost reverence and respect</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fear and trembling</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of Eph. 6:5.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">of what pleases Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">on behalf of the pleasing</char> [<char|
                                        |style="it">of him</char>]. The definite article before <char style="it">pleasing </char>is put there|
                                        |as a short way to imply <char style="it">of him</char>.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Zeitgeist</char>…Lit: <char style="it">generation</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">will rejoice and will rejoice together</char>…Or: <char style="it">rejoice and rejoice|
                                        |together</char>. The GT is ambiguous, as the present and future forms in this case are identical. Since|
                                        |this is the apodosis of a conditional sentence, it doesn’t matter so much.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">missionary</char>…Lit: <char style="it">apostle</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rundown with some sort of sickness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weak</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">honor</char>…Also insinuates that they should pay his room and board when he’s there|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And in light of this, God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wherefore and God</char>. The|
                                        |word <char style="it">and </char>is associated to <char style="it">wherefore</char>. In NT Gk., It’s|
                                        |common to have <char style="it">and </char>come after a word such as <char style="it">wherefore. </char>This|
                                        |means that <char style="it">and </char>is not associated to <char style="it">God</char>; some translations|
                                        |err in this manner and render these words “Wherefore God also” or “Therefore God, even God” (<char style="it">and|
                                        |</char>appearing as <char style="it">even </char>in this case).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">out of His generosity gave</char>…Same word <char style="it">to give </char>as is used|
                                        |in 1:29; see note there. It was generous for God to hand over the keys to His kingdom to Jesus, but on|
                                        |the other hand, Jesus earned this by his obedience. Though the word <char style="it">gave </char>as used|
                                        |here points to God’s generosity, it does not negate the fact that Jesus earned a name above every name.|
                                        |God’s generosity was in the fact that He is willing to bestow an enormous amount of power on another|
                                        |person of the Trinity, not holding it for Himself. This is a reason why the three persons in the Trinity|
                                        |are one instead of three. Islam denies the Trinity because it says that the three persons in the Trinity|
                                        |would compete for power, but the insinuation in the word <char style="it">give </char>here is that God|
                                        |the Father out of His generosity won’t vie for power but instead hands it over to the Son.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, my dear comrades, rejoice in the Lord. It’s no problem at all for me to write this over|
     v 1                                |and over, and it’ll keep you from careening into a ditch.|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Look at the dogs (i.e., those who are worthless, contemptuous people who live like animals; those who|
     v 2                                |are excluded from having a covenant with God) and don’t stop looking at them, look at those who do evil,|
     v 2                                |look at the anti-circumcision (i.e., those who think they have a covenant with God but the opposite is|
     v 2                                |true). |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that we are the circumcision (i.e., you’re the ones who actually have a covenant|
     v 3                                |with God), the ones who have a service of worship in the Spirit of God and make audacious remarks in|
     v 3                                |Christ Jesus and have no confidence in the flesh (i.e., in your own selves; in your abilities apart from|
     v 3                                |God to please God; in your ability to gain God’s favor by simply following a list of rules; in your human|
     v 3                                |credentials), |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |although I have confidence in the flesh. If some other person has confidence in the flesh, I have more.|
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Circumcised on the eighth day; an Israeli by race, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew who stands out|
     v 5                                |among the Hebrews; a Pharisee who was totally committed to doing everything according to the Law of Moses;|
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |as far as the intensity of his zeal, a person who was persecuting the church; as far as his pursuit of|
     v 6                                |a righteousness (i.e., a means of standing before God and telling Him why He should approve of your life)|
     v 6                                |which is generated by means of following the Law, faultless.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Never mind all that—whatever gain (i.e., advantages) I had, I consider it to be lost (i.e., to have been|
     v 7                                |forfeited) on account of Christ. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh, no, no—even I consider everything forfeited on account of the surpassing greatness and excellence|
     v 8                                |of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, on account of whom everything has been forfeited, and I consider|
     v 8                                |everything to be garbage and crap so that I may gain Christ |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and that I would be found in him not having my own righteousness, one which is derived from following|
     v 9                                |the Law but instead one which is through the faith of Christ, which is a righteousness from God on the|
     v 9                                |basis of the Faith— |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to come to know him and the power of his resurrection and the sharing of and participation in his sufferings,|
     v10                                |while being conformed to his death, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |if somehow I might attain the breaking free from and rising from the dead.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that I’ve already attained these things I’m writing about or have reached the point of perfection,|
     v12                                |but I’m chasing after these things in the hope that I just might put them under my thumb, on the basis|
     v12                                |of me having been put under the thumb by Christ Jesus. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Comrades, I don’t figure that I’ve reached the point where I’ve put these things under my thumb, but|
     v13                                |I do this one thing: I forget about what’s behind me and press on to what lies ahead of me. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I keep my eye on the ball and chase after the prize of God’s high calling in Christ Jesus. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So any person at all who’s mature, may we be of this opinion; and if you are of a different opinion,|
     v15                                |God will reveal this to you. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In any event, let’s be diligent about maintaining what we’ve already attained.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Become people who imitate me, comrades, and pay careful attention to those who live their day to day|
     v17                                |lives using us as role-models. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, many live their day to day lives in the opposite manner, people whom I was constantly writing|
     v18                                |to you about, but now—even while crying—I’m telling you are the enemies of the cross of Christ, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |people whose destination is destruction, whose god is their belly and who take delightful pride in their|
     v19                                |shame, who are consumed with thinking about earthly things. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |As far as we’re concerned, though, the country that we’re citizens of exists in the heavens (i.e., in|
     v20                                |the spiritual domain and in heaven itself), from which we also eagerly await a savior, namely the Lord|
     v20                                |Jesus Christ, to come out of, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who will transform our humble, lowly, abased bodies into a body of his glory done in a way which is consistent|
     v21                                |with him operating in what he’s capable of and with him making all things subject to himself.|

     f                          NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the circumcision</char>…Many biblical scholars believe that the Philippian church consisted|
                                        |of all women. If this is the case, then Paul is calling women “the circumcision,” which, physically speaking,|
                                        |only applies to men. This supports the notion that there are words in the Bible which, on the surface|
                                        |only apply to men, but in fact apply to both men and women.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Chapter 4  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |…So my dear comrades whom I miss very much, my joy and my crowning achievement, make your stand in the|
     v 1                                |Lord this way, my beloved.|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I ask that Euodia and Syntyche compromise and live harmoniously in the Lord. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Yes, and I ask you too, my honest-to-goodness business partners, help them, they who are the very ones|
     v 3                                |who came and joined me in helping spread the Gospel (i.e., the message I’m spreading), which includes|
     v 3                                |Clement and the rest of my other fellow workers whose names are in the Book of Life.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Always rejoice in the Lord. I’ll say it again: rejoice. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let your courteous, generous, mild, gentle, kind, tolerant demeanor be made known to all people: the|
     v 5                                |Lord is nearby.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t worry, be anxious, or have angst about anything, but instead in every situation and concerning|
     v 6                                |everything you need make your requests known to God by means of prayer and supplication with thanksgiving,|
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the peace of God which transcends everything in your mind and transcends all mental activity will|
     v 7                                |guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, comrades, whatsoever is true, whatsoever is honorable, whatsoever is right, whatsoever|
     v 8                                |is pure, whatsoever is admirable, whatsoever is laudable—let these things turn over in your head—let|
     v 8                                |your mind crunch these thoughts—figure these things out—meditate on them. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And what you learned, embraced, heard, and saw in me, put these things into practice, and the God of|
     v 9                                |peace will be with you.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I was just thrilled in the Lord that your consideration for how well-off I am has finally improved, in|
     v10                                |the respect that you considered my financial state of affairs over and over again but time and again|
     v10                                |lacked the opportunity to help me out financially. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that I’m forced to speak this way out of lack, seeing that I’ve learned to be self-sufficient regardless|
     v11                                |of the situation I’m in. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I know from firsthand experience both how it is to be humbled (i.e., live in a financially bankrupted|
     v12                                |or impoverished condition) and how it is to be prosperous: in each and every circumstance I’ve learned|
     v12                                |the secret of every one of these: getting my belly filled, going hungry, prospering, and having a lack|
     v12                                |of provision: |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I can do anything by him who gives me the power. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Nevertheless it was a good thing that you did in commiserating with, sharing in, and partaking of my|
     v14                                |difficulties.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now also, you know for a fact, Philippians, that in the early days of the Gospel when I left Macedonia,|
     v15                                |no church participated in regard to this matter of giving and receiving except for you only, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |that once and again a second time while I was in Thessalonica you sent me a contribution to help with|
     v16                                |my needs. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that I’m fishing for handouts—no—I’m seeking the Fruit which is being multiplied and credited to|
     v17                                |your account. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I have everything I need and then some, having been resupplied by Epaphroditus by those things sent|
     v18                                |from you, a pleasant odor, an acceptable sacrifice, pleasing to God like the sacrifices offered to God|
     v18                                |in the Old Testament that He said pleased Him. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My God shall supply all your needs reflective of His riches in glory in Christ Jesus. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the glory be given to our God and Father forever and ever. Amen (i.e., let us pause a moment for|
     v20                                |that finishing remark to sink in).|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Say hello to all the saints in Christ Jesus (i.e., those who believe in Christ) for me. The comrades|
     v21                                |with me extend their greetings to you as well. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All the saints say hello, especially those who belong to Caesar’s household.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From Paul the apostle of Christ Jesus through the agency of the will of God and from Comrade Timothy,|
 + N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the saints (i.e., the believers in Christ)—what faithful comrades!—in Colossae,|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace to you from our Father-God:|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While praying, we’re constantly thanking the Father-God of our Lord Jesus Christ for you, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having heard about your faith in Christ Jesus and about the love you have for all the saints |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |on account of the hope which is stashed away for you in the heavens (i.e., in the spiritual domain or|
     v 5                                |in heaven itself), which you previously heard about in the Message of Truth which is from the Gospel|

     v 6                                |of the world just as it is also doing the same in us as well from the days you heard about it and came|
     v 6                                |to recognize the grace of God contained in the truth, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which is consistent with the way you were taught it by our dear servant Epaphras, who is a faithful deacon|

     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">thrones, lordships, rulers, or authorities</char>…These are defined in note of 1 Cor.|

                                        |(more specifically, demonic) positions, as we know from Eph. 1:21; 6:12 that “rulers and authorities”|
                                        |refers to demonic beings.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">any warm body to be found anywhere</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to all creation under|
                                        |the heaven</char> [<char style="it">sky</char>]. Liberties taken. <char style="it">Heaven </char>is singular|
                                        |here (plural elsewhere in this chapter) and it has a definite article, so heaven refers to the sky here|
                                        |and not any of the other meanings for the Gk. word for heaven. Like in Mark 16:15, 2 Cor. 5:17 <char|
                                        |style="it">creation </char>is a metonymy which refers to people and not to the actual creation. This|
                                        |phrase “to all creation under the sky” is an idiom. “Under the sky” and smacks of “under the sun” as|
                                        |used in Eccl. 1:9. The entire idiom means that the Gospel was preached to every sort of person there|
                                        |is and every in every kind of place there is.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that I want you to know how great a conflict I have on your behalf and on the|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">that flesh-infested body</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the body of the flesh</char>.|

     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the angelic beings</char>…What we know as “angels” are often called “angels of God”|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">religious festivals, start of a new month celebrations, or holidays</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">festivals or new moons or Sabbaths</char>. These are festivities prescribed by the Law of|
                                        |Moses and are mentioned several times in the OT. An example is the prophet Hosea in Hos. 2:11, “I will|
                                        |also cause all her mirth to cease, her feast days, her new moons, and her Sabbaths, and all her solemn|
                                        |feasts” (KJV). Just as Hosea described these with the word “mirth,” these are all holidays and celebrations,|
                                        |but celebrations and holidays which are commanded by the Law.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">that which is a shadow of what’s to come but the body which casts that shadow is Christ’s</char>…Much|
                                        |of the Law of Moses was arcane rules that only makes sense in light of this clarification, that they|
                                        |were hints, symbols, and foreshadowings of what was to come, but the essence is in Christ. This reinforces|
                                        |what Paul said in Gal. 3:24. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So if you were raised together with Christ, continually seek the things above where Christ is seated|

     v 5                                |lewd, crude, crass, foul-mouthed, disgusting untidiness, abject neglect of personal hygiene; disgusting|
     v 5                                |references to or treatment of bodily functions); passion (i.e., strong, out-of-control emotion or passionate|
     v 5                                |desire which takes ascendency over logical thinking); bad, wrong, or evil desire; and greed, which is|
     v 5                                |a thing in particular which amounts to idolatry. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of these things the wrath of God comes upon the sons of disobedience (i.e., those who make it|

     v 7                                |after life in the midst of these things. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But lay aside every one of these things right now…vindictiveness (i.e., heightened anger in regard to|

     v11                                |expect to have a relationship with God because of this) and uncircumcised (i.e., those who have no relationship|
     v11                                |with God), barbarian (i.e., the foreign, uncivilized, uneducated, uncultured), Scythian (i.e., the wild,|
     v11                                |savage, ferocious), slave (i.e., who are also the menial servants, the lowest of the low, the bottommost|
     v11                                |caste), freeman (i.e., working or middle-class)—uh-uh, every little bit of everything is Christ.|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From Paul, Silas, and Timothy:|

 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re always thanking God for all of you, bringing you up in prayer, continuously |

     v 3                                |of our Lord Jesus Christ in the sight of our God and Father, |

     v 5                                |only but also in supernatural power and in the Holy Spirit and with much conviction, just as you know|
     v 5                                |full-well what sort of men we turned out to be while among you throughout our stay with you.|

     v 9                                |on you, and how you turned to God, having turned from the idols you were serving to serve a living and|
     v 9                                |true God |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to wait for His son to come out of heaven, whom He raised from the dead, Jesus who’s rescuing us|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS1 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact you yourselves know full-well, comrades, that the impact we had on you wasn’t a waste of time,|
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |rather, having suffered before and having been treated with insolence (as you’re well aware), in Philippi|
     v 2                                |we were emboldened in our God to tell you God’s good-news message, the Gospel, while in the face of a|
     v 2                                |lot of opposition. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, our encouragement was not from us being in error or from an uncleanness (i.e., something dirty,|
     v 3                                |impure, or something one should stay away from), nor did it exist in deceit or guile, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but instead it’s in line with the way we’ve been granted by God to be entrusted with the Gospel—that’s|

                                        |[Gk. <char style="it">psuchā</char>, <char style="w" strong="G05590">ψυχή</char>)]. This verse sheds|
                                        |light on the meaning of <char style="it">psuchā, </char>from which the English words <char style="it">psychology,|
                                        |psyche, </char>etc. are derived. <char style="it">Psuchā </char>means “mind, soul, and emotions”. It|
                                        |is also is surrogate used to refer to a person. This carries over into English if, for example, a ship|
                                        |sank, we might say, “there were 25 souls that perished.” Using <char style="it">soul </char>instead of|
                                        |<char style="it">person </char>emphasizes the fact that the people mentioned had a life-essence to them.|
                                        |They had families, friends; they had interesting aspects to their personality; they had a will; they|
                                        |had a thirst for life which manifested itself in various way; they were real people. Also, ref. not of|
                                        |1 Cor. 2:14.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, comrades, we ask you in the Lord—plead with you—that you go to higher and higher levels|

     v 1                                |you received from us (which is consistent with the way you are currently living your lives). |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that you know some of the instructions we gave you through the Lord Jesus.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, this is the will of God (your holiness is the will of God!): it is for you to abstain from the|
     v 3                                |fornication you’re surrounded by (i.e., by the loose sexual morals we all know about); |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for each of you to know how to gain possession and keep possession of his own personal container (i.e.,|
     v 4                                |his body, the container for his soul and spirit) in holiness and dignity, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not in an intense, all-consuming feeling of lust (just like the Gentiles who don’t know God) |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but in not stepping out of line and taking advantage of or defrauding his fellow-comrade in the matter|
     v 6                                |of sexual morality. Because of this the Lord takes vengeance in issues pertaining to these transgressions,|
     v 6                                |consistent with the way we told you previously, telling it in a dead-serious manner. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that God has not called you to uncleanness (i.e., God’s intention for your|
     v 7                                |life in His kingdom was not to commit filthy, disgusting deeds) but rather to live in holiness. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Consequently, he who disregards this command isn’t disregarding a human being but is disregarding God|
     v 8                                |instead, Who gives His Holy Spirit to you.|

     v 9                                |the love one should have for another. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, you also extend the same practices to all the comrades all over Macedonia. We beg you, comrades,|
     v10                                |to do even more |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and make it a goal to be still (i.e., not be stirred by loud, negative emotions), to do your own things|
     v11                                |(i.e., concentrate on your own lives), and to work with your own hands (i.e., don’t rely on others to|
     v11                                |do your work), and do these things in line with the way we recommended, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the way you conduct your lives would leave a good impression on those on the outside and so that|
     v12                                |you won’t need anything.|

     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, if we believe that Jesus died and rose from the dead, then we are also entitled to believe|
     v14                                |that God will take those who sleep through Jesus (i.e., those who died trusting in Jesus) along together|
     v14                                |with him the same way. |

     v15                                |the living who remain on the Earth until the coming of the Lord will absolutely not arrive at the destination|
     v15                                |before those who sleep, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because the Lord himself—with the shout of a command by the voice of an archangel and by God’s bugle|

     v16                                |to life), |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |then you who are alive who remain on the Earth will be taken together with them as a single unit into|
     v17                                |the clouds to a meeting with the Lord in the air—And that’s the way we’ll always be with the Lord.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The bottom line is that we should comfort and exhort each other with these words.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">go to higher and higher levels</char>…Lit: <char style="it">abound more</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">container</char>…Also: <char style="it">vessel</char>. Like the way it’s used in 2 Cor.|
                                        |4:7, this refers to our body.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">dignity</char>…Also: <char style="it">honor</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stepping out of line</char>…Lit: <char style="it">throwing beyond</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">until</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to</char>. As though heading towards a destination.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shout of a command</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a call</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">intense, all-consuming feeling of lust</char>…Lit: <char style="it">passion of desire</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">lust</char>]. It’s normal for a person to have sexual desire, even a strong desire,|
                                        |but Paul’s talking about a desire that’s been amplified beyond normal amounts of sexual desire (strong|
                                        |as that may be). The Gk. word <char style="it">passion </char>is also used to describe the passion of|
                                        |the pain and suffering of death, like the passion of Christ when he was crucified—this is how strong|
                                        |of a word it is. Sexual predators and sex offenders reach this point, the point where their passion of|
                                        |desire takes control of them and they commit criminal acts. A couple notches down, it will also cause|
                                        |the ordinary person to conduct immoral acts.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not stepping out of line and taking advantage of or defrauding his fellow-comrade in|
                                        |the matter</char>…Applying logic to this statement here from v. 6 in relationship to the passage as a|
                                        |whole, Paul is telling those in the church not to “defraud” their fellow brother in Christ, and this|
                                        |in relationship to sexual morals. There are two possibilities: first, Paul could be talking about a man|
                                        |having an affair with another man’s wife. Second, Paul could be talking about a man sleeping with the|
                                        |young, unmarried daughter of another man. I believe it’s more likely that Paul is talking about the former|
                                        |than the latter. Therefore, the definition of <char style="it">the fornication </char>(v. 3) is adulterous|
                                        |liaisons. This added with the additional evidence from 1 Cor. 5:1 suggest that the word <char style="it">fornication|
                                        |</char>as used in the NT is talking about grossly immoral sexual acts. Or, put another way, when Paul|
                                        |addresses the issue here and in 1 Cor. 5:1, he’s talking about something which is grossly immoral. The|
                                        |church, however, makes no distinction between sexual acts which are grossly immoral and those which are|
                                        |mildly immoral when applying the word <char style="it">fornication. </char>They should.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">having strong likings for other comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brotherly-love</char>.|
                                        |This Gk. word is a compound where the second word <char style="it">love </char>is the Gk. word <char|
                                        |style="it">philos</char> (φίλος /Strong’s 5384) and not <char style="it">agapā </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00026">ἀγάπη</char>). Philos differs from agapā in that philos is a love for a person because|
                                        |of how likeable they are, whereas agapā sees value in a person sometimes in spite of how unlikeable they|
                                        |are. Note that the word for <char style="it">love </char>at the end of v. 10 is agapā, not philos.|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">holy hug</char>…Lit: <char style="it">holy kiss</char>. Liberties taken.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirit, soul, and body</char>…This verse is key in specifying the three components of|
                                        |every human being. The listing is ordered from most important to least important.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Spirit—man is a spiritual being, and as such has commonality with all spiritual beings: God, angels,|
                                        |and demons. Sin causes the spirit to die; receiving Christ causes the spirit to be born again. The Holy|
                                        |Spirit dwells in a believer’s human spirit. Man’s spirit guides him through the course of life.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Soul—the soul is the mind, will, emotions. It’s the peculiar things that give a person personality and|
                                        |vitality.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">strong, prevailing attitude</char>…Lit: <char style="it">spirit</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">this lawlessness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the lawlessness </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00458">ἀνομία</char>). Gk: <char style="it">anomia</char> (feminine). Note that the Gk. word|
                                        |for Lawless-One in v. 7 is <char style="it">anomos </char>(masculine). Paul’s making a distinction by|
                                        |using these slightly different words: anomia refers to a quality, whereas anomos <char style="w" strong="G00459">ἄνομος</char>)|
                                        |refers to a person, the embodiment of these qualities.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he who restrains</char>…Gk. <char style="it">o katexōn </char>[ὁ κατέχων, <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G02722">κατέχων</char>)]. This is not quite the same as what’s in v. 6, which is <char style="it">to|
                                        |katexon </char>(τὸ κατέχον, <char style="w" strong="G02722">κατέχον</char>)]<char style="it">. </char>Although|
                                        |the definite articles are both neuter/masculine, the substantive of the first is masculine while the|
                                        |second in neuter. This suggest that it’s “he who restrains” not “the thing that restrains.” Ref. note|
                                        |of v. 7.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by blowing on him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">by the wind of his mouth</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">self-delusion</char>…Also: <char style="it">deceit</char>. Same word used in Mark 4:19;|
                                        |ref. note there.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">crème de la crème</char>…Lit: <char style="it">first-fruits</char>. Ref. note of Rom.|
                                        |8:23.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">traditions</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">apostasy</char>…The Gk. word <char style="it">apostasia </char><char style="w" strong="G00646">ἀποστασία</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">. </char>The NASB defines this as “a falling away from the faith.” Some Gk. scholars disagree|
                                        |with this and claim that it means “departure” instead, citing sources such as the <char style="it">Geneva|
                                        |Bible, </char>Tyndale’s translation, the <char style="it">Great Bible</char>, Kenneth Wuest, and John|
                                        |Lineberry. Their reasoning for choosing “departure” over “a falling away” is that <char style="it">aphistāmi|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G00868">ἀφίστημι</char>)<char style="it">, </char>the root verb from which|
                                        |apostasia is derived, means <char style="it">to depart. </char>Furthermore, they say that <char style="it">apostasia|
                                        |</char>(the noun form) only occurs twice in the NT, here in 1 Thess. 2:3 and over in Acts 21:21. Although|
                                        |the context of Acts 21:21 suggests that apostasia means “falling away” rather than “departure,” the critics|
                                        |claim that this isn’t sufficient evidence to negate the core meaning of aphistāmi. However, what these|
                                        |dissenters fail to take into consideration is the use of apostasia in the LXX. Apostasia is found in|
                                        |Josh. 22:22; 2 Chron. 29:19; 2 Chron. 33:19; Jer. 2:19. In all four cases, apostasia means “rebellion,|
                                        |unfaithfulness, backsliding.” In other words, it means the same thing as “a falling away from the faith.”|
                                        |Paul read from the LXX frequently and extensively (it might’ve even been his primary study-Bible), and|
                                        |he was familiar with the occurrences and usages of apostasia in these passages and was mimicking its|
                                        |usage here in v. 3. But in any case, between the LXX and Acts. 21:21, there are five occurrences of apostasia|
                                        |in the Bible apart from 2:3 here. In five of the five occurrences—100% of the time—the meaning of apostasia|
                                        |is “a falling away from the faith.” The sixth must mean the same also, the one here in v. 3.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the thing that restrains him from being revealed in his own time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |restraint for him to be revealed in his</char> [or <char style="it">its</char>] <char style="it">own|
                                        |time. </char>The “thing that restrains” in v. 7 is the Gk. <char style="it">to katexon </char>(a form|
                                        |of <char style="it">o katexon</char>), where <char style="it">to </char>is the neuter definite article|
                                        |and <char style="it">katexon </char>is the neuter participle form of the verb <char style="it">katexō|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G02722">κατέχω</char>)<char style="it">, </char>which literally means|
                                        |<char style="it">to have down upon.</char>|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, pray for us, comrades, so that the word of the Lord would spread rapidly and would be|

     v 4                                |you are doing and will do what we charged you with. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord direct your hearts to the love of God and to the steadfastness and endurance of Christ.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we charge you, comrades, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ (i.e., by the authority given to us|
     v 6                                |by Jesus Christ) to stay away from all comrades who conduct themselves with a blatant disregard for the|
     v 6                                |rules which have been set in place and not according to the bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices|
     v 6                                |established in perpetuity which you received from us. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard you know in yourselves from first-hand experience how necessary it is for you to follow|
     v 7                                |our example, since we didn’t disregard the rules when we were among you, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor did we mooch any meals from anyone—uh-uh—we were toiling day and night doing back-breaking labor|
     v 8                                |so we wouldn’t be a burden on any of you— |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that we don’t have the right to make you provide boarding for us, but we choose to do what we did|
     v 9                                |instead so that we could offer ourselves to you as an example for you to imitate.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And in fact, when we were with you, we kept telling you to obey this rule: If a given person doesn’t|
     v10                                |want to work then don’t let him have a meal at mealtime. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact we hear that there are some people among you going about not following the rules, not doing any|
     v11                                |work but goofing off instead. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To such people we charge and advise in the Lord Jesus Christ certain admonishments so that by keeping|
     v12                                |quiet while working they would eat their own meal (i.e., would be entitled to receive a meal).|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you, comrades—don’t get tired of doing good. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if someone won’t obey the message we’re giving you by this letter were sending, take note of this|
     v14                                |guy: don’t associate with or get mixed up with him, so that he’ll be put to shame. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And don’t think of him as an enemy, but warn and admonish him as a comrade instead.|
 + N V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord of Peace himself grant you the peace throughout every circumstance in every place.|
 +P  V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord be with you all.|
 + N V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The greeting written here is in Paul’s handwriting, which is a distinguishing feature of every letter|
     v17                                |I write:|
 +P  V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |<char style="sc">THIS IS THE WAY I WRITE</char>.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spread rapidly</char>…Lit: <char style="it">run</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">perverse</char>…Lit: <char style="it">not in place</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity</char>…Lit: traditions|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mooch any meals from anyone</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ate a gift-bread from anyone</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">throughout every circumstance in every place</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through all|
                                        |in all place</char>. The GT is more poetic.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have a meal at mealtime</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eat</char>. When people congregated,|
                                        |they had a couple people cook for the entire group, because that was the most efficient way of handling|
                                        |food preparation up until modern times. Everyone would sit down at a table together at the same time,|
                                        |the food would be passed around, and it would all be shared. This proscription is to forbid a person|
                                        |from having a seat at the table and share in the meal if he didn’t share in the common work also.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">goofing off</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being a busybody; meddling</char>. The Gk.|
                                        |word literally means “to go around the periphery of work.” The picture is of someone going here or there|
                                        |when working—or supposedly working. Instead, he’s bothering other people who are working, striking up|
                                        |non-work-related conversations, instead of getting his own work done. The assertion that this is what|
                                        |this Gk. means is confirmed by the statement in v. 12 which says to “keeping quiet while working.” Nothing|
                                        |has changed since ancient times!|

     v 9                                |that matter) was put in place for a reason, not for someone who lives right but for the lawless, for|

 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now to the King of the eternities—to the Incorruptible, Invisible, Singular God—be honor and glory forever|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I urge that first above all else you offer supplications (i.e., urgent requests), prayers (i.e., generic|

     v 6                                |to be that which serves as proof or makes a solemn statement in every individual period of human history—|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">supplications (i.e., urgent requests), prayers (i.e., generic prayers), intercessions|
