     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Deāsis <char style="w" strong="G01162">δέησις</char>)—a prayer which asks for wants or needs; urgent|
                                        |requests|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Proseuchā <char style="w" strong="G04335">προσευχή</char>)—lit: <char style="it">speaking out to</char>.|
                                        |This is the general word for prayer. Since a secondary meaning is a place of prayer, it insinuates prayers|
                                        |done in that setting, hence: formal prayers; structured prayers; prayers done at a set time.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Enteuksis <char style="w" strong="G01783">ἔντευξις</char>)—lit: <char style="it">a falling in with; a|
                                        |meeting with; a coming together; a conference or conversation</char>. The word is rendered <char style="it">intercession.|
                                        |</char>This kind of prayer insinuates a back-and-forth exchange between two parties; some sort of negotiation.|
                                        |The negotiations can be to suspend a judgment incurred because of a violation of the rules or other just|
                                        |circumstances, such as when Abraham negotiated with God to spare Sodom and Gomorrah. In Abraham’s case,|
                                        |the intercession was done on behalf of another party, but intercession can be done for one’s own self.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Eucharistia <char style="w" strong="G02169">εὐχαριστία</char>)—The giving of thanks to God, which is|
                                        |a kind of prayer.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in an exotic hairstyle and with ultra-expensive gold jewelry or pearls or expensive|
                                        |clothing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">braided hair and gold or pearls or expensive clothing</char>. As|
                                        |what Paul writes here is identical to what Peter writes in 1 Pet. 3:3, this implies that this was a problem|
                                        |in the early church. Since Paul precedes this by saying that women should dress in good taste, modestly,|
                                        |and exercise good judgment and self-control, it stands to reason that these hairstyling, jewelry, and|
                                        |expensive clothes were not considered to be good taste, modest, or indicative of one exercising good|
                                        |judgment. Since we in modern times don’t consider the use of hairstyling, jewelry, etc. to be bad taste|
                                        |or indicative of a lack of judgment (except for a few very conservative denominations, most of which|
                                        |have reversed their position), this warrants closer examination. |
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Let’s assume that the amount of gold in piece a jewelry is equivalent to the gold in a Roman Aureus (8g|
                                        |of gold), which was valued at 25 Denarii, and let’s assume each Denarius represented a day’s labor. If|
                                        |there are 312 working days in a years, this represents around 8% of a laborer’s annual income. So from|
                                        |the perspective of us in modern times, if a person earns $50,000 a year, an 8g piece of gold jewelry|
                                        |would cost around $5000 in today’s money (and the same 8g of gold goes for around $500 nowadays). This|
                                        |means that gold jewelry was more expensive for them back then that it is for us, as this hypothetical|
                                        |example shows an 8-to-1 difference then to now.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |So it was more expensive, in terms of purchasing power, for the average woman to dress in the way that|
                                        |Peter and Paul admonish them not to than it is for a woman to dress herself today in the same way. It|
                                        |may be that these women were spending outrageous amounts of money on their dress, and from the remarks|
                                        |Peter and Paul made, were investing their self-image in their ability to dress lavishly and were trying|
                                        |to imitate the world, including the lasciviousness of worldly women.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The lesson that modern-day Christian women should learn is to recognize the root-problems here and not|
                                        |be so concerned about the letter of the law. Women shouldn’t be obsessed with dressing in clothing that|
                                        |they can’t afford, trying to imitate those in the world who live an ungodly life, or base their self-image|
                                        |on the way they look. Being beautiful on the inside is more important than trying to make oneself beautiful|
                                        |on the outside.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">woman</char>…The Gk. words rendered <char style="it">man</char> and <char style="it">woman</char>|
                                        |are <char style="it">anār</char> <char style="w" strong="G00435">ἀνήρ</char>) and <char style="it">gunaika|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G01135">γυνή</char>), which are also the same words rendered <char style="it">husband</char>|
                                        |and <char style="it">wife</char>. The ambiguity (ambiguity…I thought Gk. was this ultra-specific language?)|
                                        |is resolved by context. When Paul leaves instructions for the anār and the gunaika in Ephesians and Colossians,|
                                        |the context is obvious: the rendering is husband and wife. Here also the rendering is context-dependent.|
                                        |Is Paul talking about husbands and wives or men and women? Most translations choose men and women. To|
                                        |justify it being husbands and wives, there must be something in the context that indicates that this|
                                        |is the case. The evidence in that favor is that vv. 11,12 are similar to 1 Cor. 14:33–36, which we know|
                                        |was addressed to wives. Also, v. 15 talks about bearing children, which means that it’s addressed to|
                                        |wives. The subject is omitted from the sentence of v. 15, relying on the verb conjugation in conjunction|
                                        |with the context to insinuate that the subject is <char style="it">she. </char>It Gk., it’s not common|
                                        |to have the subject omitted entirely. In lieu of its total omission, a definite article is used as a|
                                        |pronoun, as a definite article is short, perhaps is even a proclitic. But by omitting the subject entirely,|
                                        |the writer assumes that the reader knows beyond any doubt that the subject to be used is easily insinuated|
                                        |by the context. Such is the case. Through this insinuation, v. 15 is tightly bound to the context. Therefore,|
                                        |since v. 15 addresses wives, not women, coupled with the similarity between this passage and 1 Cor. 14:33–36,|
                                        |one may put forth a weighty argument that the entire context of vv. 11–15 is of wives specifically, not|
                                        |of women in general.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">total submissiveness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all submission</char>. Ref. notes|
                                        |of Eph. 5:22; 1 Pet. 2:18 which explain the difference between <char style="it">submit </char>and <char|
                                        |style="it">obey.</char>|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">give instructions for what a person should or shouldn’t do</char>…Also: <char style="it">teach</char>.|
                                        |The Gk. word <char style="it">didaskō</char> (διδάσκω/Strong’s ). The meaning of this word extends beyond|
                                        |mere definition of the English word <char style="it">to teach</char>, and includes giving instruction|
                                        |as to what rules a person must follow. It’s used this way in Acts 15:1 (ref. note there). Since what|
                                        |follows the word didaskō here in v. 12 is “dominate” and “give orders,” it stands to reason that didaskō|
                                        |is used in this context to refer to giving instructions on what rules one should follow more so than|
                                        |meaning teaching (explaining).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Now, in vv. 13, 14, Paul gives the reasons why a woman shouldn’t be giving instruction. First is the|
                                        |fact that Adam was created before Eve and is therefore receives the leadership position. Second, women|
                                        |are more easily deceived, more so than men (cults usually have more women than men, for example), and|
                                        |for this reason are less qualified to be instructors. In spite of this, Titus 1:3 allows women to be|
                                        |teachers.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Plus Adam was not deceived by the serpent but the woman, once deceived, found herself|
                                        |in transgression</char>…We must keep in mind that Paul credits Adam—not Eve—with the original sin (Rom.|
                                        |5:14), in spite of centuries of Christian teaching to the contrary. Though both Adam and Eve sinned in|
                                        |the garden, Adam was not deceived when he partook of the forbidden fruit, and this makes his sin more|
                                        |heinous than Eve’s, as—according to this verse here—he knew exactly what he was doing when he bit the|
                                        |fruit. It was bold-faced disobedience in light of the full understanding and recollection of God’s commandment.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spared calamity through the childbearing</char> <char style="it">years</char> …Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">saved the childbearing</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">saved </char>rendered <char|
                                        |style="it">spared calamity </char>here is not in reference to her receiving Christ. Some that this is|
                                        |a promise for a woman escape death or harm when giving birth, which up until modern times was a serious|
                                        |threat to a woman’s well-being.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the husband of one woman</char>…This covers both polygamy (incidentally) and marriage,|
                                        |divorce, then remarriage (primarily). Many interpret this proscription as applying to polygamy, but polygamy|
                                        |wasn’t practiced in the parts of the Roman Empire where Paul’s churches were. Furthermore, in 5:9 when|
                                        |Paul is talking about widows, he says that she should be “the wife of one man.” This is the same wording|
                                        |in GT as “husband of one woman,” except in reverse. If “husband of one woman” were talking about polygamy—in|
                                        |this case, a single man having multiple wives at the same time—then “wife of one man” would have to be|
                                        |talking about a single woman having multiple husbands at the same time—something which is unheard of.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mystery</char>…The “mystery of piety” here and the mystery of “Christ in you, the hope|
                                        |of glory” (Col. 1:27) refines the definition of <char style="it">mystery </char>as used in the NT: a|
                                        |“mystery” is something which is profound.|

 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t accept an accusation of wrongdoing against an elder except if it’s leveled by two or three people|
     v19                                |who solemnly swear that it’s true.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Expose those who are sinners in front of everyone, so that everyone will become afraid of sinning.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I solemnly affirm these things and declare them to be true before God, Christ Jesus, and the special|
     v21                                |angels, so that you would guard these things without prejudice, doing nothing out of favoritism.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t be too eager to lay hands on anyone and thereby make them a minister nor should you participate|
     v22                                |in others’ sins: keep yourself unsullied.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t just drink water only anymore, but use a little wine as a medicine of a sort because of your stomach|
     v23                                |and your frequent ailments.|
 +   V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For some people, their sins are obvious, paraded before them with much fanfare for everyone to see in|
     v24                                |front of them on their way to judgment; but some come right behind them, quietly, unannounced, and unexpected|
     v24                                |by everyone. |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Deeds operate the same way that I just described about sin: the deeds which are exemplary are obvious|
     v25                                |to everyone, but the ones which are otherwise can’t be kept hidden.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">address him as though he goes by “Mr.”</char>…Lit: <char style="it">entreat as father</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">give financial support to a widow</char>…Lit: <char style="it">honor</char> [<char style="it">give|
                                        |honorariums to</char>] <char style="it">a widow</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">when put to the close scrutiny of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">before</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">supplications and prayers</char>…Ref. note of 2:1|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">become ardent followers of Satan</char>…Or: <char style="it">become disciples of Satan</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">behind Satan</char>. A NT expression; ref. note of Matt. 4:19.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">If a particular woman who is a believer has widows</char> <char style="it">in her care</char>…I’m|
                                        |unsure whether this is correct|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">twice their pay</char>…Lit: <char style="it">double honor</char> [<char style="it">honorarium</char>]|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">chosen</char>…Or: <char style="it">special</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">special angels</char>…Lit: <char style="it">chosen angels</char>. This might be a reference|
                                        |to the seraphim and cherubim.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ailments</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weaknesses</char>. Ref. note of John 5:3.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">overpowered with physical, sensual desires contrary to their vow to Christ</char>…The|
                                        |single Gk. word rendered <char style="it">overpowered with physical, sensual desires</char> is a word|
                                        |Paul coins here, not found anywhere else. Paul may be referring to sexual desire, or he may be referring|
                                        |to the desire of a woman to become more affluent through marriage, which would bring those extra creature-comforts|
                                        |she misses in her poverty (or both perhaps.) To this second point, the root for this Gk. word appears|
                                        |in Rev. 18:7,9, and is rendered <char style="it">luxury </char>there.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">paraded before them with much fanfare for everyone to see in front of them on their|
                                        |way to judgment; but some come right behind them, quietly, unannounced, and unexpected by everyone</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">going before to judgment; but some follow right behind</char>. A metaphor of the victory|
                                        |parade of a general who’s won a great victory and wishes to flaunt his victory when he marches into the|
                                        |city. The procession is orchestrated so that, when arriving in the city, the spoils of war, the glitz,|
                                        |the glamor go first. This is done to attract attention and applause and to drum up awe and excitement.|
                                        |Then comes the general. After him comes the slaves he’s captured, etc. They get little attention. In|
                                        |the metaphor, the sins of some people are well-known, everyone has talked and talked about them, dissecting|
                                        |every bit of the evil deed. But the sins of some people are a well-kept secret, but they will make their|
                                        |way to judgment.|

     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which appearance he will indicate in separate eras of time, he the blessed and singular authority, the|
     v15                                |King of the kings and Lord of the lords, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the one having immortality, whose resides in unapproachable light which no one has seen or is able to|
     v16                                |stare at: to him be honor and might forever. Amen (i.e., let us pause a moment for that remark to sink|
     v16                                |in).|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Charge those who are rich in this present age not to be high-minded or to set their hope on the uncertainty|
     v17                                |of wealth, but to instead set it on God the One Who richly makes available to us all sorts of things|
     v17                                |for our enjoyment, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and makes these things available to us so we can be doing good things to others, so that we can become|
     v18                                |richer in top-notch works, so that they can be generous, willing to share, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |storing away for themselves a good nest egg for the future, so that they would grab and hold onto what|
     v19                                |life really is.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh, Timothy, guard what’s been entrusted to you, avoid the desecrated, profane kind of useless chatter|
     v20                                |and the contradictions of so-called knowledge and understanding, |
   N V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which some, by professing these things, have veered off into a ditch with respect to the Faith.|
 +P  V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of God be with you all.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">forced to be a slave</char>…Lit: <char style="it">servants under the yoke</char>. The|
                                        |Gk. word <char style="it">doulos </char><char style="w" strong="G01401">δοῦλος</char>)<char style="it">,|
                                        |</char>which is either servant or slave, is narrowed in scope to mean <char style="it">slave </char>and|
                                        |not <char style="it">servant </char>by the phrase <char style="it">under the yoke. </char>Also, plural|
                                        |words in this verse changed to singular for readability.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fellow-comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and we sure can’t</char>…Lit: <char style="it">since we can’t</char>. Various manuscripts|
                                        |differ here, and probably because what’s in several of the better manuscripts makes little sense.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">nest egg</char>…Lit: <char style="it">foundation</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">teaches things which are…shall we say…different</char>…All these are the single Gk.|
                                        |verb <char style="it">heterdidsakō </char><char style="w" strong="G02085">ἑτεροδιδασκαλέω</char>), “to|
                                        |different-teach.” This word only appears twice in the NT; Paul appears to have coined it. From the sound|
                                        |of it, he’s describing those who teach things which are perhaps novel, appealing, and sound good on the|
                                        |surface. Paul isn’t saying they are necessarily false teachings, they’re just different and warrant keeping|
                                        |a close eye on, because there may be a false doctrine lurking under the guise of a new, welcoming message.|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">competently handling</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cutting a path or a road in a straight|
                                        |direction</char>. Refers to the skill of a laborer. This together with the word <char style="it">laborer|
                                        |</char>is a metaphor, comparing how skilled a laborer is with his tools to how skilled a teacher should|
                                        |be with the word of God.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ready to be used for something good on any special occasion</char>…Lit: <char style="it">prepared|
                                        |unto all good work</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">good </char>is not the word <char style="it">kalos|
                                        |</char>(καλῶς /Strong’s 2773)which Paul uses frequently in such cases, and, based on that, one expects|
                                        |to use here, but the word <char style="it">agathos </char><char style="w" strong="G00018">ἀγαθός</char>)instead.|
                                        |Agathos means that the nature of the function the pot is to be used for is good itself; hence, it refers|
                                        |to a special occasion or the like.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM2 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now understand this: in the last days, difficult periods of time will come with their difficult conditions.|
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In connection to this, the people during those periods will be selfish; money-loving; they’ll be braggarts;|
     v 2                                |arrogant; they’ll be slanderous, blasphemous, bad-mouthing people; they’ll be disobedient to their parents;|
     v 2                                |unforgiving, unkind, and ungrateful; they’ll have no piety or religious devotion; |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they won’t have the love one naturally has for family, for kin, for nation, etc.; they’ll be irreconcilable|
     v 3                                |and incapable of negotiating solutions to problems; |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they’ll be traitors and will betray others; they’ll be rash, impulsive, and reckless; puffed up and conceited;|
     v 4                                |they’ll be pleasure-loving more than God-loving; |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they’ll have an outward appearance of godliness but will have rejected godliness’s power. Go out of your|
     v 5                                |way to avoid those sort of people.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, included with these sort of people are those who sneak into the houses of certain women|
     v 6                                |and utterly captivate silly women who have a pile of sins a mile high, silly women who are led by various|
     v 6                                |intense and impulsive desires (including sexual desire), |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |always learning but never arriving at the recognition and precise understanding of the truth. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the manner in which Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses is the same way that these people oppose the|
     v 8                                |truth, people of depraved minds, failing to make the grade where the Faith is concerned. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But never mind that—they won’t get very far; the fact is, their folly will be perfectly clear to everyone,|
     v 9                                |as the folly of those guys Jannes and Jambres also became perfectly clear to everyone.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you now—stick close to my doctrine, my way of life, my plan, my love, my perseverance, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to my persecutions, my sufferings, such as what happened to me in Antioch, in Iconium, in Lystra—oh,|
     v11                                |what persecutions I endured—and the Lord rescued me from all of them. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Everyone who wants to live a life of godliness in Christ Jesus will be persecuted.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Evil people and charlatans will make progress for the worse, leading others astray and being led astray|
     v13                                |themselves. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You, though, dwell in the things which you learned and came to trust, knowing whom you learned them from,|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and that you have known the sacred Scriptures from the time you were a wee child, the things that have|
     v15                                |the power to make you wise in the ways of salvation (i.e., ways of preventing being overtaken by calamity)|
     v15                                |through the faith which is in Christ Jesus. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All of Scripture has the breath of God (i.e., is inspired by God) and is useful for teaching, for reproof|
     v16                                |or cross-examination, for improvement, for training in righteousness, and the list goes on, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that God’s man or woman would be capable, proficient, and properly equipped for the purpose of doing|
     v17                                |any kind of good work imaginable.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">utterly captivate</char>…Lit: <char style="it">take captive as a prisoner of war</char>.|
                                        |A metaphor.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">silly women who are led</char>…The noun for <char style="it">silly women </char>is neuter,|
                                        |the participle <char style="it">led</char> is also neuter, like the participle for <char style="it">have|
                                        |a pile of sins</char>; therefore the antecedent of <char style="it">led </char>is <char style="it">silly|
                                        |women.</char> For that matter <char style="it">learning </char>in v. 7 is also neuter.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have known</char>…Lit: <char style="it">know</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the ways of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">unto</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sneak into the houses</char>…If one thinks about this more closely, the men described|
                                        |here who sneak into these women’s homes must do so with the cooperation and consent of the women. In|
                                        |other words, they cannot be burglars breaking into a house, as the door would be kept locked at night,|
                                        |the woman would scream (Deut. 22:24, though these are Gentiles), the man of the house (and there certainly|
                                        |would have been) would rescue her, etc. But the woman could find a time when nobody else was home, a|
                                        |time for the man to enter the house for a romantic rendezvous, adulterous or just consensual. Naturally,|
                                        |the man would have to be careful not to be seen entering the house, hence Paul’s use of the word <char|
                                        |style="it">sneak</char>.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">silly women</char>…Lit: <char style="it">little women; </char>more precisely <char style="it">women-ettes</char>|
                                        |[the diminutive form of the word <char style="it">women</char>]. This word only appears once in the NT,|
                                        |and the lexicons provide little information about it, except to say that it’s pejorative. The fact that|
                                        |it’s a diminutive leads one to speculate that it’s slang of a sort. The closest equivalent might be the|
                                        |word <char style="it">bimbo, </char>though that might be too strong a word. We can only guess what the|
                                        |exact meaning is.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, a menial servant of God but yet an apostle (i.e., a missionary) of Jesus Christ according to the|
     v 1                                |Faith of God’s chosen people and the recognition of the truth which is reflective of godliness |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which rests upon a living hope of eternal life, which the God Who Won’t Lie promised before time immemorial—|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But He manifested His word in individual periods of human history by means of preaching, preaching that|
     v 3                                |I was entrusted with according to the commandment of God our Savior:|
 + N V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To Titus, a real son according to the common Faith:|
 +P  V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace from the Father God and Christ Jesus our savior.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The reason I left you behind in Crete is so that you would tidy up the remaining items and would go from|
     v 5                                |city to city and appoint elders (i.e., church board members) like I told you to do. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a given candidate is without moral flaws, the husband of one wife (i.e., not divorced and remarried),|
     v 6                                |the children he has are trustworthy, not ones who can be fairly accused of having a reckless disregard|
     v 6                                |for their own self-preservation or of being rebellious, then he’s met the minimum qualifications to be|
     v 6                                |an elder.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, a bishop (i.e., a head pastor), as the steward of God’s house, must be without moral flaws;|
     v 7                                |not stubborn or self-willed; not hot-tempered; not a heavy drinker; not pugnacious or a bully; not always|
     v 7                                |trying to make a fast buck through shady business practices; |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but instead hospitable, able to reach out to others, one who likes and can work with people who are different|
     v 8                                |than himself; a lover of all things good; sensible, serious, and level-headed; just and fair; holy; self-controlled,|
     v 8                                |disciplined, and having one’s impulses under control; |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |clinging to the tried-and-true message reflective of the doctrine we teach, so that he’d be capable of|
     v 9                                |both exhorting and encouraging others in the Sound Doctrine and correcting those who oppose it.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that there are those who refuse to submit to authority, those who say nothing|
     v10                                |when they speak and who are deceivers, especially those who came out of the circumcision (i.e., those|
     v10                                |whose background was that they were following the Law of Moses), |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who must be silenced, people in particular who subvert entire households, teaching things they mustn’t|
     v11                                |for morally unacceptable gain. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |One of their own prophets said, “Cretans are always liars, vicious brutes, and fat blimps.” |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m quoting a reliable source. You must severely correct them for this reason: so that they’ll be healthy|
     v13                                |in the Faith; |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so they won’t pay any attention to Jewish fables and to the commandments of people who are turning them|
     v14                                |away from the truth.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All things are clean (i.e., according to the Law of Moses, eligible to be touched, handled, and used;|
     v15                                |absent any defilement) to those who are clean; but to those who have been defiled (i.e., who’ve become|
     v15                                |tainted and are no longer clean) and who refuse to believe, nothing is pure—no, not a chance—both their|
     v15                                |minds and their consciences have come to be defiled. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They profess to know God, but their profession is repudiated by their actions, as these people are detestable,|
     v16                                |disobedient, and failures when comes to any good deed.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">time immemorial</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eternal times</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">individual periods of human history</char>…Lit: <char style="it">their own seasons</char>.|
                                        |Same phrase used in 1 Tim. 2:6;6:15.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">son</char>…Or: <char style="it">child</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tried-and-true message</char>…Lit: <char style="it">trustworthy word</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vicious brutes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">evil animals</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fat blimps</char>…Lit: <char style="it">free-from-labor bellies</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken. The <char style="it">Expositor’s Greek Testament</char> says, “He [the poet] has in his mind the|
                                        |belly, as it obtrudes on the beholder and is a burden to the possessor.”|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m quoting a reliable source</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the testimony itself is true</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bishop</char>…Ref. note of 1 Cor. 15:24. As vv. 5–6 address qualifications for elders|
                                        |and v. 7 begins with a coordinating conjunction, it stands to reason that, at least for the churches|
                                        |Titus was dealing with, elders were bishops and vice-versa. This supports the theory that the ancient|
                                        |church was originally run by elders but later on transitioned to one which was run by bishops instead.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">”Cretans are always liars, vicious brutes, and fat blimps”</char>…From the sounds of|
                                        |it, this prophet was parroting an outrageously false, negative ethnic stereotype about Cretans, which|
                                        |the prophet categorically applies to all Cretans. Paul is vehemently condemning that kind of language.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">clean</char>…Also: <char style="it">pure</char>. Paul’s usage of clean and defiled here|
                                        |is a metaphor to the OT concepts of clean and unclean, concepts which are deeply rooted in the Law of|
                                        |Moses and touch all the temple rituals and quite a lot of other things. Once something was defiled (tainted),|
                                        |it could no longer be used in the temple service. Care had to be taken to keep or maintain people or|
                                        |things in a state of cleanness.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The metaphor presented here is that a person who’s clean is one who’s pure in mind and spirit, and everything|
                                        |that person handles is automatically clean. A person who’s pure will look at any fact, teaching, philosophy,|
                                        |etc. and come up with practical applications, anecdotes, life-lessons, analogies, etc. which are pure,|
                                        |meaning they’ll support or complement Christian truths, principles, and values. But anyone who’s defiled,|
                                        |any fact, teaching, philosophy, etc. will ultimately lead to something twisted, to the point of contradicting|
                                        |Christian truths, principles, and values.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now talk in a way that makes sound doctrine more pronounced and more palatable.|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I expect the older men to be self-controlled and to exercise moderation in vices such as drinking; to|
     v 2                                |be honorable and respectable; to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; healthy in faith, love, perseverance.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Likewise, older women should behave in a reverent manner; not be slanderers; not have reached the point|
     v 3                                |where they have a compulsion to drink a lot; be ones who teach others to strive for excellence, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that they could train the young women to maintain a discipline of sensibility and self-control which|
     v 4                                |causes them to have a strong friendship with their husbands and enjoy their companionship, and train|
     v 4                                |them to do the same for their children; |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; to be chaste; to be good housekeepers and homemakers, submitting|
     v 5                                |to their husbands, so that the word of God not be spoken badly of.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Likewise, I exhort and encourage the young men to be sensible, serious, and level-headed |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in every aspect of their life, putting yourself out there as an example of a lifestyle characterized|
     v 7                                |by fine deeds; to be incorruptible in their adherence to the teaching of Christianity; to be dignified;|
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to have wholesome speech which is unassailable to accusation, so the opposition camp would be humiliated|
     v 8                                |by not having anything bad to say about them.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I exhort and encourage slaves to submit to their masters in all respects; to be pleasing and to not give|
     v 9                                |their masters any backtalk; |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to not go around stealing things, but to instead demonstrate that they’re good people and can be trusted|
     v10                                |in every regard, so that slaves acting this way would in every regard be a feather in the cap (so to|
     v10                                |speak) of the teaching of God our Savior.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, the grace of God, which is salvation, shined to all people, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |training us to deny the ungodliness and the strong, worldly desires, so we would live in the present|
     v12                                |age sensibly, with self-control, justly, and godly, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |awaiting the blessed hope and the appearance of the glory of our Great God and of our savior Christ Jesus,|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave himself for us so that he would redeem us (i.e., recover for us what we once had) from any sort|
     v14                                |of wickedness and lawlessness (i.e., a refusal to be restrained by the rules of God or of man) and clean|
     v14                                |and purify for himself a special people, ones who have a zeal for doing good works.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Communicate these things and encourage, exhort, and correct while staying in full control of the situation:|
     v15                                |don’t let anyone look down on you.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">talk in a way that makes sound doctrine more pronounced and more palatable</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">speak that which makes sound doctrine stand out</char> [or <char style="it">becoming</char>].|
                                        |Uncertain of the correctness of the rendering.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the older men</char>…Or: <char style="it">elders</char>. The GT is ambiguous.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reached the point where they have a compulsion to drink a lot</char>…Also: <char style="it">heavy-drinking|
                                        |alcoholics</char>…Lit: having been enslaved to much wine. |
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">be ones who teach others to strive for excellence</char>…Lit: <char style="it">excellence-teacher</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">submitting</char>…Ref. note of 1 Pet. 2:18|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">would be a feather in the cap (so to speak)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">would adorn</char>.|
                                        |Some liberties taken.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">deny</char>…Also: <char style="it">renounce</char>. Unexpected verb tense used here.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have a strong friendship with their husbands and enjoy their companionship</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">husband-love</char>. Note the root word for <char style="it">love </char>used here is|
                                        |not <char style="it">agapā </char><char style="w" strong="G00026">ἀγάπη</char>) but <char style="it">philo.|
                                        |</char>Ref. note of John 12:25 and other places for differences in these words. One of the few places|
                                        |in the NT where women are told to love their husband, and the love is a <char style="it">philo-</char>love|
                                        |not and agapā<char style="it"> -</char>love. Contrast that to Ephesians where husbands are commanded|
                                        |to <char style="it">agapā </char>their wives. Philo-love is an enjoyment of the fellowship and companionship|
                                        |two people have, like when David loved Jonathan. Agapā<char style="it"> </char>-love is a love that sees|
                                        |value in the other person, sometimes in spite of what they’re doing, or (and this is in contrast to philo-love)|
                                        |to love them without them reciprocating. Philo-love is a reciprocating love; agapā<char style="it"> </char>-love|
                                        |is not necessarily reciprocal. In the NT, the same root-word <char style="it">philo </char>also means|
                                        |<char style="it">to kiss. </char>In ancient times (and even a bit in modern times), kisses were not a|
                                        |token of romantic love, but tokens of friendship, fellowship, and personal connection. Women must be|
                                        |taught to philo-love their husbands, because the alternative is to become bored with them. When they|
                                        |do, they sometimes go looking for another man to bring excitement into their lives.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">chaste</char>…Also: <char style="it">pure;</char> <char style="it">holy</char>. The|
                                        |Gk. word <char style="it">hagnos </char><char style="w" strong="G00053">ἁγνός</char>), which is derived|
                                        |from the usual word for <char style="it">holy</char> and the word for <char style="it">sanctification.|
                                        |</char>Note that Paul used a different word for <char style="it">holy </char>[<char style="it">hosios,|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G03741">ὅσιος</char>)]in 1 Tim. 2:8, in “lifting up holy hands.” Hosios|
                                        |also appears in 1:8 as a characteristic for bishops. One expects to find hosios used in 2:5 here, not|
                                        |hagnos. So the words should be more closely examined. The root-meaning of hagnos is separation. In the|
                                        |OT, things which were holy were separated from the unclean in order to preserve their holiness. This|
                                        |is hagnos. So when hagnos is used in reference to women, it’s talking about a separation—a separation|
                                        |even from men in a sexual way. This is how it’s acquired the means of <char style="it">chaste </char>(meaning|
                                        |kept sexually separate) in this verse here. Paul might’ve meant chaste exclusively and not pure or holy—we|
                                        |don’t know.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Keep reminding them to submit to and comply with rulers who have legitimate authority over you and to|
     v 1                                |be prepared to do any sort of good deed |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |without saying bad things about what you’re having to do, not being quarrelsome when you’re doing it,|
     v 2                                |not being inflexible about every little detail—in every way possible demonstrating a gentleness towards|
     v 2                                |people borne out of self-restraint.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one piece at a time</char>…Also: <char style="it">bit by bit</char>; <char style="it">gradually</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one piece at a time and it was in many ways</char>…Lit: <char style="it">many-parts|
                                        |and many-ways</char>…Gk: <char style="it">polumerōs kai polutropōs </char>[Πολυμερῶς καὶ πολυτρόπως,|
                                        |<char style="w" strong="G04181">Πολυμερῶς</char>), (πολυτρόπως/Strong’s4187)]. An alliteration, pun,|
                                        |assonance, or rhyme; these words may have formed a common expression.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Ancestors</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fathers</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">but during this time—a time in which we see His long-awaited promises coming to pass</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">at these last days</char>. Ref. note of John 6:39.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">carbon-copy</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the reverse pattern left on an object after|
                                        |being stamped by a stamp with an intricate pattern; the exact replica</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">undergirding reality</char>…Also: <char style="it">substance</char>;<char style="it">|
                                        |foundation</char>;<char style="it"> supporting structure</char>…Lit: <char style="it">what-stands-under</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">anything set under</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Highest</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in high</char>. Meaning is superlative, although|
                                        |the form is not.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">angels</char>…Lit<char style="it">: angels of God</char>. When rendered, the qualifying|
                                        |words <char style="it">of God </char>aren’t needed. Ref. note of Col. 2:18.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anointed</char>…Ref. note of 1 John 2:20|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the sky, the atmosphere, and outer space</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the heavens</char>.|
                                        |Ref. note of 2 Cor. 12:2.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Assume the position as my My chief executive</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Sit out of</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">at</char>] <char style="it">my right hand</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">completely squashed and enslaved</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a footstool of your feet</char>.|
                                        |A common idiom.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a son</char>…Or: <char style="it">the son</char>…Lit: <char style="it">son</char>. Whether|
                                        |we render this <char style="it">a son </char>or <char style="it">the son</char>, in either choice the|
                                        |article is an interpolation. There are many instances in the NT where the definite article <char style="it">the|
                                        |</char>is assumed after a preposition, and this may well be but another instance. However, there are|
                                        |instances also where the definite article is added, added apparently to prevent ambiguity. On the other|
                                        |hand, the omission of the definite article may be just that: the equivalent of (Gk. has none) an indefinite|
                                        |article (or perhaps none at all) is what was intended and what’s being conveyed; the definite was not|
                                        |intended. Though I’m not insisting that this is correct, I do favor the latter, the deciding factor being|
                                        |the context as usual.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the word of God spoken into action and having His power as its instrument</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">the word of his power</char>. The Gk. for word here is <char style="it">rhema </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G04487">ῥῆμα</char>)not <char style="it">logos </char><char style="w" strong="G03056">λόγος</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">. </char>Also, with respect to <char style="it">of his power</char>, in Bullinger’s <char|
                                        |style="it">Figures of Speech Used in the Bible, </char>Appendix B, since this phrase uses the genitive|
                                        |case, “This is hardly his powerful word; but the word which is the instrument, by which His power is|
                                        |carried out.”|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who are about to be receiving the relief which is rightfully theirs</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">those who are about to be inheriting salvation</char>…Or: <char style="it">those who are destined|
                                        |to be inheriting salvation</char>…Or: <char style="it">those who are going to be receiving salvation</char>…Some|
                                        |notes on the GT. The Gk. verb <char style="it">mellō </char><char style="w" strong="G03195">μέλλω</char>)can|
                                        |mean <char style="it">about to be</char>, <char style="it">going to be</char>, or perhaps <char style="it">destined|
                                        |to be</char>. Naturally, its meaning is decided by context. Something else which is noteworthy is that|
                                        |the infinite <char style="it">inherit </char>has a verb tense which insinuates ongoing action, as opposed|
                                        |to a one-time action. So the heirs are about to be inheriting, going to be inheriting, or destined to|
                                        |be inheriting salvation on an ongoing basis. This begs the question, what does <char style="it">salvation|
                                        |</char>mean in this context? Many Christians, scholars, and translators assume it means “receiving Christ|
                                        |in the new birth” or something similar. When applying this definition to this verse, the dilemma is that|
                                        |the angels are sent to assist only those who are about to or are going to inherit salvation, not those|
                                        |who already have inherited it, as the word <char style="it">mellō </char>refers to something which is|
                                        |going to happen in the future but hasn’t happened yet. For this reason, in this verse the word <char|
                                        |style="it">salvation </char>does not mean receiving Christ in the new birth, but it means being rescued|
                                        |from catastrophe. This is its core meaning anyways, so the only surprise should be that Christian scholars|
                                        |failed to apply it properly in the first place. The last piece to the puzzle is the meaning of <char|
                                        |style="it">inherit. </char>The Gk. and English meanings are essentially the same: it means coming and|
                                        |actually possessing what’s been set aside as yours, what’s rightfully yours. Inheriting salvation here|
                                        |is not being born-again some time in the future, but it means coming into the relief in a dire situation|
                                        |of that which is rightfully yours, a person who is already a Christ-follower. Angels are sent to assist|
                                        |Christ-followers with coming into the relief which is rightfully theirs, and to come into this relief|
                                        |on an ongoing basis.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of this confusion between angels and the Son of God, it’s even more necessary for us to pay attention|
     v 1                                |to, follow, concern ourselves with, and devote ourselves to what we heard, lest those things slip through|
     v 1                                |the cracks. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, if the word of God spoken to the human race by angels was enforced, and every infraction,|
     v 2                                |violation, and act of willful disobedience got a just punishment as a payback, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |how will we evade a just punishment after neglecting so great a salvation (i.e., an entire program of|
     v 3                                |keeping all dimensions of calamity and disaster away from us) as the salvation we have in Christ? A salvation|
     v 3                                |which was accepted and wholeheartedly embraced way back then by those who listened to it as it was being|
     v 3                                |spoken by the Lord resulting in us making it effective and enforcing it, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |a message which was accompanied by a conformational-attestation to its truthfulness consisting of signs|
     v 4                                |(i.e., miracles whose purpose is to confirm that the one performing them is authentic) and not just by|
     v 4                                |signs but by wonders (i.e., awe-inspiring miracles), by a variety of miracles, and by bits and pieces|
     v 4                                |of supernatural manifestations of the Holy Spirit which were done according to His will.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But returning to this topic about angels we’ve been talking about here: the fact of the matter is that|
     v 5                                |He didn’t subordinate to angels the civilized world which was to come, |
   N V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but somebody somewhere solemnly delivered a truthful statement to the contrary saying,|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">slip through the cracks</char>…Lit: <char style="it">drift away</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was enforced</char>…Lit: <char style="it">became</char> [<char style="it">came to be</char>]|
                                        |<char style="it">in force</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">infraction, violation</char>…Also: <char style="it">transgression</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">making it effective and enforcing it</char>…This is the same verb <char style="it">enforced|
                                        |</char>used in v. 2, and usage here in v. 3 has the same meaning as the usage in v. 2.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">under his feet</char>…Appears in 1:13 also. An expression used throughout the Bible.|
                                        |Picture a hunter who shot a large game animal standing with one foot on top of the animal as he holds|
                                        |his gun in the other hand.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">evaded</char>…Lit: <char style="it">left</char>; <char style="it">departed</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Your excellent title</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Your name</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">flesh and blood</char>…Lit: <char style="it">blood and flesh</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the same</char>…As the Gk. uses a plural form, it must refer to flesh and blood|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">atoning</char>…Lit: <char style="it">expiating</char>; <char style="it">propitiating</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the son of man</char>…Ref. Matt. 8:20 for note on <char style="it">son of man. </char>The|
                                        |sentence, “What is man that you would remember him, or the son of man that you would visit him?” is a|
                                        |figure of speech called an epexegesis. In this figure of speech, a fact is stated then is restated with|
                                        |more detail added in the restatement. The initial statement is incomplete; the restatement completes|
                                        |it. Therefore, the one spoken of in this passage is the “son of man,” not mankind in general. Some have|
                                        |taken this passage (and also Psalm 8, where it’s quoted from) and have taught that mankind in Christ|
                                        |has been crowned with glory and honor and has had all things subordinated to him. That’s not the case;|
                                        |this passage is talking about the son of man, which in this passage specifically refers to Jesus. Verse|
                                        |9 makes this even more clear by saying that it was Jesus who was “demoted somewhat lower than the angels”|
                                        |and was “crowned in glory and honor.”|

                                        |this is a one-time action|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">from among</char>…Or: <char style="it">in</char>|

                                        |</char>is derived in 2 Thess. 2:3|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tendency of sin to cause a person to become delusional</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |deceitfulness of sin</char>. Ref. note of Mark 4:19.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">servant (more specifically, an earthly servant who waited for God to speak then obeyed)</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">attendant</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">therapōn </char><char style="w" strong="G02324">θεράπων</char>).|
                                        |A therapōn is someone who attends to the needs of another by waiting on them. It applies to either a|
                                        |bedside nurse who attends to a sick person (hence its connection with healing) or serving somebody in|
                                        |a general sense where the servant waits for the person to say something then obeys it. This latter meaning|
                                        |is the case. In fact, therapōn is the word used in the phrase “Moses My servant” which appears in the|
                                        |LXX in Exod. 4:10; 14:31; Num. 12:7. As the writer of Hebrews is mimicking the exact word that the LXX|
                                        |uses to refer to Moses as God’s servant, it indicates that whoever wrote Hebrews had read the LXX extensively.|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">has traversed the sky and outer space, and reached heaven</char>…Lit: <char style="it">has|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a Sabbath observance</char>…The Gk. noun <char style="it">sabbatismos </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G04520">σαββατισμός</char>), which comes from the verb <char style="it">sabbatidzō </char>(αββατιζω/no|
                                        |Strong’s number), which means <char style="it">to keep the Sabbath. </char>The noun-converting suffix|
                                        |<char style="it">mos </char>at the end of <char style="it">sabbatismos </char>in conjunction with the|
                                        |lack (and the lack is prominent) of the definite article implies that sabbatismos is a type of Sabbath|

                                        |style="w" strong="G04521">σάββατον</char>), which is common, and would’ve included the definite article.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |This Sabbath observance that’s the subject of discourse in this chapter and the previous is not the same|
                                        |as the Sabbath which God instituted in Genesis. That’s the point which is made in vv. 8–10. The “rest”|
                                        |spoken of here is a rest where one ceases to work (v. 10) but receives the promises of God.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sharper</char>…Roman soldiers kept their swords razor sharp and in combat used their|
                                        |short, nimble swords to slice their opponents in the small gaps in their armor where unprotected flesh|
                                        |was exposed, causing wounds with little exertion of force. This is what this verse refers to.|

     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But solid food is for grown-ups, who in the course of their maturity have developed and trained their|
     v14                                |faculties of perception to distinguish both good and bad.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">human frailty</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weakness</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">during the time when he had a human body</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the days of|
                                        |his flesh</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">loud</char>…Also: <char style="it">strong</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a source of eternal salvation</char>…This does not mean that he was one of many sources|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">word</char>…Lit: <char style="it">words</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">has not demonstrated competency</char>…Lit: <char style="it">untested</char>; <char|
                                        |style="it">unproven</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">humble, earnest, urgent requests for protection</char>…The only occurrence of the Gk.|
                                        |word <char style="it">hiketāria</char> <char style="w" strong="G02428">ἱκετηρία</char>)in the NT. Hiketāria,|
                                        |and the words it’s surrounded by here appear in a phrase from Job 40:22 in the LXX. As the writer of|
                                        |Hebrews was quite familiar with the LXX (ref. note of 3:5), he must have borrowed the phrase from there.|
                                        |Hiketāria refers to “the olive branch which a supplicant held in his hand” (Liddell &amp; Scott). Also|
                                        |see Gen. 8:11. Meyer in his commentary says that hiketāria “denotes the olive branch which the supplicant|
                                        |pleading for protection bore in his hand…It implies thus the prostate or urgent entreaty of one seeking|
                                        |refuge.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">teach you the fundamentals</char>…There’s an odd word [Gk. <char style="it">tina</char>,|
                                        |a form of <char style="it">tis</char>, <char style="w" strong="G05100">τίς</char>)] tossed in here which|
                                        |is dropped from most translations because it’s difficult to make sense of. Adding <char style="it">tina</char>|
                                        |back in, the new rendering would be something like: “teach you some things which are the fundamentals”|
                                        |or “teach you some fundamentals.”|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have developed and trained their faculties of perception to distinguish both good and|
                                        |bad</char>…The <char style="it">faculties of perception </char>is the Gk. word <char style="it">aisthātārion|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G00145">αἰσθητήριον</char>), which means the perception formed from external|
                                        |stimuli. In this context, it refers to the capacity to understand, to gain insight, and to exercise discernment|
                                        |based on information which one obtains through all sources that a person obtains information from. This|
                                        |is additionally confirmed by the choice of the Gk. word used for <char style="it">good </char>in this|
                                        |verse [<char style="it">kalos</char>, (καλῶς /Strong’s 2773)], as this word refers to goodness perceived|
                                        |from the outside, as opposed to goodness which exists on the inside of someone. The goodness is perceived|
                                        |from the outside through the faculties of perception spoken of here. But in practical terms, what the|
                                        |writer of Hebrews is referring to is a person who through practice and experience is able to observe|
                                        |a given situation and through little pieces of information gleaned here and there is able to see the|
                                        |good and the evil in that situation, and distinguish between the two. One example is this: years ago|
                                        |my brother-in-law used to top by my mother-in-law’s apartment briefly, bring friends occasionally, and|
                                        |after listening to these guys talk casually a bit could tell if they were no good or not. She was always|
                                        |right. Another example: I’m thinking of a well-known evangelist who had a huge ministry who died a few|
                                        |years ago. Just about everyone in the city in which he lived either praised him as a great saint who|
                                        |could do no wrong or condemned him as a horrible sinner who could do no right. The truth is that he was|
                                        |a mixture of both good and bad, but hardly anyone in the city would say that that was the case. The problem,|
                                        |you see, is that they couldn’t distinguish good from bad.|
