     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who He is</char>…Lit: <char style="it">his name</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to bless your socks off and grow your numbers in spades</char>…Lit<char style="it">:|
                                        |blessing I will bless you and multiplying I will multiply you</char>. Saying <char style="it">blessing|
                                        |bless</char> and <char style="it">multiplying multiply</char> is a figure of speech.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">enters the inside room, the one behind the curtain</char>…Lit: <char style="it">enters|
                                        |the inside of the curtain</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">trailblazer</char>…Also: <char style="it">forerunner</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and</char>…The Gk. words <char style="it">kai</char> <char style="w" strong="G02532">καί</char>)and|
                                        |<char style="it">te </char><char style="w" strong="G05037">τέ</char>), which are the two primary words|
                                        |for <char style="it">and, </char>are interspersed in vv. 1–3 in such a way that repentance from dead|
                                        |works and faith in God are coupled together, and the resurrection from the dead and eternal judgment|
                                        |are coupled together. Also, the usage insinuates that not only is baptism a doctrine, but so is the laying|
                                        |on of hands and the resurrection of the dead coupled with eternal judgment.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">baptisms</char>…The Gk. word <char style="it">baptismos </char><char style="w" strong="G00909">βαπτισμός</char>),|
                                        |derived from the verb <char style="it">baptizō </char><char style="w" strong="G00907">βαπτίζω</char>).|
                                        |The connection to the word <char style="it">baptism </char>is obvious; nearly every (perhaps every) rendering|
                                        |of <char style="it">baptism </char>in English comes from these words. Some translations like the NASB|
                                        |render this “instructions about washings,” which is incorrect. First, the words “instructions about”|
                                        |are an interpolation (that is to say, they don’t exist in the GT and were added to make sense of the|
                                        |text). Second, “instructions about washings” are covered in “repentance from dead works”; no need to|
                                        |cover it again. Third, the context decides any ambiguity. This word <char style="it">baptismos</char>|
                                        |appears four times in the NT, here and in 2 Cor. 2:12; Mark 7:4; Heb. 9:10. The times in which it means|
                                        |a dipping in water or ceremonial washings are obvious by the context. As this passage is about “fundamental|
                                        |doctrines,” is not baptism a fundamental doctrine? Have their not been entire denominational splits over|
                                        |this issue? Is it not a pillar of the Christian faith? Fourth, although <char style="it">baptismos </char>as|
                                        |used in the NT is context-variable, the verb <char style="it">baptizō </char>is mostly used to refer|
                                        |to baptism. Fifth, those who render <char style="it">baptismos</char> as “instructions about washings”|
                                        |do so primarily to avoid the obvious fact that this word is plural (baptisms) not singular (baptism).|
                                        |They do so because they believe there is only one type of baptism relevant to the church today, namely|
                                        |water baptism, and if they were to render this word literally as what it obviously is—baptisms—they would|
                                        |they would be forced to acknowledge that there is a second baptism, the baptism in the Holy Spirit, and|
                                        |that this baptism wasn’t just for the early church but is for believers today.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">eternal judgment</char>…The “fundamental doctrines of Christ” should be understood as|
                                        |the essential doctrines of Christianity. A brief description: “repentance from dead works” is the abandonment|
                                        |of the notion that obeying the Law of Moses or any other list of rules is your ticket to obtaining righteousness.|
                                        |This is coupled with “faith in God”: that we obtain righteousness by faith. As these are the crux of|
                                        |Paul’s message, the writer of Hebrews was at a minimum a disciple of Paul. Next are the “doctrines”:|
                                        |baptisms, laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead coupled with eternal judgment. The doctrine|
                                        |of baptisms is that a person who accepts Christ as Savior should be immediately baptized in water without|
                                        |delay. Also, there is a second baptism which occurs after accepting Christ, that is the baptism in the|
                                        |Holy Spirit. It is accompanied by speaking in tongues. The doctrine of the laying on of hands institutes|
                                        |a holy ordinance for the church to practice in the form of one or several believers placing their hands|
                                        |on another believer while at the same time praying. This was done in the Bible for praying for the sick,|
                                        |for the baptism of the Holy Spirit, and for ordination into the ministry. The next doctrine is the resurrection|
                                        |of the dead, which in the NT refers to life after death. The doctrine asserts that we don’t cease to|
                                        |exist when we die, but that we live on eternally in another life, in another body, be it eternal bliss|
                                        |or eternal damnation. The final doctrine, one which connect s to the previous, is eternal judgment: that|
                                        |when our lives are over, we will stand before God in judgment, the outcome for which will be rewards|
                                        |and punishments.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">unable to engage again in the process of renewing themselves with the goal of repentance|
                                        |in mind</char>…The verb tense in the infinitive <char style="it">renew </char>speaks of the process of|
                                        |renewing and not of a renewal as a whole. This person has reached the point where he’s lost the capability|
                                        |of changing. His will is altered to where he will not change again. It’s not that God cannot forgive|
                                        |him, it’s that he will never, ever change. The once-saved-always-saved teaching should be reconsidered|
                                        |in light of this passage.|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">message contained in the oath</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the word of the oath</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sons of Levi</char>…Both Moses and his brother Aaron belonged to the tribe of Levi.|
                                        |When God spoke to Moses in the wilderness and instituted the Law of Moses, He designated the tribe of|
                                        |Levi and all their descendants to forevermore be ministers for the new religion, dispersed among the|
                                        |other tribes to assist in the religious service and regulations. The Levites didn’t work but lived off|
                                        |tithes. Now God appointed Aaron (who was of the tribe of Levi, hence himself a Levite) and his sons and|
                                        |their descendants perpetually to be the priests, and there are different terms used in this passage to|
                                        |refer to this order, some of which are synecdoches. Terms such as Levi, Aaron, the sons of Levi, and|
                                        |the sons of Aaron all mean the same thing.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who are designated by the Law to be priests have become priests apart from there|
                                        |being an oath</char>…Apparently, every oath referred to in this chapter is an oath which promises that|
                                        |the priesthood established will last eternally, like the first oath in v. 7 (“you are a priest forevermore”).|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 8  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The crux of the argument given here is this: we have such a high priest, a priest who sat down at the|

     v15                                |eternal inheritance (i.e., the things God has immutably and irrevocably reserved for them and intended|

                                        |note of Luke 17:37.|

                                        |appears that this refers to Jesus’s death on the cross.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a conscience haunted by evil deeds</char>…Lit: <char style="it">an evil conscience</char>.|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shared in the same sufferings</char>…Or<char style="it">: sympathized with</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">are in jail</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in bonds</char>. A NT synecdoche.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get rattled or lose your nerve</char>…Lit<char style="it">: throw away your confidence</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the person I deem righteous</char>…Lit: <char style="it">my righteous one</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shirks his faith</char>…Also: <char style="it">shrink back</char>; <char style="it">avoid</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">draw back</char>; <char style="it">disappear</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rummage through the right scroll</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with the knob and roller|
                                        |of the scroll</char>. Without being certain what this means, the assumption is that this is a figure|
                                        |of speech similar to Gal. 3:10, but here it refers to the turning of the knob which advances the place|
                                        |in the scroll. This is indicative of the reader browsing through the scroll to locate a passage which|
                                        |is about to be read aloud.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Holy of Holies</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of the holies</char>. Looking at the precise|
                                        |wording of the GT, the term “Holy of Holies” is introduced in 9:3, and the GT literally reads “holy of|
                                        |holies.” Thenceforth, however, the author of Hebrews shortens the literal phrase from <char style="it">holy|
                                        |of holies </char>to <char style="it">of the holies </char>(9:8); <char style="it">the holies </char>(9:12,25);|
                                        |and simply <char style="it">holies </char>(9:24). So the phrase <char style="it">of the holies </char>which|
                                        |appears in 10:19 is yet another usage of a shortened form of Holy of Holies, a repetition of the wording|
                                        |which appeared in 9:8 when you get right down to it.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 11  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Faith is the undergirding of what’s hoped for, the proof of things not seen (which includes all things|
     v 1                                |for which there is no physical evidence); |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |by this, you see, those we hold in esteem from long ago had an official account, a favorable mention,|
     v 2                                |of their actions recorded for posterity.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith our mind understands that the world was set in order by a sentence spoken by God, resulting|
     v 3                                |in what we see coming into being out of what hasn’t been manifested.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Abel offered God a much better sacrifice than Cain, through which an attestation to him being|
     v 4                                |righteous was entered into the official record, the record specifying the gifts he offered to God, and|
     v 4                                |through his faith, though he’s dead he’s still speaking.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Enoch was instantaneously transported from one place to another for the purpose of not experiencing|
     v 5                                |death; “There was no trace of him to be found because God had transported him.” You see, before he was|
     v 5                                |transported, it had been stated for the record that he had pleased God quite well.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now apart from faith it’s impossible to be well-pleasing to God, for he who approaches God must believe|
     v 6                                |(and have already believed ahead of time) that He is the Great I Am and that a reward manifests itself|
     v 6                                |and is awarded to those who seek Him out.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Noah, having been warned by God about things that had not yet been seen, in piety and in the|
     v 7                                |fear of God built and provisioned an ark for the purpose of preserving his family and keeping it safe,|
     v 7                                |through which faith he condemned the world (i.e., consigned the world to punishment) and became an heir|
     v 7                                |of the righteousness which comes from faith.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Abraham obeyed when he was summoned to leave the place he lived and go to the place which he|
     v 8                                |was going to receive as an inheritance (i.e., a place which was reserved for him exclusively and in perpetuity),|
     v 8                                |and he departed having no idea where he was going. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith he emigrated and became a foreign resident in the land of promise, living in tents with Isaac|
     v 9                                |and Jacob, joint-heirs of the same promise. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, he anticipated, expected, and was eagerly awaiting the city which is not a rickety-rackety,|
     v10                                |makeshift one but is built to last, whose builder and architect is God.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith, even Sarah, who couldn’t have children, got the ability to conceive in her old age, since she|
     v11                                |considered the One Who had promised to be faithful. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |As this was the case, one man (and this fellow was debilitated) sired a nation as innumerable as the|
     v12                                |stars in the sky and the grains of sand on the beach.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All these people died in sync with faith, not having received the promises, but having seen and greeted|
     v13                                |them from afar instead, and having confessed that they were foreigners on this planet. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, those who say such things make it evident that they seek their native country. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If they kept on rehashing memories of fondness for that ungodly place they ventured forth from, they|
     v15                                |would have found an opportunity or made an excuse to return; |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but as it stands, they aspire for better, that is to say, for something from the spiritual domain or|
     v16                                |from heaven. In light of this, God is not ashamed to be called their God, for He has prepared a city|
     v16                                |for them.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Abraham, while being tested, offered up Isaac—he who gladly received the promises offered up|
     v17                                |his one and only son, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to whom it was spoken, “The descendants who will perpetuate your family tree will be designated as coming|
     v18                                |through Isaac.” |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Abraham figured that, in addition to the promises He already made, God is able to raise someone from|
     v19                                |the dead. As a result of this, he recovered Isaac from the dead in an analogous fashion.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Also by faith Isaac pronounced blessings over Jacob and Esau in regard to what would happen to them in|
     v20                                |the future.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Jacob while on his death bed pronounced blessings over the sons of Joseph, and “bowed down in|
     v21                                |worship leaning on top of his staff.”|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Joseph, nearing the end, left a reminder about the Exodus with the descendants of Israel and|
     v22                                |left orders about his bones (i.e., orders that they take his bones with them when they leave).|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Moses was hidden by his parents after he was born out of a reverential fear because they saw|
     v23                                |that the boy had charisma, and they didn’t fear the king’s decree. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith Moses grew up and became a great man and renounced his claim of being the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having chosen to endure the hardship with God’s folk rather than to retain the pleasures of sin for a|
     v25                                |brief span of time, |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |considering the vilification and reviling of Christ to be greater riches than the treasures of Egypt;|
     v26                                |for he was focused on the reward.|
 +   V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith he left Egypt, unafraid of the wrath of Pharaoh the king, for he endured as one seeing the Unseen-One.|
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith he observed the Passover and the marking of the blood, done so that the Destroyer wouldn’t touch|
     v28                                |any of their firstborn sons. |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith he crossed the Red Sea as if it was dry land; when the Egyptians tried to cross it, they were|
     v29                                |drowned.|
 +   V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith the walls of Jericho fell after being marched around in a circle for seven days.|
 +   V31              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By faith, the prostitute Rahab wasn’t wiped out with those who were disobedient after extending a welcome|
     v31                                |to the spies and taking them in.|
 +   V32              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And what more will I say? For there’s not enough time to go into detail about Gideon, Barak, Samson,|
     v32                                |Jephthah, David, plus Solomon and the prophets, |
     V33              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who through faith conquered kingdoms, put into practice standards of fairness while ruling, obtained|
     v33                                |promises, shut the mouths of lions, |
     V34              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |extinguished intense heat-generating fires, escaped the sword’s edge, got their strength back from weakness,|
     v34                                |became mighty men in war, routed foreign armies in battle. |
     V35              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Women got members of their family who died to come back to life. Others were tortured but refused the|
     v35                                |chance to get out of it, so that they would be better off in their life after death. |
     V36              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Others experienced jeering and whipping; still others experienced being chained up and locked up. |
     V37              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They were stoned to death, they were sawn in two, they were tempted and brought to the breaking point,|
     v37                                |they were slain by the sword, they wandered about in sheepskins, in goatskins, while being impoverished,|
     v37                                |afflicted, distressed, mistreated— |
     V38              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |people whom the world is not worthy of—They lived in deserts, on mountains, in caves, in underground|
     v38                                |tunnels—|
 +   V39              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of their faith all of these people had a favorable account of their exploits recorded for posterity’s|
     v39                                |sake but did not obtain the promise, |
     V40              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God having provided something better for us, so that their ranks would not be complete without us added.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those we hold in esteem from long ago</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the elders</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">experiencing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">seeing</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">There was no trace of him to be found</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he was not found</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">believe (and have already believed ahead of time)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">believe</char>,|
                                        |but with a verb tense which insinuates a one-time believing, one that occurred in the past.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is not a rickety-rackety, makeshift one but is built to last</char>…Lit: <char style="it">has|
                                        |foundations</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">debilitated</char> …Lit: <char style="it">dead</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">found</char>…Lit: <char style="it">had</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The descendants who will perpetuate your family tree will be designated as coming through|
                                        |Isaac</char>…Lit: <char style="it">by Isaac seed to you will be called</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">had charisma</char>…Also: <char style="it">sophisticated; well-bred; handsome; capable</char>.|
                                        |The Gk. word used here at its core refers to the splendor of cities in contrast to the lack of such splendor|
                                        |one finds in the countryside.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">extending a welcome to the spies and taking them in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">receiving|
                                        |the spies with peace</char>. An expression; ref. note of Matt. 10:13.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">intense heat-generating fires</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the power of fire</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">life after death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">resurrection</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Faith is</char>…Some translations render this ”now faith is,” which is also correct.|
                                        |However, the Gk. word for <char style="it">now </char>is the conjunction <char style="it">de, </char>one|
                                        |of the most common words in the NT<char style="it">. De</char> does not mean “at this moment in time.”|
                                        |Some ministers, however, take the word “now” to mean “faith is now” in other words “faith by nature exists|
                                        |at this moment in time.” They then go on to explain how a principle of faith is that it exists in the|
                                        |here-and-now, not some time in the future. While this is true about faith, this is not what the GT of|
                                        |11:1 is saying. Other translations’ use of “now” should not be taken to mean “at the present time.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bowed down in worship leaning on top of his staff</char>…The GT of this is a verbatim|
                                        |quotation of Gen. 47:31 in the LXX. As Jacob’s blessings of Joseph’s sons is found in Gen. 48, not 47,|
                                        |it’s a mystery why these two seemingly disjointed accounts are linked together here.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 12  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For this very reason, we too, surrounded by such a cluster of tremendous witnesses, let us lay aside|
     v 1                                |every burden and the sin which entangles us and run with endurance the up-and-coming race we’re entered|
     v 1                                |in, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |setting our undivided attention on Jesus, the originator and perfector of our faith, who, instead of|
     v 2                                |giving up because of the task he was assigned to do, endured the cross, disregarding and having contempt|
     v 2                                |for the shame associated with it ,and has sat down at the right hand of God’s throne (i.e., he took up|
     v 2                                |the position of God’s chief executive). |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, consider for a moment that he has endured such extreme opposition from sinners, so that|
     v 3                                |you not grow weary in the depths of your souls and capitulate— |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You have yet to resist to the point of bloodshed, |
   N V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and you’ve completely forgotten the encouragement which addresses you as sons:|
 +PN V 5            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V 5                  VERSES_PROSE: |My son, do not take lightly the discipline of the Lord|
 +PN V 5                  VERSES_PROSE: |As he molds you into the person you need to be|
 +P  V 5                  VERSES_PROSE: |Nor capitulate when corrected by Him.|
 + N V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |You see, whom the Lord loves He disciplines,|
 +PN V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |And He thrashes every son|
 +P  V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |Whom He has whole-heartedly welcomed as His own.|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V 7 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |You endure for the purpose of being molded by discipline into the person you need to become: God treats|
     v 7                                |you like you are His son. In this regard, can you think of any son whom his father doesn’t discipline?|
     V 8 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |But if you live in absence of discipline, which you all get your fair share of now, then you’re children|
     v 8                                |some strange woman had out of wedlock and not sons who are included in the family.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, we had fathers in the natural who disciplined us time and time again, and we gave them our|
     v 9                                |respect; how much more should we submit to the Father of our spirits and live this way? |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, while it’s true that for a brief period our natural fathers disciplined us the way they personally|
     v10                                |thought discipline ought to be done, but He, though, disciplines us for our own benefit, for the purpose|
     v10                                |of us being able to partake of His holiness on an ongoing basis. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While any discipline at the time it’s occurring is not considered to be a bundle of joy, but instead|
     v11                                |is painful, later on it yields a peaceful result, namely righteousness, to those who have been trained|
     v11                                |by the discipline they received.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, put the hands that lie idle at your side and the knees which have become weak back|
     v12                                |in the position where they’re poised for action, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and clear out a straight path for your feet, so that the hip joint, knee joint, etc. which is preventing|
     v13                                |you from walking not be dislocated any more, but rather be healed.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pursue peace with all people, and pursue holiness, without which no one will see the Lord. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Check up on any person who might lack the grace of God (i.e., who needs to receive mercy, kindness, or|
     v15                                |forgiveness from God) and help them in whatever situation they’re in which is causing this, lest some|
     v15                                |root of bitterness grow up and become a source of irritation, annoyance, or trouble, and many people|
     v15                                |would be tainted by this root; |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |lest there be some fornicator metaphorically speaking (i.e., someone who’s immoral in a way which is|
     v16                                |analogous to sexually immorality) or someone who’s profane or has no piety like Esau, who sold what was|
     v16                                |rightfully his by birth for one meal. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, you know the story, how afterwards, while wanting to receive his inheritance through the blessing|
     v17                                |bestowed by Isaac, he was rejected; the simple fact is that there was no way he could turn the situation|
     v17                                |around, although with tears on his face he tried.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that you haven’t come to a physically tangible mountain like Mount Sinai, to|
     v18                                |one which is on fire, and to darkness and to gloom and to a whirlwind |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to the sound of a trumpet and to a voice speaking words, a voice which those who heard it begged|
     v19                                |that not another word be spoken to them; |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, they couldn’t take it anymore, couldn’t stand the order, “If so much as an animal happens to|
     v20                                |touch the mountain, it will be stoned to death.” |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The scene was so terrifying that Moses said, “I’m terrified and shaking all over”—|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—No, you’ve come to Mount Zion and to the city of the Living God, the Jerusalem in heaven, and to a myriad|
     v22                                |of angels, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to the mother of all church gatherings of the firstborn who’s registered in heaven, and to God the judge|
     v23                                |of all, and to spirits of upright, decent people who’ve been made perfect, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to Jesus the mediator of a new covenant and to the true sprinkling-blood, which calls for better|
     v24                                |things than the blood of Abel which cried out from the ground.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |See to it that no one disregards or rejects what’s being called for. You see, if those people who disregarded|
     v25                                |or rejected what was called for couldn’t escape after He warned them when they were on the Earth, how|
     v25                                |much more will they not escape, they who refuse Him Who warns from heaven? |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That voice shook the Earth back then, but at the present time there’s a promise which He has given which|
     v26                                |says, “I will yet cause the Earth to shake one more time, and not just shake the Earth but the sky, outer|
     v26                                |space, and the spirit-world too.” |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the phrase “yet one more time” insinuates the removal of those things which are shaken, as they are|
     v27                                |things which have been created, so that what would remain would be the things which can’t be shaken.|
 +   V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, as we heartily embrace a kingdom which can’t be shaken, let us maintain an attitude|
     v28                                |of thankfulness, one in which we serve God in a way that pleases Him, keeping it with reverence and awe:|
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For our God is a consuming fire.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cluster</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cloud</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">as he molds you into the person you need to become</char>…Lit: <char style="it">for|
                                        |discipline</char>. Ref. major note of v. 5.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">whole-heartedly welcomed as His own</char>…Lit: <char style="it">He receives</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">live in absence of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">are without</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a brief period</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a few days</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">there was no way he could turn the situation around</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he|
                                        |did not find a place of repentance</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the mother of all church gatherings</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a gathering and a church</char>.|
                                        |A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">calls for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">speaks of</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">maintain an attitude of thankfulness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">have grace </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">thanks</char>]|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">As he molds you into the person you need to be</char>…An interpolation based on the|
                                        |fact that the word <char style="it">discipline </char>in this verse comes from a root word meaning <char|
                                        |style="it">son </char>or <char style="it">child</char>, and refers to the discipline, correction, and|
                                        |instruction that a son receives that will mature him into the man he needs to become. This discipline|
                                        |is done with this long-term goal in mind and is not a simple punishment.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fornicator</char> <char style="it">metaphorically speaking</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fornicator</char>.|
                                        |We know from the OT account of Esau and Jacob that Esau never committed fornication, which is any act|
                                        |of sexual immorality (not just sex out of wedlock). Therefore, the episode where he sold his birthright|
                                        |for a bowl of stew is a metaphor to fornication: it’s the same sin but minus the sexual component. Esau|
                                        |had convinced himself that he would die if he didn’t eat the meal Jacob prepared (this was not true;|
                                        |nobody dies for lack of a single meal, especially someone who can still walk). He exchanged something|
                                        |precious for a short-term gratification of the flesh.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 13  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Continue in your love for your fellow comrade, loving the fellowship you have with them. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t neglect to extend a hearty friendship-welcome to those who are new to a church, new to the area,|
     v 2                                |or who are just plain different than yourselves. In doing this, some have unwittingly welcomed angels.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Remember those who are in prison as though you’re fellow inmates, and remember those who are ill-treated|
     v 3                                |as though you have to live in their shoes.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure to honor the institution of marriage and be sure that what you do in bed is morally pure; for|
     v 4                                |God will judge fornicators and adulterers.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure that the kind of life you live is absent the love of money; He himself said, “There’s no way|
     v 5                                |I’ll ever leave you or forsake you.” |
   N V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This gives us confidence so much so that we perk up and have the gumption to say,|
 +PN V 6            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |The Lord is my helper; I will not fear.|
 +P  V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |What can a person do to me?|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Remember your leaders, the very people who spoke the word of God to you, closely observe on a continual|
     v 7                                |basis the end-result of their manner of life—mimic their faith.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t get sidetracked by different and novel teachings; you see, it’s good that the heart be established|
     v 9                                |by grace, not by teachings about what food we should or shouldn’t eat. These teachings haven’t benefited|
     v 9                                |those who have changed their lifestyles to follow them. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We have a spiritual altar, and they who serve by performing the religious rituals in the physical tabernacle|
     v10                                |are not entitled to eat the food which is a byproduct of the sacrifices offered upon it. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, the carcasses of the animals whose blood is brought by the high priest into the Holy of Holies|
     v11                                |are incinerated outside the camp, out away from where everybody lived. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, Jesus also, so that through his own blood he would purify, sanctify, and make the folk-people|
     v12                                |holy, suffered outside of the gates of the city away from where everybody lived. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, let’s go outside the camp where everybody lives and go to him, pick up his vilification, vituperation,|
     v13                                |and reviling, and carry it ourselves.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, here on this planet we don’t have a city for us to live in which is going to last into eternity,|
     v14                                |but we’re seeking after the city to come instead. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Through him let us continuously offer up to God a sacrificial offering consisting of praise, in other|
     v15                                |words, the fruit of lips which confess words in his name and to his name (i.e., by his authority and|
     v15                                |to his glory). |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And don’t neglect to do acts of kindness and to help others financially; for God is quite pleased with|
     v16                                |sacrificial offerings such as these.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be persuaded by your leaders to the point of obeying them and submit to them; you see, they keep watch|
     v17                                |over your very lives, as they’ll be held accountable for them. But submit so that they may do their job|
     v17                                |with joy and not regress into grumbling; it just isn’t worth it.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pray for us, and keep on praying for us. We believe that we have a good conscience (i.e., we’re not involved|
     v18                                |in any wrongdoing; there’s nothing we feel guilty about) in that we are wanting to maintain a lifestyle|
     v18                                |of excellence in every respect. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But more importantly, I encourage you to pray so that I’ll be restored to you (i.e., be reinstated and|
     v19                                |continue doing with you what I was doing) as soon as possible.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now may the God of peace, Who brought the Great Shepherd of the Sheep back from the dead by means of|
     v20                                |the blood of the eternal covenant—our Lord Jesus Christ— |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in every good way put you into proper order and prepare you for a purpose, doing this with the goal of|
     v21                                |accomplishing His will, working in us what from His point of view is very pleasing through Jesus Christ,|
     v21                                |to whom be the glory forever and ever. Let us pause for a moment to let that sink in.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Bear with me, comrades, as I encourage you with this word of encouragement. You see, I’ve only briefly|
     v22                                |written to you about my personal affairs. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just so you know, our fellow comrade Timothy has been let out of jail. If he can manage to come over|
     v23                                |to where I am in a hurry, I’ll take him with me when I visit you.|
 +   V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Extend my greetings to all those in leadership positions and to all the saints (i.e., all the other believers).|
     v24                                |Those from the Roman province of Italy greet you.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the grace of God be with you all.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in prison</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in bonds</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">as though you have to live in their shoes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">yourselves also|
                                        |being in the body</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">perk up and have the gumption</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to be having courage</char>.|
                                        |Used this way in Mark 10:49; 15:43; ref. note of John 16:33.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your very lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">your souls</char> |
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they’ll be held accountable for them</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they’ll have to give|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Shepherd</char>…Also: <char style="it">pastor</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what from His point of view is very pleasing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">well-pleasing|
                                        |in His sight</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Let us pause for a moment to let that sink in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">amen. </char>Ref.|
                                        |note of Rev. 19:4.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the camp</char>…This word and the word <char style="it">tabernacle </char>used in v.|
                                        |10 are both references to the tabernacle used by the Israelites when the wandered in the Sinai desert|
                                        |for forty years. Where the people lived was called a “camp” because they had no buildings to live in|
                                        |since they could be commanded by God to pick up and leave any day.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a sacrificial offering consisting of praise</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sacrifice of|
                                        |praise</char>. This is a metaphor which compares praise offered to God to OT sacrifices offered to God|
                                        |and incinerated on the altar of burnt offerings. Some have misinterpreted this to mean that it is a personal|
                                        |sacrifice on our part to praise God.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |James, a servant/slave of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ:|
 +PN V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the blood-descendants of the twelve tribes of Israel who are among the Diaspora (i.e. the scattering|
     v 1                                |of Jews all over the world):|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m delighted to write to you:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Consider it a joy, my dear comrades, when you by chance fall into various tests and trials which find|
     v 2                                |out what you’re made of, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing that the process of proving your faith produces perseverance. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let perseverance have the opportunity to become a mature, completed work, in order that you would become|
     v 4                                |mature and that every part of you would become complete with nothing left out.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But speaking of things which are left out…If someone is lacking in wisdom, advise him to simply ask for|
     v 5                                |wisdom from the giving-God who’ll grant the request without chewing the person out or demeaning him,|
     v 5                                |and it will be given to him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But admonish him to ask in faith, nothing about him wavering in doubt: you see, a person who doubts is|
     v 6                                |like the way that ocean waves are moved and tossed about by the wind. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, you should adjust that person’s expectations so that he does not expect to receive anything|
     v 7                                |from the Lord, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since he is a double-minded man, irresolute in all his ways.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Get the Humiliated, Abased Person to glory and take pride in his exaltation, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and likewise get the rich man to practice humility and self-abasement, because, like the wild flowers|
     v10                                |of the field which reach an apex when they blossom and then fade back into obscurity, he too will have|
     v10                                |his moment in the sun then pass away and fade back into obscurity. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the sun rose and dried out the wild flower with its sweltering heat, its flower-part fell off,|
     v11                                |and the lovely appearance it projected was destroyed—this is the same way that the rich man will waste|
     v11                                |away in his journey through life.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Blessed is the man who perseveres over the course of tests and trials, since, after he’s attained approval|
     v12                                |because of his perseverance, he’ll receive the trophy of a deeply satisfying life, which is promised|
     v12                                |to those who love Him. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Teach the person who’s being tested by some sort of trial or temptation not to say, “I’m being tested|
     v13                                |by God to see if there’s any evil in me.” You see, God is un-tempt-able by any evil; He tempts no one.|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Each person is tempted when he’s lured and dragged off by the passions which are peculiar to him and|
     v14                                |not necessarily to the next person. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then once passion or desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin. When it’s finished running its course,|
     v15                                |sin produces death (i.e., stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction).|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t get led down the primrose path, my dear comrades. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Every good gift and every perfect present is from the sky above, coming down from the Creator of Astronomical|
     v17                                |Objects (i.e. the sun, the moon, stars, etc.), with whom there is no deviation in the movement of such|
     v17                                |objects and no hint or suggestion of change to them. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Having planned and decided to do so, he birthed us in a conceptualization of truth with the end-goal|
     v18                                |of us being the crème de la crème of His creation.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure you get this down pat, my dear comrades: Each person should see to it that he’s quick to listen,|
     v19                                |slow to speak, slow to anger. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, a man’s anger won’t live up to God’s standards of right and wrong. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, once you’ve rid yourself of any filthy residue of malice, with a soft-spoken, gentle|
     v21                                |self-restraint take to heart and fully embrace the implanted word of God which is able to relieve, rescue,|
     v21                                |and preserve your mind and emotions.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But become practitioners of a given subject matter and not just students who hear it taught, deceiving|
     v22                                |themselves because they listen but won’t do, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because if somebody hears a subject lectured to him but doesn’t put it into practice, that guy’s like|
     v23                                |a man who looks at himself in a mirror and gets an idea of what he looks like— |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, he got an idea of what he looks likes, walked away, and immediately forgot what he looks like.|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the fellow who crouched down and looked carefully at a perfect code, a freedom code, and stays put|
     v25                                |looking at it and didn’t become a forgetting-student but became a doing-practitioner, that fellow will|
     v25                                |be blessed in his doing.|
 +   V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If anyone thinks that he strictly adheres to the do’s and don’ts of his religion and isn’t reigning in|
     v26                                |his tongue but instead kids himself into believing he follows his religion strictly—this sort of religion|
     v26                                |is worthless. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |A pure set of religious do’s and don’ts—a set that’s untainted from the Father-God’s point of view—is|
     v27                                |to visit orphans and widows in dire need for the purpose of helping them, while keeping oneself unstained|
     v27                                |from the world, i.e. the established order of humanity which wants nothing to do with God.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m delighted to write to you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">joy</char>. A common salutation|
                                        |found in the NT; same one in Matt. 26:49; ref. note there.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">lacking in</char>…Lit: <char style="it">left out</char>. Same verb used in v. 4 <char|
                                        |style="it">nothing left out</char>, and this verb is used in the same voice<char style="it">. </char>James|
                                        |is obviously using this as a transition.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sweltering heat</char>…Lit: <char style="it">burning wind</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">trophy</char>…Lit: <char style="it">crown</char> [in this context, a <char style="it">victor’s|
                                        |wreath</char>]. Some liberties taken.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in</char>…Or: <char style="it">by means of</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">conceptualization</char>…Lit: <char style="it">word</char>. Ref. John 1:1.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">crème de la crème</char>…Lit: <char style="it">first-fruits</char>. Ref. note of Rom.|
                                        |8:23.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger</char>…James’s use of the Gk. aorist tense|
                                        |here is a bit unexpected. It’s as though he’s picturing a single, hypothetical instance and not speaking|
                                        |in generalities.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">filthy residue</char>…Lit: <char style="it">dirtiness and surplus</char> [or <char style="it">superfluous</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">remaining</char>]. An hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">relieve, rescue, and preserve your mind and emotions</char>…Lit: <char style="it">save|
                                        |your soul</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a given subject matter</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a word</char>. James uses the definite|
                                        |article with<char style="it"> word </char>in v. 21 but drops it in vv. 22, 23.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">looks at himself</char>…Lit: <char style="it">notices his face</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reigning in</char>…Or: <char style="it">bridling</char>. A metaphor which compares taming|
                                        |the tongue to taming a horse.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with the Father-God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with the God and Father</char>. A hendiadys.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the blood-descendants of the twelve tribes of Israel</char> …Lit: <char style="it">twelve|
                                        |tribes</char>. The phrase twelve tribes is a metonymy for all Israelites. By specifying the twelve tribes,|
                                        |James makes the distinction between the Jewish believers and the Gentile believers. Since James’s authority|
                                        |is over the church in Jerusalem, and perhaps all of Israel, he extends his pastoral care to all believing|
                                        |Israelites who for one reason or another are located outside of Israel but nevertheless are Jewish like|
                                        |those living in Israel. At the time this epistle was written, there were more Jews outside of Israel|
                                        |than there were in Israel. But the schism in the early church between the Jewish and the non-Jewish believers|
                                        |would naturally cause the Jewish believers living outside of Israel to gravitate towards and affiliate|
                                        |with James.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">advise him to</char>…<char style="it">admonish him to</char>…<char style="it">adjust</char>…<char|
                                        |style="it">get</char>…<char style="it">make sure that</char>…etc…Lit: <char style="it">have</char> [or|
                                        |<char style="it">let</char>] <char style="it">him</char>. James uses this third-person imperative form|
                                        |of the Gk. verb in a parallel fashion as a figure of speech.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">likewise get the rich man to practice humility and self-abasement</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">the rich man in his humiliation</char>. (The interpolations are justified by the parallel|
                                        |construction.) Before making generalizations about the wealthy based on this verse, one should first|
                                        |read James 2:6–7; 5:1–6 and understand that the “rich man” of that passage is the same “rich man” in|
                                        |v. 10,11 here. Though there’s a tendency for wealthy people to be abusive, not all of them are. But all|
                                        |of them are reminded to stay humble.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wild flowers of the field</char>…Lit: <char style="it">grass</char>. Max and Mary claim|
                                        |that in this context this refers to wild flowers and not grass and that this is a picture of fragility|
                                        |from the OT (ref. Is. 40:6; Ps. 103:15|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">trophy of a deeply satisfying </char>life…Lit: <char style="it">crown</char> [<char|
                                        |style="it">victor’s wreath</char>] <char style="it">of life</char>. This is a metaphor where obtaining|
                                        |a deeply satisfying life by persevering through trials is compared to a victor being awarded the victor’s|
                                        |wreath. The word <char style="it">life</char> leans on the definition Jesus put forth in John 6:53, “if|
                                        |you won’t eat the Man’s flesh and drink his blood, you don’t have life within you.” In the next verse|
                                        |Jesus goes on to talk about eternal life, which is that special fullness of life that God gives. By this|
                                        |reasoning, the word <char style="it">life </char>in v. 12 here does not refer to physical existence but|
                                        |rather is the same concept of life and eternal life which Jesus taught. What James is saying is that|
                                        |perseverance through trials and temptations results in a deep richness to one’s life.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">conceived</char>…Same word used in Luke 1:24 when Elizabeth managed to become pregnant,|
                                        |insinuating a bit that this was only achieved after some difficulty. A few words later in this verse,|
                                        |James says <char style="it">gives birth to sin</char>, where the word <char style="it">give birth </char>is|
                                        |just that—a woman giving birth.<char style="it"> </char>This verse is a metaphor where temptation is|
                                        |compared to a man who impregnates a woman (i.e. a person) and she conceives a child sin and gives birth|
                                        |to it.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Creator of Astronomical Objects (i.e. the sun, the moon, the stars, etc.), with whom|
                                        |there is no deviation in the movement of such objects and no hint or suggestion of change to them</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">Father of Lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of changing</char>. The|
                                        |same Gk. word for <char style="it">lights </char>used here in v. 17 is the same Gk. word used in Gen.|
                                        |1:16 in the LXX, “And God made the two great lights…”; therefore, the “lights” James refers to are the|
                                        |sun, the moon, and every other celestial object which emits light. The word <char style="it">shadow </char>used|
                                        |in this verse is similar in meaning to the way it’s used in Heb. 10:1; i.e., it’s not a physical shadow|
                                        |but rather an imperfect representation of another object. The Gk. words for<char style="it"> variation|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">changing </char>are astronomical terms. In addition, it’s been known since|
                                        |ancient times that the movement of the planets, the rotation of the earth, etc. are extremely precise|
                                        |and entirely predictable. Therefore, James is saying that the same God who put into place such precision|
                                        |will apply the same precision to His gift-giving.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">forgot what he looks like</char>…James is describing what we all experience on a daily|
                                        |basis. While you’re looking in the mirror, you know exactly what you look like, but the moment you step|
                                        |away, you immediately forget what that was no matter how long you were staring into the mirror. Let’s|
                                        |say a woman looks in a mirror to see how her hair looks. She’ll step away, worry that this lock or that|
                                        |braid doesn’t quite match her outfit, then step back up to the mirror and look at herself again. Why|
                                        |did she step back to the mirror a second time?—Because she forgot what she looked like.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">thinks that he strictly adheres to the do’s and don’ts of his religion</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">thinks to be religious</char>. Some liberties taken. The word <char style="it">religious </char>insinuates|
                                        |the rituals performed by the Jews. This insinuation is confirmed by the selection of words James uses|
                                        |in v. 27, namely <char style="it">pure </char>[<char style="it">undefiled</char>] and <char style="it">unstained</char>,|
                                        |which smack of Jewish religious purification rituals.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My comrades, don’t have a faith in our Lord of Glory Jesus Christ which shows favoritism. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a powerful businessman wearing an expensive suit were to join your synagogue, and a poor man in ragged|
     v 2                                |clothing were to join, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you’d be naturally inclined to favor the fellow in the expensive suit and tell him, “Let’s make sure|
     v 3                                |you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important people sit,” and you would tell|
     v 3                                |the poor guy, “Stand against the wall in the back or sit where the usher sits and be ready to fill in|
     v 3                                |for him and run an errand when we call.” |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Have you not shown bias towards those among you, preferring one person over another, and have you not|
     v 4                                |become decision-makers whose thought process consists of really bad, downright evil, things?|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Listen, my dear comrades: Hasn’t God chosen the world’s poor to be rich in faith and to get their individual|
     v 5                                |slice of God’s involvement with the human race, which He promised to those who love Him? |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you’ve treated the poor with contempt. Don’t the rich oppress you and drag you into court? |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t they cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, hard-earned reputation? |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If there really is a perfect regal code which we live by and if the code is based on the Bible verse|
     v 8                                |which says, “Love your neighbor as yourself,” then you’re on the right track. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if you show favoritism, you’re committing a sin and are incriminated by the Law of Moses. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, that particular individual who’s willingly trying to keep the Law but falls short in one area|
     v10                                |is guilty of violating it as a whole.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Here’s an example: the same Old Testament Law which said “Don’t commit adultery” also said “Don’t commit|
     v11                                |murder.” Now if you didn’t commit adultery but committed murder, you nevertheless became a Law-violator,|
     v11                                |violating the Law as a whole even though you violated just one part of it. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Talk and behave as though as though you’re going to be held to a standard defined by freedom’s code and|
     v12                                |judged by it. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the judgment that you will eventually face will be merciless towards those who won’t show mercy.|
     v13                                |Mercy trumps judgment.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What benefit is it, my comrades, if (using some person for the purpose of illustration) this person says|
     v14                                |he has faith but has no actions which normally accompany it? That sort of so-called faith won’t pull|
     v14                                |him out of a bad situation, will it? |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a comrade were to find himself or herself having no clothing whatsoever to protect his or her body|
     v15                                |with and lacking minimum-sustenance food, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and if you were to tell him, “See you later, take care now. Stay warm and get plenty to eat,” but not|
     v16                                |provide physical necessities for him, what good is that? |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The sort of faith we’re talking about here is the same way: if it were to not have actions which normally|
     v17                                |accompany it, it would be void of life, being in a state which is consistent with itself.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Putting that aside now—someone is bound to say, “You have faith but no actions to go along with it and|
     v18                                |I have actions but no faith to go along with them.” Show me your kind of faith apart from the actions|
     v18                                |which normally accompany it, and I’ll show you the genuine kind of faith from out of my actions. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You believe that there is only one true God and that He is of one mind and has His own will, and there|
     v19                                |is no other being comparable to Him? Good job. The demons believe it as well and quiver in their boots|
     v19                                |over it.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh you nit-wit—were you interested in knowing that the sort of faith which is apart from actions which|
     v20                                |normally accompany it amounts to nothing? |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Wasn’t our patriarch Abraham made right in God’s sight from actions after offering his son Isaac upon|
     v21                                |the altar? |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the case of Abraham offering Isaac, one sees that the genuine sort of faith operates together with|
     v22                                |its accompanying actions and comes to fruition out of the actions. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The verse of Scripture was fulfilled which says, “Abraham believed in God, and it wound up being credited|
     v23                                |to him as righteousness,” and he was called a friend and close-companion of God. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Observe that a person is made right in God’s sight as the result of actions and not by faith on its own.|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Wasn’t the prostitute Rahab made right in God’s sight the same way—as the result of actions—cooperating|
     v25                                |with the agents and hurrying them out another way? |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For as the body is dead when it is apart from a spirit, in the same way the genuine sort of faith apart|
     v26                                |from works is dead too.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a powerful businessman</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a gold-ringed man</char>. <char|
                                        |style="it">Gold-ringed</char> is a synecdoche. The ring on the man’s finger is a signet ring, a ring|
                                        |used for making sizeable purchases or validating transactions.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wearing an expensive suit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in bright clothes</char>. Some|
                                        |liberties taken. Only the rich and noblemen wore bright clothing. |
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">join your synagogue</char>…Lit: <char style="it">enter into your synagogue</char>. An|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ragged</char>…Lit: <char style="it">filthy-dirty</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">decision-makers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">judges</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get their own individual slice of God’s involve with the human race</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">inheritors of the kingdom</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">then you’re on the right track</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you do well</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">falls short</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stumbles</char>. A less-common word for <char|

                                        |but both are Gk. renderings of the OT word <char style="it">stumble. </char>Ref. note of Matt. 11:6.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pull him out of a bad situation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">save him</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">See you later, take care now</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Go forth in peace</char>.|
                                        |A common parting remark.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">would be</char>…Lit: is. A grammatical error made by James, presumably.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">quiver in their boots over it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">shudder</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">amounts to nothing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">idle</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">made right in God’s sight</char>…Lit: <char style="it">justified</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Let’s make sure you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important|
                                        |people sit</char>…<char style="it">Stand against the wall in the back or sit where the usher sits and|
                                        |be ready to fill in for him and run an errand when we call</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Sit here good</char>…<char|
                                        |style="it">Stand there or sit under my footstool</char>. Liberties taken. Unlike modern times, in ancient|
                                        |times, people at an event were not seated randomly but were seated in seats that were arranged so that|
                                        |one could tell their importance at the function by the location of the seat in proximity to whatever|
                                        |is the center. Also, the phrase <char style="it">sit under my footstool</char> is a NT expression which|
                                        |means that such person is subordinate to whomever he’s seated under.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, hard-earned reputation</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">blaspheme the beautiful name</char> [or<char style="it"> excellent reputation</char>]<char|
                                        |style="it"> that’s been given as a surname to you</char>. Many scholars assume that James is talking|
                                        |about blaspheming God’s name, but a literal interpretation does not support this assumption.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">perfect regal code</char>…Lit: <char style="it">perfect royal law</char>. James 1:25|
                                        |“perfect law” refers to this same concept. The perfect law transcends the legalistic practice of the|
                                        |Law of Moses and lays down a better, perfect, and higher code of conduct, the same one that Jesus talked|
                                        |about in the Sermon on the Mount when he said, “It is written but I say.”|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">That sort of faith</char>…Lit<char style="it">: the faith</char>. In the Gk. James adds|
                                        |the definite article before the word <char style="it">faith </char>to indicate that he’s talking about|
                                        |a specific type of so-called faith. He adds a <char style="it">the </char>before <char style="it">faith|
                                        |</char>in in various places in the passage of v. 14–17.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">there is only one true God. He is of one mind and has His own will, and there is no|
                                        |other being comparable to Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God is one</char>. Also appears in 1 Cor.|
                                        |8:4; Rom. 3:29; Gal. 3:20: this is a quotation from Deut. 6:4. The brevity of the statement only enhances|
                                        |its profoundness, as it speaks to so many things about God. This one statement is the foundation for|
                                        |all Abrahamic religions.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Observe that a person is made right in God’s sight as the result of actions and not|
                                        |by faith on its own</char>…The passage consisting of vv. 14–26 has been misunderstood for years, even|
                                        |to the point where Martin Luther refused to include the book of James in his translation of the Bible,|
                                        |as he thought James is promoting a righteousness based on works. He’s not. The point James makes is that|
                                        |genuine faith is always accompanied by works (actions) which reflect it and are the result of it. Genuine|
                                        |faith cannot exist without these accompanying actions. This does not mean that if a person manufactures|
                                        |the actions they necessarily have the works, but it means that the two must go hand-in-hand.|
