     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">we’ll be held to a higher standard</char>…Lit: <char style="it">we will receive a greater|
                                        |judgment</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mess up or fall short</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stumble</char>. Same word used in|
                                        |James 2:10, see note there.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">that fellow has got his act together</char>…Lit: <char style="it">that man complete</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Now we</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Now if</char>. Appears to be a mistake in the autograph;|
                                        |some early manuscripts have redacted it out.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |J<char style="it">ust a tiny flame can even set an enormous forest on fire</char>…Lit: <char style="it">How|
                                        |small a flame how great a forest kindles</char>. In the GT this is: <char style="it">hālikon pur hālikān|
                                        |hulān anaptei </char>(ἡλίκον πῦρ ἡλίκην ὕλην ἀνάπτει). An obvious alliteration/assonance and presumably|
                                        |a commonly-used expression.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">elaborate mechanism</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a world</char>. Keep in mind that <char|
                                        |style="it">world </char>refers to the established order of mankind more so than the physical planet.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">occupies a position of preeminence</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sits</char>. The meaning|
                                        |of the word <char style="it">sits </char>as used in this verse is the same meaning as it’s used in Ps.|
                                        |110:1.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Father-God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God and Father</char>. A commonly-used NT hendiadys.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">distort the truth by bragging and lying</char>…Lit: <char style="it">boast and lie against|
                                        |the truth</char>. Assuming this is an idiom and guessing what the idiom means.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">which comes from the spiritual world where God lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">coming|
                                        |down from above</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every bad thing imaginable is done</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all bad deeds</char>.|
                                        |The word <char style="it">all </char>is used as a figure of speech, a hyperbole or metonymy of a sort.|
                                        |Same figure of speech used in 1 Tim. 6:10, “For the love of money is the root of all evil.”|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the end-result where everything turns out right has its origins</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |fruit of righteousness is sown</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">instructors</char>…Or: <char style="it">teachers</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">teacher|
                                        |</char>is both (or either) one who imparts insight and understanding and one who gives moral instruction|
                                        |(ref. note of Acts 15:1), telling the pupil how he should conduct his life. In relation to giving moral|
                                        |instruction, it becomes clear why the instructor must be held to a higher standard.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reign in his entire body</char>…Lit: <char style="it">able to bridle his entire body</char>.|
                                        |The word <char style="it">bits </char>in v. 3 is derived from the <char style="it">bridle </char>in v.|
                                        |2. This combined with the repetition of the word <char style="it">body </char>in v. 2 and <char style="it">bodies|
                                        |</char>in v. 3 indicates that <char style="it">reign in his entire body </char>is a metaphor which compares|
                                        |controlling one’s body by controlling one’s tongue to controlling a horse’s body by the use of bits.|
                                        |Coincidentally (or perhaps not), the word <char style="it">body </char>in the NT sometimes means <char|
                                        |style="it">carnal nature. </char>Putting this together, like bridling a horse a person who can control|
                                        |his tongue will be able to bring his carnal nature under control.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">makes outrageous remarks</char>…Lit: <char style="it">boasts great things</char>. The|
                                        |word <char style="it">boasts </char>[<char style="it">aucheo</char>, <char style="w" strong="G00850:a">αὐχέω</char>)]|
                                        |is used here instead of the commonly-used NT word <char style="it">kauchaomai </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G02744">καυχάομαι</char>). This verse is the only place in the NT that <char style="it">aucheo|
                                        |</char>is found, and the lexicon says that in a general sense it means <char style="it">to protest, declare</char>.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Merry-go-round of Life</char>…Or: <char style="it">the Engine of Life</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">the Wheel of Origin</char>. James is using the well-known metaphorical concept of a|
                                        |wheel, where a wheel represents cycles which keep on repeating themselves. This metaphorical use predates|
                                        |James by centuries, having its roots in astrology and mythology. For example, the term “Wheel of Fortune|
                                        |(Rota Fortunae)” is derived from this same concept.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">among other things ruthlessly pragmatic, psychopathic, and diabolic</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">earthly, mental, demonic</char>. <char style="it">Earthly </char>refers to a Machiavellian-sort|
                                        |of cunning. Keep in mind that the Gk. word for <char style="it">wisdom </char>means both wisdom and cunning.|
                                        |<char style="it">Mental </char>means a wisdom which is mental and emotional in contradiction to being|
                                        |spiritual; is concerned with this life only. It is mental thought which like an animal has, where, for|
                                        |example, an ape can tear apart another ape or eat another ape’s baby and have no remorse for it. <char|
                                        |style="it">Demonic </char>(<char style="it">diabolic</char>)<char style="it"> </char>patterns itself|
                                        |after an evil imp which goes around harassing people.|

                                        |<char style="it">he of the tomorrow what sort of your life</char>. This does lend itself to a literal|
                                        |translation.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">evil</char>…Or: <char style="it">absolutely awful</char>. The word <char style="it">evil|
                                        |</char>here is a bit of a hyperbole.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pleasurable carnal impulses</char>…Lit: <char style="it">pleasures</char>. This is the|
                                        |Gk. word which <char style="it">hedonistic </char>is derived from. James is talking about the pleasure|
                                        |one gets from indulging in one’s carnal nature. For example, the pleasure it gives you to fly off the|
                                        |handle and scream at someone; the pleasure when you stab someone in the back whom you dislike; the pleasure|
                                        |of lusting after a scantily-clad woman.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">component of your human nature</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in your members</char>.|
                                        |The word <char style="it">members </char>is short for <char style="it">members of the body. </char>The|
                                        |theory held by the writers of the NT is that a person’s carnal nature is a part of their body (Rom. 7:18,23).|
                                        |This carnal nature is referred to as the flesh, the body, or simply “members.” This is another reason|
                                        |why a believer receives a new body in the afterlife: the new body has no carnal component.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Spirit that has taken up residence in us and among us jealously longs and desires</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">for hearts turned towards Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">The Spirit that has taken|
                                        |up residence in us and among us jealously longs and desires</char>. The last part <char style="it">for|
                                        |hearts turned towards Him </char>is an interpolation, as it’s my best-guess as to what James meant. All|
                                        |theories on this verse have logical holes in them, but I assume that he’s paraphrasing (there is no exact|
                                        |OT quote) Exod. 20:5, “I the Lord thy God am a jealous God.” The OT says that He’s jealous for the affections|
                                        |of His people. James combines with this the OT concept of God dwelling among Israel. Like the other theories,|
                                        |there are contradictions to this one. Keep in mind that James is not writing a science textbook.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">So submit to God</char>…James uses an out-of-place verb tense (aorist imperative) throughout|
                                        |this paragraph for the purpose of jarring the reader even harder. It also insinuates that he means for|
                                        |the reader to do what he’s telling them to do in the paragraph one time and be done with, as opposed|
                                        |to doing it over and over.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">trashes the rules that govern us and writes them off by his speech</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">speaks against law and judges law</char>. Note the missing definite articles before the word|
                                        |<char style="it">law</char> in three places in this verse. Though the word <char style="it">law </char>here|
                                        |might insinuate <char style="it">Law of Moses</char>, the missing articles skew the meaning to a broader,|
                                        |conceptual use of the word <char style="it">law.</char>|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">weep and wail</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weep while wailing</char>. A figure of speech|
                                        |that adds intensity.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assail you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">come upon you</char>. This is an expression|
                                        |used throughout the Bible that means something which assaults you and likely overcomes you.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">show you just how guilty you are</char>…Or: <char style="it">point out your guilt to|
                                        |you</char>…Lit: be a witness to you|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">eat you alive</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eat your flesh</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the midst of the going-ons of this life</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon the </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">face of the</char>] <char style="it">earth</char>. A biblical metonymy (ref. Gen 1:2 (<char|
                                        |style="it">face of the water</char>); Gen. 7:23; Gen. 11:8 (<char style="it">whole earth</char>); Gen.|
                                        |11:8; Luke 21:35. The face of the earth stands in for the affairs of those who dwell on it.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">They don’t even try to fight you off</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he does not oppose</char>|
                                        |[or:<char style="it"> resist; </char>lit:<char style="it"> deploy against</char>] <char style="it">you.|
                                        |</char>The change from singular to plural of <char style="it">he </char>to <char style="it">they </char>is|
                                        |a result of <char style="it">the righteous </char>(a figure of speech) being singular in form but plural|
                                        |in meaning.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">applies patience through the course of it all</char>…Lit: <char style="it">patient at|
                                        |it</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ultimately getting</char>…Lit: <char style="it">until he gets</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is waiting for someone to give him the nod to take action</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stands|
                                        |before the doors</char>. <char style="it">Stand before the door </char>is an idiom; also used in Acts|
                                        |5:9; Rev. 3:20.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in order not to incur a tremendous burden of guilt</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in order|
                                        |that you won’t fall under judgment</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">run down with a malady of some sort</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weak</char>. Ref. note|
                                        |of Matt. 4:23.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">governing board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">acting under the authority of the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the name of the|
                                        |Lord</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get him back on his feet and going</char>…Lit: <char style="it">raise him up</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prayed a tremendous prayer</char>…Lit: <char style="it">prayed with a prayer</char>.|
                                        |The repetition is a figure of speech.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all over the place</char>…Lit: <char style="it">on the earth</char>. An idiom used throughout|
                                        |the Bible.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rescue his psychological well-being</char> <char style="it">(and perhaps even his very|
                                        |life) from waste, ruin, destruction, and worthlessness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">saves his soul from|
                                        |death</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you rich people who act like the stereotypical rich</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |rich</char>. The usage of the definite article <char style="it">the </char>means that James is referring|
                                        |to a stereotype. Not all rich people behave the way James describes, but plenty of them do.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in this era in which God is doing the great things He promised He’d do</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">in the Last Days</char>. The <char style="it">Last Days </char>is an expression used throughout|
                                        |the Bible. In the OT it’s the era in which God’s promises come to pass. This usually is not eschatological.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have secured the attention of the Great Unseen Army Chief of Staff</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">have entered into the ear of</char> [<char style="it">the</char>] <char style="it">Lord of|
                                        |Hosts</char>. The common expression <char style="it">enter into the ear </char>paints a picture of gaining|
                                        |the attention of a person who’s difficult to reach because of his limited accessibility due to his high|
                                        |position—but it implies that this high-ranking person is disposed to deliberate in a favorable manner.|
                                        |The title <char style="it">Lord of Hosts </char>[<char style="it">the army</char>] appears throughout|
                                        |the OT and naturally refers to God heading his army of angels. Angels in this case symbolize the exercise|
                                        |of God’s supreme power in judgment, and this often takes place when the longsuffering patience of God|
                                        |has been exhausted.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">don’t pledge any oath by the sky</char>…Swearing by something was a common practice|
                                        |in Israel at the time, one which Jesus spoke against in Matt. 23:16,17 and other places. This is like|
                                        |the oath Don Corleone made, “I swear on the souls of my grandchildren that I will not be the one to break|
                                        |the peace that we have made here today.”|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Peter, missionary of Jesus Christ:|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the specially chosen temporary residents (namely, the scattered believers of Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia,|
     v 1                                |Asia, and Bithynia) |
   N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |chosen by the Holy Spirit according to the foreknowledge of the Father-God and directed towards obedience|
     v 2                                |and towards a ceremonial-like sprinkling of the blood of Jesus Christ (just like Moses ratified the covenant|
     v 2                                |by sprinkling oxen blood over the people):|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace to you, and peace too, and may they come to you in wave after wave.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The blessed God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who, according to the enormous amount of mercy He|
     v 3                                |has, has rebirthed us to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to an imperishable, unsullied, non-deteriorating Customized Allocation tucked away for us in both|
     v 4                                |the spiritual domain and heaven itself— |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |we who by God’s power are being protected through faith and directed towards a rescue program to be revealed|
     v 5                                |in the thick of it all— |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and in the thick of it all we are jubilant, if it so happens that at the moment we must undergo the distress|
     v 6                                |caused by various trials, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the passing grade earned by our faith—a passing grade many times more precious than perishable-gold|
     v 7                                |(but is verified to be pure by melting it in a furnace)—would be found to result in praise, glory, and|
     v 7                                |honor in an unveiling of who Jesus Christ is. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You love him whom you don’t see; you believe in him whom at the moment you’re not familiar with through|
     v 8                                |direct sensory contact, and you exuberate with inexpressible, glorious joy, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |taking possession of the end-result of your faith: a rescue and preservation program for your mind and|
     v 9                                |emotions and for your very lives as well.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |About this “rescue and preservation program”…prophets researched and examined aspects of the grace that|
     v10                                |was prophesied into you, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |looking into which individuals or which particular timeframe the Spirit of Christ in them was specifying|
     v11                                |over and over, going on record before it happened stating the circumstances of the Messiah’s suffering|
     v11                                |and the glory which followed. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It was revealed to them that the prophesies which were uttered through their ministries weren’t given|
     v12                                |for themselves but for you, namely the things you’ve been told already by the evangelizations of the|
     v12                                |Gospel to you by the Holy Spirit sent from heaven—things which the angels long to peer into.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore, having poised your minds for action, being clear and level-headed to the utmost extent, hope|
     v13                                |for the grace delivered to you in an unveiling of who Jesus Christ is. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |As obedient children, don’t be molded by the carnal desires you had in your previous life of ignorance,|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but in pace with your holy calling into the Faith, get to where you’re holy in all of your conduct as|
     v15                                |well, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because it’s written, “Be holy since I Myself am holy.”|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And if you call on a Father who judges each person impartiality on the basis of their actions, live out|
     v17                                |the time you spend on this planet in fear, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing that you were not bought back with perishable silver or gold from your pointless, useless lifestyle|
     v18                                |handed down from your ancestors, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but with precious blood like one gets from a sacrificial lamb without defects or spots, namely Christ.|
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While, yes, he was known beforehand starting from day-one, but aside from that he’s made an appearance|
     v20                                |at a critical point in time for your sakes: |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you who through him believe in God, who raised him from the dead and glorified him, so that our faith|
     v21                                |and hope would be set on God.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now that our mind and emotions and our very lives as well have been purified by the obedience of truth|
     v22                                |to a genuine enjoyment of and close friendship to our fellow man, love one another fervently out of pure|
     v22                                |hearts, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having been rebirthed not from perishable seed but from imperishable, through the living Word of God—and|
     v23                                |the Word remains with us. |
   N V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore the Bible says:|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">missionary</char>…Lit: <char style="it">apostle</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">temporary residents</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sojourners</char>|

     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rescue program</char>…Lit: <char style="it">salvation</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the thick of it</char> <char style="it">all</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in</char> [<char|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">perishable gold</char>…An expression or perhaps an idiom; used here, in 1:18, in Acts|
                                        |8:20. Not sure what it exactly means.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mind and emotions and for your very lives as well</char>…Lit: <char style="it">soul</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">into</char>…Or: <char style="it">in</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">having poised your minds for action</char>…Lit: <char style="it">having girded the loins|
                                        |of your minds</char>. A metaphor. Ref. Luke 12:37.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">clear and level-headed</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sober</char>. Somewhat of a metaphor.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get to where</char>…Lit: <char style="it">become</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spend on this planet</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sojourn</char> (like in a foreign|
                                        |country)|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">starting from day-one</char>…Lit: <char style="it">from the foundation of the world</char>.|
                                        |A biblical expression; also used in Matt. 13:35, 25:34.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">critical point in time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">at the last of times</char>. <char|
                                        |style="it">Last times </char>is a biblical expression.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Every physical body and man’s attempts to live righteously apart from God—and let’s|
                                        |throw in the carnal nature</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all flesh</char>|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">when the flesh is at its finest moment, at the pinnacle of its beauty and achievement</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">its glory</char>|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Customized Allocation</char>…Or: <char style="it">Special Parcel</char>…Lit: <char style="it">inheritance</char>.|
                                        |The word <char style="it">inheritance </char>as used in the NT leverages the concept of an inheritance|
                                        |from the OT (ref. note of Luke 10:25), then applies this to the covenant of the NT. To recap, just as|
                                        |God in the OT had a specific piece of land for His people to dwell in, He has a specific place where|
                                        |He wants His NT people to “dwell.” This NT “land” is not a physical land but is a place, spiritually|
                                        |speaking, where God has allocated for his people and has tailored it specifically for each Christian|
                                        |denomination and even each Christian individually, just like the land of Israel in the time of Joshua|
                                        |was partitioned by tribe, by clan, and finally by family. This spiritual “land” consists of promises|
                                        |given in the Bible; of the movement of the Holy Spirit collectively in a denomination, a church, and|
                                        |even customized down to the individual: a special gift or calling for each person.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in both the spiritual domain and heaven itself</char>…Lit: <char style="it">heaven</char>.|
                                        |The Gk. word <char style="it">heaven </char>has multiple meanings depending on the context. Paul mentioned|
                                        |that there are at least three “heavens” (2 Cor. 12:2); these include the sky above, the spiritual domain,|
                                        |and heaven itself.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">but is verified to be pure by melting it in a furnace</char>…Lit: <char style="it">but|
                                        |through fire approved</char>. The word <char style="it">fire </char>here is a synecdoche for a furnace|
                                        |used for melting and reforming gold.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the rescue program, the program which keeps you from calamity</char>…Lit: <char style="it">salvation</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to offer up</char>…The Gk. verb tense is aorist and not present, which implies that|
                                        |it’s a one-time offering. This is unexpected.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Scripture</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put in place</char>…This is the same word used in v.6 and refers to that verse|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">awesomeness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">excellencies</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who aren’t Christians</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Gentiles</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">upon close, careful examination</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in a</char> [or perhaps|
                                        |<char style="it">the</char>] <char style="it">day</char> <char style="it">of examination</char>. Note|
                                        |that <char style="it">day of </char>is a biblical expression. Note that many translations use the word|
                                        |<char style="it">visitation </char>[from <char style="it">episkeptomai</char>, <char style="w" strong="G01980">ἐπισκέπτομαι</char>)]|
                                        |and not <char style="it">examination </char>[from <char style="it">episkopeō</char>, <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G01983">ἐπισκοπέω</char>)]<char style="it">. </char>The Gk. word used here is <char style="it">episkopas|
                                        |</char>(ἐπισκοπῆς), which is a noun form of episkopeō —not a form of episkeptomai (although episkopeō|
                                        |and episkeptomai are similar and are related etymologically).|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">come clean and tell the truth</char>…Lit: <char style="it">glorify God</char>. An idiom;|
                                        |ref. note of John 9:24.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to every man-made position of authority</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in all human creature</char>.|
                                        |An idiom apparently.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">established through the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through the Lord</char>. It’s|
                                        |not clear whether this phrase means to submit through the Lord or that the positions of authority were|
                                        |created through the Lord. I’m guessing it’s the latter, and that this somehow extends the idiom.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">band of fellow believers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the brotherhood</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I assume you are but if not you should be submitting</char>…Lit: <char style="it">submitting</char>.|
                                        |For the next several verses and into chapter 3, Peter uses participles in place of imperative verb forms,|
                                        |while the reader understands that the imperative form is meant. By using the participle, Peter takes|
                                        |on a less accusatory posture.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">abuse and reprimands—even getting slapped around</char>…Lit: <char style="it">beatings|
                                        |</char>[more literally <char style="it">buffeting </char>or<char style="it"> cuffs</char>:<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>multiple hits with a fist or with the palm of one’s hand]. The picture here is of a slave being|
                                        |punched or slapped by his master because of displeasure or disobedience.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">from</char>…Or: <char style="it">with</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">wooden cross-beam</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wood</char>. Ref. note of Acts 5:30.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Great Leader, Overseer, and Protector</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the</char> <char|
                                        |style="it">shepherd </char>[<char style="it">pastor</char>]<char style="it"> and overseer </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">bishop</char>]. A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">minds, emotions, our very beings</char>…Lit: <char style="it">soul</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">logical analogy to</char>…Lit: <char style="it">logical</char>. Or: <char style="it">Word</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">of God</char>]-<char style="it">related</char>. There’s some ambiguity in what Peter|
                                        |means by the Gk. word <char style="it">logikos </char><char style="w" strong="G03050">λογικός</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">, </char>the adjective that most other translations render <char style="it">Word. </char>One|
                                        |could put up a substantial argument for either. Perhaps it means both.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">like a newborn baby yearns for milk, yearn for the (logical analogy to the) pure milk</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">like a newborn baby, you all yearn the logical </char>[or<char style="it"> Word-related</char>]<char|
                                        |style="it"> pure milk </char>This is a hybrid simile and metaphor, one of the most excellent metaphors|
                                        |in the NT. The most tremendous growth spurt that a human being experiences is when a one is a newborn|
                                        |baby between the ages of three and seven weeks. During this time, a baby is continuously hungry for milk,|
                                        |crying around the clock to be fed. A baby grows substantially during this four week period. Peter is|
                                        |telling Christians to mimic the hunger which a newborn baby has; he is not telling them to imitate babies|
                                        |in any other respect. Just as this baby hungers, is fed, and grows enormously, is the same way should|
                                        |Christians hunger for the Word. Their growth will be like the baby’s.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">since—surely now—</char>…Lit: <char style="it">if</char>. The rendering of this word|
                                        |[<char style="it">ei, </char><char style="w" strong="G01487">εἰ</char>)] has caused confusion to the|
                                        |point that several ancient manuscripts have altered this word from <char style="it">ei </char>to <char|
                                        |style="it">eiper</char> (εἰπερ/no Strong’s word) forcing it to say <char style="it">since </char>instead|
                                        |of <char style="it">if. </char>There are secondary meanings to the word <char style="it">ei </char>that|
                                        |Peter is likely drawing on here, but nevertheless some ambiguity remains.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A stone which causes one to veer off into a ditch resulting in wrong-doing and also|
                                        |a rock which offends…Lit: a stumbling stone and a rock of stumbling</char> [or, <char style="it">offense</char>].|
                                        |Liberties taken. The word <char style="it">stumbling</char> is an idiom; ref. note of Matt. 11:6.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they slander you as being a bad person</char> (etc.)…What Peter is saying here in v.|
                                        |12 is that although non-Christians will slander you simply because of prejudice, stereotypes, rumors,|
                                        |lies, misunderstandings, etc., when they’re pressed to get down to the brass tacks and look at the specific|
                                        |circumstances about someone they know who’s a Christian, they’ll have to (or perhaps will reluctantly)|
                                        |admit that, based on that Christian’s good behavior in the specific situations he was observed in, he|
                                        |is a decent person after all.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">submit</char>…The Gk. word here for submit [<char style="it">hupotassō</char>, <char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G05293">ὑποτάσσω</char>)] literally means <char style="it">to arrange oneself under</char>.|
                                        |There are multiple words in the NT which essentially mean <char style="it">to order, to give a command,|
                                        |</char>etc. The stem from which the word <char style="it">arrange </char>comes means to given an order,|
                                        |and it was a military term used when a commander issued orders to deploy units of phalanxes, etc. on|
                                        |a battlefield. A good arrangement of the units, and one which was carried out successfully, was crucial|
                                        |to victory on the battlefield. So <char style="it">hupotassō</char> means to allow oneself to be “arranged”|
                                        |by the person in command, knowing that the one in command has the overall view of what needs to be put|
                                        |and where and is placing you in position according to a master plan—a plan which you might not even be|
                                        |familiar with. This shade of meaning to the word <char style="it">submit </char>differs from a shade|
                                        |of meaning of an underling being crushed by an oppressive overlord.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |In this regard, the Gk. word <char style="it">hypakouō</char> <char style="w" strong="G05219">ὑπακούω</char>),|
                                        |which corresponds <char style="it">to obey</char>, literally means <char style="it">under the giving-ear-to.|
                                        |</char>This refers to being under the audible sound—the voice commands—of another person. The nature|
                                        |of the word is that one person is to simply obey the spoken-orders (and this would apply to any order,|
                                        |not just a spoken one) of the one above him. The emphasis is on simple obedience to the order, without|
                                        |questions asked and without an expectation that the one obeying will understand the big-picture. And|
                                        |this is where submit and obey diverge. The one who submits understands that his submission is necessary|
                                        |to accomplish the overall goal; that he should understand the overall goal and understand that he is|
                                        |one of multiple parties, all of whom must do his part and comply with his specific command for the sake|
                                        |of the overall strategy, vision, or long-term plan, which is planned and executed by the one in charge.|
                                        |Therefore, a child or a slave is expected to obey, not submit, but an adult, one who has heavy responsibilities,|
                                        |such as a soldier, is told to submit, not obey.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Throughout history, there have been two methods whereby the common soldier takes orders from a superior:|
                                        |the soldier can submit or he can obey. Generally speaking, armies where the soldiers submit are more|
                                        |effective than armies where the soldiers obey. Those who submit are encouraged to think beyond their|
                                        |individual contribution, and because of that, a person who submits may at times improvise according to|
                                        |the need of the moment, not doing what he was directly ordered to do for the sake of the overarching|
                                        |plan. Soldiers who simply obey will fear potential retribution due to improvisation and not exploit opportunities|
                                        |or adapt to changing conditions on the battlefield.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">disobedient, don’t believe, or simply aren’t convinced</char>….The Gk. word <char style="it">apeitheō|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G00544">ἀπειθέω</char>)means all three of these: <char style="it">to</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">not be persuaded; to not believe; to be disobedient. </char>The more common word for|
                                        |<char style="it">to believe </char>is <char style="it">pisteuō </char><char style="w" strong="G04100">πιστεύω</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">; to not believe</char> is <char style="it">apisteuō </char><char style="w" strong="G00569">ἀπιστέω</char>).|
                                        |<char style="it">Apisteuō</char> has connotations of stubbornly refusing to believe out of hard-hearted|
                                        |disobedience . Acts 28:24 shows by example the difference between these two Gk. words. But the point|
                                        |of the matter is that Peter said that those husbands who are <char style="it">apeitheō </char>will be|
                                        |won over—he did not say that the <char style="it">apisteuō-</char>husbands can or will be won.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">getting your hair done and putting on expensive jewelry or wearing stylish or alluring|
                                        |clothing</char>…<char style="it">stylish or alluring clothing—what you put on to make yourself look good</char>…Lit:|
                                        |Gk. <char style="it">kosmos </char>for <char style="it">what you put on to make yourself look good</char>.|
                                        |<char style="it">Kosmos</char> <char style="w" strong="G02889">κόσμος</char>)<char style="it"> </char>in|
                                        |this context uses a secondary meaning, which is <char style="it">adornment, dress, decoration. </char>It’s|
                                        |hard to imagine that this secondary definition of <char style="it">kosmos </char>doesn’t acquire overtones|
                                        |from its primary definition (world/worldly), which, assuming that is the case, justifies the rendering|
                                        |<char style="it">stylish, cosmopolitan, </char>and even <char style="it">alluring. </char>In addition|
                                        |to this use of <char style="it">kosmos</char>…Years ago, Christians who were part of the holiness movement|
                                        |(which includes Pentecostals) interpreted verses to mean that Christian women shouldn’t braid their hair,|
                                        |wear jewelry or wear nice clothing. This is not the point Peter is making. (And as Jeanne Wilkerson used|
                                        |to say in rebuttal to this flaky teaching, “If the barn needs painting, why then: paint it.”) Peter is|
                                        |saying that a woman shouldn’t consider herself to be a beautiful person because of her outward appearance|
                                        |but because of her inward nature.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">quiet (in the sense of being at-rest and at-peace)</char>…The Gk. word used here for|
                                        |<char style="it">quiet </char>appears nowhere else in the NT. Had Peter meant a woman who doesn’t talk|
                                        |a lot, he would’ve used a different, more commonly used word which means quiet. But this verse is referring|
                                        |to a woman who isn’t consumed with drama; playing games; false suspicions of the motives of others; easily|
                                        |angered; prone to jealousy; etc.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |a <char style="it">person whose wide range of human expression is put to use</char>…Lit: <char style="it">vessel</char>.|
                                        |In the NT, the word <char style="it">vessel </char>when referring to a person and not to an actual container|
                                        |is a figure of speech, a metonymy and an idiom. Ref. Acts 9:15; Rom. 9:21; 1 Cor. 4:7; 1 Thess. 4:4;|
                                        |2 Tim. 2:20. A vessel is a container that holds something which is worth storing; the vessel’s ability|
                                        |to hold and store that thing is what gives the vessel value. Our physical bodies are containers which|
                                        |hold our spirits and the Holy Spirit, and this is what gives our bodies value, as our bodies are animated|
                                        |by the Spirit inside of us. But vessels are not only bodies but human beings.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirits in prison</char>…According to the context, these are all the people on the earth|
                                        |except for Noah and his family, those who didn’t make it into the ark. The assumption is that the “prison”|
                                        |referred to here is hell and that Jesus “preached” to them when he was in hell after his death and before|
                                        |his resurrection. Perhaps Jesus was preaching to them about the fact that he was going to be rescued|
                                        |from that place in the same way that, when they were alive, Noah preached to them that he was going to|
                                        |be rescued from the flood coming on the earth. This is speculation of course.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kept on pushing out</char>…Also: <char style="it">kept on postponing. </char>Peter is|
                                        |saying that God was doing His best to get the people on the earth to repent so He wouldn’t have to send|
                                        |a flood, and kept on postponing the time of the flood to give them yet another opportunity to repent.|
                                        |The oldest living person recorded in the Bible is Methuselah, whose name means “his death shall send.”|
                                        |His name itself is a prophecy of the coming flood, and the prophecy is that when he dies the flood will|
                                        |come (and upon correlating the dates, the flood occurred the year Methuselah died). In God’s longsuffering,|
                                        |He postponed the date of flood, but also had to lengthen Methuselah’s life because of the prophecy. Methuselah’s|
                                        |long life is a testimony to God’s longsuffering.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">demonic agents, demon spirits with authority over other demon spirits, and evil forces</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">angels</char> [<char style="it">agents</char>] <char style="it">and authorities and|
                                        |powers</char>. Based on a preponderance of NT teachings, this verse is talking about demonic spirits|
                                        |and not about humans. The word <char style="it">angels </char>here means <char style="it">messengers|
                                        |</char>(which is <char style="it">agents</char>)<char style="it"> </char>instead of fallen angels. These|
                                        |agents are demonic spirits (“messengers of Satan”, 2 Cor. 12:7, NASB) which Satan sends to fulfill a|
                                        |specific mission. The word <char style="it">authorities </char>refers to demons which are given authority|
                                        |over other demons, and the same word is used this way in Eph. 6:12. The word <char style="it">powers|
                                        |</char>refers to demons that are simply a force for evil. Before Jesus ascended into heaven, these wicked|
                                        |spirits were made subordinate to him.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on the church governing board</char>…Lit: <char style="it">elders</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken; ref. note of Acts 11:30.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s way</char>…Lit: <char style="it">according to God</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those assigned to you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of the portions</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not leading the heirs of eternal life as a domineering, micro-managing dictator</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">not lording-over</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">lording-over </char>literally|
                                        |means <char style="it">lording down upon </char>or <char style="it">lording to the utmost extent.</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cause things to turn out well for you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">exalt you</char>.|
                                        |An expression; also used in Is. 14:13,14; 2 Cor. 12:7.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">when the time’s right</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in season</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Be level-headed and stay focused</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Be sober and watch</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is being perpetrated on your fellow comrades</char>…Or: <char style="it">your fellow|
                                        |comrades are being subjected to</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">over the course of a few paragraphs</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through</char> [<char|
                                        |style="it">the</char>] <char style="it">few ones</char>. Similar wording used in Eph. 3:3.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Pastor (i.e. lead; be a shepherd to)…</char>Lit: shepherd. The word <char style="it">pastor</char>|
                                        |only appears in a couple of places in the NT (in this verse and in Eph. 4:11); the word for <char style="it">pastor|
                                        |</char>is the same as <char style="it">shepherd. </char>The word <char style="it">shepherd </char>in|
                                        |the OT refers to a leader (Ez. 37:24 is one example). The implication is that people are difficult to|
                                        |lead like sheep are difficult to lead, so the word <char style="it">pastor </char>is one who faces the|
                                        |difficulties in leading people, who are by nature difficult to lead.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with a leadership style</char>…Some of the older manuscripts include a variation of|
                                        |this interpolation explicitly in a single Gk. word [<char style="it">episkopountes, </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G01983">ἐπισκοποῦντεσ</char>)]<char style="it"> </char>rendered <char style="it">exercising oversight;|
                                        |</char>the word <char style="it">bishop </char>[<char style="it">episkopos</char>, <char style="w" strong="G01985">ἐπίσκοπος</char>)]|
                                        |is obviously the noun form of this verb. As the two principal Alexandrian manuscripts omit the word <char|
                                        |style="it">episkopountes</char>, it is my opinion that this word is a spurious addition—although it fits|
                                        |nicely in the context. As Christianity evolved into the late first and early second centuries, churches|
                                        |governed by elder bodies were replaced by churches governed by a single person—a bishop. They sought|
                                        |to stamp out any suggestion in the NT that churches can or should be governed by elder boards and not|
                                        |by bishops; hence, the addition of the word <char style="it">episkopountes </char>to some of the manuscripts.|
                                        |This controversy persists to the present day.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stand in and stick to the grace!</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stand to it</char> [<char|
                                        |style="it">“it” referring to “the grace”</char>]<char style="it">!</char>…Or: <char style="it">stand|
                                        |in it </char>[<char style="it">“the grace”</char>]<char style="it">!</char>. The words <char style="it">the|
                                        |grace </char>are a clarification for the reader, and this interpolation is justified by matching a pronoun|
                                        |with its antecedents by gender. The GT literally reads <char style="it">stand to it</char>, but scholars|
                                        |argue that Peter actually meant <char style="it">stand in it.</char> Some guesswork was used to come|
                                        |up with “stand in and stick to.”|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The sister-church in metaphorical Babylon (which is Rome)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |fellow-called </char>[<char style="it">church</char>]<char style="it"> in Babylon</char>. The word <char|
                                        |style="it">called </char>in <char style="it">fellow-called </char>shares the same root word for <char|
                                        |style="it">church</char>, so <char style="it">fellow-called </char>is <char style="it">fellow-church|
                                        |</char>or <char style="it">sister-church. </char>Some Bible “experts” incorrectly render this verse <char|
                                        |style="it">she who is in Babylon (etc). </char>This is an incorrect understanding of Gk. grammar, as|
                                        |the prepositional phrase <char style="it">in Babylon </char>, inserted between the definite article and|
                                        |the noun, must be moved, leaving the definite article to couple tightly with the noun, rendering it <char|
                                        |style="it">the fellow-church </char>instead of the dangling word <char style="it">she </char>etc<char|
                                        |style="it">. </char>Moving along…many scholars agree that Peter is speaking metaphorically when he speaks|
                                        |of Babylon. In the same verse, he refers to Mark as his son, and as this is metaphorical, it lends credence|
                                        |to assuming that Babylon is metaphorical as well.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Mark my son</char>…Peter is referring to John-Mark, the same Mark who wrote the Gospel|
                                        |of Mark. Mark was not Peter’s actual son, but was Peter’s close companion and son in the faith. Church|
                                        |tradition tells us that Mark served as Peter’s translator, and that Mark wrote the Gospel of Mark shortly|
                                        |after Peter was executed. This Gospel is essentially a compilation of all the stories which Mark translated|
                                        |for Peter time and time again throughout the years.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">with hearty handshakes and warm hugs of love</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with a kiss|
                                        |of love</char>. Liberties taken. Kisses were normal greetings, and were exchanged irrespective of gender.|
                                        |Judas greeted Jesus with a kiss in the Garden of Gethsemane.|

     v19                                |thing a person’s been defeated by, he’s enslaved to. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |At this time I’m writing this second letter to you, beloved, in which letters I thoroughly rouse your|

 +P  V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |“Where is the fulfillment of the promise of His coming? The fact is, starting from when it all began|

     v 4                                |was not fulfilled in their lifetime, and everything’s continued following this same pattern with no interruption|
     v 4                                |from ancient times onwards.”|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, what the ones who’re deliberately ignoring this are just not getting is that the sky, the upper|

     v 5                                |out of water and by means of water through the word of God, |

 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now, make sure you get this, beloved: to the Lord, one day is like a thousand years and a thousand years|
     v 8                                |is like one day. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The Lord isn’t procrastinating in keeping His word, like some consider Him to be procrastinating, but|
     v 9                                |He’s exercising patience in regard to you instead, not wishing anyone to be destroyed but leaving space|
     v 9                                |for everyone to have a change of heart and of ways instead.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The day that the Lord will arrive like a thief coming at night to steal, in which day the sky, the upper|

     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While all these things are shattered into pieces this way, the sort of lifestyle you must maintain is|

     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |eagerly awaiting for and hastening the Day of God, by means of which the sky, the upper atmosphere, and|

     v12                                |heated to an extremely high temperature. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We eagerly await a new sky, upper atmosphere, and outer-space, and a new earth according to His promise,|
     v13                                |where in these new things righteousness dwells.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore, beloved, while eagerly awaiting these things, accelerate being found spotless and blameless|
     v14                                |in him in peace. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Consider our Lord to be the patient savior, just as our beloved comrade Paul wrote to you too, according|
     v15                                |to the wisdom that’s been bestowed on him, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |as he too talks about all these things in his letters, in which letters some things are difficult to|
     v16                                |understand, things that the unlearned and unstable distort to their own self-destruction, like they do|
     v16                                |with the rest of the Scriptures. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So you, beloved, aware of this beforehand, protect yourselves so that you won’t be deceived by unprincipled|
     v17                                |men, to be led away from and ultimately fall from your individual steadfastness.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. To him be the glory from this|
     v18                                |moment to the eternal day. Amen (i.e., and with that I rest my case).|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN1 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That which was from day-one, that which we’ve heard, that which we’ve seen with our eyes, that which|
     v 1                                |we’ve beheld and our hands handled concerning the word of life— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the life was manifested, and we have beheld it and give an official report about it: we announce|
     v 2                                |to you the Eternal Life (i.e. that special fullness of life) which was with the Father and was manifested|
     v 2                                |to us. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That which we’ve beheld and heard, we announce even to you, so that you would have fellowship with us,|
     v 3                                |but also that Our Fellowship would be with the Father and with His Son Jesus Christ. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re writing these things to you so that your joy would attain its greatest extent.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is the very announcement which we heard from him and announce to you, that God is light and there|
     v 5                                |is not a single bit of darkness in Him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say that we have fellowship with Him and conduct our lives in the darkness, we would be|
     v 6                                |lying and not practicing the truth. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if we were to conduct our lives in the light just as He is in the light, we would have fellowship|
     v 7                                |with one another, and the blood of His son Jesus would cleanse us from all sins. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say on a given occasion that we don’t have sin, we would be fooling ourselves and the truth|
     v 8                                |would not be in us. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to confess our sins, He’s faithful and always does the right thing so that He would forgive|
     v 9                                |us of our sins and would cleanse us from all unrighteousness. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say on a given occasion that we’ve reached the point where we haven’t sinned, we’re making|
     v10                                |Him out to be a liar and His word (His system of thought) is not in us.|
     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">give an official report</char>…Lit: <char style="it">testify</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">conduct our lives</char>…Lit: <char style="it">walk about</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">would cleanse</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cleanses</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">truth would not be</char>…Lit: <char style="it">truth is not</char>|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">go through a turn of conduct</char>…<char style="it">conducting his life</char>…Lit:|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">waning</char>…Lit: <char style="it">passing by</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">His reputation and everything He stands for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">His name</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">body’s carnal nature</char>…Lit: <char style="it">flesh</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what one longs for but doesn’t have</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eyes</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it’s the endgame</char>…Lit: <char style="it">it’s the last hour</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and is true and—just to be clear—is not a lie</char>…Lit: <char style="it">and is true|
                                        |and is not a lie</char>. Adding <char style="it">and is not a lie, </char>which is deduced from <char|
                                        |style="it">and is true </char>is a figure of speech|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you boys who work</char>…Lit: <char style="it">boys</char>. John uses a different word|
                                        |in 1 John 1:2 for children than this word here. The word <char style="it">boy </char>means <char style="it">worker|
                                        |</char>or <char style="it">servant. </char>Ref. note of John 21:5.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you’ve arrived at the point where you know and understand Him</char>…<char style="it">aspiring|
                                        |young adults, because you’re strong and the word of God dwells in you, and you’ve defeated the Evil One</char>…The|
                                        |repetition of these two statements just a couple verses before is a figure of speech.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a special dispensation bestowed on you</char>…<char style="it">special dispensation</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">anointing</char>. Also, ref. note of Luke 4:18. The word <char style="it">anointing|
                                        |</char>refers to pouring oil over someone (ex: John 11:2). Throughout the Bible, anointing a person marks|
                                        |that person with extraordinary abilities, abilities which originate from God and are actuated by means|
                                        |of the Holy Spirit (are a manifestation of the Holy Spirit). These special abilities are specific to|
                                        |that one person and are for a particular purpose. In this context of 1 John 2, John’s usage of the word|
                                        |<char style="it">anointing </char>is an extraordinary ability bestowed on each believer, but like any|
                                        |anointing, the extraordinary ability is unique to that person; no other person receives the same anointing.|
                                        |The 1 John 2 anointing is the ability to understand how exactly one should conduct himself in a godly|
                                        |manner on a day-to-day basis. The 1 John 2 anointing gives a person the ability to discern for himself|
                                        |what the correct thing is for him to do in life. Incidentally, this passage here refutes the notion that|
                                        |any church leader (especially a cult leader) should be deciding what an individual church member should|
                                        |do in their circumstances of life, especially to a fine detail.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN1 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Look at the kind of love that the Father has given us, that we would be called God’s children—and we|
     v 1                                |are. Because of this, the world, the established order of humans, doesn’t know and understand us, since|
     v 1                                |it didn’t know and understand Him. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Beloved, at the present time we are God’s children, and it hasn’t yet been made apparent what we’ll be.|
     v 2                                |We know that if he were to be manifested, we would be just like him, because we would see him the way|
     v 2                                |he is. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And everyone who has this hope, a hope which is focused on him, purges himself from defilement in the|
     v 3                                |same way that he has no defilement.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Everyone who practices archetypical sin also practices archetypical lawlessness, that is, the refusal|
     v 4                                |to be restrained by the rules of God or of man. and the archetypical sin IS the archetypical lawlessness.|
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And we know for a fact that that person appeared in order to take away the archetypical sins, and there|
     v 5                                |is no sin in him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Everyone who’s dwelling in him isn’t sinning; everyone who’s sinning has not seen him nor has come to|
     v 6                                |know and understand him. |

                                        |style="it">down </char>means <char style="it">in opposition to</char>; <char style="it">against</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">a negative or oppressive action</char>]<char style="it">. </char>Compare this to katakrinō,|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Messiah, the Christ, has been begotten from God, and everyone|

     v16                                |in that case. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All wrong-doing is sin, but there is sin the nature of which does not result in spiritual death.|

     v 4                                |as having the consequence of their actions result in judgment; ungodly men, transforming our God’s grace|
     v 4                                |into debauchery and denying the one master, our Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now I wish to remind you…A long time ago, as you’re well-aware, the Lord rescued a people from Egypt—the|
     v 5                                |second time they fell into a crisis, He wiped out those who refused to have faith and believe; |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not only that but He’s imprisoned angels who didn’t stick to the domain which was their right to exercise|
     v 6                                |authority over but instead abandoned their habitat, which resulted in a verdict being delivered against|
     v 6                                |them when the scores were settled, leading to everlasting bonds and being oppressed by gloom. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Like Sodom and Gomorrah and those in the surrounding cities, they were put on exhibit as an example of|
     v 7                                |undergoing the punishment of eternal fire for having committed gross acts of sexual immorality in having|
     v 7                                |pursued having sex with a different kind of physical body than their own the same way those other guys|
     v 7                                |(those angels) did. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Nevertheless—sure—those people who also dream about having sex with different kinds of physical bodies|
     v 8                                |defile themselves, but on top of that they also reject things pertaining to authority structures, and|
     v 8                                |yet on top of that bad-mouth the sacrosanct.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now when the archangel Michael was in the middle of an argument with the devil over Moses’s body, he|
     v 9                                |didn’t dare rain an invective judgment down on him, but instead said, “May you be rebuked by the Lord!”|
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now those people indeed bad-mouth things which they have no direct knowledge of, those whose understanding|
     v10                                |has a nature like ridiculous creatures; they’re being destroyed in these matters by their decadence.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Woe to them because they’ve followed the same trajectory as Cain; and by following in the deception of|
     v11                                |Balaam, Balaam’s reward has been poured out on them; and by analogy in the ridiculousness of Korah’s|
     v11                                |rebellion, they were destroyed.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |These are the ones who are stains in your love-feasts, irreverently joining you in festive merry-making—self-guided,|
     v12                                |self-directed; moisture-less clouds that get driven past by the wind; trees which yield nothing at harvest-season,|
     v12                                |absolutely and completely dead and uprooted; |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |savage ocean waves, their shame causing the foam that waves naturally generate; wandering stars for whom|
     v13                                |the gloom of darkness has been forevermore reserved.|
 + N V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now Enoch, the seventh generation from Adam, prophesied about them, saying:|
 +P  V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |“Look at this now—the Lord came with his holy myriads |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to enact judgment against everyone and convict every living being in regard to all their ungodly works|
     v15                                |which they did in an ungodly way and about all the harsh things which ungodly sinners spoke against Him.”|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Those guys are grumblers, fault-finders, going here and there following their intense, personal desires,|
     v16                                |and their mouths speak condescendingly, flattering others in order to gain favors.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now you, beloved, remember the words spoken beforehand by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |that they kept on telling us, “At a critical juncture in time, from among the ungodly there will be mockers|
     v18                                |going around following their intense, personal desires.” |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |These are the ones who cause division; they are naturally-minded and dominated by the mental facilities,|
     v19                                |not possessing the Spirit.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you, beloved, edifying yourselves—building yourselves up—in your most holy faith, praying in the|
     v20                                |Holy Spirit, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |keep yourself in the love of God while awaiting the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ resulting in that|
     v21                                |special fullness of life, eternal life.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On the one hand, have mercy on some, namely those who are in doubt, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but on the other hand, grab some others and jerk them out of the fire. Now have mercy on these people|
     v23                                |reverently and with trepidation, hating even the shirt dirtied by the flesh.|
 +   V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now to the One who’s able to guard over you keeping you from falling prey to temptation or making a mistake|
     v24                                |and to present you before His glory without blemish with exultation, |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to our One Savior-God who saves through Jesus Christ our Lord be glory, majesty, power, and authority|
     v25                                |in the forefront of the entire age, in the present moment, and extending to all the ages to come. Amen|
     v25                                |(i.e., and with that I rest my case).|

     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">physical body than their own</char>…Lit: <char style="it">flesh</char>|

     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">absolutely and completely dead</char>…Lit: <char style="it">doubly-dead</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">harsh</char>…Lit: <char style="it">hard</char>|
