     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">archangel Michael was in the middle of an argument with the devil over Moses’s body</char>…Scholars|
                                        |say that this refers to a story in the <char style="it">Assumption of Moses</char>, a 1<char style="sup">st</char>-century|
                                        |Jewish work. The Assumption of Moses is not part of the Bible.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">moisture-less clouds that get driven past by the wind</char>…Generally speaking, a farmer|
                                        |hopes that any cloud which pass overhead will sprinkle some rain on his crops. These pass by but deliver|
                                        |no rain.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  REV Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |A revelation—a revealing—by Jesus Christ of matters hidden, a revelation which God gave to him, to show|
     v 1                                |his servants what must come to pass post-haste. He transmitted what he saw through His angel to his servant|
     v 1                                |John, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave an official account of God’s discourse and of the statement of Jesus Christ. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Blessed be the one reading aloud to the congregation and the listeners in the congregation who hear the|
     v 3                                |words of the prophecy and who keep what’s been written therein, for the time is near.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From John to the seven churches in the Roman province of Asia: grace be to you and peace from He Who|
     v 4                                |was, Who is, and Who is to come, and from the seven spirits that are right in front of His throne, |
   N V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and from Jesus Christ, the Faithful Witness, the first-born from the dead, and the ruler of the kings|
     v 5                                |of the earth.|
 +P  V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To him who loved us and who by his blood detached us from our sins, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and who made us into a kingdom, into personal attendants to his Father-figure-God—to him be the glory|
     v 6                                |and the power forevermore. So be it.|

 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I turned around so I could be facing the voice while it was speaking to me. Once I turned around I saw|
     v12                                |seven golden lamps, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and in the middle of the lamps I saw something equivalent to the ideal embodiment of a human being, wearing|
     v13                                |a long robe that went down to his feet and wearing a golden sash around his chest. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |His head and his hair were as white as white wool—as white as snow—and his eyes were like wheels of fire|
     v14                                |which turned around and around. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |His feet were the same as copper or bronze as it’s being melted in a furnace, and his voice is like a|
     v15                                |voice composed of a large volume of rushing water. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He had seven stars in his right hand, and from his mouth was a sharp, protruding, two-edged sword (a|
     v16                                |4 foot/120cm long Thracian sword), and his face shined like the sun when it’s at its maximum intensity.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I saw him, I fell at his feet as though I was dead. He put his right hand on me while saying, <char|
     v17                                |style="wj">“Don’t be afraid. I’m the first and the last </char>|
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |<char style="wj">and the living one. I happened to die and—as you can see—I’m alive forever and ever,|
     v18                                |and I have the keys to the mysterious world of death</char><char style="wj">. </char>|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |<char style="wj">So write what you see and that which is and that which is going to come to pass after|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">post-haste</char>…Lit: <char style="it">quickly</char>. This doesn’t necessarily mean|
                                        |that he’s coming soon; it means that he’ll travel quickly when he does come, like a thief in the night.|
                                        |Ref. usage of <char style="it">quickly </char>with regard to travelling in 1 Cor. 4:19.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">statement of Jesus</char>…Lit: <char style="it">testimony of Jesus. </char>This phrase|
                                        |is repeated throughout Revelation.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Father-figure-God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">God and Father</char>. This is a hendiadys;|
                                        |ref. note of Matt. 3:11.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">so be it</char>…<char style="it">Let it be so…</char>Lit: <char style="it">amen. </char>Ref.|
                                        |note of Rev. 19:4.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">breaking through</char>…Lit: <char style="it">coming with</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on the island</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the island</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on a Sunday</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the Lord-day</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ideal embodiment of a human being</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a son of man</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a large volume of rushing water</char>…Lit: <char style="it">many waters</char>. Like|
                                        |the sound a waterfall makes.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">personal attendants</char>…Lit: <char style="it">priests</char>. In this context, a|
                                        |priest is one who carries out the ritualistic duties demanded by the holy presence of the Almighty, similar|
                                        |to how priests in the OT had duties in the temple.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tribes of the earth</char>…Using the word <char style="it">tribes</char> as a metonymy|
                                        |for the present-day ethnic groups and nations; the assumption being that all ethnic groups and nations|
                                        |were spawned by a single, specific tribe at their inception, in the same as is recorded in the OT, Gen.|
                                        |10 in particular.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the Spirit</char>…A strong presence of the Holy Spirit (1 Cor. 12:3) comes upon a|
                                        |person, often accompanied by some sort of prophetic utterance.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mysterious world of death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the death and the Hades</char>.|
                                        |A reference to death as alluded to in the OT and to death as portrayed by Greek mythology. As Christians,|
                                        |John and those who read the revelation will take this as a figure of speech, as they are taught in heaven|
                                        |vs. hell mythology (mythology meaning the understanding of the components in the unseen world, not a|
                                        |fictitious story).|

                                        |style="it">he who has ears to hear, let him hear</char>. Ref. Matt. 11:15.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">system of thought</char>…Lit: <char style="it">word</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what I stand for</char>…Lit: <char style="it">my name</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">permitting—indeed, causing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">granting</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">my idea of what perseverance is</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the word of my perseverance</char>|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">so-be-it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">amen</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his Angels</char>…Angels are affiliated with the holiness of God, and God uses them|
                                        |as attendants in the same way that priests used to attend to the temple in Jerusalem. They are bystanders,|
                                        |in other words, so they hear anything which is presented before God’s throne.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Philadelphia</char>…The Quakers named the city of Philadelphia in Pennsylvania after|
                                        |the city this church was in, as they aspired to emulate this church, since the church received all praise|
                                        |and no censure.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’ll write my God’s name upon him</char>…The significance of writing a name on a person|
                                        |is that it puts a stamp of approval on a person, and additionally advertises that approval to everyone.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">buy gold from me</char>…An elaborate metaphor of buying purified gold, clothing, and|
                                        |eye ointment from Jesus. The buying aspect is to allow God to do His work in one’s life, rather than|
                                        |for a person to attempt it on his own. The purified gold represents trials which are allowed in one’s|
                                        |life, the purpose of which is, in the pressure exerted by them, to remove life’s impurities. White clothing|
                                        |represents righteousness that’s received by God and not a righteousness generated out of one’s own efforts.|
                                        |The eye ointment allows one to see plainly what the issues are in one’s life, seeing what should already|
                                        |be obvious.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in heaven, on the earth, nor in the underworld of death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in|
                                        |the sky</char> [<char style="it">heaven</char>] <char style="it">upon the earth nor under the earth</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shoot</char>…Lit: <char style="it">root</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who are holy</char>…Or: <char style="it">the saints</char>; <char style="it">those|
                                        |who’ve been set apart by God</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">clan</char>…Lit: <char style="it">tribe</char>. Ref. note of Rev. 1:7|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">culture</char>…Or: <char style="it">folk-people</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">priestly kingdom</char>…Lit: <char style="it">kingdom and priests</char>. A hendiadys.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">so be it</char>…Lit: <char style="it">amen</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sealed shut</char>…The seals may have consisted of melted wax which was affixed to the|
                                        |scroll after it had been tightly rolled up. Before the wax cooled and hardened, the seal was stamped|
                                        |to give it an inscription. After the wax cooled, the scroll could not be unfurled, and the scroll thereby|
                                        |read, unless the wax was broken. Therefore, the seals served two purposes. First, they ensured that the|
                                        |scroll had never been read before. Second, the inscription was proof of the scroll was genuinely written|
                                        |by whomever claimed to have written it. Ref. note of 2 Cor. 1:22.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">break the seals and open the scroll</char>…Lit: <char style="it">open the scroll and|
                                        |break the seals</char>. The assumption is that the literal wording of opening the scroll and breaking|
                                        |the seal is backwards, being an expression of a sort, and that the reader at the time would take this|
                                        |for granted. This is analogous to us telling a child, “Put on your shoes and socks,” which we don’t mean|
                                        |for the child to do it in that order, but to put on the socks first before putting on the shoes.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">millions and millions and billions and billions</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ten-thousand|
                                        |ten-thousands and thousands of thousands</char>. This is more of an expression than a precise numbering.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">broke</char>…Lit: <char style="it">opened</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">incense dispenser</char>…Lit: <char style="it">censer</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">upon</char>…Or: <char style="it">at</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the set-apart-people</char>…Or: <char style="it">saints</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">grass which was still growing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">green grass</char>. <char|
                                        |style="it">Green</char> is rendered <char style="it">freshly-cut </char>in Luke 23:31.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Bitter-Flavoring</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Wormwood</char>. This is an actual plant.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vulture</char>…Or: <char style="it">eagle</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ushered over and made to stand</char>…Here in this passage are some of the brass tacks|
                                        |that Ray Summers in his book <char style="it">Worthy Is the Lamb</char> claimed were grammatical mistakes.|
                                        |The verb <char style="it">stand </char>here is in the passive voice but most translations, such as the|
                                        |NASB, translate it as active. The word <char style="it">give </char>in v. 3 translated <char style="it">offer|
                                        |up</char> is future tense but should be subjunctive. The words <char style="it">the prayers </char>is|
                                        |in the dative case, which is unexpected. In v. 5 the verb <char style="it">to take </char>is in the perfect|
                                        |tense, but is used like it’s aorist. Some observations on the claim that these are grammatical errors.|
                                        |First, looking at John’s contributions to the NT as a whole and not just at Revelation individually,|
                                        |Revelation is the only book with these kinds of errors. In the grammatical incidences enumerated from|
                                        |this passage, it’s hard to imagine that these would not have been mistakes caused by ignorance of the|
                                        |language. Now, grammatical mistakes are made when someone’s careless, perhaps writing while he’s tired|
                                        |or writing in too much of a hurry. And that may be the case. But inspecting a couple of the verb forms|
                                        |which are listed here, the passive form of <char style="it">to stand </char>and the perfect form of <char|
                                        |style="it">to take </char>are less common than the expected forms. Someone who’s sloppy, careless, or|
                                        |rushed would use the more common forms instead of the less common. So what’s the conclusion? Perhaps|
                                        |John couldn’t remember some of the forms of words and knew that the reader would be able to figure it|
                                        |out. Or he understood what he was writing and deliberately chose to write it and these are not mistakes.|
                                        |This leaves a translator with the task of figuring out what he meant on a case-by-case basis.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">very</char> <char style="it">high up in the sky</char>…Lit: <char style="it">mid-heaven</char>.|
                                        |In NT times, the sky and heaven as we know it were conflated into one, and there were multiple layers|
                                        |(many say there were seven). Progressing through these layers, one goes from the atmosphere surrounding|
                                        |us; to very high up in the sky; to where the sun and the stars are; then from there into the various|
                                        |layers of heaven, which presumably include paradise and the throne of God. According to such a gradation|
                                        |scheme, mid-heaven would be half-way through, and therefore very high up in the sky, perhaps even in|
                                        |their minds near where the stars are. Seeing that v. 13 mentions a vulture (or perhaps an eagle), vultures|
                                        |(and eagles for that matter) have been known to fly as high as 37,000 feet/11,275 meters). |

                                        |of Matt. 11:21.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">public declaration</char>…Lit: <char style="it">witness</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">That Worldly Land of Captivity Sodom</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Sodom and Egypt</char>.|
                                        |A hendiadys.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a tenth of the city collapsed</char>…Lit:<char style="it"> a tenth of the city fell</char>.|
                                        |It’s unclear whether the city physically fell due to the earthquake or their inhabitants died—or both.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">citizens</char>…Lit: <char style="it">names of men</char>. Or, <char style="it">well-known|
                                        |individuals</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">finally admitted to their guilt</char>…Lit: <char style="it">gave glory to the God of|
                                        |heaven</char>. An idiom; ref. note of John 9:24.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">right time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">season</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the set-apart-people</char>…Or: <char style="it">the saints</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by who You are</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of Your name</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">nobodies</char>…Lit: <char style="it">small</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">exclude the outer courtyard from the measurement, since it’s been given to the Gentiles</char>…The|
                                        |reason for measuring the temple is to confirm that it complies with God’s exacting standards of perfection,|
                                        |a prerequisite for His approval, and assuming it does, God will condescend to dwell in it. When God dwells|
                                        |in it, it will receive His protection. Now, the outer courtyard is not measured since God will not dwell|
                                        |in it, just as in the second temple at the time of Jesus Gentiles were allowed in that outer courtyard.|
                                        |Furthermore, the outer courtyard extends into the Holy City, which does not receive God’s protection.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And if at any given moment someone wants to harm them, fire comes out of their mouth|
                                        |and devours their enemies. And if at any given moment someone would want to harm them, he must be killed|
                                        |in this manner</char>…Two consecutive conditional sentences, where the conditional clauses are almost|
                                        |identical. The conditional clauses differ in the verb tense for the verb <char style="it">to want. </char>The|
                                        |repetition of these clauses and sentences is a figure of speech used throughout the Bible. The shift|
                                        |in the verb tense of <char style="it">to want </char>is a figure of speech called a <char style="it">polyptoton</char>.|
                                        |The subtlety of this polyptoton is additional evidence that John’s weird use of verb tenses is idiomatic|
                                        |rather than the result of carelessness or neglect. Ref. note of 8:3.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I watched events unfold</char>…This interpolation was inserted for the benefit of the|
                                        |reader, as, generally speaking, the verbs in subsequent passage use the past tense, whereas in the previous|
                                        |they were using the future.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spirit of life</char>…In this context, the word <char style="it">spirit </char>does|
                                        |not refer to an angelic spirit, but refers to a supernatural, physical refreshing. See usage of <char|
                                        |style="it">spirit </char>in other verses such as 1 Pet. 3:4.|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">come clean with Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">give Him glory</char>. An expression;|
                                        |ref. note of John 9:24.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">under the scrutiny of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">before</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the set-apart-people</char>…Or: <char style="it">the saints</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who believe in and serve the Lord</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the Lord</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">someone who looked like a perfectly-proportioned man—the ideal man</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">the same as a son of man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Get out in the field and get to it with the sickle…took his sickle</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">Send</char> <char style="it">your sickle </char>[into the field to work]…<char style="it">cast|
                                        |his sickle</char>. A figure of speech, as the sickle itself is not sent but the person swinging it is;|
                                        |the sickle is just a tool.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shoulder-high</char>…Lit: <char style="it">up the horse’s bridle</char>. Liberties taken.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">200 miles/300 km</char>…Lit: <char style="it">1600 stadia</char>. Ref. note of Luke|
                                        |24:13.|
     k         SPACER_BEFORE_FOOTNOTES: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">undiluted mixture</char>…In ancient times, wine was often times diluted with water.|
                                        |The metaphor has God’s wrath at maximum potency.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The fact is, as they parade in, their deeds are showcased</char>…Lit: <char style="it">For|
                                        |their works follow after them</char>. A metaphor to the triumphal entry of a general into a city, with|
                                        |the spoils of war carried behind him. Same metaphor used in 1 Tim. 5:24.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">since the timing is perfect to reap the earth’s harvest</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |harvest of the earth has dried out</char>. Some liberties taken. The spring rain (the “latter rain”:|
                                        |ref. James 5:7, Joel 2:23, Jer. 5:24) arrives at the end of the growing season, and prepares the grain|
                                        |for harvest. After receiving the rain, the crop must dry out, otherwise it’ll get moldy. The moment it|
                                        |dries is the exact moment to harvest it.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the winepress was tread outside the city</char>…In those times, grape juice was extracted|
                                        |from grapes by putting the grapes in a vat and having the workers step on them, crushing them, causing|
                                        |the juice to seep out of the vat and into a pot or something. In the NT, something done <char style="it">outside|
                                        |the city </char>was something which was dirty, messy, or disgusting and consequently should be prevented|
                                        |from contaminating the city.|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the sumptuous and splendid</char>…Lit, in Gk: the <char style="it">lipara</char> [λιπαρὰ,|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Using the same cup she did her mixing in, mix a cocktail for her which is twice as concentrated</char>…The|
                                        |ancients mixed wine with spices and other flavorings similar to the way we mix cocktails. When hosting|
                                        |a dinner, they would prepare a special wine-based mix for the guests.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">poured dirt on their heads</char>…Lit: <char style="it">threw dust on their heads</char>.|
                                        |Attempt to emulate the ancient form of grief, mourning, or repentance, as it says in Job 42:6, “Wherefore|
                                        |I abhor myself and repent in dust and ashes.”|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">any sound of harp players and their accompanying band of musicians and flute players|
                                        |and trumpet players</char>…In ancient Rome, harps and flutes were the principal instruments played in|
                                        |amphitheaters in front of large crowds. To put this in perspective, harps and flutes were to them what|
                                        |electric guitars and keyboards are to rock bands. Famous performers—the pop stars of their day—went from|
                                        |city to city and played in front of large crowds, and all were enchanted by their music. Trumpets were|
                                        |third behind harps and flutes in popularity.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the end at last</char>…Lit: <char style="it">amen</char>. This well-known Hebrew word|
                                        |which, depending on the context, has one or more of the following meanings: <char style="it">the end|
                                        |at last</char>;<char style="it"> that is so true</char>; <char style="it">that is the last of it</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">let it be so</char>; <char style="it">so be it</char>; <char style="it">the final word|
                                        |has been spoken</char>; <char style="it">I/we affirm what you just said/did; the end</char>; <char style="it">the|
                                        |end at last</char>.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">up in the upper atmosphere blocking the sun</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the sun</char>.|
                                        |The ancients’ perception of the sun is that it was a lot closer to the Earth than it actually is. Consequently,|
                                        |a liberty taken to adapt the wording in a way that fits the modern perspective of astronomy.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">any bird that’s capable of flying at a high altitude</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all|
                                        |birds the ones that fly in mid-heaven</char> In regard to <char style="it">mid-heaven</char>, ref. note|
                                        |of 8:13. Birds which are “capable of flying at a high altitude” refers to eagles and vultures and perhaps|
                                        |a few other carrion-eating types of birds. In any case, what’s referred to is birds which pick at dead|
                                        |carcasses and tear their flesh off.|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the A-to-Z</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Alpha and the Omega</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">1500 miles/2400 km</char>…Lit: <char style="it">12,000 stadia</char>. Ref. note of Luke|
                                        |24:13 for conversion of units.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">being who lies about doing detestable things</char>…Lit: <char style="it">that doing|
                                        |detestable and a liar</char>. A hendiadys.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">god-figure</char>…The word <char style="it">God </char>in the GT of the NT is usually|
                                        |preceded with a definite article; this occurrence is not. This is not to say that God is simply a god-figure|
                                        |and not God. A god-figure is one who supplies what is necessary for survival. Pagans, in fact, view their|
                                        |idols as god-figures and credit them with providing what is needed for their survival. In the OT, the|
                                        |Jehovah-names for God do, for the most part, describe God as the ultimate god-figure, the one who promises|
                                        |to supply our survival needs. Hence, Jehovah Jireh (the Lord our Provider), Jehova Rapha (the Lord our|
                                        |Healer), Jehovah Nissi (the Lord our Banner), Jehovah Rohi (the Lord our Shepherd), etc.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">measure</char>…Measuring the city verifies that it is perfect, in the same way that|
                                        |exact dimensions of the tabernacle are specified in the Torah. The act of measuring confirms that it|
                                        |perfectly complies with God’s exacting standards; in this context, that it is made by God and not by|
                                        |man. Also, ref. note of Rev. 11:2.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">215 ft/ 66 meters high</char>…Lit: <char style="it">144 cubits</char>. A cubit is approximately|
                                        |18 inches/450 millimeters.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">daytime all the time</char>…Gates in ancient cities were normally kept open during the|
                                        |day but shut at night, as to protect against bands of marauders who roamed the night and other such threats.|
                                        |With there being no night, there is no need to ever shut the gates.|
